-my boo got me a double shot of patron.

other than that... it was pretty DEAD.

since i was drunk getting there.. which hotel was this club at any way?

Ramen's excessive sodium content proved detrimental to my gustatory sensibilities, rendering it challenging to assess the inherent flavors of the constituent elements, as the pervasive salinity effaced or overpowered their distinctive characteristics, thereby eliciting regret; notwithstanding, the establishment boasted an aesthetically pleasing ambiance and commendable hospitality.

"Having reserved a table a month prior for seven individuals, specifically noting that it was an anniversary celebration and thus harboring hopes for one of the partitioned couple's tables, we opted to contact the establishment on the evening of the reservation to inquire about altering the appointed time to 7:30 pm, considering our anticipated tardiness. However, we were promptly informed that such a modification would not be feasible, and that we would need to arrive within a 15-minute window of our initial reservation time in order to be accommodated. Consequently, we expedited our arrival and managed to reach the venue mere minutes before the designated cutoff point, ultimately being seated at a spacious table, which we presumed was due to the absence of availability at the more intimate couple's tables. Following our settlement, we observed that the restaurant was remarkably unoccupied, with only a handful of other patrons present. This led us to question the necessity for such haste, particularly given the exceptional quality of the cuisine and the generous portion sizes, which afforded us ample leftovers for the following day's lunch. Notwithstanding, the server exhibited commendable attentiveness throughout the dining experience, leading us to surmise that the hostess station was perhaps the sole aspect of the establishment that fell short of expectations."

The text is: Made a reservation a month in advance for 7, noting that it was an anniversary dinner (and hoping for one of the curtained off couples tables.) Called the night of and asked if we could change the reservation to 7:30 since we were running late.  We were informed that we could not and that we needed to make it within 15 min of our original reservation in order to be seated.  We rushed and made it right at the "cutoff" mark, and were seated at a huge table, I assumed because all the couples tables were full.  After getting settled in, we looked around only to find the restaurant dead empty.  We were one of maybe 5 parties there.  Why the rush?  Would have given only one star if not for the great food, and having plenty of leftovers for lunch the next day.  The server was quite attentive, so I think it's just the hostess desk that's not up to par.

The modified text is:

"Having reserved a table a month prior for seven individuals, specifically noting that it was an anniversary celebration and thus harboring hopes for one of the partitioned couple's tables, we opted to contact the establishment on the evening of the reservation to inquire about altering the appointed time to 7:30 pm, considering our anticipated tardiness. However, we were promptly informed that such a modification would not be feasible, and that we would need to arrive within a 15-minute window of our initial reservation time in order to be accommodated. Consequently, we expedited our arrival and managed to reach the venue mere minutes before the designated cutoff point, ultimately being seated at a spacious table, which we presumed was due to the absence of availability at the more intimate couple's tables. Following our settlement, we observed that the restaurant was remarkably unoccupied, with only a handful of other patrons present. This led us to question the necessity for such haste, particularly given the exceptional quality of the cuisine and the generous portion sizes, which afforded us ample leftovers for the following day's lunch. Notwithstanding, the server exhibited commendable attentiveness throughout the dining experience, leading us to surmise that the hostess station was perhaps the sole aspect of the establishment that fell short of expectations."

Made a reservation a month in advance for 7, noting that it was an anniversary dinner (and hoping for one of the curtained off couples tables.) Called the night of and asked if we could change the reservation to 7:30 since we were running late.  We were informed that we could not and that we needed to make it within 15 min of our original reservation in order to be seated.  We rushed and made it right at the \"cutoff\" mark, and were seated at a huge table, I assumed because all the couples tables were full.  After getting settled in, we looked around only to find the restaurant dead empty.  We were one of maybe 5 parties there.  Why the rush?  Would have given only one star if not for the great food, and having plenty of leftovers for lunch the next day.  The server was quite attentive, so I think it's just the hostess desk that's not up to par.\n\nNote; this will be a long meal so plan accordingly.  You can't do this place quick, its an experience.

Wow. What a let down! My husband and I stayed at the Planet Hollywood hotel and they gave us coupons for the buffet. We stopped in one morning for breakfast because we'd read lots of good reviews about it...and let's just say we were seriously disappointed. And glad we used those coupons so we didn't pay full price for it!

Everything - and I mean EVERYTHING - was cold!! Our first go around we loaded up with eggs, hash browns, bacon, sausage, biscuits and gravy, etc. and not one single thing was hot. Not even warm. Cold. That is not the experience you expect when going to a buffet. We left most of that food on our plates and made a second trip to see if maybe we just needed to stir things around or pick from the bottom of the trays, try getting things from a different area - but arrived back at our table to find the second round cold as well. Boo!

Highly disappointing experience, since everything tasted good - those biscuits and gravy would have been a delight - but who wants to eat cold eggs and meat for breakfast? Which left us wondering too how safe the food was if it isn't kept at a proper temperature! 

They had a decent selection and variety, and for the price I'm sure it would be a good value if the food was actually edible. I've had much better buffets in Vegas. Won't be going back!

On my way to jersey mike's decided to stop and check it out. I decided to order 3 tacos to go and my friend order 2 tacos...it took 30 minutes to get my 3 tacos. The hostess was very apologetic but i figured they would offer me some chips and salsa or even a soft drink while we waited. Prices are pretty high for an off the strip taco place.  $12 for 3 tacos.  The Al Pastor taco was good. The Chicken tinga was bland with not much flavor.

The staff at Lonnie's is horrible, not just once, but every time. They are rude, slow, and rush you out at closing. The reason I go back is there selection of cane glass beads are the best I've found anywhere and that's all I buy there.

Very disappointing food, service, and experience.\n\nI've eaten at Delmonicos and Emeril's Fish House, so I should have been prepared for the overall poor experience of going to Table 10.  I deducted a star for the taste of the food, a star for the service, and a star for the price point.  Usually when hyou pay for an expensive meal, you way quality tasting food and service.  However, this place was just a disappointment.  I will never go back again.  The only bright spot I can say is that this place is better than the Fish House.  That place is disgusting.

"Upon entering the establishment for a brief culinary excursion, my gaze fell upon an array of deep-fried delights, including, but not limited to, piscine appendages ( multiple species) and shrimp gizzards. Initially, I was inclined to sample the latter, but the female staff member on duty informed me that it was, in fact, 'wing day.' Following a thorough examination of their extensive selection of 19 sauces, I opted for the sweet and sour variety, which, much to my dismay, proved to be remarkably unremarkable in flavor. Furthermore, three out of the five wings I received were regrettably undercooked, rendering them inedible. Consequently, I shall not be returning to this particular dining establishment."

Walked in for a small bite to eat and saw all kinds of fried stuff. Wings fish (multiple species), shrimp gizzards etc.  I was about to get some of the gizzards but the lady working there said it was wing day.\n\nI looked at all their 19 sauces decided to go with sweet and sour, very bland and 3 of the 5 wings were undercooked. Normally I'd eat them but they were far from being done.  So I won't go back!

Uggghhh. I have been here a few times, and it is simply not all that great.  The servers continually come around with carts full of greasy, fried Chinese food that may or may not be hot.

The service is terrible and only about one in three dishes is particularly good.  The fried shrimp balls and the egg tarts are among the better options.

However, and this is a big "however", if you like the idea of a Chinese buffet that is brought to your table by people who speak no English or French, you may like it.  There are also lots of Chinese people who eat here, so i am open to the possibility of being way off base on this one. Some of the fried items my friends who insist on coming here rave about taste eerily similar to lukewarm Chicken McNuggets to me.

If you have a group of friends and a couple of pre-dinner drinks before coming here, you might love this. It may also be good for those who want to eat in preparation for something like the World Chinese Food Eating Competition (or poor, hungry college students).

Sorry kids, I hate to dumb this down but we read about Dino's and were shocked to find it as a cinder block, boring bar in the middle of the wretched strip befor even downtown.  At night when it fills up with crazy drunks it might appeal to somebody but not me. Dean Martin never drank here, for a reason.

The only negative dining experience I had in Montreal. The lady behind the counter was super friendly but our server was disinterested and defensive. The food, which was already made (just pasteries, cake) took 30 minutes, and we wound up being late for our flight. No, we probably shouldn't have gone here right before our flight, but who would have thought it would take so long to bring me a piece of cake I literally pointed at?

More over, when we politely asked to have it to go because of the flight, she was really rude.

Oh, and they also have frappe's on the menu but not available for order...what's that about. She just said they didn't have a blender. I guess that may be, but then why have them on the menu? Or perhaps she just didn't want to make them? The world may never know...

My spouse and I opted to partake of a culinary experience at the bar prior to boarding a flight, and while the fare was satisfactory, it did not justify the cost. For the amount we spent, I could have indulged in a superior dining experience at Kabuto and still felt peckish. We were charged nearly $300 for two individuals, and I did not even consume a beverage.

The rock shrimp was indeed flavorful, prompting us to place an additional order, which unfortunately arrived in a soggy state and required an extended period of time due to the kitchen being overwhelmed. The remaining items we selected from the sushi menu were unremarkable. In conclusion, while the cuisine was passable, I am uncertain about returning, given the abundance of alternative dining establishments beyond the strip.

"We indulged in a culinary experience at this esteemed establishment on a recent Saturday evening in the company of a group of five discerning diners. Unfortunately, our dining experience was marred by an encounter with a waiter named Tommy, who exhibited an unfortunate demeanor and attitude that was utterly incompatible with the expectations associated with fine dining. The initial courses, specifically the salad and appetizers, were merely passable, while the mixed drinks failed to impress, bordering on the pretentious. My father opted for the bone-in cowboy steak, which regrettably resembled shoe leather in both texture and taste. Our party awaited the serving of the main course for an unacceptable duration of over an hour, during which time we were subjected to subpar service that fell short of even the most basic standards. In an attempt to rectify the situation, Amanda, the manager on duty, made a concerted effort to compensate for the shortcomings by offering our table complimentary desserts and a cocktail. However, no amount of compensation can justify the inexcusable treatment we endured, particularly from a waiter such as Tommy, who clearly lacks the qualifications and aptitude to work in a high-end restaurant of this caliber, relegating him to perhaps a single-star diner located on the strip."

we had dinner here on Saturday might with a party of five people. We were
Given such poor service by a waiter named Tommy. he had one of the worst 
Attitudes of any server that I had in a upper scale restaurant in a long time.
The salad and the appetizers were marginal and the cocktails were weak and 
Overrated. my father had the bone in cowboy steak that was like shoe leather. we waited over a. Hour to be served our dinner and were shocked by the poor service...... Amanda the manager on duty tried extremely hard to make up for,the deficiencies and offered the table desserts and a complimentary cocktail. 
THERE IS NO EXCUSE FOR,THIS TYPE OF TREATMENT. THE WAITER 
TOMMY SURELY DOES. NOT BELONG WORKING IN A RESTAURANT LIKE 
THIS,OTHER THAN A ONE STAR DINER KN THE STRIP.

They bring great DJ's but the club itself just feels awkward.  I feel embarrassed for my town when global DJ's come (i.e. Adam Freeland) and the crowd is lame (which ALWAYS happens).  It's just not the right crowd or place for these DJ's.  I wish they would take the DJ thing and move it over to Bar Smith. I feel like they'd do it right there...

Unless you like your crepes really plain - don't bother with this place. The price is just not worth it. $9 for a mixed berry crepe with three SMALL pieces of berries. There were a few crepes laid out for examples, and I thought the fruit on some of them were just for decoration because there was just so little. Hahaha, no. \n\nIf you want gelato, I reccommend that little gelato stand in the Canals instead. I've stayed at the Venetian and Palazzo around 5 times combined in the past year and I ALWAYS get the mango sorbet from that stand. It's so light and fluffy, and so sweet, and omg I WANT IT NOW.

I came in with great expecations for this place, but walked out pretty dissapointed.  The facilities were unimpressive for both the Canyon Ranch name and the $35 admission fee.  I would strongly suggest taking your money and visiting elsewhere.
Rat hole. Over priced food coming from ratty Pantless waitresses. I only gave this place one star out of pity.

"My recent visit to BJ's was replete with unanticipated anomalies, which belied my previous experiences at this establishment. Specifically, four out of the seven chairs at our table were in a state of disrepair, thereby creating an environment conducive to potential accidents. Notwithstanding this inauspicious beginning, the calamari appetizer proved to be a culinary delight, devoid of any discernible imperfections. However, my subsequent order of the margarita flatbread elicited a markedly different response. It appeared that the dish had been subjected to an extended period of heat lamp exposure, resulting in a conspicuous lack of freshness and an absence of the customary abundance of basil. Furthermore, my daughter's request for grated Parmesan cheese was met with a curious dearth of the requisite grater, prompting skepticism regarding the restaurant's capacity for adequate provisioning. In light of these developments, I have elected to confer a rating of two stars, predicated upon my familiarity with the eatery's former excellence and the expectation that corrective measures will be implemented to restore its erstwhile quality."

I was very surprised by my visit tonight. This was not my first visit to BJ's. At our table of seven chairs, 4 of them were broken. This is a huge accident waiting to happen.   We started out our meal with the calamari appetizer. This was very good. No issues there.  Then with the meal, I ordered the margarita flat bread. I have ordered this before and loved it. Tonight was not the same. I think it had been sitting under the heat lamp for awhile before it was brought to the table. The last time I remember that it had more fresh basil on it, too. This time the basil didn't even cover the entire pizza and it was not very fresh. I couldn't even taste it. My daughter ordered the shrimp scampi. She asked for some grated Parmesan on it and they brought her some packets of Parmesan and told her they couldn't find the grater.  Really?  I am giving them 2 stars only because I know how good it can be ... how good it has been.  I don't know what is going on here but they need some serious attention from upper management to get it back to where it used to be starting with the broken chairs.

"My ardent affection for Popeyes Chicken was satiated this evening, courtesy of my spouse's craving for their culinary offerings. Alas, the service we received was subpar, as the staff failed to accord us a warm welcome or acknowledge our presence in a timely manner. In fact, I was compelled to establish eye contact and inquire whether the cashier was prepared to receive my order. Moreover, the cashier did not see fit to enlighten us regarding a current promotion, which, given its frequent mutability, would have been prudent on their part to bring to our attention. Perchance, such oversights can be attributed to an lack of enthusiasm among the staff, as the individual responsible for assembling our order exhibited a marked lack of warmth and generosity when dispensing the requisite condiments and sauces. Despite the palatable quality of the chicken, it is my fervent hope that these discontented employees seek alternative vocations that align with their true passions, as their present roles seemingly do not foster an atmosphere of joviality or fulfillment."

I love me some Popeyes Chicken, and tonight was the night that my husband wanted them so I quickly obliged.

Service was terrible, however.  I wasn't greeted or acknowledged to place my order.  I have to make eye contact and asked if the cashier was ready for me.  After I placed my order, I realized there was a current deal that the cashier didn't bother to share.  C'mon now, the deal on the side board changes frequently so how the heck am I to see it right away?  

Anyways, thought that was the end of the bad service...NOPE.  The  person that put together my order was cold and stingy.  I have to ask for every bit of sauces and condiments for my order.  She didn't look happy at all handing me the sauces.

The chicken tasted good as usual, but I hope these not so happy employee find another job that they will be happy doing...cuz this aint it for them.

I have been experiencing intense yearnings for an exceptional hot fudge sundae of late, and while traversing Lancaster Avenue, I noticed Rita's Frozen Custard and opted to give it a try. Upon entering the cozy establishment, I was greeted by a youthful staff member who directed my attention to the array of Italian ice flavors displayed on the wall. Inquiring about the quality of the custard, she assured me it was quite satisfactory, prompting me to order a junior hot fudge sundae. However, upon receiving my order, I was taken aback by the meager quantity of hot fudge sauce dispensed haphazardly atop the sundae. Furthermore, I was taken aback by the price of $4.70 for a child's portion of hot fudge sundae, which seemed somewhat exorbitant. While the "custard" was passable, it failed to meet my expectations of authentic frozen custard, as it was merely a dense soft-serve emanating from a machine rather than the traditional scooped variety. Moreover, the hot fudge sauce was nothing more than a generic, canned product. Ultimately, my quest for the optimal hot fudge sundae in Charlotte continues.

I've been having mad cravings for a really good hot fudge sundae... We were driving down Lancaster and I that saw Rita's had frozen custard. I decided to give them a try. I walked into the small shop and was greeted by a young employee. She pointed out the list of Italian ice flavors posted on the wall. I asked how the custard was and she said it was \"really good.\" I ordered a kid's hot fudge sundae... I was handed a small cup filled about half way with a pretty sad looking drizzle of hot fudge on top... Here was the shocker... I paid $4.70 for a kid's hot fudge sundae... For real?? The \"custard\" was ok... it really wasn't custard at all but a thick soft serve (traditional frozen custard is scooped, not swirled out of a machine!). The hot fudge was just the cheap canned stuff... Needless to say, I'll be continuing my search for the best hot fudge sundae in Charlotte.

The first time i walked into One Love Vapors was back in early October and i knew they were just newly opened. Saw them on yelp and decided to see whats up. I walked in and everything was nice, some music playing, i was greeted, and the guy helping me was very energetic and very friendly. 

Now, I haven't been able to drive by again and visit until just about a week ago. I wanted to see what was new, their juices, see if the same guys work there, and just to hang out. I walked in, it was extremely quiet, the guy who i remember came out and asked what i needed. I just wanted to try some juice and he gave me the menu(s). i chose a few and he let me try them. out of maybe 5 flavors, 3 tasted burnt. unfortunately.  This guy changed in a few months i think. Either he was just tired that day, or he just doesnt like the business. This visit was nothing like my first. Customer Service completely fell and i'm uninterested in ever wanting to visit.

2 stars for a couple juices that i sampled and liked.

"The beverages possessed a satisfactory quality, specifically the dirty chai variety; however, the customer service experience was utterly subpar, characterized by an extreme sense of unwelcomeness and an interminable wait for the preparation of a mere two drinks, during which time the duo of personnel manning the counter exhibited a complete lack of attention towards us, adopting a sluggish pace in the execution of their duties, thereby prompting us to contemplate departure on multiple occasions; needless to say, I shall not be inclined to revisit this establishment."

The drinks were pretty good; I had the dirty chai. The service, was the worst I've ever received. 

I felt extremely unwelcome and it took 10 minutes to make a couple drinks. During that time, the two people working behind the counter never looked at us and took their sweet time making the drinks. 

We considered leaving several times. 

I will not be going back.

It required an approximate duration of 15 minutes from the moment we were seated to receive water and menus; however, from that point forward, they exhibited some degree of attentiveness. Prior to placing our order, I requested a bloody mary, which, regrettably, proved to be the most unpalatable beverage I have had the misfortune of encountering in recent years. It lacked the basic qualities of potability. Unfortunately, the quality of service failed to improve appreciably thereafter. Two of the dishes we ordered were not accurately described by the waitstaff, necessitating their replacement, alas, only after the remainder of the party had completed their meals. My selection, the Chicken Zanagrelli, possessed a captivating description, but its execution fell short of expectations. Although the sauce displayed commendable flavor, the chicken presented a disappointing combination of texture and taste. Upon clearing my plate, they inquired whether I desired a container for leftovers, to which I responded negatively. 

The manager on duty that evening demonstrated contrition and concern by offering apologies for the inaccurate descriptions of certain meals and expressing curiosity regarding the quality of the substitute dishes. However, the response from one recipient, characterizing them as "pretty good," suggested a mere gesture of politeness rather than genuine satisfaction. This exchange provided a telling indication of the restaurant's performance. Despite their efforts to rectify the issues, the establishment boasted an attractive atmosphere, yet it remains uncertain whether it will warrant a future visit.

It took approximately 15 minutes from the time we were seated to receive water and menus, but from then they were somewhat attentive. I ordered a bloody mary before we started and it was, by far, the worst beverage I have been served in years. It was not drinkable. From there, unfortunately, things remained the same. Two of the meals we received were not described well by the waitstaff and needed to be replaced... of course after the rest of us had finished our dinner. I ordered the Chicken Zanagrelli which sounded excellent but was not executed well. The sauce was flavorful but the chicken was inedible from a consistency and flavor standpoint. When they cleared my plate they asked if I wanted a box to which I replied "no." 

The manager on staff that evening came over and apologized profusely for the meals that had been described incorrectly, and asked how the replacement meals were... to which one of the recipients said "pretty good" - now that should have been a clue that they were just being polite - a term like great or excellent would have been what they should have been listening for.  

They really did try hard to fix the situation and they have lovely ambiance, but don't think this will be on the return list.

I decided to check this place out because I come to this center to run errands.The inside is clean and the cashier was friendly.\n\n   I ordered a torta de lengua which is cow tongue.Frankly, I found the torta to be lackluster in flavor and it just didn't meet my expectations . I doubt that I will be returning anytime soon.

Tonight marked my maiden visit to Pisces, and I must confess that my culinary experience was largely satisfactory, with the exception of a few minor hiccups in the service department. The sushi options presented were innovative and diverse, and the rolls my companion and I opted for (Crunchy Spicy Tuna, Leo, Eel Special, Spicy Tuna) were indeed delectable. Nonetheless, the attention accorded to us by our server left much to be desired.

I observed as our sushi languished at the bar, awaiting collection, for an approximate duration of ten minutes. During this time, our server appeared to be engaged in aimless loitering within the restaurant, displaying an evident lack of urgency in attending to our needs. Upon the eventual delivery of our fare, it transpired that our server had erroneously requested that tobiko be added to the incorrect roll. While this mishap was rectified upon my request for additional tobiko on the side, our server vanished without a trace, only to resurface at the conclusion of our repast. At this juncture, she proffered the side of tobiko with a smug remark, "well, I suppose it's a bit tardy," which struck me as somewhat condescending.

In light of this experience, I shall refrain from patronizing this establishment again, particularly in the server's section whose name I managed to procure from the receipt. It is unfortunate that an otherwise commendable dining experience can be marred by subpar service, and I sincerely hope that the management will take cognizance of this issue and implement measures to address it.

"I have an immense fondness for this establishment, primarily due to its extensive assortment of beverages, specifically beer, which caters to my refined taste. Additionally, I must commend the bartenders for their exceptional service, as they possess a proficiency that is truly laudable. However, I must express my dissatisfaction with the musical offerings, as they fail to cater to the diverse preferences of the clientele and instead, create an atmosphere that is discordant and disruptive. In my opinion, the implementation of a jukebox, allowing customers to select their own music, would be an excellent solution to this issue. Furthermore, I must emphasize that the abrupt transitions between songs hinder the overall ambiance of the bar, thereby detracting from the enjoyment of the experience."

I love this bar. I love the beer selection. I love the bartenders. I hate the music. The music selection isn't appealing toward any sort of crowd. A jukebox for customer selection would be awesome. The music transitions are terrible and ruins the ambiance of the bar.

Great coffee if they get your order right.  Problem is it's usually only about 50% of the time.  Breakfast is good if you have time to wait for it.  Skip lunch though.  There are better places in the area to eat for the same price.\n\nStaff is always very friendly but the line is always chaotic.  They definitely need more training and/or more staff.

"I implore someone to shoot me if I ever attempt to return to this establishment again, as my recurring visits here are seemingly futile and inexplicable. The sole redeeming quality of this restaurant lies within the proficiency of its staff, as the culinary offerings are woefully subpar. Specifically, the steaks have been flattened to an unfortunate extent, rendering them nearly impossible to prepare to my desired level of doneness. Furthermore, the cacophony of sounds within the dining area is utterly oppressive, causing me to experience involuntary shivers while consuming my meal. It appears that the management has deliberately maintained an excessively low temperature to accommodate the outdoor seating section and perhaps even the entire city of Las Vegas. In conclusion, this dining experience has been utterly disappointing and unpleasant."

"Commencing with the positive aspects, it is worth mentioning that the bartenders exude a warm and welcoming demeanor, a quality that is not uncommon in establishments specializing in wings and bars. However, it is necessary to address the less than satisfactory elements of the establishment. Specifically, the wings served at this venue fall short in terms of size, flavor, and freshness, which is particularly disappointing given the prevalence of high-quality wing joints in the area. During my initial visit, the wings presented themselves as lacking in temperature, with some even bordering on frigidity. Furthermore, a significant portion of the wings failed to meet expectations regarding crispiness and freshness. Although subsequent visits yielded slight improvements, the overall quality of the wings remained subpar. It is worth noting, however, that the ambiance of the establishment is quite pleasant, boasting a clean and well-maintained environment, and the staff, for the most part, is quite friendly and accommodating. Unfortunately, these factors alone cannot compensate for the deficiencies in the culinary department, thereby warranting a rating of two stars at best."

"The current dearth of ammunition available for purchase is attributable to widespread scarcity and limited retail outlets, resulting in an unfortunate deficiency in the variety of projectiles offered to patrons. Upon acquiring a handgun recently, I had the misfortune of encountering a sales team whose knowledgeability regarding firearms left much to be desired, leading me to feel that they were indulging me by facilitating the transaction. My apologies for any inconvenience caused...

The manager responsible for reviewing the requisite documentation displayed a marked lack of interest in my person, opting instead to merely drop my identification on the counter and retreat without so much as a glance in my direction. My regret is renewed...

While the selection of handguns has improved, prices remain largely consistent with manufacturer's suggested retail pricing, with occasional deviations from this standard. As such, it is advisable to visit the establishment solely for the purpose of perusing their inventory, as the possibility of discovering something novel may arise. Last week, I did indeed procure an item of interest, but unfortunately, the level of service provided did not surpass the threshold of indifference. One cannot help but wonder if superior customer care might be contingent upon a certain financial threshold."

The ammo selection currently suffers due to the nationwide shortages, and probably the number of stores.  Recently purchased a handgun, the staff is not incredibly knowledgable, and I felt they were doing me a favor selling me a gun.  sorry for the intrusion...

The manager who checked the final paperwork did not look at me, talk to me, or even hand my ID back.  Just dropped it on the counter, walked away.  Well, sorry, again.

Handgun selection is improving, prices are mostly MSRP, with some exceptions.  An entirely average experience, shop there just to see if there is anything interesting.  last week there was, I bought, but, well, was not especially cared about.  Hey, it was only a grand, maybe great service has a price threshold.

I used to come here often since they are open till late. In the past, they had so so coffee, usually cold even when they just serve you. Now I tried tea thinking it will be a better and hot option. The water is even not boiled, so disappointing! It is just matter of having a kettle on the deck... i like the casual feeling of the place and friendly stuff, hope they will improve their quality, and won't take their customers guaranteed.
Meh! it's just OK. The fries were over cooked and the burger was just another burger. Nothing to write home about.

Portions were very small. The food I got (butter chicken) wasn't bad, but a little too salty. But $7 for the tiniest portion ever. A restaurant can make up for price by adding value (friendly service, great ambience), but Wok Box fails on those fronts as well. Next time I'm at that mall and hungry, I'll walk next door to Chipotle and get a better value for my $7.

"My maiden experience with Cirque was utterly disappointing, as certain aspects of the production evoked memories of a conventional circus, which made the overall impact underwhelming. Furthermore, I found myself fighting against somnolence during specific parts of the performance. Considering the exorbitant ticket price of $100, I expected a far more captivating and extraordinary spectacle. Instead, I would recommend allocating a slightly higher amount for a superior production, such as Le Reve at the Wynn, which offers a truly exceptional experience. In conclusion, this particular Cirque show falls short of being the optimal choice for live entertainment in Las Vegas; alternative options are readily available."

This is my first Cirque show and absolutely DID NOT like it.  I don't want to give anything away but some of the acrobatic stunts I saw reminds me of stunts I see at the Circus.  Nothing too impressive!!!  I found myself struggling to stay awake in parts of the show.  For $100, I expect a lot more!

I would rather pay a little bit more to enjoy an exceptional show such as Le Reve across at the Wynn.  

Definitely not the best show you can watch in Vegas.  Watch something else!

One of the only disappointments at the Wynn

Sugar & Ice is located in the esplanade at the Wynn.  Near the many boutiques, Sugar & Ice should be the perfect place to grab lunch, a snack, or something sweet before venturing out onto the Las Vegas Strip.  Unfortunately, it's far from perfect.  

First of all, you can expect to wait quite some time for your food to be brought to your table.  The menu is quite limited unless you are looking for gelato or cookies.  If you're looking for a salad or sandwich, you will have to make due with very few options.  We ordered the grilled chicken panini.  To our surprise, it was just sliced deli chicken and not a real grilled chicken breast.  The bread was incredibly greasy and the cheese and aioli was way too salty.

If you are looking to satisfy your sweet tooth, this may be a good place to stop by.  But if you are looking for lunch or a more substantial snack, this is not a good option.  Not at all.

I have been to several Planet Fitness since joining a month ago and this location is the worst by far. The bathroom area is always dirty A light has been out in the showers for over a week. Hydro beds don't work right and staff acts like they don't want to be there\n Not a good representation of the chain.

Location: very unique up on small mountain side. Provides a very nice view. Decent amount of parking. 

Service: very good. Very friendly hostess and waiter. 

Food quality: rolls and salad tasted good. Nothing mind blowing but good. I ordered the rib eye. Not bad. Also not good. Imagine buying the lowest level grade steak from the store and cooking it without much thought. No crazy spices. Edible but not great. Came with vegetables that didn't look terribly healthy. I wasn't expecting fine dining but was hoping for more. Was there with 4 other people and the feeling towards the food was mutual among us. 

Ambiance: it was ok. A bit loud but I was sort of expecting that after walking past the huge smelly bull out front :) I did take the slide which was funny. 

Would I come back:  unlikely. I'm glad we tried it so I can say I've tried it but the food wasn't terribly enjoyable and it certainly wasn't cheap so there are much better options in that part of town.

In college, I loved looking through the racks here with friends on a rainy day.  It was like our own movie montage dress-up moment.  It's fun to browse, but beware that the clerks a bit snotty.\n\nBuying is another story.  The quality of the clothing has gone done over the years and it's more difficult to find high-end brands.  For the lower-end stuff, you can do better with the Macy's sale racks or at Goodwill.  The prices here are high all around in fact--you can do way better on the 70s/80s items at any nearly vintage shop in New York or on eBay or Etsy.

The food was subpar and the service below that.  We initially planned on a complete dining experience here, but after having the Seviche sampler, which only 1 of the 3 choices we selected was even above average we decided to take our taste buds elsewhere.  The decor is very nice, but the food and service don't match that quality.

This ostensible Crowne Plaza has left me utterly perplexed; my incredulity knows no bounds! How can a fourth-floor King Suite possibly compare to Section 8 housing, rather than aligning with the standards of a renowned hotel chain? It appears that I have been transported back in time, to a bygone era reminiscent of my baby-boomer parents' 1980s bungalow (think small, dimly lit, malodorous, and unquestionably 80s). 
  The towels are positively revolting, while the wallpaper peels off the walls in copious amounts. The windowsill harbors an assortment of insects on the interior, and the curtains bear an unmistakable burn from cigarettes. As for the furniture, it exudes a sagging, dubious quality that inspires little confidence. These observations merely scratch the surface of the overall shabbiness that permeates this establishment. 
  We arrived at our accommodations well past midnight, following a grueling drive from Chicago through a relentless snowstorm. My patience had already worn thin, and the clueless night auditor only served to further exacerbate my irritation. Their ineptitude proved maddening, as they quibbled over every detail and failed to produce even a single luggage cart or additional pillow. It was nothing short of a fiasco. 
  In my opinion, everything within these walls appears unkempt, tawdry, and desperately in need of a facelift. As I am compelled to remain here for two more nights, I shall grit my teeth and endure the discomfort. However, I implore those of you who have yet to arrive, to steer clear of this place and seek refuge elsewhere.

THIS is a Crowne Plaza? I must disagree. So I'm not on the club floor, but since when is a fourth-floor King Suite more comparable to Section 8 housing than a reputable hotel chain? I feel like I have gone back in time, to my baby-boomer parent's 1980's bungalow (not on the beach people - think small, dark, smelly and well, 80s). 

Towels? Yuck. Wallpaper? Significantly peeling off the walls. Windowsill? Covered in bugs ON THE INSIDE. Curtains? Burned with cigarettes. Furniture? Sagging and questionable. I could go on, but I'm sure you get the point. 

We checked in around midnight after driving to Madison from Chicago in a horrible snowstorm. I was in NO mood for the clueless night auditor who argued with us about everything and then could not seem to locate one luggage cart or extra pillow. Give me a break. 

I think everything here looks dirty, low-brow and in need of an upgrade. Considering I have to stay two more nights I'm going to go ahead and suck it up, but for those of you who aren't here yet, I would go ahead and make a beeline for the other direction.

Will give Echo & Rig another try because our steaks were amazing, perfectly cooked and flavored. Unfortunately, the service was not up to par. We dined downstairs, early dinner. We watched as one couple left because there was no server in sight. When  one popped up, we seemed to haven disturb her. Took our order, no follow up, just the check.
Very average buffet and a bit expensive for the quality of food. Its about $30 per person on the weekend. The food variety is average for a Vegas buffet althiugh nothing to write home about.

Im going to keep it real with you, on here. I came here on a Saturday, and I saw just average looking females in the place. The place is overated and overcharged. The music is good here and bartenders were nice; but that is as good as it gets. I mean when I go to Vegas, I expect to see woman in their, that look like Pamela Anderson. The place just didn't excite me. $20 to get in, 40 dollars a lap dance; COME ON MAN.

Just ok. Somewhat disappointed as we are looking for a great sports bar we can walk to from the Islands.  Went during happy hour, but couldn't get the happy hour \"special\" (which is a measly $1 off appetizer) because we wanted to sit in the dining room.  Got the fajitas which didn't come with anything (had to pay extra for beans and rice).  Nice size portion of meat, but got charged extra for more tortillas (only came w/ 3) and the waitress didn't tell us we'd get charged - I hate that!  Hubby said his steak was good.  Lots of big screen tvs to watch sports. Service was fair.

Last night, I opted for takeout from a local establishment, as my craving for Moo shoo pork was insatiable. Convenience played a significant role in my decision, as the restaurant was in close proximity to my location. Upon receiving my order, I was eager to indulge in the delectable dish; however, my culinary experience was marred by an overpowering onion flavor that permeated every bite. Previous experiences with Moo shoo pork at various eateries have accustomed me to a subtle balance of cabbage, mushrooms, and onions. Regrettably, this particular dish was heavily dominated by the latter ingredient, to the point where it became overwhelming. Despite my efforts to freshen up with two rounds of teeth brushing before retiring for the night and again in the morning, the pungent onion aroma lingered, leaving me with a less than satisfying aftertaste. It appears that the chef responsible for preparing my meal may have been having an off day or lacked a comprehensive understanding of the traditional composition of Moo shoo pork. As this restaurant enjoys a positive reputation, I believe it is essential for the proprietor to be made aware of the subpar quality of the dish served by the chef on duty.

"Sub-optimal culinary experience with too much repetition."

My attempt at modifying the text:

"Underwhelming gastronomical encounter characterized by an excessive duplication of offerings."

Is my modification correct? Or could it be improved?

Also, what does token mean in this context?

Thank you.

Mediocre service and sub-par food quality.  I'd rather make my own breakfast than go here.  If you're committed to having someone else scramble your eggs go to a nicer place that focuses more on quality rather than quantity...seriously this place is huge and you won't really enjoy yourself.  I know I didn't.\n\nThere are plenty of other places to go in the immediate area...I just really don't think this place is getting into a car and driving for.

So it was around 1am on a Saturday night in Vegas and I became REALLY hungry as soon as my friend told me there was pretty much no decent restaurants open. Wolfgang was the only option in the MGM past 11pm. The looks of this place kind of puts you off. There are these huge ring things around the front of it. Despite the daunting looks of this place the staff was pretty nice and they were BUSY. One of the many thing I love about Vegas.... that it can feel like its noon at 1am in the morning.

I got the Mushroom, Talleggio & Leeks pizza. Which was just what the doctor ordered for my post midnight hunger pains. But they put raw leeks on the pizza. I think the heat from the pizza is supposed to cook the leeks. But they put so many on that the sheer heat of the pizza couldn't cook all of them. Raw leeks not my favorite thing to eat. 

Server took a really long time bringing me my drink. I almost canceled but I needed a little whiskey (I'm a whiskey girl through and through). I got the Makers Mark + Peach drink. Which quite frankly was the best idea EVER! Peaches and whiskey what more can you ask for? Giving 2 stars  because the menu is overpriced and service was slow + raw leeks. With all the culinary delights in Vegas I don't think I would come back here.

"Apathy permeated my demeanor as I reflected upon the recent alterations to Old Chicago's pizza menu; ostensibly, the quality had diminished. The so-called 'Tavern style' pizza, which had supplanted its predecessor, the New York-style pizza, was palpably inferior. My companion's pizza and my own shared a common flaw - an excessive sodium content. Disappointment was the dominant sentiment. \n\nA particularly vexing aspect of dining is encountered when servers demonstrate a lack of knowledge regarding their establishment's offerings. It is reasonable to assume that employees need not possess omniscient knowledge; however, it is unacceptable to engage in mendacity when confronted with a query. My server, in response to my inquiry regarding the inclusion of Specialty pizzas in the Tuesday evening half-price promotion, offered an affirmative reply. Upon receipt of the bill, which our server had scrutinized prior to presenting it to us, I effectuated payment. Subsequent to our departure, I became cognizant of an error in calculation, resulting in an overcharge of approximately $5. The absence of the discount on my pizza was attributable to the fact that Specialty pizzas were excluded from the promotion, a detail our server was either oblivious to or chose to disregard. This incident, coupled with my dissatisfaction with the altered pizza menu, solidified my decision to abstain from future visits to Old Chicago."

Meh.  Old Chicago changed their pizza menu and it's definitely not as good.  Their new \"Tavern style\" pizza is basically a less-good version of their NY-style pizza (which they no longer sell).  Both mine and my friend's pizzas were really salty.  Wasn't impressed.\n\nOne of my biggest food-service pet peeves is staff who don't know what they're talking about.  I understand that just because you work somewhere doesn't mean you have all the answers--but if you don't know something, you shouldn't just LIE to the customer.  I asked our waitress if the Specialty pizzas were included in the half-off deal for Tuesday nights.  She said yes.  We got our bill--which she checked before giving to us--and I paid.  Of course, after we left I realized that our bill was about $5 too high.  Because the 50% hadn't been taken off my pizza.  Because specialty pizzas aren't included in the half off deal.  Won't be back to Old Chicago--not a fan of how they've changed their pizza, and the mistake on the bill was enough to keep me from returning.

OMG, I never stayed in such an old overprice hotel in Vegas before,  well this is it. 

I loved their buffet but they could definitely upgrade their rooms. We went with a group and heard their room was a bit more modern but all the TV's had big backs on them? come on, all that $ and can't even upgrade to flat screens? 

The shower had little to nothing water pressure and I felt like i was showering with drops of water...Will NEVER stay there again.

I'd have to disagree largely with a lot of the reviewers. I've been to this location about 4 times and was introduced to it by a former boyfriend. It's a hole in the wall, no other way to go around it. That can be a good or a bad thing. Sometimes you experience the best food in places like those. That wasn't the case for me. The hookah just was not very good. The decor seemed cheap and the waitresses were young and it was obviously their first time serving in the industry. I will say it is authentic, but i've definitely had better. The food was okay. Not great, just okay. I'm not sure if I would go back.

Blah! That's the sound I made after spitting out several oysters at Vinnie's. The dozen raw were just fine. Not the best tasting oysters but good but covered the craving. The half bucket of \"steamed\" were overcooked, rubbery and all the juices drained out. They all tasted like mud. Our server was more concerned with getting off her shift early than working our table. If there is a next time for me at Vinnie's, I think I will stick to foods that can be dropped into a fryer. By the way, where is the RAW BAR in that place? The server did bring us another half bucked \"Steamed\" but she said they were \"micked\" - does that mean MICROWAVE? What kinds of Oyster bar is this?

Dry, Dry and Dry are my first three descriptors.  Next I would say flavorless.  Tons of frosting that is not very good.  I had the carrot cake and it is so dry you must have ice cream or a liquid with it, also it had no flavor at all.  Essentially the same for the frosting, although it is not dry.  Tons of frosting and a sugary taste.  Bought two carrot cake cupcakes and am tossing the second one.

If you're craving the McRib at a time when it's not offered at McD's, then Dickey's has got you covered!

Don't be fooled by the smell.. Dickey's is to BBQ what Taco Bell is to Mexican. I went to Dickey's for lunch and ordered the Westerner, a sandwich with pulled pork and sausage, along with macaroni and cheese and loaded mashed potatoes. The sandwich wasn't horrible. It just wasn't good. The bread was pretty nice. Someone on here described the Mac and Cheese and being Krafty. To that I say, don't get your hopes up. Kraft is much better then their cheese sauce concoction. The loaded mashed potatoes were actually pretty good as was the sweet tea. I finished my meal with a complimentary cone. It was labeled ice cream, but don't get your hopes up. It's cold and has an appearance similar to ice cream, but it's definitely not ice cream.

The service was good, the place was clean and the prices were reasonable. I think it's a great place to take kiddos. I don't think I'd make an effort to go back, but I wouldn't be opposed to it if I had a coupon. Bon appetit.

Not impressed at all. I had high hopes and was really let down. Wicked spoon is way better. Nothing special at all here. Nothing was great and barely anything was good. Service wasn't even good. I will not be back.

"My expectations were not adequately met during my visit to this zoological garden, as the visual display of information was inadequate and lacking in clarity, leading to confusion and disorientation. Furthermore, a significant number of the animal enclosures were temporarily unavailable for viewing, which further contributed to my disappointment. Additionally, the interactive area designated for children's edification and enjoyment was limited to a single species of domesticated ruminant mammal, which seemed inadequate given the diversity of fauna present in the surrounding environment."
I was fairly disappointed with this zoo. Signage was unclear. Many of the exhibits were on loan. The petting zoo consisted of a large pen of goats.

We were looking at this place everyday and planing to try for the breakfast and, finally we get in to the place. nice staff and quick service got our attention. we had great tasting coffee and we took a order and i tried the chicken hash which is the most popular  consider to the waiter. Plates are pretty big and the bread is so hard and cant even taste that. all the food has no taste at all. i was surprised and add some hot souse and pepper and salt to  make my taste bud happier,. bad luck!!! i didnt like the food at all. i can't say anything good about food and we just had BLAH! breakfast. I still top the Black Bear Dinner is the best breakfast so far!!

I was surprised and relieved to find that Whisky River is not a shrine to Dale Earnhardt Jr. Still, it's a haven for his adoring middle-aged fans and very much a tourist trap. There is even a stand selling Whisky River T-shirts, hats and other merchandise. 

If you're not into NASCAR, you definitely shouldn't go during a race, which dominates all 20 TVs in the bar. 

Whisky River is a private club, so if you're going for the first time, you'll have to go through the annoying process of waiting in line and filling out a membership form. You'll also have to pay a cover to get in.

Unlike other EpiCentre hotspots, Whisky River's crowd isn't very dressed up. Most women wear jeans and halter tops; most guys wear jeans, collared shirts and baseball caps.  

With three large bars and several beer tubs, there are plenty of spots to get a drink in the smoky, packed bar. And I'll admit that watching people (mostly women) tackle the mechanical bull can be entertaining. 

A big plus is that it's right off the light rail.

When faced with the predicament of having indulged in an excessive amount of sake, resulting in the inability to endure a prolonged bus ride, the most practical solution would be to seek refuge in the nearest hotel. In our particular situation, the Thistle King James Hotel was the closest establishment that offered lodging, albeit with limited options, specifically twin rooms. Despite the less-than-ideal circumstances, we opted to take advantage of the available accommodations, which, although adequate for my preferences, were not entirely suitable for my companion due to the firmness of the mattresses. Furthermore, the ambient temperature in the room proved to be unbearably high, and despite our efforts to locate the thermostat, we were unable to regulate the temperature. Additionally, the absence of effective soundproofing became increasingly bothersome, as external noises from the surrounding area permeated the room, detracting from the overall quality of our sleep. Upon inquiring about the matter, we were informed by the receptionist that the hotel was slated for demolition, which, while not necessarily a cause for concern, might warrant some attention to the issue of sound insulation in the interest of enhancing the guest experience, particularly given its relatively affordable rates for a central hotel.

What do you do when you've had one sake too many and can't be bothered with a 90min bus ride home? Stumble into the closest hotel you can find! Which, in our case, was the Thistle King James Hotel. With only twin rooms left, it would have to do. \n\nFrom there on in, we passed out, on what I would term as gloriously hard mattresses, perfect for me, but hated by the boy. It was roasting hot, and we couldn't find the thermostat. Neither of which was a super big deal for me, but the fact that I felt I was lying next to the drunk roaring outside rather than being separated by concrete and 6 floors was a little more frustrating. I've lived downtown before, screaming police cars are not a big deal for me - but soundproofing was pretty handy, and the age of this building shows in it's lack thereof. The lady on the counter cheerfully advised us that it was due to be knocked down... to that I am not sure if I care particularly about, but at least if it is to continue in it's guise as a hotel (for a central hotel, surprisingly cheap... or maybe not that surprising) perhaps some soundproofing in rooms so I don't hear the *pop* of the champagne bottle next door next time....

Growing up in Tempe I always thought this was THE liquor store, mind you as a kid riding in the back seat of my parents station wagon. 

They had the flashing lights on their sign, the awesome location, a drive through so you don't even have to get up out your car to get that bottle surrounded by a black plastic bag. 

Well when I became of age to purchase legally, I realized there is no reason to drive past 30 liquor stores (aka 4 miles in Tempe) to get to this one so I never went. 

Groupon enticed me in with their $20 for $40 deal on liquor. I finally went in and used it the other day and pretty much disappointment for a liquor store. These guys will be a-okay because they practically on the ASU campus, people will drive through on the way to a football game to grab their drinks, and again, ASU.

If you have a bit more time, go elsewhere because I felt like I was buying liquor in the lobby of a Las Vegas hotel with these prices. Otherwise, location, location, location.
Hard to tell which was colder: my beer or my burrito. The service was non-existent. And had to beg for chips and salsa. Skip this one.

I love Starbucks but this one is not so great. It's strange when there isn't a line and it's so LOUD that it's impossible to relax and/or get any homework done. It's always full of annoying kids. The only reason I keep going back is because it's literally 3 mins away from my place and the staff is super friendly and they usually do a good job making my coffee. They also have a nice outdoor seating area but I can never use it because it's usually too hot outside and lately it has been unusually cold. I really wish they had a drive-thru at this location!

I want to say food is good.  Please Do Not purchase any retail products!  I purchased a 80$ purse and used it for 1 week and a strap started coming apart.  I took it in a week later and was told all retail sales are final!  Sorry!!!  You can take it and get it fixed.  Wow!!

The exorbitant pricing strategy employed by this establishment is utterly egregious, particularly when juxtaposed with the minuscule proportions of the dishes served. It is utterly perplexing that such an esteemed culinary institution would resort to such questionable practices, especially given the plethora of authentic, mouth-watering Mexican cuisine available in the Southwestern United States at a fraction of the cost. While the ambiance may be aesthetically pleasing, it cannot justify the extortionate prices charged for such meager servings.

Ridiculously small portions for ridiculously high prices.  This is MEXICAN FOOD for gods sake!!!!  Do they realize how many knock-you-socks-off authentic Mexican food restaurants there are in the southwest???!!!!??  For a portion of the price!!!!  The pretty setting is a plus, but not THAT MUCH!

If you are looking for any type of Asian food, you are not going to find it here.  What you are going to find is slightly overpriced mediocre food next to CMU which makes it popular for no particular reason. 

I have tried the pho (really sad) and the rice with duck which was decent, but was not butchered well.  

Overall if you need something in the CMU area you can do a lot better and the service could use improvement as well.

I had an ok experience, it was during lunch on the weekend... not a lot of people inside and they had the games on but the TVs were blasting loud... couldnt enjoy conversation. I ordered the french dip, it was very greasy... the au ju appeared to be some form of a gravy. The tots were good.. nice and crunchy and not too salty. Its a ride from my house and not a place I would go out of the way to go to again.

Ordered a Focaccia sandwich.  They said it was \"different\".  Yes, it was different.  Nothing like focaccia bread.  More like a burrito or wrap.  Not good.  Sweet potato chips were bland.  Beer was cold.  Would try somewhere else next time.

I have to admit, the first time I stepped in I was incredibly unimpressed.  It's big, they sell GIANT glasses of beer and the crowd is a bit too eclectic for even this guys tastes.  That's usually a recipe for disaster...  but for some reason this place is growing on me.  

Sure, it's not my favorite bar in madison.  It's not even in my top 20.  I wouldn't make this a weekend destination, but it fills that niche of  "Hey, you wanna grab a beer?"  Plus it's close to home.

Weeknights are pretty quiet, you can sit and have a conversation and drink.  Sometimes that's all you need out of a bar.  

The Come Back is not good, it's definitely not bad... it just IS

Impressive wine list, but the service was a little apathetic, and very high prices for the quality of food.   Food was lukewarm when it arrived and the \"menu description\" to \"product\" ratio was pretty far off.  I essentially had a BBQ-sauced ham hock over far too buttery grits.  But I will say that the wild board meatballs were awesome.\n\nI think I just expected more.

I want to like this place, I really do.  I can't get over 3 things:  1)  Their bbq is just OK.  Sauces are good (at least 4 stars), but the meat, by itself, just isn't that great.  Their sides are just OK, too.  Mashed sweet potatoes, potato salad, barbequed pinto beans, etc.....  just average.  Not really much flavor to anything I've ever had there (roughly 4-5 experiences).  Even their sweet tea is just OK - not bad, but not memorable in any way.  2)  Their prices are much higher than their competition.  If I'm going to pay this much, I want to eat Midwood Smokehouse or Mac's.  3)  It drives me nuts when restaurants weigh out portion sizes.  Especially BBQ joints.  Feels like I'm in a Subway.  I understand it's part of their business model to control portion sizes, but c'mon man!?!?!\n\nService is great.  The guys behind the counter are always helpful, fast, and fun to engage in conversation, but the food is average at best.

Token Limit: 512 tokens
Accepted tokens: 496 tokens

The text is: "A diminutive drinking establishment, commonly referred to as a 'dive bar,' which serves as a popular gathering place for individuals seeking to imbibe alcoholic beverages, particularly those of Native American descent, and offers a unique service wherein patrons can procure a quantity of fermented liquids, typically packaged in glass or metal containers, for consumption at their residences, thereby establishing an ambiance characterized by simplicity and informality, reminiscent of a bygone era."

Just a little dive bar!  This is a spot that we used to head to for a few beers at the end of the night when I lived in the neighborhood.  There are a bunch of Native American's that frequent this establishment.

The best thing about Playa Bar is they will package up a few brews for you to take home with you.

Not much to say about this old little hole in the wall.

I've been here probably four times, mostly because I don't want to drive all the way to Spring Mtn. I felt compelled to write this review after my last and final visit. The service is as bad as everyone has mentioned. The owner/server does not greet you or smile. He will eventually make his way over and say \"ready?\". He will never return until 20 minutes later when the soup comes out. I am pretty sure they dont have to make this to order. Soak the noodles, add the broth and rare beef and serve. It can come out in 5 minutes. While I waited I began to notice the mini-blinds were so dirty and then I started wondering what else was dirty. When the large bowl of pho I ordered to share with my youngest arrived, it had like 4 slices of beef. I asked the owner if this was right since I ordered a large. He says that is normal. No attempts to fix it. Well I won't be returning and the food is just meh!
Over priced and the food is blah, the only thing that I found good on the menu was the choco taco, and those can be picked up for a couple of bucks at any convenience store.

WHen I started going here it was pretty good.   Two of the ladies there did a good job Than I started getting this older guy and woman and I'd find that I'd go in for a fill in and it would last maybe a week where I used to be able to go for 2 to 3 week.  I'm sure my nails haven't suddenly started growing faster.  My nails also started lifting after a few days.  He just doesn't do a very good job and not being one who can make an appointment, I kinda gotta take what I get.  If I knew I was going to get either of the 2 ladies that I used to get in the beginning I would go back there everytime but I keep getting stuck with the guy so I just don't think it's worth the gamble anymore.  Time to find a more consistant salon and also one that appreciates the year round resident over the snowbird.

Okay I've been here numerous times before always for oysters but we went the past weekend for the pan roast and it was two thumbs down. The broth was sweet for some reason and just not good. Go for the oysters but that's all.

Imagine... you are on a diet for about 2 weeks and you've lost a significant amount of weight.

Now, you're on vacation with your girlfriends and you don't wanna be a party pooper  or the stupid downer on a diet so you decide to have a HUGE cheat meal and enjoy really good food with good company, possibly undoing 2 weeks' worth of starvation. 

After much deliberation, you decide on a buffet, wait two hours in line and pay $40 upon entering the restaurant to have what you think will be one of the tastiest meals of your life (considering you haven't eaten any real food for the past 13 days).

--------------------------------------------------------
I was UTTERLY DISAPPOINTED in their food selections... or lack thereof.  
I kept walking around the buffet with my plate hoping that more variety of food would magically appear.
I wanted sushi so I stood in line in the "rolls" section to no avail. 
...just some sad looking California rolls that consisted of like 90% rice.

SADNESS

Other than the king crab legs, the best thing there was either the scrambled eggs or pesto mashed potatoes.

To come out of a buffet and say that their scrambled eggs were one of the best items they offered... is just really really sad.

"My desire for a more favorable evaluation of this establishment is unwavering; however, I am regretfully unable to confer such accolades due to the inconsistent nature of their offerings. Initially, our dining experience at this venue was quite pleasurable, boasting an inviting ambiance, commendable hospitality, and passable cuisine. Unfortunately, subsequent visits have yielded a stark contrast, characterized by questionable edibles and abysmal customer service, prompting us to reconsider our patronage. Despite our reluctance to return, we continue to indulge in the hope of a satisfying meal, opting instead to allocate our culinary expenditures toward establishments that have proven themselves as reliable and worthy of our endorsement, such as Atlantis Taverna."

I only go here when I know exactly what I want so I dont have to try and ask an employee for help. 1 out of 10 of there employees actually knows something. Sometimes this place is just so fustrating. Customer service sucks.\n\nBut when I do find something I want it is a really good price.

We went here on a recent visit to Madison with our kids after riding the Polar Express train.  If you're not a fan of clowns and circus stuff surounding you at every turn, don't go here.  If you are looking for outstanding food, don't go here either.  After paging through the 30 page binder they call their menu, our table had a Chicago style hot dog, meatloaf and mashed potatoes, a cheeseburger, a reuben sandwich and some soup.......  We all said the same thing after we left, \"well that was a disappointment\".\n\nThe kids really enjoyed themselves and ate most of their chicken tenders, I guess I haven't indoctrinated them enough yet into the belief that clowns and circus memorabilia  is evil.  Seriously, this may be a good place for desert and a quick look with the kids.  If you are looking for a great meal, keep looking.

"Notwithstanding the universal enthusiasm surrounding the art festival, I must admit that, while the items on display were certainly distinctive, the overall experience felt akin to a glorified craft fair. The ambiance of such events is typically enjoyable, but this particular instance did not live up to my expectations. Following a hasty perusal of the festival with my companion, we opted to divert our attention to the nearby arcade, where we expended the majority of our funds. Frankly, I believe that the festival would have been more enjoyable had I been a decade younger. 

Owing to the festival's popularity, finding suitable parking can be a challenge. Consequently, I suggest alternative modes of transportation, such as cycling, or parking at a distance and walking from there. 

Although there were certainly gifted individuals in attendance, none of their works truly astounded me."

I understand everyone's excitement about the art festival, but I think yes, while the  stuff was unique, it just seemed like a giant craft fair. I like the atmosphere of festivals but this was not what I was looking for. It was a bit of a letdown, after my friend and I quickly rushed through the festival we went to the arcade and spent most of our money there. I think the festival would have been more fun if I were 10 years younger.  

It's hard to find parking when the festival is in town so I'd recommend biking if you can. You could even park farther away and walk it. 

There were a lot of talented people there but nothing that blew me away.

The staff were very nice, and try to help when they get the time, however this is a very busy place, so getting hold of a member of staff can take some time.

Disabled access could be MUCH better, and even on the wettest and coldest of days, they do try and encourage wheelchair users to eat outside as the staff freely accepted that there wasn't much space.

The fish is NOT fresh, but frozen, nothing better than what you could get in a supermarket but at a fraction of the cost. £12.25 for frozen fish and "fries" is just a bit extortionate. However my partner had a freshly made Pizza which she thoroughly enjoyed. The food can be a bit greasy, and while we were there, several customers had complained about the same thing.

There does seem to be a drastic lack of management. I was determined not to sit outside in minus 1C, so when I asked to speak to a member of management about this, I was told one would be right with me. Still nothing after a 45 minute wait!!!

There are far more accessible places, with better management, and far better food, even the chip shop opposite serves MUCH better fish and chips and at half the price.

This is one place I won't be returning to in a hurry

I am ok with $7.50 warm beers as long as there is a professional sports event in front of me.... The only event that I witnessed was the surprise on everyone's face when they saw how small the portions were!!  I do like the uniforms though.... Reminded me that my car was due for an oil change!!

MR says ... if I've known I'm going to get beaten up...

MRS says ... we went here to get a foot massage. After a long day of walking Vegas strip, we figure, a good massage will ease up our tired aching feet. This place offers not just foot massages but body. Sure nice to have a body massage but our experience was horrible with the masseuse. She was rubbing my head so hard that I feel like my thinning hair is getting abuse and got me worried that I'm walking out of this foot spa already bald.

As for the actual massage, it was painful. The masseuse lady must be using same strength or force on all of her customers because she didn't even bother to ask if I want it harder or extra pressure points. 

We were hoping for a foot massage but gotten a beating. It was more of a body massage than foot reflexology. Will consider other massage place in the area as there are TONS of them out there. So many to choose from. Unfortunately we ended up here because they're just $20 an hour and they're open late. 

Lesson learn not to get caught up with the $20 deal ... it's too good to be true!!!
Been going to Mr. Lucky's for years.  Had the gamblers special.  The shrimp, salad, and potatos were very good.  The quality of the steak has gone downhill.  Disappointed.

If you possess a predilection for culinary indulgences similar to my own, you may find yourself unimpressed by the offerings at Hillside Spot. My companion and I visited this establishment several weeks ago, seeking a hasty midday repast subsequent to an excursion to Ikea. Our order comprised of the Blue Sky burger and a salad/sandwich combination. Allow me to emphasize that the chopped salad was indeed delectable - though it is worth mentioning that the utilization of fresh ingredients renders it challenging to produce an unsatisfactory outcome. Conversely, the grilled veggie sandwich was utterly revolting. The vegetables were saturated in oil and grease, and were positioned upon the driest bread I have had the misfortune of encountering. It was inconceivable that this was their notion of a healthy alternative. The Blue Sky burger was similarly underwhelming... but, alas, we were unable to discern any flavors beyond the dominant blue cheese. This dining establishment proved to be the most considerable letdown in recent memory.

In light of the foregoing, it is reasonable to surmise that Hillside Spot is overrated, despite its three and a half star rating. To reiterate, merely expressing my opinion.

If you're a foodie like me, you will NOT be impressed by Hillside Spot. My boyfriend and I came here a couple of weeks ago for a quick lunch after a trip to Ikea. We ordered the Blue Sky burger and a salad/sandwich combo. Let me just say the chopped salad was delicious--but then again how can you go wrong if you use fresh ingredients? The grilled veggie sandwich, however was DIS-GUSTING. The veggies were sopping in oil/grease and were put on the driest piece of bread I've ever had. I couldn't believe that's what they considered the healthy option. The Blue Sky burger was no better...but then again we wouldn't know because the only flavor you could taste was the blue cheese. This place was the biggest disappointment in a long time.\n\nOverall, even with three and a half stars this place is overrated. Just sayin.

Been a four day a week customer of Yogurtland for months. Great place, friendly employees, excellent selection. Decided to try agave out of curiosity. First time there I got the cake batter yogurt and absolutely loved it. I thought this might be my next favorite place. Went the next day and poof! Cake batter was gone. Unlike yogurtland which always has the flavors I like, this place swaps them out daily. I was impressed when the cashier said he had wifi and even provided 15 different cables to charge various devices. My iPhone was almost dead so I asked if he could get me an iPhone charger. Guess what? He didnt have one. Are you kidding? The best device in the world and he has every charger but that one? Also, very pricey. Yogurtland is 8 cents per ounce cheaper. With a family of five that adds up.

We went here tonight for dinner, and the whole experience was just a notch above median. We picked this place through Yelp, and though we cook Indian food (I'm Indian) at least 3 days a week, sometimes we crave for restaurant Indian food. We ordered the mixed grill plate for appetizers and chicken tikka masala and naan for the main course. The mixed grill plate comprised of kabobs (both seekh and tikkas of chicken, lamb and beef) laid on a THICK bed of sauteed onions and a couple of lemon wedges. It arrived sizzling hot, and several people turned their heads to see where that szzzzz sound was coming from!  I dug into it with my mouth salivating in expectation, but it was a rude shock. The chicken was dry to the mouth. The seekh kabobs were overpowered with spices (mainly red pepper), and the quantity--so abysmal! The bed of onions probably weighed more in quantity than the meat. The tikkas were standard fare...oily and spicy gravy, with cubed pieces of chicken. The place is good for students, because it's so close to ASU, but otherwise, I don't think I will go back there again!

"Wow, what an unforgettable escapade! It appears that this hotel prematurely launched its operations, particularly with an excessive number of rooms, which led to numerous challenges during our stay. Our check-in process was an absolute debacle, as we did not gain access to our quarters until well after 7 pm. Furthermore, they were unable to accommodate our request to be placed on the same floor as our fellow travelers. One member of our party never even received room service, while our own meal arrived much later than expected, around 5 pm. Additionally, we encountered various issues with cleanliness, including hairs in the sink and an unkempt toilet area. The check-in staff members were less than hospitable, and their lack of customer service skills only exacerbated the problems we faced. However, we must commend the efficient and friendly service we received during the check-out process. Unfortunately, it seems that Aria is cognizant of its deficiencies and is actively striving to enhance its services. Nonetheless, the majority of guests are unlikely to return, as exemplified by the three disgruntled patrons we encountered in line, all of whom received some form of compensation for their troubles. In contrast, the hotel's dining establishments offered palatable cuisine. The overall ambiance of the hotel is shrouded in darkness, prompting us to prefer alternative luxury resorts such as Bellagio, Wynn, or Venetian. This hotel requires considerable refinement."

"I have an aversion to crafting negative assessments, but this establishment genuinely merits the designation of a refined Outback Steakhouse. My significant other and I requested the Wagyu Filet, and its flavor profile was analogous to that of a conventional filet offered by Outback! Indeed, my partner remains convinced that the restaurant inadvertently served us a standard filet instead of the Wagyu variant...a notion that does not seem entirely implausible. 

Our dining experience involved an expenditure of over $400, encompassing wine, dessert, and an appetizer. Unfortunately, the culinary offerings did not live up to our expectations. While we are known to spend considerable sums of money on gastronomic indulgences due to the experiential aspect, this particular meal did not justify the cost.
