Notwithstanding a brief delay in the preparation of the burger, Monica's genial deportment engendered a sense of contentment that rendered the brief wait inconsequential. Furthermore, the eatery's state of tidiness and cleanliness garnered approbation, while the melodic ambiance, characterized by a mellow country twang, contributed to the overall convivial atmosphere, although a slight diminution in volume might have enhanced the dining experience for this patron."

"We have had the privilege of dining at this establishment on multiple occasions, and our experiences have been somewhat inconsistent, as the ambiance and culinary offerings have alternated between impressive and unremarkable. Following a renovation several years ago, the atmosphere still retains a cafeteria-like quality, despite efforts to enhance its aesthetic appeal. The variety of dishes available is adequate but not exceptional, and the quality can fluctuate depending on the day and time of visit. Our previous visit a couple of months prior was forgettable, but we opted to give the buffet another chance after learning that George Michael would be performing at the MGM, and our second experience was relatively successful. The grilled steak station was operational this time, and the aroma of cooked meat greeted us upon entry, complemented by the satisfying taste of the steak. Additionally, the crab legs were flavorful and enjoyable. However, a special event surcharge of $10 per person was applied that evening, bringing the total cost to around $30 per person, which we felt could have been better spent at the Wynn."

After relocating from the metropolitan area of Chicago, it became imperative to locate an exceptional sushi eatery within the vicinity of Madison. Initially, I harbored reservations regarding the prospect of finding a suitable establishment, given its location within a modest strip mall adjacent to a discount store. However, upon conducting a thorough assessment, I was pleasantly surprised by the culinary excellence that this particular venue had to offer. Over the ensuing year and a half, I have remained a loyal patron of Takara, albeit with a brief period of diminished satisfaction. Notwithstanding, I would unhesitatingly endorse this dining establishment, particularly in light of their exceptional lunchtime offering, which comprises two sushi rolls accompanied by a bowl of savory miso soup, all at a remarkably reasonable price point.

I was tempted to confer a rating of two stars upon Goodtimes; however, due to my status as an out-of-town visitor and the fact that I have only had the opportunity to visit the establishment on a single occasion, I cannot, with any degree of credibility, attest to its consistent quality.

On a Thursday evening, we decided to pay a visit to Goodtimes, as they were hosting a Goth-themed event titled "Carpe Noctem." Upon our arrival, I could discern that we had indeed arrived at the correct location, as there were several youths clad in spooky attire loitering about the parking lot, and a hearse was parked nearby.

The dance floor was pleasantly crowded, while all tables and seating areas surrounding it were occupied, thus prompting us to proceed towards the bar area, which was devoid of patrons. The bartender demonstrated remarkable efficiency, courtesy, and precision in the pouring of drinks.

Following the consumption of a sufficient quantity of alcoholic beverages, I ventured forth to engage in dancing activities; however, I quickly realized that the dance floor was lacking in sufficient space, as it was composed of peculiar, slick metal plates, rendering me unable to fully unleash my latent dancing abilities.

It is inherently challenging to formulate a definitive judgment regarding a Goth club based solely on a solitary visit. This particular way of life constitutes a scene, and not something that one can casually immerse oneself in. Reflecting on my experiences at my regular club back home, where it took me a considerable duration to establish a sense of belonging, I chose not to rush to judgment.

In light of the gradual decline of the Goth scene (a phenomenon that I shall refer to as a "dying breed"), it is reasonable to assume that the availability of such clubs in Las Vegas is limited, thereby making it essential to derive satisfaction from whatever establishments are available.

I was tempted to give Goodtimes 2 stars but since I'm from out of town and have only been here once, i can't vouch for it's consistency.

We stopped by Goodtimes on a Thursday night for their Goth night "Carpe Noctem". I could tell we atleast reached the right place based on a few spooky kids in the parking lot and a hearse parked out there too.

The dance floor area was pleasently full. All tables/seatting area around it were taken so we headed back to the EMPTY bar area.  The bartender was quick, curtious, and poured nicely.

After I got a good buzz on I went out to dance and realized there wasn't enough space. Their dance floor is made out some strange/slick metal plates. I didn't feel sturdy enough to really cutloose. 

You really can't judge a goth club based on once experience. This lifestyle is a scene and not something one can jump into. It made me remember how long it took for me to feel welcome at the club back at home so i won't make quick judgements here.

I suppose since the goth scene is a slowly dying thing (ahhh, pun), you take what you can get in Vegas.

The son and I tried Elmer's last night for the first time.  Figured he could see what the place is about so he knows where he can dash to for lunch from CHS.

He got the Asada burrito which he said tasted good.   I got the green beef hot burrito.  It was tasty, but very messy.  I had to grab a fork and knife to finish.

They have a pretty decent sized menu.  Prices are dirt cheap.   Hands down they beat Guedo's because they offer chips and salsa and take debit cards.  Food, prices and counter help is better at Elmer's too.

Not the cleanest of places.  Definite hole in the wall.  The smooshed food on the floor by our table kinda got to me.

"I had the pleasure of meeting a acquaintance for a morning meal at this establishment, and I must say, the hospitality we received was quite satisfactory. The ambiance of the restaurant was reminiscent of a certain chain of restaurants that shall remain nameless, but the quality of the cuisine was undoubtedly superior. I opted for the farmer's omelette, which, to my delight, was assembled with fresh, locally-sourced ingredients. My companion, on the other hand, selected the corned beef hash and eggs, which, according to their account, was also expertly prepared. Notably, the generous serving of corned beef hash was crafted entirely from scratch, a testament to the culinary prowess of the chef. While my omelette was, regrettably, not as impressive as my companion's dish, it was still a satisfying repast. However, I must express my mild disappointment at the absence of any complementary fresh fruit or vegetables, as such an addition would have elevated the dining experience to a truly exceptional level. Nonetheless, I would unhesitatingly recommend this eatery to anyone seeking a hearty, satisfying meal in a welcoming atmosphere."

Everyone was raving about the oxtail chili cheese fries but it just tasted like a regular chili cheese fries with an egg on top. Nothing extravagant. But the fries itself was pretty good. 

I originally ordered the Kiki's burger and my husband ordered the Miyagi Wagyu burger but then I totally changed my mind so we switched burgers. I personally like the Miyagi burger better. It reminded me of the Manly burger at Umami burger. And my husband says he liked the Kiki's burger better so I guess it all worked out. 

I'm giving it a 3 stars because their food is really yummy but it's also expensive. Also this is the first place in Vegas that has decent boba. I've searched long and hard for boba places that can give me almost the same thing I had in California and this place came pretty close. The only problem is, like I said, it's expensive. And such small portions. But I mean overall I'd still eat here again.

"Inexpensive culinary options, variable quality, and inconsistent service are hallmarks of this establishment. Ideally suited for large gatherings of friends and family, comparable to Paradise Buffet or other Freemont buffets. An interesting aspect is the bathroom's connection to the Berlin Wall. 
  Sunday brunch costs $12 with the club card, offering an excellent value. My experiences have shown the food to be relatively consistent with the price, albeit the prime rib is satisfactory, and the brisket could benefit from slower cooking and proper cutting. Notably, the nearby bar serves beer at a reasonable price of $1 per cup. 
  Unfortunately, the service is unpredictable, sometimes meeting expectations and other times neglecting to provide essential drink refills throughout the meal, resulting in only two sightings of our waiter. The ambiance, cleanliness, and location are generic, reminiscent of Bioshock Infinity, within the Main Street Station casino at the end of the Freemont Street Experience. 
  My rating system involves three categories, each starting at 3 points. Impressive aspects earn one point, while disappointing elements deduct a point. Calculating an overall rating by rounding the average of the ratings yields a score of 3."

"An adequate neighborhood coffee establishment, characterized by a welcoming ambiance and congenial staff, serving a satisfactory quality of coffee, albeit not the most exceptional, yet still preferable to the offerings of a certain ubiquitous multinational chain. The Kona blend, in particular, elicits excitement upon its appearance on the menu, precipitating an eagerness to sample its rich flavor profile. However, a glaring deficiency in the breakfast options is evident, as the absence of bacon, egg, and cheese sandwiches is acutely felt, leaving patrons to settle for inferior pastry selections or bagels. Furthermore, Sunday mornings witness a surge in patronage, courtesy of the adjacent church attendees, transforming the once-quaint coffee shop into a chaotic throng of acquaintances engaging in leisurely conversations, rendering navigation within the already cramped space a formidable challenge."

It is challenging to refrain from adoring anything situated on picturesque William Street, yet, for some unexplained reason, I failed to experience an elevated level of enthusiasm upon visiting The Melville during my recent excursion. Perhaps it was the trio of gentlemen of a particular age indulging in tobacco products near the entrance, or the perceptible odor that filled the atmosphere upon my arrival, leading me to momentarily speculate that the smoking prohibition had yet to be enforced within the premises.

The cost of beverages was somewhat steep in comparison to various other establishments in the proximate city center region, lacking the identical carefree and fashionable ambiance that Teuchters, located just across the street, seemingly possesses. Notwithstanding, the menu showcasing edibles appeared enticing and reasonably priced, thereby impelling me to consider patronizing this establishment again in the future, albeit without an exceptionally high ranking on my list of priorities.

It's hard not to love anything on gorgeous William Street, but for some reason I didn't get too excited about The Melville when I came here the other day. It just seemed a bit too olde worlde, in a bad way, for my liking. Whether it was the three gents of a certain age smoking in the doorway, or the smell when I walked in that made me think for a second that the smoking ban had never been implemented.\n\nDrinks were pricey compared to a lot of other pubs in this area of the city centre, and although it was no more expensive than Teuchters just across the road it lacks the same relaxed and trendy vibe that Teuchters has. Although in its defense, the food menu did look nice and inviting as well as being good value for money, so I'll probably head back here at some point to try it out. It's just not at the top of my list.

"My expectations were favorably surpassed upon dining at Les Deux Gamins, a quaint French bistro nestled among an array of overpriced establishments catering primarily to tourists on Prince-Arthur. Although not a bring-your-own-wine (BYOW) venue like many neighboring eateries, the prices were relatively reasonable. The menu offered traditional French cuisine, including steak tartare, steak frite, and lamb shank, without any unexpected variations or contemporary twists. While the kitchen encountered a minor mishap with our appetizer order, they graciously compensated us with a complimentary bottle of house wine. Ultimately, although superior French restaurants exist in Montreal, Les Deux Gamins presents a satisfying dining experience, especially considering its convenient location."

I am originating from Southern California, where an abundance of sushi options are readily available. Upon relocating to Arizona, I have been ardently seeking a local sushi establishment that can provide comparable quality to that of Los Angeles, all while maintaining reasonable price points. Considering the fact that the seafood in LA is often fresher and not previously frozen due to the city's proximity to harbors, I entered Hiro's with tempered expectations to avoid potential disappointment. Generally speaking, the atmosphere and sushi quality are quite satisfactory for a venue situated in Arizona. Nonetheless, the prices are somewhat elevated, which is only natural given the restaurant's location in Scottsdale and the associated increased costs of procuring premium seafood in an inland area. Furthermore, I find it perplexing that the bento boxes, such as the Teriyaki Chicken and Mixed Tempura, carry such a hefty price tag. In light of this, I am unlikely to return to Hiro's, particularly if I am seeking non-seafood options. Such items should not be priced so exorbitantly, especially when they are sourced locally. I would comprehend if they were offering Kobe beef or something of similar caliber, but for chicken, it seems unjustified. To compound matters, the chicken I received during my visit was slightly dry. Although it may have been an isolated incident, for such a steep price, I rightfully anticipate superior quality or, at the very least, naturally raised organic chicken. Thus, I feel misled in this regard. My apologies, Hiro; I shall continue my search elsewhere.

"The individuals in question possess an exceptionally personable demeanor, which was exemplified during our initial interaction, as they accommodated my request for assistance with a relatively straightforward electrical task on the very same day that I contacted them. Notwithstanding their commendable efforts, they were regretfully unable to resolve the issue at hand, but rather than exacerbate the situation, they adopted a refreshingly candid approach by openly acknowledging the limitations of their expertise and advising me to seek the services of a qualified electrician, whom I subsequently engaged and who successfully resolved the problem in a mere five minutes. Furthermore, I have arranged for them to perform another assignment, albeit with a delay of two weeks owing to their busy schedule, and they provided me with a quote that was considerably lower than the prices tendered by other contractors."

These guys are very personable. The first time I called them it was with a simple electrical job. They fit me into their schedule the same day. Ultimately, they were not able to fix the problem, but rather than make matters worse, they simply stated that they couldn't figure it out and that I should call and electrician, which I did. The electrician fixed the problem in 5 minutes.  That said, I've got an appointment scheduled for another job. This time I couldn't get on their schedule for two weeks. The price they quoted me for this job was a fraction of what other contractors were charging.

The food was decent so they lose a star there.  We tried the chicken which had good flavor but was a bit dry.  The BBQ sandwich was much the same.  The ribs were killer though.  And the insane amount of side they have is awesome.  All 4 sides we tried were really tasty.

They lose another star because we sat and watched person after person that ordered after us get their togo orders before they even bothered to tell us they messed up on our order.  Their saving grace was the gentleman that work the register there telling us he was sorry and gave us a free dish.

I will try this place again hoping it was a fluke.

My husband and I went for an early dinner, sat outside on the patio....  nice, but unfortunately the road noise was a bit distracting from the ambiance.  Inside was stuffy and very noisy, so outside was a better choice,
The flat bread and garlic balls bread basket was good, served warm.
Now the main course, my husband ordered linguini and clams... When it came, he honestly said "we need to go to McDonald's". The portion was incredibly small.... We counted 7 small, super tiny clams.... and maybe a half cup of linguini.
I ordered the chicken marsala, it was a good size portion, huge compared to the linguini, flavorful and tastefully done.  I shared my food with my husband and skipped McDonald's.  
Service was super slow....
Not sure we would go back with do many other places to try.

Sub par sushi. 

Ra was the first place I had ever tried sushi and I really enjoyed it. However, after broadening my horizons and dining at other sushi establishments (Hiro, etc.), I discovered that there are much better options all over the valley. 

If you go, I would recommend the Las Vegas roll (not sure what's in it) and calamari roll (fried calamari, cream cheese, white rice, and topped with eel sauce and tempura flakes). Both are decent and are much better tasting than their other rolls.

They have good happy hour deals. Rolls are definitely much smaller here than anywhere else I've been.

"A passable Chinese fast-food establishment that bears a resemblance to Panda Express, offering an experience comparable to that of a food court.  The cost of the food entrees was slightly elevated, while the price of a bottle of beer was exorbitant, making it advisable to acquire alcoholic beverages at the casino during gameplay.  A suitable venue for a rapid meal, worthy of revisiting; however, refrain from purchasing beer."

Decent Chinese fast food that is similar to Panda Express.  About what you would expect at a food court.  

The prices for the food entrees was a bit high.  The price for a bottle of beer was way too expensive.  Just get your alcohol at the casino while playing.

Good place for a quick meal.  I would stop by again.  I just would not buy beer.

So I haven't been to a $.99 store in a while.  And I forgot about all the great deals they do have.  Times are tight for just about everyone and a good bargain is sometimes hard to find if you don't look in the right place.  So if you haven't already started looking here every once in a while you might want to start!  They have just about everything here, from plates and dishware to canned food. There is usually one thing you will find even if you aren't really looking.  So the next time you get a chance you might want to take a stroll through and see what you find.

I think their food is pretty good BUT it never fails Every time I order the pear salad it's always missing something! It's like the waitress isn't listening. Or I order wings and I ask for blue cheese and always get ranch! It's little things like this that makes the experience and the prices I pay irritating. I want to get what I pay for. I don't want to get home with my take out and dip a wing and discover its in a dressing I hate or that my salad is all together wrong! BUT they are always very accommodating and fix their error and compensate me for it, but it happens all too often.

What a hidden treasure.  Tucked away in corner strip center at 19th Ave. and TBird next to high school we found a new sushi and japanese restaurant.  Very small but comfy.  Booths, tables and sushi bar.  Looks like it's run by the owners - an old couple.  We ordered the bento box specials for lunch today.  $6.95 = choice of soup + egg roll + tempura veggies, + 1/2 a California roll, + white rice and a choice of several entrees.  Bro picked General Tao Chicken.  I picked Mongolian Beef.  Both were great.  We'll be back for bento boxes and to try the real sushi and sashimi.  Spread the word - they need business.

"Despite the conflagration that transpired previously, the culinary offerings at this establishment remain palatable, albeit with a slight diminution in portion size in the case of salads. However, it is lamentable that the contemporary renovations have obliterated the former convivial ambiance."

"Reliable and venerable establishment, Beanscene, has consistently served as my preferred venue for a substantial cup of Americano, coupled with a complimentary perusal of the day's news and a tranquil atmosphere conducive to focused studying, all within the confines of its spacious leather booths, for numerous academic years. The harmonious confluence of welcoming staff, mellifluous background tunes, and an individualized approach, distinct from the impersonal nature of larger commercial enterprises, has fostered a gratifying and dependable experience that perpetually lures me back. Although, I must admit, my visits have been primarily motivated by the desire to partake in their diverse assortment of expertly crafted coffee beverages, rather than indulging in their menu offerings, which include nachos and paninis; nonetheless, Beanscene's inviting ambiance and commitment to quality remain unwavering."

Trusty old Beanscene. Academic year after academic year this has been my favourite place to grab a large mug of Americano, pick up a copy of the Metro and slip into one of its leather booths for a quiet read and a flick through my lecture notes.

Inviting staff, mellow beats playing in the background and a more personal alternative to the bigger corporate cafe brands result in a pleasant and reliable service that will keep coming back for more.

Admittedly, I've never come here for the food: Nachos, Paninis etc are the typical fare. But for a coffee and a place to sit and read, Beanscene will do just fine.

Of all the gay bars in the city, 941 probably ranks in the middle of them all. There's really nothing awful about it and yet there really isn't anything amazing about it either. And to be honest, you wouldn't even know it's a gay bar unless you've researched it. 


Having said all this, it really depends on the time you go. I visited here this previous weekend in the afternoon. There were only a few people there which made the atmosphere comfortable. I got a Mai Tai (sp?) that was on special for $4.75 and it came in a bigger glass. The bartender was also very pleasant. Great experience!

Now let's rewind a little bit. A few months ago I came here with my boyfriend on a Friday night. The crowd was weird. It was the most unusual mix of people. Not saying it's a bad thing, but some of the characters were very... "Downtown," ...you know what I'm saying. Not too mention that the prices were a bit much for beer. I also remember ordering a cranberry vodka and it came in this small glass, probably only holding 1/4 of the liquid that was in my drink this weekend. It's very touch and go here so just be prepared.

The ambiance was somewhat kitschy, yet the gastronomical offerings were undeniably delectable, specifically the trio of carne-based tacos that I had the pleasure of sampling. However, I cannot say the same for the arroz con frijoles, which regrettably lacked a certain je ne sais quoi. Notwithstanding, I shall return, albeit with the hope of encountering more satisfactory side dishes.

"While this establishment offers a satisfactory breakfast experience, the prices charged are somewhat prohibitive. For a more cost-effective option, consider visiting Cora, where the value offered is superior. Alternatively, if your culinary preferences lean towards more gastronomic indulgences, Cafe Orange is worth considering, as its menu offerings are of a higher quality. However, if proximity is a factor and convenience is paramount, then this venue may still be a viable, albeit relatively pricey, option."

I opt to visit Outback due to the predictability of the culinary experience they offer, which is characterized by consistently palatable fare, a spotless ambiance, and passable, albeit unremarkable, customer service. This particular establishment fulfills all of the aforementioned criteria. Two individuals, including myself, partook in an evening repast at 5 pm, thereby avoiding the throngs that often congregate during peak dining hours.

"A perceptible enhancement has transpired since the era of Terrible Herbst, with a palpable improvement in the culinary offerings and a marginal acceleration in the pace of service. The $10 special deals continue to represent a reasonable value. My personal preference for the Cafe over the Buffet remains unwavering, despite the latter's previous complimentary status. Notwithstanding, a lingering issue persists, specifically, the tendency for elderly waitstaff to experience a gradual decline in their work ethic, resulting in sluggishness and the necessity to request items such as condiments or supplementary settings for additional patrons on multiple occasions."

There has been an improvement from when this was Terrible Herbst. The food is better and the service is slightly faster than before. The $10 specials are still a good value. I have always liked the Cafe over the Buffet even when the buffet was comped. The one remaining problem is that this is where old waitresses go to die. Slow and often need ing to ask two or three times for condiments or set ups for additional people.
Pretty standard theatre, never had a bad experience here, except sometimes it can be crowded, and of course its expensive. Except matinee = $5!
I just hate the lines at Walmart and it takes for ever to get in and out of this place. Need to open up more registers.
Do you work at Bally's?  Look at your physique...  This place is a nice place to relax and drinks are cheap.  It's just not that big of a pool.

"Diminuative Mexican eatery discovered serendipitously while seeking an alternative culinary establishment. Menu offerings are succinct, comprising merely ten options. Observed during my visitation, a solitary, hirsute gentleman, devoid of any discernible Mexican ancestry, attended to both the culinary preparations and customer service. Each table boasts its unique assortment of fiery condiments and diminutive vessels brimming with seasonings. My curiosity regarding this minuscule edifice is piqued, prompting further exploration. The interior design integrates elements of tiki huts, Mexican flags, Frida Kahlo's artwork, paper lanterns, miscellaneous cinematic posters, and laminated menus. Additionally, they provide a variety of traditional Mexican confectionaries and potables. Enchiladas smothered in mole sauce constituted my meal of choice, which, while not exemplifying proficiency in mole sauce preparation, proved satisfactory, albeit my limited exposure to this quintessential Mexican delicacy. The kitchen's diminutive size suggests that the majority of their offerings undergo reheating in a microwave oven, a practice that, while unremarkable, remains understandable given the constraints imposed by the compact cooking area. An endearing and memorable dining experience, which, owing to its novelty, warrants repetition."

Tiny Mexican hole in the wall I found while looking for a different restaurant. The menu is brief - ten items.  When I was there, it was one bearded not very Mexican guy taking the orders and making the food. Every table has its own selection of hot sauces and little pots of seasonings.  I'm incredibly curious about this little restaurant. The decor is a mix of tiki hut, Mexican flags, Frida Kahlo art, paper lanterns, random movie posters and laminated pictures from the menu. They also have a selection of Mexican candies and beverages.

I had the enchiladas with mole sauce and they were good - I'm no mole expert but in my limited experience I felt that the sauce was a good example of Mole.  The kitchen is very tiny and I'm thinking that most everything they serve is reheated in a microwave but I also realize that this is probably the case in many situations where the kitchen is not visible.  

All in all a neat little experience and I would go again.

"Two days and two excursions to the rotisserie stick of culinary euphoria. 

I must admit that I had already placed an order for the dolmas when I sat down to peruse the critiques, and regrettably, Valerie's assessment of them is not drastically different from reality. Dolmas bear a resemblance to pakora, which are commonly offered within Indian eateries, in that they are ubiquitous yet unpredictable in their quality. The ones I received appeared appetizing, but aside from a faint citrus aroma, extracting a distinct flavor from them proved challenging. I was left with five and a half out of eight. Now, I am becoming increasingly anxious about what will follow. However, I was relieved to discover that my concerns were unwarranted.

The gyro salad was generously portioned, fresh, and featured an abundance of succulent meat. The pita bread was satisfactory, and the accompanying dipping sauces met my expectations. My partner opted for the Gyro Pita Basket, and I must say, it was also quite satisfying. The fries served alongside it were decent, further contributing to its appeal. Based on the strength of the entrees alone, I would unquestionably return, and if it weren't for the underwhelming experience with the dolmas, my rating would have been a perfect four."

"Having observed an extensive array of performances, it is evident that this particular production fell short of expectations. Numerous errors in coordination among the cast members detracted significantly from the overall enjoyment, further exacerbated by the discourteous behavior of certain staff members. Prior to the commencement of the show, one performer announced that flash photography was prohibited; however, following this declaration, audience members opted to disable their camera flashes, only to be confronted by a rude elderly woman who not only admonished them for taking photographs but also attempted to physically confiscate their cameras, citing a blanket ban on photography during the performance. It would be advisable for the show's organizers to provide clearer instructions regarding photography restrictions to avoid such unpleasant encounters. Moreover, the quality of the show itself was subpar, rendering it a less-than-desirable experience for viewers. In conclusion, while the performance may have had some redeeming aspects, the prevalence of mistakes and poor staff conduct made it an underwhelming experience, thereby warranting a below-average rating."

Watched a lot of shows, this one was well below average. Lot of mistakes in the co-ordination among performers spoiled all the fun, add to it the rude staff. One of the performer announced at the beginning of the show that flash photography is not allowed, after which people turned off the flash to take snaps, only to find a rude old lady coming up and almost getting physical with them and snatching their cameras- saying photography is not allowed at all. They need to be specific in giving the instruction. No one wants to take a snap of their mediocre show if they are not allowed to, but for God's sake save them the humiliation by telling them. Gamble and lose your money than to watch this show!! \nOverall Average Performance, Poor staff, overrated

I normally love the ambience of this place and the beautiful layout of the bar.  Food is OK, but the fried bologna sandwich is excellent.  Didn't give it 5 stars because I went in there last Saturday over Memorial Day weekend, sat at the bar, and ordered a glass of white wine to go with my lunch.  The bar didn't have ANY white wine - no chardonnay, no sauvignon blanc, no pinot grigio - nothing.  What kind of bar doesn't have white wine on a holiday weekend?  They need to do some inventory control.  No wonder the place was deserted.

The establishment in question is a run-of-the-mill sports bar, albeit with a few distinguishing features that set it apart from others of its ilk. One such attribute is the expansive outdoor seating area situated on the Scottsdale greenbelt, which affords patrons an opportunity to indulge in the fresh air and scenic surroundings while enjoying their libations and fare. Another notable aspect of this venue is the menu, which boasts an array of sandwiches that have been thoughtfully paired with salad versions, effectively rendering the bread redundant and replaced by a bed of crisp lettuce. Furthermore, the eatery offers an assortment of enticing specials and promotions, including a special birthday deal that adds an extra layer of festivity to the dining experience. Spread across multiple sections and replete with televisions scattered throughout, the interior space is both capacious and well-appointed, providing ample room for patrons to revel in their favorite sporting events or simply unwind with friends and family.

"Culinary excellence prevails, yet a slight shortcoming in hospitality is discernible. Peruse the introductory offerings, specifically the dumplings, which unquestionably constitute a gastronomic apogee. Additionally, the mixed drinks, particularly the margaritas, possess an elevated potency, thus, it is advisable to exercise caution, lest one succumb to an agreeable intoxication."
The place is over rated, the pabellon is not that great. The rice is dry and the prices are too much for the food I get. I was expecting more... Meh!
Pretty good look at the heavy # of people walking around the Casino. staff were nice. Not the cheapest spots for drinks though

"Satisfactory, albeit not optimal, yet appreciably distant from mediocrity. Have not experienced dissatisfaction thus far and frequent this establishment on a weekly basis. The Thai basil and steak salad are particularly noteworthy."
Pretty good, not the best but very far from bad. Haven't been disappointed yet and we eat here about once a week. The Thai basil is really good as well as the steak salad.

"A conventional dining establishment with a familiar ambiance, devoid of any extraordinary features. The refurbishment from its predecessor within the Tropicana resort primarily involves superficial alterations, yet still manages to create a welcoming atmosphere that dispels the need for post-dining cleansing rituals. The interior design exudes a tranquil coastal charm, incorporating calming hues and elements reminiscent of a seaside setting. Patrons can relish the picturesque views of the Tropicana pool's cascading water feature from select vantage points, while having the option between indoor and alfresco seating areas. The hospitality of the staff is warm and inviting, complemented by the scrumptious fare and generous portion sizes, all of which justify the slightly elevated prices compared to its antecedent eatery."

This particular Dillard's location can be described as merely satisfactory, as my experiences within its confines have been inconsistent and varied. During my previous visits, I have procured several dresses and blouses, yet the service provided by the sales associates in the women's dress department has been either excessively intrusive or utterly absent, failing to strike a balance between the two extremes. In contrast, my encounters with the accessories department personnel have been relatively more pleasant, as they appear genuinely interested in understanding customers' needs and providing appropriate assistance. However, a recent episode involving a return of an item in pristine condition with accompanying tags attached, albeit slightly beyond the return policy time frame, resulted in the store manager offering me a store credit, which I appreciated, considering my awareness of the return policy limitations. In summary, this store can be characterized as average, and while I intend to revisit it due to its diverse selection of dresses and tops, I remain hopeful for a truly exceptional customer service experience, which I believe should be a standard aspect of any shopping excursion.

This Dillard's location is just okay. I have purchased a few dresses and tops from this location over the last couple of months and every time I have been in my experience has only been so so. The sales associates in the women's dress department can be either too pushy or completely non existent but not a good balance of one or the other. I have had a little bit of a better experience in the accessories department and the associates in that department seem to be more interested in what you are looking for and how to help rather than just making a sale. I also had an issue recently with needing to return an item that was in perfect condition with tags attached but it had been just a few days over the return policy limit. The manager was able to give me a store credit which I appreciated because I knew I was over the limit of the return policy. Overall this store is just okay. I will be back because I like their selection of dresses and tops but I am still waiting for that wow customer service experience that I think you should get no matter where you are shopping.

I think Champions is the only real bar in Gilbert. It's worth a trip for the clientele along - moslyt the Bud Light vs Coors Light crowd. Lots of pool tables plus 6 or so dart boards. This isn't an upscale establishment ... but is a great place to go for a few cheap drinks in a friendly atmosphere.

"The culinary offerings at this establishment were merely adequate, but the service we received from the peculiar pair of waitresses was truly bizarre and off-putting. Their unconventional demeanor and eccentric behavior made for an unsettling dining experience that precludes us from ever returning to this location again."

The culinary experience was thoroughly enjoyable, however, the quality of service was subpar and left much to be desired. Despite my decision to take a seat at the bar, the portly bartender remained oblivious to our presence, necessitating my departure to an adjacent sports bar to procure a beverage prior to his belated acknowledgment of our arrival. It was approximately 6:30 p.m. on a Saturday evening.

As a fervent Milwaukeean residing at the Wynn, I felt compelled to partake in the culinary offerings of the in-house Bartolotta's restaurant, despite my ignorance of their origins as a Milwaukee export. However, my gastronomical journey was somewhat curtailed due to my personal aversion to seafood (which is flown in fresh from the Mediterranean daily), which I deemed excessively extravagant, albeit comprehensible given the arid climate's dearth of aquatic delicacies. Thus, I opted for a select few pasta dishes and a portion of pancetta. While the pancetta proved to be somewhat chewy and fatty, I anticipated such characteristics; nevertheless, it could have been more refined. In contrast, the sheep's milk ravioli delighted my taste buds, although the spaghetti accompanied by ragu could have been more flavorful. Ultimately, my satisfaction with Bartolotta's was limited, primarily due to the premium pricing; nevertheless, I acknowledge that dining alfresco might have enhanced my overall experience. In my modest opinion, the Wynn would greatly benefit from incorporating Bartolotta's Lake Park Bistro, a Milwaukee staple, into its establishment.

As a die-hard Milwaukeean staying at the Wynn, I had to try out the in house Bartolotta's restaurant, considering I didn't know they were a Milwaukee export.

I did not get the full experience at this place mainly because I am not someone that eats seafood (it is flown in fresh from the Mediterranean everyday).  I think that is a little ridiculous, but considering there are no fish in the desert, I don't blame them.

So, this relegated me to a few pasta dishes and some pancetta.  The pancetta was tough and fatty, but I expected that.  Could have been better though.  The sheep's milk ravioli was delicious, but the spaghetti with ragu could have been better.

Overall, not that impressed for the price,but I didn't eat outside.  That could have made the experience cooler.  The should take Bartolotta's Lake Park Bistro in Milwaukee and stick it in the Wynn, in my humble opinion.

"During the early stages of my nuptial excursion in September, I opted to visit Edinburgh, which served as the idyllic backdrop for my honeymoon. Upon arriving in this picturesque city, my spouse and I were determined to initiate our exploratory endeavors with a copious breakfast, thereby ensuring that we possessed the requisite vigor to indulge in prolonged sightseeing activities throughout the day. In light of this, we meandered towards the Grassmarket from our hotel situated on Prince's Street, surveying our surroundings and selecting Cafe Jacques as our dining establishment of choice, primarily due to the fact that it was teeming with patrons, which we deemed a positive omen. Upon entering the minuscule eatery, we managed to secure a seat, following a somewhat arduous process of squeezing ourselves into the limited space available. I opted for a customary English breakfast, while my spouse preferred an American-style breakfast. Unfortunately, my attempt to rapidly consume my initial cup of coffee resulted in an unpleasant burning sensation in my mouth, which persisted for at least two subsequent days. Notwithstanding this minor mishap, our server accommodated my husband's peculiar request for two towering glasses of milk, leading us to ponder whether this was a peculiarly American custom. Based on my assessment, Cafe Jacques garnered three stars, denoting its satisfactory quality and facilitating our initiation into the captivating city of Edinburgh."

I visted Edinburgh on my honeymoon in September. Our first full day of exploring must start with a bountiful breakfast so we had energy to explore all day. We strolled down to the Grassmarket from our hotel on Prince's St. Looking up and down, we chose Cafe Jacques because it had the most customers dining. A good indicator is how busy the place is, right?

We squeezed in, and I DO mean squeezed because it's tiny, and found a seat. I had a traditional English breakfast and my hubbie the American. The coffee was SO HOT and I made the mistake of trying to gulp my first taste as I tried to caffeinate my jetlagged self. My mouth was scorched for the next two days at least. Although we received a weird look, the waiter brought my husband two tall glasses of milk on request. Is that an American thing to drink milk with breakfast?

As my three stars indicate, this place was A-OK and got us going on our first full day in Edinburgh.

This is one of my favorite breakfast places, solely because of the AMAZING corned beef hash.  I had to give them just 3 stars, however, because I had HORRIBLE service during my last visit!  I had arrived for a late breakfast at around 2:15pm.  I noticed walking in that the neon Open sign was on, so I walked in.  My boyfriend told me after we had entered that the sign on the door said they were only open until 2.  I asked a server if they were still open and told her that I had just noticed the sign, and the server, Cindy, said she asked the kitchen and her boss and they could accommodate us.  We realized that we had arrived late and were ready to leave, but Cindy assured us it was ok. Cindy was extremely sweet during our whole meal, but what made our visit horribly uncomfortable was another server named Carol, who very loudly and openly bitched about our being seated after 2!!  I couldn't believe it.  Carol was rude and unprofessional and made us feel unwelcome.  The food was amazing and Cindy was great, but Carol's attitude ruined it.   Lady, your boss approved it, so shut up and be happy you have the business!  If it's such a big deal, take initiative to turn off that neon sign at 2pm-- I noticed it was still on when we left at 3.

Yesterday, I had an imperative to convene with a patron hailing from the northern region of the valley, and coincidentally, I had several other clients to visit in Deer Valley. Owing to the dearth of establishments in the vicinity that serve breakfast and are not part of a chain, I opted to dine at this particular eatery. Arriving at 8 a.m., I presumably avoided the majority of patrons who typically frequent the restaurant for breakfast or acquire sustenance for lunch. The proprietor of the establishment exhibited a somewhat abrasive demeanor, although I hastened to acclimate myself to his disposition in a relatively brief period. 

I placed an order for the Max burrito, which includes an assortment of ingredients such as egg, potato, cheese, and a choice between bacon, sausage, or ham, all for the sum of $4.29. The culinary creation was quite flavorsome, albeit its dimensions were of a moderate magnitude. Considering the price per ounce, it becomes evident that the cost is approximately twice that of a comparable burrito offered by nearby Mexican fast-food restaurants. This discrepancy in pricing can be attributed, in part, to the prime location of the establishment in Deer Valley, as well as the associated employee expenses. 

During my visit, a steady influx of patrons entered the premises, although the atmosphere remained unpretentious and unhurried. However, it is worth noting that accessing the parking area can prove challenging due to the proximity of the Dunkin' Donuts located at the opposite end of the building, which tends to generate a considerable backup. Notwithstanding, I am inclined to revisit this establishment in the future, primarily due to its non-chain status, passable cuisine, and agreeable service.

"To provide clarity and resolve the prevailing confusion regarding the three China Stars within the city limits, I shall elucidate the distinctions between them. Through my daily commute, I have observed both China Stars situated on Murray Avenue (across the street from a Giant Eagle store, curiously positioned to intensify the enigma), and upon investigating their addresses, I have ascertained the following factsâ?

1. THIS CHINA STAR: 
-Location: 4219 Murray Avenue, Greenfield 
-Occupies the former site of Yen's Gourmet 
-Lacks any affiliation with the China Star in the North Hills 
-Offers standard American-Chinese cuisine 

2. THE OTHER CHINA STAR (<http://www.yelp.com/biz/china-star-pittsburgh-3>): 
-Address: 1900 Murray Avenue, Squirrel Hill 
-Former site of Pacific Ring 
-Associated with the China Star in the North Hills 
-Serves traditional Chinese fare 

Thus, there exists a definitive dichotomy between the two China Stars along Murray Avenue. Personally, I have solely patronized this particular China Star and cannot comment on its counterpart. 

When it comes to Chinese takeoutâspecifically, affordable, oily, fried âChineseâ?foodâChina Star excels. Although every Chinese takeout establishment with the ubiquitous red menu appears identical, I feel compelled to share my thoughts on one such eatery on Yelp. However, after sampling various Chinese options in Pittsburgh based on price and accessibility, I must confess that China Star ranks as my top choice. Their dishes simply taste superior."

I'm going to settle this once and for all, since everyone seems beyond confused about the three China Stars in town. I drive past both of the Murray Ave China Stars every day (both located across the street from a Giant Eagle, presumably just to puzzle us more) and based on the addresses have confirmed the following--

THIS CHINA STAR:
-4219 Murray Ave, in Greenfield
-At the old location of Yen's Gourmet
-No affiliation with the China Star in the North Hills
-Standard American-Chinese food

THE OTHER CHINA STAR (http://www.yelp.com/biz/china-star-pittsburgh-3):
-1900 Murray Ave, in Squirrel Hill
-At the old location of Pacific Ring
-Affiliated with the China Star in the North Hills
-Traditional Chinese food

So, there you have it. A guide to the China Stars of Murray Avenue. I, personally, have only ordered from this China Star and cannot comment on the other.

For Chinese takeout--and I mean cheap, greasy, fried "Chinese" food--China Star is awesome. I mean, yeah, every Chinese takeout place with the infamous red menu is pretty much the same, and I feel stupid even writing a review of one on Yelp. But I get a craving for General Tso's Chicken, Pork Lo Mein, Cold Sesame Noodles, and Fried Dumplings about once a month, and now having tried several of Pittsburgh's Chinese options based on price and convenience, I gotta say China Star is my number one choice. Everything just tastes GOOD. I totally can't justify giving a Chinese restaurant more than 3 stars, but next time you feel the need to pig out on greasy takeout food, I'd highly recommend China Star.

cooked food are ok. but the ingredients selection is not high quality. nice decor but services could be better. Got to try the fried bananas, which is the best thing I like in this japanese all u can eat restaurant!
Fish and chips typical irish fare, have some good bands that plays there as well great for happy hour and hang outs great staff as well. U2 tribute band Joshua tree usually plays out there.

This place is cool, but it pales in comparison to the Foundation Room, which sits at the top of the same hotel.  The music here was okay and the atmosphere here is kinda cool, but get yourself on the list for the Foundation Room to check out the cool club at Mandalay Bay.

I think that the Monte Carlo has seen better days. It was once pretty dang nice and one of the best placed to go on the Strip, but it is starting to show some wear and tear. There is a -5 Bar, but it isn't the better one. I can see that there is some renovation going on, so that might mean that the place is on the up-swing. It is right in the middle of the Strip which makes it prime for those that want to stay in a central location. However, I think that I would not likely get a room here and opt for one of the newer, shinier places.

"The ambiance of Beckett's Table is undeniably captivating, boasting an assortment of elements that contribute to its allure, such as the strategic arrangement of the restaurant's layout, the aesthetically pleasing water glasses and table settings, and an atmosphere that exudes warmth and hospitality. However, my culinary experience at this establishment did not quite live up to my expectations, despite my initial enthusiasm.  

While the bacon cheddar biscuits possessed a certain je ne sais quoi that made them enjoyable, the apple honey butter accompanying them was regrettably too firm and lacked the desired spreadability, thereby diminishing my overall satisfaction with the dish. Similarly, both the green chile pork stew and the osso buco failed to elicit any extraordinary praise from my palate, neither dish offering any remarkable features that might have elevated them above the realm of mediocrity.  

Nevertheless, one particular dish managed to surpass my expectations, namely the chocolate-dipped bacon s'mores. By venturing outside my comfort zone and opting for this unconventional dessert, I was pleasantly surprised by its delectable flavors, with the homemade peanut butter being a particularly delightful component that harmonized beautifully with the remaining elements of the dish, resulting in a truly satisfying culinary experience."

I really like the ambiance of Beckett's Table, from the way the restaurant is set up to their water glasses and table settings. I just didn't fall in love with their food. 

I liked the bacon cheddar buscuits, but would have liked them more if the apple honey butter wasn't so rock hard and was easily spreadable. I tried to the green chile pork stew and the osso buco and I definitely wasn't blown away by either of them. Neither dish had anything special to it, not to say they were bad, but didn't overly impress me. 

My favorite dish was probably the chocolate dipped bacon s'mores. I definitely went out on a limb ordering this, but I was pleasently surprised. The homemade peanut butter was excellent and all of the parts of this dessert complimented each other very well.

"Situated in close proximity to the Henderson Whole Foods, LYFE Kitchen enjoys an optimal location that makes it an establishment of considerable convenience for those seeking nourishment. Prior to embarking on our regular shopping excursion, we opted to partake of a culinary experience at this eatery, thus we ventured a short distance to savor their offerings. My order consisted of a vegan Thai curry bowl, accompanied by a hibiscus tea, while my companion chose a grass-fed burger, complemented by a cafe mocha. 
 
The beverages proved to be truly exceptional, as the hibiscus tea displayed an impressive degree of flavor and refreshment, and the cafe mocha was described as satisfying and invigorating. However, the primary courses gave rise to some misgivings, specifically regarding their modest proportions and questionable composition. Although my vegan Thai curry bowl possessed commendable taste, its spiciness surpassed my expectations, and it lacked a sufficient amount of wheat berries and tofu, instead featuring an abundance of secondary vegetables. The grass-fed burger of my companion was deemed satisfactory, with a subtle smoky flavor, yet it failed to satiate our hunger entirely, prompting us to crave additional sustenance. Furthermore, concerns regarding the organic nature of the tofu and grass-fed beef arose, leading me to ponder the rationale behind consuming non-organic ingredients at an establishment that purports to prioritize health-consciousness. 
 
Despite these reservations, we might revisit LYFE Kitchen to sample alternative menu selections, but we will be certain to arrive with lesser degrees of hunger."

"The culinary offerings were of exceptional quality, however, the hospitality experience was subpar. Specifically, the server was challenging to locate, and despite an absence of patrons, it required an extended period of time to procure a beverage, specifically, five minutes for a carbonated beverage and an equivalent duration for H2O."

"Although it bears some resemblance to the esteemed Samurai Sam's, this establishment falls short of its lofty standards.  The cost is fair and the serving size adequate, but the meat is regrettably lacking in substance.  The accompanying condiment, while not excessively saccharine as those found at comparable venues, fails to fully compensate for the deficiency in quality.  A minuscule receptacle of the sauce is provided should one desire additional quantities."

Good food, but a little expensive.  Their cable cars are delicious.  Food was good, but not great.  For breakfast, I'd recommend going to the buffet at the Bellagio instead - it was much cheaper, and the food was about as good.

I'll leave my review at 3 stars for now.  This was my first visit to a Panera Bread to get sandwiches for dinner.  We needed a break from getting subs at different places and I chose to try something new.  This location opened recently.  It makes where I live about halfway between to Panera's but I decided to try this one.

Service was great at the counter, but the wait seemed long for the take out until I realized they had a number of people eating in who had ordered just before I got there.  I brought the sandwiches home and they were very good.  My wife had their Cuban chicken panini and I had the signature Steak and white cheddar.  They were both very good.  My panini had a fair kick from the horseradish spread on the sandwich.  With the sandwiches, I opted for the small bag of chips for each of us.

The order was packaged really nice in two small cardboard boxes.  My only complaint with this is there's really no way to tell which sandwich is which unless you peel back some of the bread to reveal the contents.  Some places put a numbered sticker on their sandwiches to match the items on your receipt.  The boxes at Panera have a place you could write the name.  I sent a suggestion to HQ and the responded that they'd look into it.

I'll return and I think I'll eat in.  The dining room is very nice and there's outdoor seating for when it's cooler.

Unfortunately, our culinary exploits did not incorporate a sweet conclusion, as we opted for a midday repast instead, which, despite the lackluster performance of the potato pancakes, was thoroughly relished. In the event of a future visit, I shall endeavor to sample the pastry offerings or patronize the establishment at a later hour and occupy a seat at the bar.

"The array of tequilas available for consumption has undergone a marked diminution in recent times, and perusing the menu can be a frustrating experience due to its lack of accuracy, with apologies being offered to patrons for the unavailability of certain brands (a scenario that is not uncommon, unfortunately). Furthermore, the culinary offerings are merely adequate, and the level of service provided by the staff is less than optimal, even when the establishment is not bustling with customers."

Tequila selection isn't what it used to be, and the menu has a lot of inaccuracies (sorry sir, we don't have that tequila anymore either).  Food was alright but service was a chore, and it wasn't very busy either.

"I had the misfortune of lodging at this establishment for a solitary night this week, and my experience was marred by a plethora of issues. The furniture, including the sofa, was covered in a thick layer of dust, giving the impression that it had not been cleaned in some time. The coffee maker and hair dryer were both grimy and unhygienic, and I could continue enumerating the deficiencies in the room's maintenance. Furthermore, I was unable to procure an itemized room service receipt or even a receipt for my stay via email, which led me to question the hotel's preparedness for guests. While the location may be convenient for some, I would strongly advise against selecting this hotel for accommodations. Instead, I would recommend the HGV on the strip, which boasts exceptional upkeep and customer service."

Rehab burger is your total local dive bar but has a cool vibe to it as well. They offer great drink specials, and have a great burger menu. I had there Hangover burger with the sweet potato tots and to me it was pretty mediocre plus I ordered my burger medium rare and received a well done burger so of course I am sure that had something to do with the taste. Would I go back and give em another shot? Probably not considering there are alot more great burger joints in Scottsdale.

While my desire for Art Your Way (AYW) to be more economical in pricing persists, it remains an enjoyable venue for children to explore their artistic inclinations. The staff, with a few exceptions, has demonstrated a propensity towards cordiality and helpfulness. However, there have been isolated incidents where younger female employees appeared to prioritize interpersonal interactions amongst themselves over attending to customers, although this does not seem to be standard practice. Notably, the efficiency of their turnaround time is commendable, typically requiring only a few days for completion, much to the satisfaction of clients.

While I wish AYW was a little cheaper, they are a fun place for the kiddos to express their creativity.  

The staff is, for the most part, friendly and helpful.  A few times, the younger female staff have been more preoccupied with chatting among themselves, but that doesn't appear to be the norm. 

Turn around time on the pieces is quick, just a few days, which is nice.

I love the food, location is great, love the rootop patio...no problems there\n\nBUT...the drink prices are FRIGGIN OUTRAGEOUS, as has been mentioned in other reviews. To get drink prices this high you either have to be drinkin' in a strip bar  or one of the ultra chi-chi bars uptown like Blue.....at least $2 higher on beer and $3-4 higher on drinks than ANY OTHER P-Wood bar. As I've worked in bars before I understand how drinks are priced and these prices are NOT gonna be popular around here. Everyone that I've heard talk about it has the same thing to say: \"great food, great location, plan on drinking tea or soda when you go unless you want to go broke..\"...C'Mon guys, you don't have to recoup your investment the 1st month by gouging folks on drinks; price them reasonably and you'll be around for a long time to make money...

"A thoroughly unremarkable, pedestrian establishment specializing in the culinary delights of fried dough, this donut shop boasts an impressive array of delectable treats that are sure to satiate even the most discerning palate. Maintaining a fastidious level of cleanliness, this eatery is open for business around the clock, conveniently situated alongside a Subway restaurant. The donuts themselves are freshly prepared, ensuring an optimal taste experience for patrons. Of particular note is the devil's food cake, whose moist texture and rich, chocolate flavor make it a standout item on the menu. Additionally, the glazed donuts are endowed with a pleasing sweetness that complements their subtle crunch. While it is true that some may prefer the offerings of Winchell's over those of Dunkin' Donuts or Krispy Kreme, it is important to recognize that such preferences are inherently subjective and often vary from person to person. In conclusion, this humble abode of gastronomic delight warrants a respectable grade of C, with its selection of edibles being suitably diverse and satisfying."

Just an average run-of-the-mill commercial donut shop. Very clean. Open 24hrs & housed together with a Subway.  Donuts were fresh. The devils food cake was moist & chocolaty and the glazed had good flavor. I think Winchells is a lot better then Dunkin Donuts or them nasty sugar holes from Krappy Kremes. Overall grade C. Selection was decent.

We proceeded towards City Center with the intention of partaking in a late evening repast prior to venturing out to the nocturnal entertainment venues, and our culinary destination of choice was Julian Serrano, primarily due to the fact that they offered vegetarian options on their menu, which catered to my dietary preferences.  I must confess that our experience at Julian Serrano was somewhat underwhelming, as we encountered certain inconsistencies in the quality of the cuisine.  Our order consisted of the mushroom soup, Tortilla Espanola, Shrimp Ceviche, chicken skewers, eggplant/peppers, and a mixed Paella featuring lobster, chorizo, and chicken.  While the paella demonstrated some promise, it failed to surpass my expectations, given its price point of $40; in fact, I have had the pleasure of indulging in superior paella dishes at a fraction of the cost.  The remaining items we sampled were merely average, and did not particularly impress.  Despite this, the ambiance and service at Julian Serrano were commendable, and their extensive menu and wine list seemed impressive, yet ultimately, the culinary offerings did not live up to my expectations.  In conclusion, unless circumstances arise whereby someone else is footing the bill, I would not consider returning to Julian Serrano in the near future.

"Celebrated my natal anniversary at this culinary establishment in the company of colleagues and found the ambiance to be quite pleasing, thus prompting a return visit during the restaurant's 'happy hour' period, whereupon I experienced an enjoyable social interaction with acquaintances.  

While the prices may be considered somewhat elevated, the attentive and courteous demeanor of our server, a young woman adorned with a robot-themed tattoo, greatly enhanced our dining experience. 

Personally, I found the mixed drinks to be superior in quality compared to the food offerings, specifically the POLYNESIAN CHICKEN SANDWICH accompanied by SWEET POTATOE FRIES, which proved to be a satisfying culinary choice.  

The assortment of beverages available was quite impressive, and I would recommend attempting the Scorpion bowl, ideally in the presence of multiple companions."

We partake in culinary indulgences at this establishment on an intermittent basis, and our experiences have been reliably average, oscillating between underwhelming and unremarkable. The fare provided by this restaurant can be likened to that of Arby's, rather than Subway, due to the unimaginative selection of ingredients. Furthermore, it fails to offer a commendable value proposition, as the prices charged are only nominally lower than those of authentic sushi establishments. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the convenience and efficiency of the service, coupled with the peculiarly satisfying nature of the food, render it a viable option for those seeking a hasty and unpretentious dining experience.

We eat here occasionally and the experience is consistent and mediocre. More Arby's than Subway, because the ingredients are uninspiring. Nor is it a great value in that it is only slightly less expensive than real sushi. All that said, it is convenient fast and strangely satisfying

"Although the culinary offerings at this establishment may not conform to the conventional definition of gourmet, the quality of the fare provided can be considered satisfactory, particularly when evaluated within the context of the genre of dining experiences to which it belongs. It is advisable to adopt a realistic perspective when assessing the merits of the edibles served, as doing so will enable one to derive enjoyment from the meal. My personal recommendation would be the Spanish omelet, which boasts an impressive flavor profile. However, it is worth noting that the pace of service may be somewhat leisurely, so patrons are advised to cultivate patience."

It pains me to write an update for this place because I really had exceptional experiences before my last two appointments. It may be because my appointments were scheduled at 5:30 (prime time for working folk who go after work). I had at least a 30-45 minute wait both times and that was just in the waiting room. When I got to an exam room, had to wait another 15-20 minutes to be seen. 

I still love Dr. Langford because she apologized profusely for the wait. I understand 5:30 is a prime time but they could avoid the wait by not overbooking. I still got the same warm, undivided attention from the doctor so the wait didn't bother me so much after that.

Also I called twice prior to an appointment and spoke to someone who I found to be quite rude. She said she would check on something for me and call me back. I didn't get a call back so when I called again, she said she already told me the answer (when she clearly told me she'd double check with the doctor). I don't appreciate people who are rude  to loyal patients.

Even though I had a bad experience, there are other staff members who are kind and are good at their job. I am still happy with most of the staff and with my doctor. I just can't give them 5 stars anymore. 3.5 stars.

"As a neophyte, I indulged in my first meal of the day at this establishment, which offered an alimentary experience that was somewhat expensive but nonetheless delectable and served in an ambiance that was singularly captivating. Being present prior to the commencement of the midday repast, the venue was remarkably tranquil, with nary a soul in sight. However, my encounter was slightly marred by the youthful mechanical attendants, whose lack of warmth and courtesy, manifested in their failure to proffer a simple greeting or smile, detracted from the overall quality of my visit, thereby rendering it less exceptional than it could have been."

"While the culinary offerings were satisfactory, the ambiance was somewhat marred by an abundance of particulate matter scattered throughout the eatery, particularly on my designated seating area. I was taken aback by the sheer quantity of dirt and debris that seemed to have escaped notice. Compelled to express my concerns, I penned a brief missive. The attentive server, having espied both the grime and my scribbling, responded with a mirthful chuckle, acknowledging the issue with a nonchalance that bordered on incredulity."

"The culinary offerings presented at this establishment deviate considerably from the conventional Charlotte menu, boasting an array of deep-fried delights that, while undoubtedly flavorsome, fail to possess the fiery or piquant qualities one might anticipate. Despite these departures from the norm, the venue maintains a relaxed ambiance, rendering it an appropriate setting for a casual luncheon excursion and ensuring that return visits are indeed plausible."

Came here 15 minutes before closing and only had to wait 10 minutes for the chicken to cook.  This place is really small.  The pictures don't lie.  

The chicken was pretty good although it's probably only good when its served hot and fresh.  It is a little on the salty side as some reviews have pointed out.  I enjoyed the hot sauce alot.  

The lady there was really nice and gave us a free 2 liter of soda and 4 extra pieces of chicken bc they were cleaning up and we weren't able to sit at the counter.  

They didnt have any of their red velvet pancakes which seems common among these reviews but no worries as I have a 2nd groupon to redeem.

Funny thing I read about Flavor Flav's failed restaurant in Clinton, Iowa just a year ago.  Hopefully this location will fare better over time.   This place is decent - take away Flavor Flav and I'm not sure if this place would have much success. 2 stars + 1 star b/c it's Flavor Flav

"Russ recommended dining at My Florist during the daytime, given our proximity to the establishment, but I countered by expressing my preference for indulging in a meal at a quaint eatery situated directly across the street from My Florist, which I had been eager to experience for some time; thus, we opted to patronize the latter venue instead. Although the culinary offerings at this particular restaurant may not have been particularly remarkable, the ambiance and overall aesthetic appeal of the setting did manage to leave a favorable impression upon me. Specifically, I ordered the chicken feta pita, which, while palatable, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that would have elevated it to a truly memorable dining experience. Nonetheless, I must commend the proprietors of this establishment for their apparent attention to detail in terms of marketing and interior design, which, in my opinion, merits recognition and appreciation."

"A mid-morning repast on a drizzly Sunday, within the confines of an establishment boasting an aesthetically pleasing interior, was accompanied by an impressive level of customer service. However, the coffee, while visually appealing, failed to elicit even a modicum of enthusiasm. Perplexingly, the culinary offerings, despite their visual appeal and evident attention to preparation, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi; a seeming paradox, given the palpable care taken in their creation. A cursory examination of the menu revealed an array of options, each ostensibly crafted with an emphasis on quality ingredients and skillful technique. Regrettably, such promise remained unfulfilled, as the flavors proved uninspired and lackluster. Upon mentioning this discrepancy to our server, she graciously offered to compensate for the deficiency by waiving the cost of our beverages. Despite this gesture, my buckwheat crepe, cooked to perfection, unfortunately suffered from an unfortunate dearth of warmth in its core (a circumstance which led me to speculate that the ham had not been adequately warmed prior to being incorporated into the dish). This resulted in my only consuming a portion of the breakfast, as ennui set in around the one-third mark. Notwithstanding this underwhelming experience, I might still consider returning, motivated by the hope that alternative dishes will exhibit a more satisfactory equilibrium of flavors."

"Pink's Hot Dogs, I am utterly perplexed as to how you successfully enticed me into consuming your culinary offerings, yet somehow you managed to do so. A coterie of individuals, including myself, opted to partake in a gastronomical excursion to your esteemed establishment, primarily due to the widespread acclaim and praise that it has received from various patrons. My adventurous palate led me to order the Chili Cheese hot dog burrito, which consisted of two frankfurters enveloped in a tortilla along with chili and cheese. Although it provided a fleeting sense of satisfaction during a night of indulgence, I must admit that it had a rather deleterious impact on my digestive system. Perhaps, if I were to patronize your restaurant again in the future, I would be wise to opt for a more rudimentary hot dog, thus avoiding any potential gastrointestinal repercussions."

Pink's, I don't know how you seduced me, but you did. \n\nA small group of us stopped here because we were hungry and have heard people rave about this place. I was feeling brave and got the Chili Cheese hot dog burrito with two dogs, chili and cheese wrapped in a tortilla. It did the trick for a drunken evening, but man talk about super upset stomach! Maybe if I ever ate there again I should just try the basic hot dog.

"One of my preferred destinations due to its proximity to my place of employment, situated directly across from the building, thereby rendering it easily accessible via foot. The parking facilities are quite satisfactory, and even more so for myself, as I am able to traverse the short distance by walking. The prices of consumables are rather reasonable, with a hot dog or soda available for $4, and a combination package consisting of a hot dog, beverage, and popcorn offered at the affordable cost of $11. The vantage points afforded by the seating arrangement are quite acceptable, and provide ample opportunity for enthusiasts to pursue autographs from players. However, it is regrettable that the outfield grass is absent, a feature that has been lamented by another commentator. Additionally, the sensation experienced within one's gluteal region subsequent to occupying the metal bleacher-style seats positioned along the left field line for an extended period of time is less than desirable, although at a cost of $7, coupled with the advantageous parking, favorable location, and economical concessions, I find myself quite content."

One of my favorite locations because it is conveniently located across from my work building. The parking is good - even better for me since I can walk. The concessions are cheap - $4 for a hot dog or soda. A combo pack of a hot dog, drink and popcorn for $11. The views are good and provides good access to players if you want to try for an autograph. As another reviewer pointed out, there is no outfield grass, which is a disappointment. Another thing that is down is the feeling in your ass after sitting on the metal bleacher style seats down the left field line  - but for $7, good parking, nice location and cheap concessions, I am a fan.

I Was there from Thursday to Sunday. I cannot complain about the price - since the room was ordered from an agency outside of the country - and it was half price of what I found online. (Vegas.com, Expedia, hotels.com). 
The location of the hotel - 5 stars - right In the best part of the strip
Casino - 5 stars. Professional dealers and plenty of games. 
Food - 2 stars. No Starbucks in The hotel. 
No 24/7 restaurant. You have to walk all the way to Bally's to grab a slice of pizza or subway at 3 am when you really need it . . 
The room - 2.5 stars  - the bed - horrible. Springy and cheap. Felt really bad ony back. 
(I am 31 years old , not 75 - and still it was bad) 
For some reason they decided to locate the tv away from the bed - so it's not convenient to watch from the bed. The room was clean and felt expensive. But I wouldn't expect anything else from a hotel that is on the strip. 
Average - 3 stars. I would come back again because its a good value fort vacation. 
I must also state that I have been in Vegas many times and for someone who is there for the 1st time - the hotel would probably be amazing. ;-)

I don't have a complaint about the food.  I have a complaint about the location and the decor.  We had the lobster for two.  A much better deal than buying everything separate off of the menu.  For two, it cost about $150.  The food was tasty and the Chardonay was great!  The restaurant is not fancy and it is in a part of Caesars that looks like a mall.  The restaruant looks like a store front at a cheasy mall.  Very disappointing.  For the price, I would go to a fancier restaurant.  I was dressed up for a night on the town and was out of place at this bib-wearing cartoon pictures pasted on the wall restaurant.  The only thing missing were the peanut shells on the floor.  Too high priced for such a casual place in an ugly area.

Recommend for DATE NIGHT or group experience

So I am a hiking, white water rafting, run on a regular type of woman.
I am all about active activities, yet my experience at Victory Lanes was really disappointing. Riding in circles at high speeds and cramped in a kart aren't my idea of a good time. It just did not wow me, but I will give it another try if I had a group of friends.

Location: Easy to spot from highway, but use GPS or you will get lost 
Price: we bought a members pass
Staff: Able to answer questions; prepare to sign your life away
Children can act as spectators, but I wouldnt encourage driving
Bathrooms would get a 2/5 not big enough for dressing room.
Suites are cool and help with excitement, the look awesome in pictures.

Food is ok...drinks or ok...beer is beer but I love pubs so if I'm at mandalay Bay I stop for a pint no matter what!!!!  My ex says it's the best shepherds pie he's had in this whole entire life so maybe try that!

"My affection for the culinary offerings at Paradise Bakery remains steadfast, despite the inconsistent quality exhibited by this particular establishment. Previously, I had endeavored to place orders for pickup, only to be met with a litany of errors, including omissions from my meal and instances where the order was not even prepared upon my arrival. Furthermore, recent efforts to expand their business hours have been met with limited success, as key items are frequently depleted in the latter portion of the day. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the quality of the food, when properly prepared, is undeniably exceptional. However, the persistent inconsistencies in both the preparation and availability of menu items serve as a significant source of frustration, particularly given the premium pricing associated with dining at Paradise."

"My acquaintance and I are embarking on an expedition to discover the most delectable steak in the Valley, hence every time we gather for dinner, we opt to sample a distinct steak restaurant. Our excursion to Fleming's fell short of my expectations. 

I had been apprised of Fleming's exceptional happy hour offerings, which indeed presented numerous remarkable options. I shall return for that purpose. The service was adequate; we were seated at the bar. Furthermore, they boasted an impressive wine list with reasonable price points.
