Nonetheless, with regard to the steak: mine was cooked beyond my requested doneness (medium) and lacked sufficient trimming (I chose a filet). The sides were forgettable."

"An excellent venue for a rapid and affordable culinary experience. For neophytes to Filipino gastronomy, an auspicious initiation would be via the grilled delights and pancit. For those who crave more exotic flavors, the dinuguan (a savory concoction containing animal blood) or balut (a fertilized avian ovum), when accessible, are worthy alternatives. Although my maternal figure prepares superior renditions of these dishes, this establishment offers a satisfactory compromise between cost and expediency. However, I opt for take-out due to the occasional broadcasting of melodramatic and dismal Filipino soap operas on their televisual devices, which can create an unpalatable ambiance."

Great place for a quick cheap meal. If your new to Filipino food, I would start off with the barbecue and pancit. If you're feeling more adventurous, try the dinuguan (blood stew) or balut (fertilized duck egg), if available. My mom still makes better dinuguan and pancit but this place is pretty good for price and convenience. I prefer to get take-out because sometimes they play terrible and depressing Filipino dramas on their TVs. The constant crying in the background is not appetizing.

Ok, I am not going to talk about the service too much because I think It's a cultural issue. their wait service is NOT friendly at all. The waitress and waiter do not know how to smile.

However, I have to say that the service never detracts us from going there. The reason is the food is so good. If you are there during there lunch special, try the shredded pork pan fried noodles order it "Hong Kong Style"

Our second favorite dish is the salt and pepper shrimps with the head on. Some people find eating the head weird, but it is so rich.

The third dish to try is the salt fish and chicken fried rice. Salty but really good. I know this is not the typical "American ordering Chinese food" (i.e. General Cho's Chicken and Shrimp fried rice) type of order but trust me These are the best things on the menu.

"The quality of service at this establishment fluctuates depending on the time of day, with peak efficiency observable during non-peak hours.  A peculiar phenomenon we observed was the staff's propensity to inquire about our need for a beverage to alleviate the symptoms of a hangover, which we found amusing.  In light of this, and considering my penchant for sampling chicken fried steak whenever possible, I opted to order the Chicken Fried Steak for breakfast on both Saturday and Sunday.  My culinary experience was satisfactory, as the dish possessed an appropriate batter-to-meat ratio.  However, I must express my disappointment with the coffee shake, as its flavor profile did not resemble coffee and failed to meet my expectations, which have been set by the superior offerings of Jack in the Box.  Notwithstanding, I would still frequent this restaurant when staying at the Hard Rock, as it presents a viable alternative to the Pink Taco, which, while decent, does not compare to the gastronomic experience provided by this establishment."

"The subpar automobile cleaning establishment situated on Bell road does not instill confidence, as evidenced by the two instances whereupon I entrusted my conveyance for a cleansing process only to discover upon retrieval that the ignition key had been inadvertently left within the vehicle, thereby heightening concerns regarding potential grand theft auto. Moreover, the quality of customer service encountered has been merely adequate, with the early bird special being unavailable to those who settle their accounts subsequent to 9 am, as I discovered through personal experience by presenting my vehicle at 7 am, departing for employment, and returning at midday to effect payment, only to be informed that the lack of a time-stamped paper trail precluded me from receiving the discounted rate."

"My ardent desire is to wholeheartedly embrace the Daily Dose as my preferred venue for leisurely weekend repasts, owing to its ideal location that renders it a convenient and accessible destination for me. However, despite my persistent efforts to familiarize myself with the extensive and diverse menu offerings, I find myself incapable of fully committing to any particular dish, settling instead for unremarkable options such as omelets or French toast. Notwithstanding, I shall persist in my pursuit of a culinary experience that resonates with my discerning tastes, though my optimism wanes with each successive visit."

I want so much to love the Daily Dose.  It is in the perfect location for me to make it my go-to spot for weekend brunches.  But I just can't get 100% behind it.  Every time I'm there, I search the extensive menu over and over again for something that jumps out at me.  But every time, I find myself at a loss and just ordering an omelette or french toast or something equally banal.  I'll keep searching, but with every trip my hope dwindles.
Been here a few times. Drinks are not really good. Service is great.\n\nTried a few of the cocktails, they tasted good, but were lacking in EtOh. Had to get a few extra to get the job done.

It has a Vue Cinema, the entrance to Britannia, Starbucks, Bear Company, M&S Food-Court, H&M, Superdry, Fat Face, HMV, Boots, FCUK, Baxter, GAP,  Debenhams and a beautiful laid out Food Court - with Zizzi, Burger Company etc.. 

I do like the food-court,  with its view over Fife and new developments of Newhaven. (I compare those views with Blade Runner scenes..) 

Not my favourite shopping centre - as it is more like an main street shopping missing the charity shops (apart from the Superdry Store) 
I go shopping here when I have a few hours to spare on a Sunday. 

It is clean building in and out and has got a straightforward layout  rectangular and 3 stories high. 

There is a car park and a bus terminus for Lothian buses 22, 35, 34, 36, 11
Also the tourist buses stop here. 

There are (still) plans to extend the (in)famous tram line to here but those are currently shelved

One of the smallest airport in the U.S.  Flew here for a short layover to Greenville (GSP).  Can't really stand small airport since all the planes are so small and me being 6'4\" is very difficult to sit comfortably in my seat.  Next time I'll fly into big airports.

Last night, we endeavored to partake in the culinary offerings of this establishment, and our experience was somewhat dichotomous. The ambiance was quite vibrant, with a considerable number of patrons present at 9:30 pm on a Tuesday. The interior design was tasteful and effectively utilized the available space. We sampled their miniature burgers, which were rather delectable. However, our interactions with the staff were not entirely satisfactory. A bartender approached my spouse and inquired about his desire for a beverage, yet failed to acknowledge my presence. Subsequently, my husband was served a beer that he had not requested. Two other bartenders demonstrated proficiency in their roles and exhibited a welcoming demeanor. Unfortunately, the initial bartender continued to neglect us throughout our visit, leaving our drinks unreplenished and ignoring us for an extended period of time after we had pressed the button to signal for payment. A fourth bartender proved adept at collecting empty plates and glasses, but did not inquire about our need for any additional assistance. Considering their recent opening, I may grant them another opportunity to demonstrate their capabilities.

"An abundance of exceptional beers are available on tap, including Modelo Especial, Negro Modelo, and Delerium Tremens, among others. The restaurant boasts a unique and intriguing concept, which is complemented by its offering of delectable nachos. While the service was not optimal, it is recommended that patrons sample the Florentine Nachos, a dish that showcases the culinary expertise of the establishment."

"This particular Whole Foods market, situated within a relatively diminutive retail space, may be perceived as the 'baby bear' among its trio of sister stores within the locality, yet it does not compromise on either the range or diversity of its product offerings. Although I do not frequent this establishment as often as I do its larger counterparts, I must admit that I find the ambiance of this store to be quite appealing, perhaps due to its more intimate setting. 

Upon venturing into the produce department, I was delighted to discover an extensive array of fresh fruits and vegetables, including the presence of nopales, which added a touch of exoticism to the otherwise conventional selection. It is worth noting that the presentation of the produce section was consistently impressive, with nary a sign of disarray or neglect during my visits. 

While the meat counter may be somewhat smaller in scale compared to the other two locations, the deli, salad bar, and prepared foods sections were comparable in magnitude to those of its fellow branches. 

In conclusion, this particular Whole Foods store, despite its relatively modest proportions, manages to maintain a respectable level of quality and variety in its offerings, making it a suitable alternative for patrons seeking a convenient shopping experience without sacrificing the essence of the Whole Foods brand."

"What's more enjoyable than mini golf? Mini golf with inebriated individuals, of course! Following our visit to DW, we decided to kill some time before the effects of the bottomless mimosas had dissipated. Anthony M. treated us to a round of mini golf, and let me tell you, he was quite charming and sassy in his intoxicated state. 

The name Putt Park proved to be fitting, as the course offered a genuine putting experience with various entertaining themes. However, I couldn't help but feel that the course designers could have made a greater effort to create more challenging and distinctive holes. Instead, several holes seemed somewhat similar, which detracted from the overall experience. Nonetheless, it was an amusing way to spend time and bond with friends while engaging in a lighthearted activity. We attempted to play a serious game, but the alcohol soon took its toll, and it became a hilarious, collaborative effort to get the ball in the hole. 

At $8.50 per person, the price was reasonable, and we didn't have to worry about losing our balls down a hole that swallowed them whole, like at many other mini golf courses. While it may not offer enough variety for repeat visits, it's certainly worth experiencing at least once. 

My recommendation? Visit Putt Park after enjoying a leisurely brunch and bottomless mimosas at DW. Trust me, it will amplify the fun factor and make for a delightful afternoon, just as it did for us. 

(Yelp 100 Challenge 23/100)"

hmm.. $20 lunch buffet (on a Monday). not bad. definitely cheaper than the Wynn.

I pretty much ransacked the cocktail shrimp station and must've eaten half their supply when we were there. i tried the lamb, duck, turkey, pretty much a little bit of everything. all was decent enough.. but nothing amazing. the lamb with mint jelly was probably the highlight of my meal, along with the napoleon (dessert). dessert is my favorite part of the meal! i was slightly disappointed that they didnt have crab or lobster, but i guess for $20 wut do you expect. sushi was california rolls.. the kind i can make at home. the service (aka the person bringing us drinks) was good. 

hmm.. wut else.. nothing else i can really say about the buffet here.. i think next time i'll try the buffet at Paris.

I ate here w/my gal pal after a late night of poker and we sat at the bar where the bartender was very friendly and accomodating!  We shared a pizza and the dumplings (which come w/duck inside) and it was all pretty tasty.  This is your upscale version of the Cheesecake Factory...it all looks the same inside!

The buffet is great, yet the downside is the changes over the years. There is only one station to get crab or lobster now. You can wait up to 15 min just for plate AFTER waiting to get seated. Obvious they are trying to reduce cost and make you wait a huge amount of time instead. This needs improvement. It used to be much better and they are seeing if they can get away with no one noticing. -2 stars for this.

"During my recent culinary excursion to this esteemed eatery, I had the pleasure of partaking in their delectable roast beef sandwich, which proved to be a satisfying and flavorful experience. Furthermore, my fellow diners at the table opted for the Thai salad, which, due to its generous proportions, elicited profuse expressions of gratification from them. Notably, another member of our party chose to sample the Mahi, and their positive appraisal of it further reinforced the restaurant's commitment to serving high-quality dishes. Additionally, the hospitality displayed by the staff was indeed commendable, as they exhibited a keen attentiveness and warmth towards all patrons. In light of these factors, I would unhesitatingly endorse a visit to this culinary establishment, although it is worth noting that the prices charged were not particularly economical."

Much like Jenny I have to say A-ok is this place in a nutshell.

Was there on Saturday in an attempt to cure my hangover. Again being a lover of meat I was really hoping this place would prove to be an awesome burger salvation.

I was ok, it jkust fails to hit the high notes. They get so much right it really is a shame, the service is fantastic - the girls interact with the customers and helpfully advise on their favourites and suggestions.

I had the Pestorica or something to that effect, burger with relish, pesto mozzarella etc. Also had a side of onion rings with dips.

The burger when it comes is visually fantastic and seems huge, the pedto and mozzarella are great, the salad fine. To the burger - its just too thin. When you order they make a point of saying are you happy for the burger to be cooked medium, to which i smiled and said medium rare is fine by me!!

The burger is far too think to maintain a juicy redish centre that I was hoping to see and lacks a bit of seasoning.

The onion rings are dipped in corn flour and fried, i prefer a batter as it sticks to the onion better, these were crumbly and greasy and just not what i had hoped for.

To finish I had an oreo milk shake which was awesome to the max! 

This place could be the best burger joint in town but for now sadly they are letting themselves down!!

I am having difficulty comprehending the essence of this establishment; despite my perception of their intentions, the culinary offerings fail to meet the standards of numerous upscale steakhouses in Las Vegas, and the prices are exorbitant. The sole rationalization I can muster is that the majority of patrons receive complimentary meals, thereby creating an illusion of luxury for ego-driven gamblers. While the quality of service is unquestionably exceptional, the discrepancy between the fare served and that offered by esteemed venues such as Cut, Delmonicos, and Del Frisco's is palpable. For those seeking an authentic Old Vegas ambiance, a visit to Hugos, located within the Four Queens, is recommended, as the cuisine is delectable, the atmosphere reminiscent of a bygone era, and the prices significantly lower than those of this establishment.

I don't quite get this place. I see what they are trying to do,but the food is not as good as most high end steak houses in Vegas and he prices are way too high. The only thing I can figure is most meals are comped and it makes the ego driven gamblers think they are really getting a three hundred dollar meal, your not. The service cannot get any better its  just the food does not compare to Cut,Delmonicos,Del frisco ect. If you want old Vegas feel go to Hugos in the four queens the food is good with the same mob look but the prices are one third this place
This Paradise location is one of the noisiest locations I have ever been to. Keep that in mind if you are planning a lunch business meeting. Otherwise the service is great!

If you desire to halt and relish the culinary delights offered by The Mad Greek, while simultaneously having the opportunity to observe the world's largest thermometer, then this particular stopover is tailored specifically for your preferences. The Mad Greek, in and of itself, constitutes an acceptable eatery, boasting two separate locations; one situated in close proximity to Death Valley, within the town of Baker, and the other positioned at the entrance of Las Vegas. These establishments tend to attract a sizable clientele, thereby ensuring a perpetually crowded ambiance, particularly for devotees of Greek cuisine. The menu features an array of delectable options, such as the flavorsome falafel balls, which are prepared with a judicious balance of crispiness and succulence, complemented by a rich, creamy Tahini sauce that serves to enhance the overall dining experience, given the sweltering climate of the region. The exterior of the restaurant showcases a design inspired by ancient Roman architecture, replete with statues and columns, rendering it conspicuous and easily recognizable upon departure. In contrast, the interior presents a layout reminiscent of a traditional Greek cafeteria, characterized by a multitude of seating spaces and patrons that correspond to the eatery's popularity. For those seeking a brief respite from their travels, the Baker location offers a passable restroom facility, while the unique feature of a towering pole displaying the current temperature, located adjacent to The Mad Greek, remains a singular attraction in all of America, despite minor discrepancies in its accuracy.

If you want to stop off to see the worlds largest thermometer and have some food, then this stop is for you. The Mad Greek in itself is an ok place. There are two locations; one in Baker (near Death Valley) and then one near the entrance to LV. It's usually packed so if you like Greek food, then this may be for you. From what I remember, the falalel balls were tasty and weren't overly fried. A creamy Tahini sauce accompanies most dishes which is perfect since the weather here is HOT! The restaurant designed with roman statues and columns on the outside so you can't miss it when you are exiting. The inside is more like a greek cafeteria and is congested with a lot of seating space and people to match. The Baker stop has an option for a decent bathroom and like I said before, if you look to the left of the Mad Greek, you will see a large pole showing the temperature. This is the only one found in America and although it boasts that it shows the right temperature, its actually off a couple of degrees.

Pretty standard for an Italian place. The food was good but not super amazing. The service was okay too, our waiter was really rushed and would walk away before we were done talking to him. The prices were a little high for what you actually get but not outrageous or anything. Overall the it's has a nice atmosphere and a consistent taste so I'd definitely give it another try.

I really wanted to like this place - I live nearby and was happy to see that we had another locally owned restaurant in NE Mesa. But....the food and service just really weren't very good. The table was sticky, the service was VERY rushed (pressured to order, and then salads were brought out about 30 seconds after our appetizer) and the food was just "meh." 

We started with the brushchetta - which was incredibly dissapointing. The toppings were good enough, but it was served on flatbread which was cold and tasted rather stale. I prefer it on sliced bread like its made at Postino or D'Vine. 

My husband had the orichette with sausage - it was oversalted and the sausage was pretty bland. I had porcini ravioli with a tomato cream sauce, which would have been much better had the sauce not been so oversalted. 

The ambiance is ok - large TV's in the bar, which I guess are fine if you are sitting in the bar, but they were kind of distracting from the dining room. 

I doubt we'll return, it just wasn't good enough for the $$$ spent.

This shopping center appears significantly diminutive in comparison to the expansive retail spaces I had the pleasure of perambulating through in Las Vegas, particularly given the absence of an extensive array of commercial establishments available for perusal. Notwithstanding the aesthetically pleasing nature of the interior design and ornamentation, the boutiques situated within this mall tend to possess exorbitant price points. If one desires to engage in a leisurely promenade within a retail environment, this location may prove suitable for such purposes, despite its relatively modest proportions.

This mall is a lot smaller than the ones that I walked through in Vegas, especially since they don't have a huge number of stores for you to look at.

While the interiors and decorations of the mall looked really nice, the stores that they had were super pricey.

Well, if you want to take a nice little walk in a shopping area, then this place is okay to do so.

Pretty polular chain. The service is usualy pretty good here, I've had more positive experiences than not.

 I usuay get grilled cheese with hash browns nearly everytime I go there, even in the evenings. I love the way the bread is crispy and the cheese is melted. One time I came here the sanwich looked as though the put the cheese in between, then put it on the grill for a few seconds and took it off. The cheese wasn't melted at all. I asked the lady if the cheese can be melted more and she replied "that's how we always make them, but I'll have them melt it more." I've been there enough times to know that is not the case. When my plate came back the whole thing was hot. She put the whole plate in the microwave. Not only did she put it in the microwave, she put it in there too long. The cheese was like rubber. And the bread didnt taste good. 
Something else I like to get are the cheese sticks. They're really good when the cheese is perfectly melted on the inside. You have to eat them while they're hot. I use ranch and marinara dipping sauces. 

Other than that incident, the service is good. The food is good. Overall its a good place to just come, eat and converse with others. Or come have some alone time and eat, read the paper whatever.

I saw the Blue Man Group last week with high expectations. It is one of the longest running shows in Las Vegas (although it is moving soon to the Monte Carlo) and is performed in a few other cities across the country. Understandably, I was excited.

And while there were many great scenes, I thought the show lacked continuity. The three blue men would spend 5-10 minutes beating on drums and then for seemingly no reason start climbing the chairs in the audience. Then in the next scene they performed a very impressive marshmellow throwing trick (I won't spoil it) that seemed really random in execution. While everything they did was impressive, I've seen similar things done on the streets of Las Vegas Boulevard. I was especially confused with what each had to do with one another.

The show does get points for humor though. The comedic timing of the three blue men was terrific and there were at least a couple full laugh-out-loud moments. They also had some fun audience participation that would presumably make each show a little different. Plus it was very simple, slap stick humor, so it was appropriate for the whole family.

Ultimately, I enjoyed the show but it just didn't live up to the hype or the price.

"I visited this establishment in the company of several colleagues, seeking a rapid midday repast. Having previously partaken of beverages at this locale, I was curious about the quality of their luncheon offerings. The Kilted Pig presents a diverse array of modestly priced fare (ranging from Â£3.50 to Â£8) that includes soups, sandwiches, baked potatoes, fish pie, risotto, and stovies. Furthermore, patrons can still peruse the regular menu. My associates and I opted for selections from the luncheon menu, and while the dishes may not have been particularly sophisticated, they were certainly satisfying and generously portioned. Our total expenditure for six meals, a bottle of wine, and three soft drinks amounted to a trifling Â£50, rendering our dining experience eminently affordable. Prior to our visit, I reserved a table, and upon divulging our requirement for a prompt turnaround, the accommodating staff furnished us with menus in advance, enabling us to place a pre-order before our arrival, thereby ensuring an efficient and satisfactory dining experience."

"Satisfactory, albeit unspectacular experience with a few notable drawbacks. Prompt service, as anticipated. Excessive coleslaw proportion, personally speaking. Palatable sandwich, yet pastrami exhibited an unfortunate toughness. Fries lacked adequate crispiness. Request for double meat yielded no noticeable difference compared to companion's serving. Not particularly worth going out of one's way for."

Good.  Not great.  Service is quick as expected.  Too much coleslaw for my liking. Sandwich is good but pastrami was chewy.  Fries were a little undercooked. Asked for double meat but same amount as friend.  Don't go out of your way

It was spa day at the camelback inn spa. We had facials and massages, lunch, and then wanted to have some FaceTime since we don't see each other often. That's when the trouble began. The quiet police were after us! Finally, we escaped to the outside where there were no water spritsers. We found some icy towels to cool us. Andrea gave me a great facial and spent a lot of time with me answering questions about my skin, eyebags, and products that could help. If you favor silence to read and relax you will enjoy it! They offer lemon water, tea, and when you leave you can make your own sachet which was awesome. My sachet has lavender in it and really helps me get to sleep. A nice touch!! The food and drink offerings were very good and the attendants were always nearby to help or keep everyone quiet. Shhhh when you go there!

I give it three stars because their coffee was very indifferent to me and I think I should try their coffee twice before judging it. I will say the hours are bad for a coffee house, because they're only open until 7. I will definitely say there are better coffee places to go to then this.

"Establishments offering alcoholic beverages along Edinburgh's famed Royal Mile cater primarily to sightseers oblivious to exorbitant prices and lacking a genuine sense of community among patrons, according to my perspective. The Albanach, while conforming to some of these criteria, boasts an interior that has undergone a recent refurbishment, featuring sleek slate flooring and polished wooden accents that diverge from the conventional ambiance associated with age-old taverns in the historic district. A cursory examination of the menu reveals a cheeseburger and fries costing approximately ten pounds, and tourists perusing maps with confused expressions are commonplace in the outdoor seating area. Despite these factors, our group often ends up at this venue during the course of an evening out, attracted by the reasonably priced house wine, available for twelve pounds per bottle, a sum barely exceeding the cost of a single glass of comparable vintage in nearby George Street watering holes. Moreover, the step leading into the entrance requires caution, as it tends to catch my attention (and that of others) every time, making it a conspicuous feature."

Bars on the Royal Mile are, if you ask me, pretty much exclusively reserved for tourists who don't realise how overpriced they are, and aren't looking for a 'local' with any sense of community.

And to a certain extent, The Albanach fits all of those criteria: a cheeseburger and chips wiill set you back the best part of a tenner, and at every second table in the outside area there'll be somebody staring at a map of the centre with a slightly puzzled expression on their face.

That said, if I ever go for a drink with friends in this area we nearly always end up here at some point during the evening. House wine, although not exactly going to win any vintage awards, is only £12 a bottle which isn't much more than the price of a glass of equally average wine in some George Street bars. Not too shabby at all. Also, I don't know if they've recently had a big refurb but inside it is really nicely decorated. Unlike lots of traditional pubs in the old town, where "traditional" means it still smells of the pre-smoking ban days and is always full of old men drinking pints of real ale, The Albanach has lovely slate floors and new polished wood everywhere.

Just watch the step up as you go through the door on your way in. It catches me out every time and yes, everyone can see you.

Stopped in this morning because a friend started waiting tables here.  Obviously the service was stellar as hers always is but because I have a bias I am not including it in my rating.

Got seated out on the patio and it was a wonderful morning to do so.  Getting there early it wasn't very crowded. I noticed over twice as many cars in the lot when I left.  Whoever ordered the patio chairs never had to sit in them for very long.  They are sorta ok for setting back with coffee but a bit of work to set up to the table.

Speaking of coffee I had decaf.  For breakfast I had scrambled eggs, sausage, pancakes.  Eggs apparently got plated first as they were only lukewarm as the rest of the dish was still hot.  They honored my request to cook the sausage well.  I actually liked the thin pancakes, they were not doughy or over crisped and were still warm enough when I got them to finish melting the butter.

The Good Egg is not my favorite breakfast spot but it is ok and consistent across the chain.  And it is an Arizona chain.

My acquaintance avowed that this establishment was the optimal location for an early morning repast, and while it does indeed possess certain unique breakfast offerings, the quality of service is inconsistent, as at times, one may receive prompt refills on their coffee, while on other occasions, they will be left with an empty cup for an extended period... Despite these inconsistencies, I continue to frequent this eatery with regularity.

My primary grievance pertains to the cost, as I believe that two eggs and a few slices of bacon should not approach six dollars in value, in my judgment. The menu features both advantageous and disadvantageous options, and the selection is contingent upon one's culinary inclinations.

Furthermore, the purported military discount is only applicable to those who are attired in their official uniform, which seems unreasonable, as it is unlikely that individuals would don their uniforms during their days off, and furthermore, what difference does it make whether one is clothed in their uniform or not?!?

If you opt to visit this establishment on the weekends, it is advisable to arrive early, as the late-night revelers seeking to alleviate their hangovers typically congregate around 10 am, resulting in an extended waiting period for those who fail to arrive promptly.
It's ok.  I think they survive more on presentation, big portions, and name recognition than actual taste of food.  There are a bunch of better breakfast/brunch options in Vegas in my experience.

My offspring thoroughly enjoy this establishment, as it offers an array of apparel and paraphernalia inspired by popular cable television programs and musical ensembles, catering to a younger clientele. The sales personnel, who personify the target market, provide excellent customer service, offering assistance in selecting items that fit within their budget constraints. The prices, though slightly elevated due to the licensing fees associated with these products, are still reasonable and align with the quality of the merchandise offered.

My kids love this place.  Cool shirts and gear based upon cable shows and rock groups.  Obviously for a youthful demographic.  Sales people certainly represent that.  Prices seem reasonable for licensed items.  Quality seems good too.

I found decent prices here and I did feel a little out of my element I couldn't understand the names on their packaging. I bought some bamboo spoons for 35 cents each. I love wooden spoons for my tea.

This is a Colombian restaurant, not Mexican. Very different menu than you will find in a Mexican restaurant. All very large portion entrees but you definitely pay for it. Being in the part of town it is in you would expect it to be inexpensive but that is not true. Entrees range from $13.00 to $25.00 but are, for the most part, worth it. I can only review one dish here as it is the only thing I have had here all 10+ times I've been. I always get the #25. Shrimp in coconut sauce over tostones (crispy fried green plantains) it has been fantastic every time. Their juices are great as well. Also, try the fried Yuca, it has a taste and texture similar to French fries. \n\nService at the restaurant is decent. Friendly staff and relatively fast service. I have only been there on slower nights so I cannot speak for their service on a busy night.

This marks our third sojourn to the gambling capital of the world this calendar year, yet it is our inaugural stay at the luxurious Mandalay Bay resort. Our previous two excursions were accommodated at The Hotel, where we experienced unparalleled service and opulence. However, our current lodgings have failed to meet our expectations in certain aspects, particularly regarding the state of the sleeping quarters and adjoining bathing facilities. Specifically, the space appears excessively cluttered with an abundance of furnishings, while the bathroom's hygiene leaves much to be desired, boasting an assortment of unseemly stray hairs scattered about the tub and shower wall, in addition to various unsightly stains marring the surface of the countertop. In contrast, The Hotel's accommodations, all of which are lavish suites, offer a superior level of comfort and cleanliness. Each room is appointed with plush bathrobes and slippers, thoughtfully provided for our convenience without the need for request, as was the case at Mandalay Bay. Moreover, the pristine condition of The Hotel's bathrooms is a refreshing departure from the disappointing state of those encountered during our present stay.

I was really excited about this place based on personal recommendations and yelp reviews. I've heard the dinner is amazing, and with such a high rating level, knew this would be a great place to take friends from out of town. However, we decided to go earlier in the day instead of for dinner.
Went for brunch with 3 other people. Now, I understand that Charlotte is still working on their brunch scene compared to other cities, but brunch is brunch!
The food was cold, and service was slow. Our waitress was really friendly but very relaxed. She was attentive when it came to our coffee, but would disappear in bouts of 10-15 minutes. It wasn't very busy. The food was good, not great. I got the Breakfast Burrito. It was cold, and the cheese was hard. My friend really enjoyed the Shrimp Omelette, but did mention it was luke warm. Could be an attribute to our waitress performing Houdini disappearing acts. 
Overall, this place is good not great for brunch. It would be a place that if I had to have a fourth or fifth option for brunch, I might think about trying it again during this time. As to other times during the week/night,  I'm not giving up on this place! I've heard their Shrimp And Crawfish Etouffe and Bloody Mary Bar are as authentic as it can get. I will be back for dinner!

It's a good concept, circuit training.  It's go-go-go from the beginning so if you're not in great shape then this will be an eye opener.  We did 6 sets of 4 reps lasting about 3-4 min each throughout the 1 hr we did. 

Liked: TV monitors tracking your heart rate and the trainer was really nice
Don't like: that you're constantly comparing yourself to others, and it can be distracting as you're trying to figure out if you're in the "zone".  Which is not really a big dislike......

I had a free class at 6:30am and it was packed on a Saturday morning with just one guy, about 15 people.  The gym itself is small and confortable feeling, and orange is the color which is vibrant and inviting.  They had a few things for sale but a little expensive.  

The program itself I think is too expensive, but I think it can work for people who like to do different things in their workout instead of just sitting at one station the whole time.  Good luck.

For the food I would have to give 5 stars.

The only problem is the shaky service.  If you to during lunch rush except very bad service.  Not sure why they can't hire another part time server.

There have been times that we almost had to leave because of the bad service.

I have to admit that I keep coming back for the matzoh ball soup!

took advantage of the coupons and got the chicken fingers. fast service and friendly. the chicken fingers were good,just be careful ordering hot! I still have much to try here so the jury is still out,but so far so good!

I was a bit disappointed because the service was not very good. Even from first entering the restaurant the service was not good. The decor and atmosphere is nice, especially if you can get a seat outside by the lake of dreams. The vegan food was delicious but nothing to rave about. The show which is played on the lake is quite cheesy. So all in all it was just ok. I was expecting better.

Been a fan of this place through several names and owners. It's one of the few places in town to get a cigar, a pint of beer, and enjoy it inside.

The staff is very friendly, and they have a pretty good selection in their humidor. They carry a small but solid lineup of beers, including some of the local breweries. You can sit at the bar, grab a comfy chair, or sit at a table and watch the TV.

My only ding is for the atmosphere. Literally, the air. I like a cigar once in a while but am not a heavy smoker, and the smoke in there was on the edge of what I can stand. I had to fumigate my clothes when I got home. So definitely not for the weak of nostril.

Il Bosco Pizza and Handlebar-J were our prior destinations, whereupon completion of our repast, we opted to perambulate in the direction of this establishment, primarily due to its proximity and the fact that it offered a wide range of potables during their extended happy hour, which commenced at the eleventh hour and concluded at the seventeenth hour. Furthermore, we were drawn to the premises by the presence of numerous televisual displays, which afforded us the opportunity to observe various athletic competitions transpiring concurrently. Although we did not partake in culinary indulgences, the menu presented an impressive array of gastronomical options.

We were out and about, having just finished a late lunch/snack over at Il Bosco Pizza and Handlebar-J did not open until 4pm so we wandered over here to get a drink.  It was clean and has happy hour daily from 11am-7pm .  There are plenty of TVs to watch whatever sporting event is on.  We didn't order any food but they have an extensive menu.

"Cool for juveniles...Not so much for grown-ups. I arrived specifically for the mummified cadaver display and I was somewhat disillusioned. I appreciated the diminutive computer terminals that expounded upon Egypt and the authentic mummy. Apart from that, it was unremarkable. I wouldn't advocate for remunerating additional fees to witness it."

Cool for children... Not so much for adults. I came especially for the mummy exhibit and I was kind of disappointed. I liked the little computer stations that talked about Egypt and the actual mummy. Other than that, it was mediocre. I wouldn't recommend paying extra to see it.

"A plethora of exceptional thin-crust pizzas are proffered within this establishment, particularly the 'wise guy' variety, which showcases a remarkable balance of flavors and textures; prices are quite reasonable, making it an accessible dining option for patrons seeking a satisfying meal without breaking the bank; however, the service, while generally cordial and attentive, can be somewhat inconsistent, with periods of prolonged wait times or erratic attention from staff members."

"Gastronomical excellence is undeniably evident in the culinary offerings of this establishment, however, operational deficiencies, discourteous staff, and an absence of managerial oversight have conspired to create an unfortunate dining experience, characterized by protracted waiting periods sans any tangible justification. Despite the delectability of the fare, a second visit is conditional upon the implementation of tangible improvements in service quality, as the patron is unlikely to be accorded any consideration or compensation for inconvenience incurred, and indeed, may be subject to financial penalty for lateness, much to their chagrin."

Great tasting food, really, it is.

Problem, disorganized, rude, lack of management, long waits for no specific reason.

Willing to give it a second shot because the food is really good, but would recommend to ensure you have nowhere to go to afterwards because you may miss that event or appointment and they won't care, will still charge you and give you now deal, boo!

"This establishment purveys a rudimentary assortment of culinary offerings, with an emphasis on a traditional burger-centric menu, augmented by a select array of supplementary items that, while intriguing, remain untested by this writer. Given the pecuniary constraints inherent in any dining excursion, it is conceivable that an alternative venue, such as Smashburger, might present a more enticing value proposition, particularly in light of its relative proximity. Notwithstanding, the superior quality of the burgers served at this location relative to other nearby eateries renders it a viable option for future dining experiences."

Just your basic burger joint..  They do have a few other interesting things on the menu which I have not tried.  For the money I would rather go to Smashburger if it were closer.  I would eat here again because it is the best burger nearby for sure.

My friends and I got a deal here and I was expecting the worse, but we got good. :)

We got an adjoining suite and the kitchen was well stocked for what you needed in vegas. The pool was heated, which made me want to come back. 

Otherwise, the place was kind of old. I'd come back here if I ever had a family and wanted to do the tourist thing.

Not a bad deal - $40 for 2 people with two mimosas.   My husband and I ate to our hearts content - we got there at around 11am, and ate for what seemed like an eternity.  Since it was lunch time, we got a mishmosh of things:  crepe with everything (YUM!); gnocchi, salad, grilled veggies, dolmas, hummus and other dips, pita, all sorts of dessert and breads.  \n\nSeriously we had the worst food coma - I fell asleep in the elevator on the way back to our hotel.  I woke up four hours later to go get married. =)

"Beverages are reasonably priced, however, the ambiance is not particularly characteristic of a dive bar, per se. There is a disc jockey and a minuscule dance floor, yet the absence of exceptional service is palpable. The barback's stature and physical attractiveness captured my attention, prompting me to engage in rhythmic movements with my lower torso. The entrance fee of four dollars seemed somewhat unremarkable. It is worth mentioning that certain patrons appeared youthful, almost juvenile, which struck me as mildly peculiar, given the venue's reputation. Nonetheless, the prices for Jameson, Jack Daniel's, and most beers were reasonable, amounting to approximately 6.50 Canadian dollars. If one seeks an establishment conducive to fostering a sense of hipsterism, this may be an appropriate destination. Despite my personal preferences skewing towards a slightly more mature atmosphere, I must admit that this location possesses certain merits."

Drinks are decent price. Honestly it's not the most divey spot but its cool. There's a DJ and small dance floor. No services to remember. The bar back was pretty tall and handsome so I felt fascinated. I danced, shook my butt everywhere- 4$ cover: meh! \n\nSome of the people in it looked 15 years old which was weird but hey I'm on Vacation. 6,50 CAD for jameson, jack, most beer. If your into more of the I need to feel hipster scene come here. Its a great place just young for my lifestyle.

"Indubitably, the inaugural special offer of $16 for AYCE Korean BBQ may appear advantageous, but upon closer examination, it becomes evident that it falls short of expectations in various aspects. Firstly, parking poses a significant challenge, as the limited capacity of merely 20 spaces results in a cramped lot, raising questions about the feasibility of accommodating a large influx of patrons. Moreover, the service, despite the servers' attempts at cordiality, proved subpar, with forgetfulness regarding certain dishes and a tendency towards overcooking, leading to disappointment. Furthermore, the culinary offerings themselves were unimpressive, lacking depth of flavor, particularly in the marinated bulgogi and galbi, while the other meats suffered from dryness and an unpleasant chewiness, perhaps indicative of questionable freshness. Additionally, the AYCE appetizer selection was scant, with only gyoza and steamed eggs available, which, though palatable, failed to satisfy the craving for greater variety. In light of these deficiencies, it becomes apparent that this establishment must elevate its standards to surpass the competition among AYCE Korean BBQ venues in Las Vegas."

Yes the grand opening special $16 for AYCE krn bbq is great and all but its still not worth it in my book. 

First off, parking. IF this place ever gets off, where will all the customers park? Is everyone forced to carpool? because there are literally only 20 spots and its a cramped lot. Gotta fix that.
Secondly, service. Our service didn't suck as bad as everyone else's but it was still bad. I mean the servers try to be nice and all but they did forget a couple of dishes. I also don't mind them cooking for us, however  much of our food turned out burnt. boo.
Lastly but most importantly, the food was just not that good. I really like strong flavors and both the marinated bulgogi and galbi were too bland for my taste. The other meats were also too dry and chewy.. maybe an indication that stuff wasn't too fresh? There was also a lack of variety in the AYCE appetizers. Sure gyoza and the steamed egg are good and all but I wanted more. I mean you're up against all the other AYCE krn bbq places in Vegas.. step it up yo.
Solid variety of options, on the pricey side. We had sushi, chicken lettuce wraps, and a shrimp noodle dish. The food was good, but not quite authentic the way pan-asian places often are.

My favorite thing about this comic store is the fact that they just about always have a copy of something I'm looking for. They tend to order enough of books that come out. Other stores might be out but they will usually have some left. They have a bunch of figures and tons of books. Deforest will continue Coming in and maybe even subscribe for a box!

I've always wanted to try this place and finally did. I ordered the cast iron skillet cornbread, which was good, then I had their smoked salmon hash which was just okay. My fianc\u00e9 had a salmon burger which he said was pretty good and the portion was huge!\nAlthough, I didn't feel the welcoming vibe as we walked up to the front. There were four people at the host stand and they were all just too busy doing sidework and chitchatting with each other but hey, we were fed in a timely manner so whatever and our server was nice and attentive. I should've tried one of their humongous burgers but there's always next time. I'll come back and give it another shot next time I'm in town.

"The culinary experience afforded by this establishment's pizza and salad offerings is satisfactory, but the level of service provided falls short of exceptional standards. Notwithstanding, this venue remains an acceptable setting for socializing in the evening, particularly following a cinematic excursion."

Saw \"Oklahoma!\" here a few years ago and enjoyed the show.  We also had the dinner buffet, which was OK- nothing to write home about.  I remember thinking that the desserts were the only items worth trying...\nIf its location just wasn't so out-of-the-way (back then I lived in Chandler!), I'd have been back many times by now, but I've only visited that one time.  Even now, I have a chance to buy 80% off gift certificates online, but it's a 28-mile drive from Scottsdale, so I think I'll pass...

So my girlfriend and I stayed at Aria and had a reservation for 2 months at The Steakhouse and the bubblehead woman at check in sat us at a horrible table so we will never go back.   If you don't take care of hotel guests, what's the point?   A group of 4 walked in with no reservation and sat next to us and complained about the table, so although our waiter was good and the food ok the experience was soiled by an idiot woman who sat us in Siberia.   Bad job!!!!!

"My previous assertions proved erroneous, as I found myself succumbing to the allure of Sports Authority's diverse inventory, seeking a fresh pair of athletic shoes that would accommodate my expanding repertoire of physical activities. Upon entering the store, I was promptly approached by David, an employee whose exceptional customer service acumen became apparent from the onset. He demonstrated a profound understanding of my specific needs, engaging in a thorough inquiry regarding my intended usage of the footwear, prior to presenting me with a selection of four options that he personally endorsed. Notably, he even persuaded me to consider a more economical alternative, opting for a discounted offering from Asics, which has proven to be an ideal choice. Although the checkout process remained somewhat chaotic, David's extraordinary assistance justified this revised assessment."

I lied. After saying I'd never go back to Sports Authority convenience won out and I stopped in for a new pair of kicks. David sought me out immediately and was incredibly helpful, taking the time to understand what activities I was really going to be using the shoe for before directing me to three or four of his personal picks. He even talked me out of a more expensive pair of New Balance in favor of some discounted Asics, which I love. Checkout is still a bit of a mess but David's exemplary service warranted this updated review.

Beware of the EBAY MAFIA and their evil friends...

If you are going to Last Chance there are a few things you should know:

1. They have the best deals in town.
2. You have little chance of getting these deals, as bitchy women and evil sleazoids plot to keep these deals away from regular consumers.   There is a group of "team shoppers" who go to Last Chance every day. Their mission is to scoop up every piece of good clothing the minute the store opens. They work in teams to keep "outsiders" out. They even work with unscrupulous staff members to keep regular people away from the best clothing. Many of these people even sell the stuff they score at Last Chance on Ebay.

Want proof? Go to Ebay and search for things like Marc Jacobs purses or True Religion Jeans in Phoenix. You will see TONS of items from Lat Chance listed on Ebay. You know it's from Last Chance because of markings in the bags, cut tags on jeans and other things Last Chance does to prevent returns to Nordstrom.

So in summary - Last Chance would be great if the Ebay Mafia and their evil friends would stay away.

"It's analogous to Korean and Japanese fast food, where one can obtain sushi, albeit with difficulty in Pittsburgh, yet this establishment manages to proffer an acceptable rendition. Additionally, customary Korean cuisine such as bulgogi, galbi, and kimchi are available. My personal preference is the galbi bento, although its cost surpasses $8, rendering it an occasional indulgence, or the bulgogi bowl. 

The bento boxes contain a limited quantity of chap chae (Korean glass noodles), kimchi, a salad dressed with an oriental vinaigrette, Japanese yellow pickles, several pot stickers of mediocre quality, and, naturally, the primary dish of one's choice. 

The bowls are straightforward, consisting merely of rice topped with meat, thereby eliciting satisfaction. 

However, the space is somewhat diminutive, thereby accommodating groups of four individuals at maximum."

It's like Korean and Japanese fast food. You can get sushi (its hard to get good sushi in Pittsburgh so by those standards, its pretty decent). You can also get the usual Korean fare: bulgogi, galbi, and kimchi. My favorite is the galbi bento (although its over $8 so I don't usually get it), or the bulgogi bowl. 

The bento boxes come with a little bit of chap chae (Korean glass noodles), kim chi, a salad with "oriental dressing", japanese yellow pickles, a few pot stickers (not bad, not good), and of course, whatever entree you ordered. 

The bowls are simple: rice topped with meat. Yum! 

The space is small though so its okay for 4-people groups.

"Commenced a corporate gathering with colleagues at this establishment, indulging in a delectable culinary experience that, while satisfying, did not linger in my memory as a standout occasion. The ambiance was vibrant and conducive to socializing, characteristic of Las Vegas venues, and situated within the luxurious Cosmopolitan hotel, amidst an array of dining options. Notwithstanding, the wait times for seating were generally prolonged at neighboring eateries, rendering this particular location a relatively convenient alternative. While not necessarily a personal favorite, it remains a passable choice for casual dining."

My bf and I weren't a fan of this place. It's very loud and small inside. I ordered a mushroom and cheese omelette, bacon and a biscuit. Bf ordered a spanish omelet with salsa and home fries.\nMy omelette wasn't seasoned at all and lacked flavor. The bacon and biscuit were great tho. The bf liked his meal. The one thing we both agreed on was that the coffee was awful!!

I am desirous of patronizing local establishments, as I recognize the significance of supporting local entrepreneurs and artisans. However, I harbor doubts regarding the genuine interest of certain businesses in cultivating a rapport with their clientele. Specifically, my recent visit to your store raised several concerns. 

Upon entering the premises on a Wednesday, I observed a queue comprising four or five individuals, which initially led me to infer that it was a popular destination. Nonetheless, upon closer inspection, it became apparent that the staff members were not particularly zealous in their endeavors to assist customers. Rather, they exhibited a lackadaisical demeanor, lethargically fulfilling orders with minimal enthusiasm or passion. 

When I eventually reached the counter, I posed a few inquiries regarding your seasonal flavors and the possibility of blending them. Unfortunately, extracting information or recommendations from the employee proved to be akin to an arduous task, akin to pulling teeth. I felt embarrassed, as if I were inconveniencing him, although I quickly recalled that as a paying customer, I was entitled to courteous service. 

The barista, who seemed equally disinterested, prepared my order with a conspicuous lack of enthusiasm. Despite my best efforts to engage her in conversation, she responded with a perfunctory grunt, which I found thoroughly unacceptable. It is regrettable that such an encounter would persuade me to take my business elsewhere, specifically to a large chain establishment. 

In light of these circumstances, I respectfully implore your organization to prioritize improving customer engagement. Adopting a more attentive and appreciative approach toward patrons, incorporating phrases such as "thank you," "please," and "you're welcome," would greatly enhance the overall experience. Additionally, expressing sentiments like "glad I can help" would contribute to a more welcoming atmosphere. By implementing these changes, I am confident that your business can flourish and foster a loyal customer base.

Met some people for McKoys for lunch and it was a good decision.

I had the pulled pork sandwich and it was tasty and well priced.  Also, with a side of mac&cheese fill me up perfectly.    

2 things to be on the look out here for.
1 -  They won't seat you until you entire party is there.  I was 2 mins late to the door and had to make everyone wait to be seat.
2 - Beware getting seat outside.  The traffic noise is really loud.  They need to install some more bush is some type of sound barrier.  It was hard to talk one another out there.

I used to live in So Cal & Vegas, so all Asian food gets compared to those areas.  As much as I wanted to love this place, it only gets 3 Stars. 

The portions here are pretty big and the flavors are unique.  
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/republic-ramen-noodles-tempe?select=ksAFcidCv_BmBaBXB8aXzw#ksAFcidCv_BmBaBXB8aXzw
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/republic-ramen-noodles-tempe?select=qmZ7A6n_Is96cBXnDNw6Tw#qmZ7A6n_Is96cBXnDNw6Tw

Their idea of "spicy" is really mild though....so for spice lovers, you'll have to supplement it with Sriracha.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/republic-ramen-noodles-tempe?select=hfn4x4jMbFl8pF73iXVUgQ#hfn4x4jMbFl8pF73iXVUgQ

It's not like a legit, Ramen place you'll find in other cities....but it will suffice until I travel somewhere I can get the real thing.

Return Factor - 65%

"Upon approaching the establishment, I was met with a rather discourteous reception from the hostess, who displayed a lack of enthusiasm in addressing my inquiry regarding the seating arrangement. Her nonverbal response, a mere shrug, conveyed a sense of indifference that was somewhat surprising, given the high volume of patrons present at the time. Notwithstanding this initial encounter, my experience improved significantly upon being seated, as a friendly server named Jack attended to my needs with promptness and attentive service, save for a minor mishap involving the incorrect beverage, which was swiftly rectified upon my request."

The host was very rude when I walked up although I wasn't expecting amazing service from an airport bar. I asked her a question about the seating situation and she just shrugged her shoulders. She literally didn't say a word. I think her name tag said Della or something starting with a D. Once I sat down my experience here got better. A young lady by the name of Jack greeted me and took my order. She brought me back the wrong beer but quickly offered to fix my order. I'm not one to let drinks go to waste so I didn't make her fix it.

I like this place a lot, good food, good service. Only thing I do not like at ALL, is the fact that they allow minors to be seated in the bar area. There is a restaurant portion with plenty of seating too. Really kills the vibe!

YAY!  Cheap food!   Corn dog was super good! Now I was a little intoxicated both times that I got it, but at 1:30 in the morning you can't beat the price and location!  Grab a corn dog and go into the casino and continue on, perfect!

First off, the view of the bellagio and the water show is AMAZING FROM HERE!!

The food here is just decent. You're paying more for the view and the fact you're on the top of las vegas in a qausi eiffel tower. 

Def worth the experience. Not sure if they have a bar up there, but i'd just get drinks up there if I could instead of eating

These delectable, visually-appealing cupcakes possess an aesthetic quality reminiscent of those that are meticulously crafted and presented at upscale social gatherings, specifically weddings, evoking a sense of refined elegance and sophistication attributed to the renowned lifestyle icon, Martha Stewart; they would undoubtedly be the centerpiece of attention when displayed in abundance and diversity on a serving tray, exuding an air of lavishness and charm. My admiration for their allure is complemented by my fondness for the judicious application of frosting, which strikes a harmonious balance between restraint and indulgence, further enhancing the overall visual appeal of these delightful treats. Additionally, I must commend the creators of these culinary gems, whose expertise and dedication to their craft are evident in the unique and intriguing flavors they have created, imbuing each cupcake with its distinct character and charm. While the cupcake itself may be experiencing an identity crisis, straddling the line between its traditional form and a muffin-like transformation, my curiosity and appreciation for its unconventional nature prompt me to consider revisiting this establishment, provided that I am in close proximity, as the flavors are truly captivating and worthy of further exploration, although I would not undertake a special journey solely for the purpose of sampling them.

These cupcakes have the look of cupcakes that are looked at.

They're very pretty in a well-bred Martha Stewart weddings way. They would look fabulous on a tray in quantity and variety.

I like the prettiness. I like the restrained hand with the frosting. I like the frosting itself, which is unusual. I like the clerks. I very much like the toys!

The cupcake itself is such that, if I made it at home, I'd dub that batch "experimental." This cupcake was having an identity crisis but had not yet fully transitioned to muffin.

I'd go back, if I'm right there, as the flavors are interesting, but I wouldn't make a special trip.

"Was this venue satisfactory? Indeed, it met my expectations. 

Are there numerous alternative establishments offering superior culinary experiences? Undoubtedly, they abound! 

Upon perusing the menu, we opted for the Jumbo Shrimp Cocktail and the Shrimp Spring Rolls as introductory selections. The shrimp cocktail conformed to my expectations, presenting a chilled seafood platter accompanied by a tangy dipping sauce. The spring rolls, however, surpassed my expectations, boasting a delectable flavor profile that warranted a repeat order. If I were to return to this eatery, I would unquestionably initiate my meal with an order of these tantalizing rolls. 

For the primary course, I selected the Crown Cut Bone In Filet Mignon, measuring 12 ounces. Unfortunately, this cut of beef failed to impress my palate, given its premium pricing. At this price point, I could easily seek out superior steak options at neighboring restaurants. 

In the event that I find myself at the Forum Shops with a craving for steak, I will likely venture next door to Joe's, where I can indulge in a more satisfying dining experience."

Was this place good? Yes. 

Are there a lot of better places? Yes!

I had dinner here and we ordered the Jumbo Shrimp Cocktail and the Shrimp Spring Rolls as appetizers. The shrimp cocktail was exactly what I expected, cold shrimp with cocktail sauce.The spring rolls were actually really good and if I came back here I would start my meal off with an order of these.

For the main course I got the Crown Cut Bone In Filet Mignon, 12 oz. This steak really didn't do much for me. At this price point, I can go almost anywhere else for a better steak.

Next time, if I'm in the forum shops and looking for a steak I'll probably go next door to Joes.

The service is friendly.. and the ambiance is cool!  I love the outside benches where you can sit, have a beer, shoot the shit.... and just chill.  On a nice night, it's a really nice place to just BE.  

The waitresses are friendly... as well as the patrons.... 

I do believe that they serve food... though instead of ordering food, I ordered beer.  Beer was excellent.  hahaha!

Prices aren't to bad either.... what I really dig about this place is the outside seating area.  I just like being outside.  

Thanks for the good times Al's!  I'll be back

We recently afforded San Remo an additional opportunity to demonstrate its culinary proficiency, and on this particular visit, I managed to acquire a satisfying and economical breakfast, while my dining companion, JK, opted for a chopped steak accompanied by a mixed green salad dressed with a flavorful house-made blue cheese vinaigrette. Our server, who exhibited both cordiality and competence throughout our meal, kept our glasses replenished with an attentive diligence that bordered on obsessiveness. Although I must admit that the ubiquity of flat screen televisions positioned throughout the establishment detracted slightly from the overall ambiance, it is worth noting that their presence can potentially serve as a welcome diversion for solitary patrons; furthermore, upon request, the volume emanating from the screen nearest to our table was considerately lowered. Despite its lingering reputation as a somewhat unrefined eatery, San Remo has demonstrated a capacity for improvement, and one can only hope that such progress continues to manifest itself in the future.

We recently gave San Remo another shot. I scored a solid, inexpensive breakfast while JK had a decent chopped steak and salad with good house-made blue cheese dressing. Our waitress was competent, friendly and on top of refills throughout our meal. I'm not a fan of the flat screens in every corner, but that can be a plus when you're dining alone - also they reduced the volume on the one closest to us as we requested. San Remo will probably always be a bit of a dive, but that's not a bad thing. Hopefully we'll continue to see improvements here and there at this low-key diner.

"The culinary offerings possessed a pleasant gustatory quality, which was gratifying to discern. Moreover, the establishment's policy of offering morning repasts throughout the day was a source of satisfaction for me. However, certain drawbacks were evident, such as an excessive delay in being seated, a lukewarm reception by our server, and an unfortunate diminution in the temperature of the fare by the time it reached our table."

The food had a nice flavor to it. And I enjoy the fact that they serve breakfast all day. On the negative side of things; the wait to be sat was way too long. The server was mediocre at best and the food was cold by the time that it got to us!

Okay, so I might not be the best person to review Brew Lab as I don't do coffee. At all. The whole coffee thing is properly lost on me. So a place famed for this particular beverage probably has to work harder for me. 

However, I liked Brew Lab when I could finally get some space to sit down and soak up the place. It feels a bit like a train station with people constantly wandering around trying to find a spot to sit, and it's rammed full of rich student types. 

I like the decor, the staff were very pleasant and my peppermint tea was really very nice. Fresh peppermint leaves and all. Lovely. Couldn't fault the cuppa - would happily sup another one.

However, it's losing the fourth star for me just now because it's so busy and I don't find it very relaxing. If I want to enjoy a pot of tea I'd rather go somewhere a bit less packed. But hey, that's just a testament to how popular the joint is :)

"Upon entering the establishment, I was met with an air of skepticism, as if the proprietor was dubious about the presence of my canine companion. I assiduously inquired as to whether it was permissible to admit my pooch into the courtyard area, only to be met with a resounding 'negative' from the hostess. Undeterred, I opted to partake in the culinary offerings, despite the dearth of hospitable treatment by the overwhelmed servers. Suffice it to say, the gastronomical experience was satisfactory, albeit the service was subpar, leaving me ambivalent about the prospect of revisiting the venue."

"It is imperative that I confess the TB constitutes a culpable junk food indulgence when adhering to a vegetarian dietary preference. The vast majority of items listed on the menu can be tailored to accommodate vegetarian patrons, which is quite advantageous when time is of the essence. This particular establishment appears to be on par with its peers, and while I am uncertain regarding my ability to bestow four stars upon it, the cuisine is unquestionably consistent with the TB's customary offerings - neither revolutionary nor particularly memorable, but reliably satisfying. The personnel at this location are predominantly youthful individuals, as is often the case with fast-food establishments, yet their demeanor is invariably cheerful. My experiences with the drive-thru have been pleasant, as the staff members are scrupulously polite and relatively prompt; although their efficiency does not approach lightning-speed, I have yet to encounter substantial delays. Therefore, if an individual seeks to acquire TB fare, this venue is a suitable choice, owing to the presence of affable and competent employees manning the drive-thru."

I concur wholeheartedly with a select group of Yelp reviewers who hail from California, as I too, have had the privilege of residing in the southern region of the Golden State. It is indeed true that the cost of a sandwich in Las Vegas is nearly double that of its counterpart in Los Angeles, specifically at Lee's Sandwich; however, I have come to realize that this establishment represents the sole venue where I can indulge in my craving for a delectable Vietnamese sandwich. It is worth noting that all items on the menu are quite pricey. My curiosity regarding the remaining dishes offered by this restaurant led me to return with my spouse, during which we sampled the Banh Cuon - a delicate rice roll filled with a savory ground pork filling, accompanied by an assortment of yam chips, Vietnamese ham, shrimp green bean cake, and bean sprouts. My better half opted for the Rice dish complemented by a BBQ Cornish Hen and Pho Dac Biet. While the flavors were undoubtedly rich and satisfying, I cannot help but attribute their exceptional taste to the liberal use of monosodium glutamate in every dish, barring the sandwiches. In point of fact, the MSG content was so high that it induced a throbbing headache that lasted throughout the day, leaving me feeling parched and discomforted.

"Today, my expectations were not met with regards to the flavor profile of the chai tea latte that I consumed, as it lacked the robust and nuanced characteristics that I have come to associate with this particular beverage; specifically, the taste was diluted and unpleasantly watery, which made it difficult for me to even consume half of it, ultimately leading me to discard the remainder, much to my disappointment."
Today I just didn't like the chai tea latte...tasted watered down...didn't even drink half if it had to throw it out, just tasted gross

"Their prices convey an air of exclusivity, as if they are the sole purveyors of gastronomical delights within the vicinity. The cost of their culinary offerings, however, borders on the exorbitant - a whopping $49.00 for a meal suitable for a child and two adults, while the beverages, a $5 Guinness and a metered pour of $4 Pinot Grigio, though not unreasonably priced, pale in comparison to the extravagant expense of the food. Furthermore, the presentation of the salad, served in a humble styrofoam takeout container with plastic cutlery, serves as a harbinger of the premium one must pay for a second helping, while the diminutive size of the salad dressing container portends a substantial fee for an additional serving. Notwithstanding the quality of the salad and its accompaniments, including the gristly chicken and satisfactory bacon, the utilization of a pizza sheet and genuine tableware for my spouse's Stromboli, and the pedestrian nature of the cheese pizza procured by my daughter, the extended delay between the arrival of our beverages (approximately 15-20 minutes) and the subsequent delivery of our fare (an additional 15-20 minutes) only serves to further underscore the need for more appropriate pricing and a greater attention to detail regarding the presentation of their cuisine. A more judicious approach to pricing, coupled with a commitment to employing authentic dinnerware, would greatly enhance the overall dining experience at this establishment."

They are priced like they know they're the only game in town. The food is too expensive - $49.00 for a child and two adults, my husband had a $5 Guinness and I had a metered pour of $4 Pinot Grigio, not bad prices, then came the food. They served  my salad in a styrofoam takeout container with plastic cutlery, the miniature size of the salad dressing container was warning enough that a steep price would be paid for a second. It was a good salad and dressing the chicken I got on top had a lot of \"gristle\" , the bacon was fine. My husband got Stromboli , ordinary but good, he got a real fork and knife and was served on a pizza sheet. Daughter got a cheese pizza.   It was 15 to 20 mins before our drinks came about 15 to 20 more for food. I really wish the place had actual dinnerware and was more appropriately priced, the bar is a great addition.

"While the cost was reasonable and the serving sizes were generous, the culinary experience was somewhat underwhelming. All of the dishes were priced below $10, which was certainly a welcome aspect; however, the dishes themselves were rather unremarkable and lacking in variety. Essentially, what was provided was a bowl of noodles accompanied by a sparse amount of vegetables and meat. While it may satisfy one's hunger and budgetary constraints, those seeking a more satisfying and flavorful Asian dining experience would be advised to explore alternative options."

Worth the money, but not too great.  All of the dishes were less than 10 dollars, and the portions are really big.  However, what you get is basically a bowl of noodles with very few vegetables and meat.  If you're looking for a cheap, filling meal this is a great place.  If you want good Asian food, look elsewhere.

I ordered Take-Out.  I got the Masaman Curry with Tofu & Vegetables.. it was okay.  Not very note-worthy, but not horrible.  I wish I had gotten it for lunch, it would have been cheaper and would have come with more stuff.  I would return for lunch in or take-out to give them another try.

"Dave's Canine Culinary Establishment fabricates exquisite, delectable, gourmet hot dogs, boasting an exceptional, East Coast-style bun, characterized by its robust, yet pliable texture, reminiscent of a slice of hearty, artisanal bread. The sausages themselves are of superior quality, brimming with rich, bold flavors, and offered at a reasonable tariff. Although the fries are somewhat unremarkable, they remain a palatable accompaniment to the primary dish. Following their relocation to a site proximate to the Gammage Parkway loop, accessibility to the eatery during academic hours has become somewhat more arduous for students situated on Mill Avenue. Nonetheless, Dave's Dog House maintains a distinct advantage over its competitors in terms of the superiority of its canine cuisine."

LAX Nightclub within the Luxor Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nevada, fails to rank among my preferred nightlife venues in the city, primarily due to its unremarkable ambiance and lackluster experience, despite its reputation as a popular destination for nocturnal revelers. My visit to the club took place on a Wednesday evening, and although the crowd was sizable, it did not detract from the pervasive feeling of monotony that characterized my time there. Notwithstanding, our cocktail waitress in the VIP section exhibited exceptional dedication to ensuring the satisfaction of our group's needs, which constituted a welcome departure from the overall mediocrity of the establishment. Furthermore, I noted that LAX features a mezzanine area for certain VIP booths, offering an additional degree of exclusivity to those willing to pay the premium price. However, this arrangement proved problematic when two disparate groups occupied the same booth, leading to an uncomfortable confrontation that the security personnel endeavored to resolve by partitioning the space with a couch. The DJ's performance was merely adequate, eliciting only a middling response from the audience. In conclusion, while I might consider returning to LAX under extraordinary circumstances, it does not constitute my top choice for nightlife entertainment in Las Vegas.

Not my favorite club in Vegas. But after a while, every club is really the same. Came on a Wednesday night. Good crowd. Our cocktail waitress in VIP was very helpful and attentive to everyone's needs in our party. I like that LAX has a mezzanine area for some of the VIP booths, but every VIP booth houses two different parties which can prove to be problematic if the two parties conflict (which happened to us). The security attempted to remedy this by dividing the booth with one of the couches. The DJ was ok. I guess I would come back if I absolutely had to.

"My sentiments regarding the culinary offerings at this establishment are somewhat ambivalent, as the fare provided was merely ordinary and unremarkable. 

The eatery itself was unexceptional in numerous aspects, serving two lunch boxes containing an abundance of meat, including a portion of stir-fried rice accompanied by an additional helping of meat. While the price was modest and the convenience of delivery was appreciated, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled. Specifically, the chicken with broccoli was underwhelming, as the poultry did not possess the characteristic flavor and texture associated with high-quality chicken, but rather seemed to be a inferior, diluted version thereof. 

Notwithstanding my reservations, I would consider patronizing this restaurant again in the future, primarily due to my parsimonious nature and inclination towards convenience."

I really don't know what to say about the food except it's very average. 

This restaurant was solidly average in many ways.  I got two lunch boxes (which consisted of meat, meat, meat and a side of stir fried rice...with meat). Besides the fact that it was super cheap and they conveniently deliver, I don't think I was satisfied.  The chicken with broccoli killed it for me, the chicken didn't taste like chicken...but like a lesser, mediocre version of chicken.  

I'd definitely give this place another go because I'm cheap and lazy.

I was so hoping I'd love Port of Subs because they have so many locations in Vegas but I concluded it's only OK.  The service was good.  Helpful cashier and quick sandwich maker but the product ... meats and cheese were freshly sliced and tasty but the bread wasn't as substantial and wasn't as tasty as some other sandwich shops.  The prices are good but not so good as to overcome the feeling that you're missing out by not spending a bit more across the street.

Food was the best part.  I would have given a 4 if the service was a little more engaging.  Then I went to the bathrooms (gross) and had to drop to 3 stars...  Nice to have a free miso soup, iceberg salad and fresh fruit at the end of the meal.  Has the potential for 4 to 5 stars...!

Nice store, seems a bit outside my usual area of town for shopping, but found myself over this side today, so I stopped in for a few items.
