The margaritas we had were great.  Try them on the rocks or frozen--doesn't really matter.  I was pretty surprised to be honest, as they just make huge batches of the stuff and pump it out en masse. 

The food wasn't anything spectacular, but you most certainly could do worse on the strip for your money.  You are really paying for the atmosphere here.  Everything is tacky and very Vegas, but that's why you are there in the first place.

Definitely would go again, just nothing incredible or mind-blowing in my book.

I actually visited the original location in DC Ranch. I stopped here with some friends for a late night snack and drinks. This was my first time here so one of the guys ordered a couple of Tootsie Rolls for the 4 of us (well 3 of us since my boyfriend doesn't like sushi) and a Berry White martini (It's blue) and it was fantastic. Don't remember what was in the Toostie Roll, sorry, but I love sushi so I usually just inhale it, but it was good too. There's a cool sleek vibe to this place.

"This specific Target store embodies the quintessential attributes of a typical Target location, possessing an unremarkable quality that renders it indistinguishable from others of its kind, with the sole exception being the presence of hybrid car charging stations in its parking area, which serves as a minor distinguishing feature that sets it apart from other Target locations, albeit marginally."

This specific site is characterized by a high level of activity and traffic, which is indicative of its popularity and appeal to a diverse range of patrons seeking convenient and satisfying dining options. Notably, it offers an advantageous promotion on the iconic Big Mac sandwich, which is a significant draw for customers seeking a substantial and gratifying meal at a reasonable price. Furthermore, the speed and efficiency with which this establishment provides its culinary offerings make it an ideal choice for busy parents seeking nourishing fare for their children while on the go.
This location is quite busy. Had a good deal on Big Mac's. Quick and easy food to pick up for the kids on the go ...

"I experienced an immense sense of disillusionment, which persists to this day. My anticipation for an exceptional culinary experience at this establishment was utterly unfulfilled, despite my initial enthusiasm. While I do appreciate the aesthetically pleasing ambiance and the friendly demeanor of the staff, my expectations for a superior quality of cuisine were sadly unmet. However, I would consider returning in the future, contingent upon the availability of dining options and my curiosity regarding their bread offerings, which demonstrated a notable level of taste and texture."

I was so disappointed. I'm still disappointed. This place was supposed to be the best Italian food ever and quite frankly it wasn't. I like the layout of the place, its beautiful and the people that work here are awesome, but my expectations were so high for the food to be so low. I would come back though. I dont know when since there are so many other restaurants to try in LV, but if this was one of the only places open on a certain day then yes count me in. I don't even remember what I ordered. THAT is a bad sign. Their bread was tasty though.

"Satisfactory experience overall, with a few notable exceptions - specifically, the presence of burnt garlic in the sag paneer was particularly unpleasant and detracted significantly from the dish's overall quality. However, the naan bread was quite good and the mango lassi was exceptional. 

Furthermore, the signage on the entrance regarding the availability of alcoholic beverages was somewhat perplexing, as it gave the impression that the establishment only offered beer and wine, whereas in reality, patrons are permitted to bring their own alcoholic beverages, albeit limited to beer and wine. 

Aesthetically, the interior design and ambiance were pleasing and well-appointed."

Okay overall - nasty burnt garlic in sag paneer (big points off) but naan was good.  Mango lassi was great.  

The sign on the door about beer & wine was confusing - I thought it meant they had only beer & wine and no cocktails.  But it actually means there is no alcohol - you can bring your own, but only beer and wine.  

The decor is very nice.

"I had the pleasure of partaking in a culinary excursion to Shoku Ramn approximately three weeks ago, at which time I opted to sample their tonkotsu ramen and potstickers. While the latter was quite satisfactory, with a delightful crunchiness that was enhanced by a subtle charring, the former left much to be desired. Specifically, the broth was excessively saline, rendering it difficult to discern any other flavors, and the noodles were unfortunately overcooked, resulting in an unpleasant mushiness upon biting. Such issues notwithstanding, I might consider returning to Shoku Ramn in the future if I found myself in close proximity and experiencing a strong desire for sustenance, but I would not venture out of my way specifically to dine there again."

Went to shoku ramn about 3 weeks ago. I ordered the tonkotsu ramen and the potstickers. the potstickers were good they were slightly burnt thats usually how i like it. its a lot crunchier when you bite into them. the ramen...now the ramen needs work the broth was extremely salty and the noodles were way too overcooked. basically when you bit into the noodles it was mushy. i definitely did not like that. i felt like the broth was so overly seasoned i couldnt taste anything but salt. i wouldnt go back to shoku unless i was really hungry and i was extremely close to it. i wouldnt drive out my way to go eat there again.

"The prices are somewhat prohibitive, however, the quality of the culinary offerings and the ambient surroundings justify the expense. The portions, albeit diminutive in size, are artfully arranged and presented, thereby enhancing the gastronomical experience. The interior design is visually stunning, creating an atmosphere conducive to relaxation and enjoyment. The ahi tuna dish is particularly noteworthy, its flavors and textures coalescing in a manner that elevates it to a position of prominence among the menu options. Regrettably, I was unable to partake in the establishment's mixological offerings, a deficiency that I hope to rectify at some point in the future."

A truly exceptional and indulgent spa pedicure experience that not only elevated my day but also enhanced my entire week, characterized by a pristine and welcoming ambiance, albeit with a pressing need for upgraded massage chairs, which did not, however, deter me from thoroughly enjoying the treatment and enthusiastically returning for future appointments, irrespective of whether the aforementioned chairs are replaced or not.
A very nice spa pedicure that made my day!  Heck, my week!  They are clean and friendly but need new massage chairs.  Will definitely go back again and again, new chairs or not!

"I patronized this establishment with the intention of partaking in their happy hour offerings, accompanied by a acquaintance whom I had arranged to meet here. Upon arriving 20 minutes prior to the appointed time, I opted to procure a beverage and engage in a game of Draw Something on my mobile device while awaiting the arrival of my companion at a table situated proximate to the bar. Despite my anticipation of expedient service, it took a considerable amount of time, specifically 15 minutes, for a staff member to extend a greeting and inquire about my desire for sustenance or potables. The delay was somewhat perplexing and unexpected, given my previous experiences at this venue. Following this initial hiccup, the service was generally satisfactory. I sampled their happy hour wine, specifically a Cabernet, while my associate selected a Sam Adams. We both opted for the culinary delights offered during happy hour, with my companion choosing the blackened fish tacos and myself selecting the chicken and shrimp lettuce cups. While they were indeed flavorful, the dishes were also rather greasy, which rendered them somewhat challenging to consume due to the excessive moisture. However, I have previously enjoyed the fare served here, so this minor drawback did not significantly detract from my overall satisfaction. In conclusion, I would still consider visiting this establishment again in the future, perhaps to indulge in their flatbread or sushi offerings."

Came here to meet a friend for happy hour today.  I arrived 20 minutes early so thought I'd grab a drink and play Draw Something on my phone while I wait at a table by the bar.  I normally experience prompt service here, but it took someone 15 minutes to say, \"Hi, can I get you something?\"  It was a bit strange to wait so long for someone to come by.  \n\nAfter that the service was good.  I had their happy hour wine Cabernet and my friend had a Sam Adams.  She got the blackened fish tacos and I got the chicken and shrimp lettuce cups.  They were very good, but greasy.  I wasn't sure what was causing the grease, but it made my lettuce cups rip easily.  I normally like the food here, so it wasn't the biggest deal.  They were very tasty, just hard to eat.  I would come here again and get the flat bread and sushi!

I am not the biggest fan of fast food ever. But I really like Five Guys and this location is superb! 

They have really yummy fries and they give you so many! Like your bag overflows with the greasy buggers. Say what? Yeah they are really greasy. But good!

The burgers are really quite the bang for your buck too! Not the best burgers in the world but it is fast food not gourmet burgers. Be considerate for what you are eating and enjoy it for what it is. 

The pop machines are radical. You can pretty much have flavoured any beverage you like. 

The staff here is really friendly and that is a plus anywhere you go!

I love the food at Noodles. Always delicious, portions are faily large, selection is great. The service leaves a bit to be desired. The last time I was in, there were approximately three occupied tables in the dining room. Every single other table, aside from one small 2 seat table had dishes and food left on them waiting to bussed. We had to ask to have a table cleared for us before we could sit down. Maybe if the restaurant had been busy at the time, it would be a bit more understandable, but the place was dead.

I came here around 8:40pm on a monday night and there were around 3 parties already there. I went to the bathroom before sitting down and, low and behold, there was a humungous cockroach staring back at me while I was peeing! Ew

My friend and I both got the AYCE dinner for $22.95 and the appetizer labeled "THE SHIT! must try," which was more shitty than the shit in my opinion. My friend really liked it though. We also got the 2-for-1 sapporo deal, which was pretty awesome because we got 2 huge bottles that was enough to fill 4 cups. 

The sashimi salad was hooked up with sashimi, which is good because I don't like eating a bunch of rice at AYCE places, as it gets me unnecessarily full. I also ordered salmon, yellowtail, and albacore sashimi, which all tasted pretty fresh, but definitely not the best fish. Really thin slices too. The sashimi roll was good too, stuffed with assorted raw fish and rapped in cucumber (no rice). My friend ordered a spicy crab roll (basically a california roll but with spicy crab), monster roll, baked lobster roll, and baked scallop roll, which were all pretty good. 

This place kinda smelled like clorox, but it wasn't anything too overbearing.

I cannot express an excessive amount of dissatisfaction with this establishment, primarily due to the fact that my stay was complimentary, courtesy of my platinum player status. Although the hotel's age and lack of modernity may have contributed to its relatively low level of appeal, I did not find it particularly bothersome during my brief period of occupancy. However, I must admit that certain aspects of the service left much to be desired, specifically the housekeeping staff's tendency to disregard our explicit requests for privacy by entering our room unannounced, even when the 'do not disturb' sign was prominently displayed. This particular incident occurred in the early afternoon, when my companion and I were attempting to take a brief nap, and the sudden intrusion left me feeling understandably uneasy. Furthermore, I must caution potential guests against the inconvenience caused by the live music performances that take place on the strip side of the hotel, which can be heard throughout the day and late into the night. Specifically, the band responsible for these musical offerings possesses a questionable level of talent, and their prolonged sets can prove to be particularly grating on the nerves, especially for those seeking a peaceful rest. In light of these factors, I would advise future visitors to exercise vigilance when booking their accommodations, particularly regarding the chapel hours, as my acquaintance discovered that the third-floor chapel was already closed by the time he attempted to utilize its services. Despite these drawbacks, I do not wish to discourage prospective guests from experiencing the hotel's amenities firsthand.

I seriously can't bitch too much about this place....it was Comp'd for being a Platinum Player. Of course this hotel is older and not as "hip and trendy" but for the little time it's used I honestly didn't mind it.
It was a little creepy though with house keeping...we had out "don't disturb" door hanged outside the door and it was around 3pm we were trying to quick-nap and she didn't even knock and just tried making her way in...I was like "No No Please leave" I was so hungover I couldn't really bitch but yeah total creeper haha

Also if you happen to stay on the strip side with a view HEADS UP!!! 

They have this shitty band that plays from 11am until 2am it's HORRIBLE and on the last day when I wanted to SLEEP I couldn't I seriously almost went to the local grocery store just to buy a few dozens of eggs and throw it at them (I know classy right) 
Anyhow overall not a super bad experience be cautious on their Chapel hours as well my buddy tried to marry some random and the chapel on the 3rd floor was already closed (not sure who lucked out on this one) but anyway Enjoy your stay :D

"Gastronomical indulgences of a rich and savory nature, ardently desired by yours truly, yet hampered by an excessive utilization of a particular staple, specifically the tortilla, which unfortunately diminishes the overall gustatory experience of the salad, rendering it less than satiating; furthermore, the beverage dispensary appears to be inadequately provisioned during the noontide repast, leading to an unfortunate dearth of hydrating options for patrons; lastly, the personnel responsible for facilitating the acquisition of sustenance during this peak period demonstrate commendable proficiency in expediting the process, albeit accompanied by an irksome delay of approximately twenty minutes, which serves only to exacerbate my personal dissatisfaction with the culinary experience as a whole."

"Hof Kelsten has recently joined the ranks of Mile End's plethora of boulangeries, and its entrance into the competitive landscape of Montreal's bustling bakery scene has been nothing short of remarkable. Indeed, the establishment's proprietor, Mr. Jeffrey Finkelstein, has managed to cultivate an impressive reputation among local gastronomes by virtue of his unwavering commitment to providing an array of delectable bread products to various esteemed eateries throughout the city, prior to branching out and catering to the needs of an eager public clientele. Hof Kelsten's culinary approach is deeply rooted in the rich traditions of Central European baking, with an emphasis on artisanal breads such as caraway rye, rugelach, and babka, among others. However, cognizant of the local palate's predilection for Gallic influences, the bakery also offers an assortment of quintessentially French loaves, including what this writer considers to be the most exceptional Montreal baguette currently available. Patrons may partake in a variety of savory meals during lunch and brunch hours, although this critic has elected to concentrate primarily on the baked goods, which, while occasionally marred by instances of undercooking, showcase an undeniable inventiveness and flair that sets them apart from the customary offerings ubiquitous in Montreal's bakeries."

Hof Kelsten is the latest addition to Mile End's boulangerie scene, and it instantly became recognized as a city-wide contender.  Baker/owner Jeffrey Finkelstein built up a reputation supplying many of Montreal's top restaurants with their bread before opening up to the public.  The approach leans towards Central Europe (caraway rye, rugelach, babka, etc.), but Hof Kelsten bakes some French loaves too (including my favourite Montreal baguette at the moment).  \n\nThey also serve meals (lunch, brunch), but so far I've stuck to the baked goods.  The pastries are generally good, and they're definitely refreshingly different from the kind of fare one tends to find in Montreal's bakery scene, but I've encountered problems with undercooked items from time to time, so now I just focus on their bread.

"The notion that one's financial expenditure directly correlates with the quality of services received is a fallacy that has been perpetuated by the hospitality industry for far too long. In point of fact, it is not uncommon for establishments to deny guests' requests for a later checkout time, despite the fact that such a request is both reasonable and nominal in nature. Indeed, it is precisely this type of inflexibility that can mar an otherwise satisfactory stay, as was the case during my recent visit to Las Vegas. Notwithstanding the fact that I have stayed at numerous hotels in the past, none of which have ever denied my request for a modest extension of checkout time, I was taken aback by the lady's refusal to accommodate my simple ask. It is worth noting, however, that the room itself was quite pleasant and modern, a fact that served only to heighten my sense of disappointment and frustration with the service I received."

An unpretentious, traditional watering hole offering libations, billiards, and a convivial atmosphere for socializing with companions. Unfortunately, the ambiance is somewhat marred by the presence of cigarette smoke, which permeates one's attire upon exiting the establishment. Nevertheless, this venue remains a popular gathering spot for a diverse clientele comprised of gay men of varying ages, body types, and interests, as well as their female counterparts who are fondly referred to as "fag hags." Despite its shortcomings, this bar serves as a suitable precursor to a nightclub visit, owing to its daily drink promotions. Moreover, its vintage charm evokes a sense of nostalgia reminiscent of Old Las Vegas.

I have been employed at Planet Hollywood for an extensive period, yet I had never had the opportunity to dine at this particular establishment until now. A recommendation from an acquaintance prompted us to explore the venue, as they boasted an assortment of meats that were allegedly quite delectable. Furthermore, the presence of a Groupon offer made the experience even more appealing. For the sum of $79, we availed ourselves of the all-you-can-eat surf and turf option, which encompassed an array of meat and seafood delicacies, including sirloin, lamb, and an assortment of seafood such as mussels, shrimp, salmon, and tilapia. The surf portion was presented on a separate plate, allowing us to sample each item individually. While some of the meats were slightly disappointing in terms of their texture, I found the shrimp and sirloin to be rather satisfying. The salad bar offered a diverse selection of vegetables and hot dishes, making it a well-rounded culinary experience.

As part of the package, we were also treated to an alcoholic beverage of our choice. I opted for a Chinahuia, which was expertly crafted with pineapple, lime, and tequila. Although it was not a terrible drink, it did not quite live up to my expectations. My companion, on the other hand, enjoyed a Rum Runner, which was generously poured and packed a potent punch.

In conclusion, while the restaurant offered an acceptable dining experience, I would still prefer to dine at Texas de Brasil, where the quality of the meat is superior. Our server, Marcile, provided attentive service despite the challenges posed by having a divided section. Despite some reservations based on unfavorable reviews, the actual experience was not as unpleasant as we had anticipated.

I have worked at planet Hollywood for years but have never been up here. Someone suggested that they had a pretty good variety of meats so we decided to give it a try since there was a groupon. So for 79$ you get all you can eat surf and turf( meat and seafood) the consisted everything from sirloin to lamb. Then the surf part which consist of mussels, shrimp salmon and tilapia? Comes on a separate plate. I can't rave too much on the food because some of the meats were quite dry but I did like the shrimp and sirloin. The salad bar was decent  with a variety of vegetables and hot dishes. 

So an alcoholic beverage is included in the deal, I got a chinahuia (sp?) with pineapple, lime and tequila. Not too bad; definitely my  kinda drink. The hunny had a rum runner and it was poured much heavier than my drink. 

So overall, it's an okay restaurant but for the same price I would go to texas de brasil. They have much better meat. Marcile was our server tonight and he was running around because his section was split, which I understand because I've worked in restaurants.  I was hesitant coming here because of all the bad reviews that I saw. But it wasn't as bad as anticipated.

Every time I've gone here, usually week nights, there's always an initial and pungent smell of vomit possibly from last nights lets-go-have-dinner-turn-crazy-night-on-the-town vibe I get from this place.

Once I overcame the smell and was seated from the strangely under-dressed hostess, our waiter came to get our order in an even stranger bandana jean look that was very curious.

We started with the pretzel Gouda fondue appetizer.  Very gooey and delicious as expected, maybe too much salt, but gooey and delicious.  He had the salmon and I tried the French Dip.  The salmon was delicious and none was left on the plate.  I'm a sucker for French Dips, the one's that melt in your mouth and have a great au jus.  I was sadly disappointed here.  To start, a strange mayo based dressing is applied liberally giving the, what I would assume is the most tender and juicy, roast beef a strange creamy taste and texture that is not pleasant.  The au jus is a strong french onion soup that does not go well with the sandwich. 

Overall I felt the place tries too hard to be different, too hard to be the cool place in town.  The food was a 4 (the salmon was truly excellent), the environment was a 2...I split the difference.

After perusing the critiques and hailing from the Eastern Seaboard, we felt compelled to sample In-N-Out Burger during our recent sojourn to Las Vegas. I must admit that while the culinary offeringings were satisfactory, the frenzied zeal with which patrons endorsed this establishment struck me as somewhat perplexing. It appeared to be a run-of-the-mill fast food chain, albeit with an emphasis on expediency and perhaps a tad unrefined in its presentation.

Upon placing our order at the drive-thru window, the attendant inquired as to whether we desired ketchup, to which we replied in the negative. His subsequent prolonged gaze of incredulity was quite amusing, as if we had just revealed that we were extraterrestrial beings unfamiliar with this staple condiment. Evidently, he held a deep affection for ketchup, for his countenance conveyed a sense of utter disbelief.

While I would recommend In-N-Out Burger to those who have yet to indulge, I would caution against going to extraordinary lengths to partake in their offerings. A hamburger, by any other name, remains simply a hamburger.

After reading the reviews (and being from the East Coast), we needed to try In-N-Out Burger on our recent trip to Vegas.

I will give it to you guys - it's a good burger, but people seem to go insane for these things!! LOL. Fries are good too. An average fast food chain. Quick and dirty - more emphasis on the 'dirty'.

A note to the guy at the Drive-Thru Window: when you ask someone if they want ketchup, and, they reply 'no thank-you' - DO NOT stare at them blankly for 10 seconds like they're from another planet.  I guess you really like ketchup - don't you buddy - LMAO!!

If you've never tried, go for it, but, don't go too far out of your way. A hamburger is a hamburger......

i found this place on yelp just went there for dinner ordered chow mein and thai tea.thai tea is absolutely great.this is the best thai tea I had.but disappointed on chow mein... its different type of chow mein than other thai restaurant.its just a Little thin than lo mein.(the fat noodle)\nfood was good EXCept too saltY.  service was alright.will come back try pad thai sometime and definitely will get thai tea too go A lot since im just 5min away from them.

A great place to cut your teeth if you've never tried Thai before (although I can't imagine many people not having tried something). This place seems to trying to sway you towards a buffet rather than giving you things straight off the menu. My waitress seemed very adamant that we give that a try, almost like her life depended on it.\n\nI understood as soon as I got the bill, \u00a321 a head. The buffet was good, but I certainly didn't eat \u00a321 worth.

Not great but not terrible. Just run-of-the-mill quality food at typical prices. The food isn't bad tasting, but it surely isn't the highest quality. On the flip side, it isn't trying to be. Egg Works embraces its mediocrity and prices appropriately.\n\nI will almost definitely eat here again because eating eggs is surely healthier than being lazy and eating donuts, for example, but the food is just okay, and the 3-star is labeled \"A-OK\" by Yelp! so that must be the one I have to pick.

"While it may not be the optimal dining establishment, it is by no means the worst. One drawback is that they do not publicize their special offerings, yet they are of satisfactory quality. The prime rib unlimited, which has since been discontinued, was a culinary masterpiece worthy of high praise. Its removal from the menu has led to my reluctance to return. Upon further examination, the cost did not align with the gustatory experience provided. Ultimately, it falls within the same category as Denny's."

"The culinary offerings presented at the midday repast were merely adequate, lacking the gastronomic excellence that one might anticipate from such an establishment, despite a diverse array of options."
Really average food in buffet for lunch. It was a good selection but food was a little less than I would expect.

i cannot belive this place has not been reviewed this is a smalltown cafe with great and some times tweeky service not bad service just tweeky help but the breakfast here are very  good standard breakfast fair the interior is old cowboy john wayne/gene aughtrey kind of kitch fun breakfast place

I need to per-qualify this rating by saying that I'm rating this off one dish. Unlike other posts here our server was very respectful and nice.  OK, let's get to it. I had the chicken Madeira. I cook a fabulous chicken Madeira but when I go to a classy place such as this I expect to be wowed. The anticipation was great as the build up came from the surroundings of such a modern restaurant with a very balanced darkness which completed the experience with atmosphere lighting.  You certainly felt upscale. Seeing the rest of my party being served certainly had an impact as their orders were very visually appealing. However, when I was served I found their chicken Madeira leaves a lot to be desired. It was definitely  a let down from first sight which unfortunately continued until the last uneventful bite.  The sauce was bland and not seasoned at all and carried none of the tastes you would expect from such a dynamic dish. While the sauce required more flavor for sure, the three chicken pieces I received were so small I almost laugh out loud, but managed to keep it under my breath. The only thing salvageable were the homemade French fries which I'm convinced you can't really mess that up having deep fried many homemade fries myself.  Didn't justify the $17.00 charge.. no way.    Just saying... stay clear of this dish...

"It must be conceded that my initial acquaintance with the Krispy Kreme phenomenon transpired approximately a decade ago in Canada, and I must admit that the ardent assurances of my unwavering fondness for these confectionaries struck me as somewhat dubious. Nonetheless, upon receiving an abundance of said doughnuts from a magnanimous colleague hailing from Edinburgh, I must confess that their delectability was rather impressive. The team's collective enthusiasm for the sugary bounty was palpable, and it became apparent that the Krispy Kreme craze had indeed permeated our workplace in diverse, saccharine, and deep-fried forms. However, despite the munificence of the complimentary pastries and the ensuing euphoria, I cannot help but harbor reservations regarding the necessity of such copious amounts of sugar and grease. Furthermore, I am compelled to ponder whether we have, in some manner, reverted to the early 1990s. Consequently, I shall assign three stars in recognition of their gustatory appeal, but that is the extent of my endorsement."

"It is our profound consternation that the culinary experience at this establishment did not meet our expectations, as the server appeared to be preoccupied with an array of tasks, thereby compromising their ability to provide adequate attention to our needs. Furthermore, the gustatory delight of the comestibles did not conform to our standards, specifically the Steak Gorgonzola and the Pappardelle Pescatore, which lacked the pictorial representation and emitted a dubious odor reminiscent of marine products. Additionally, the Northern Tour of Italy and the accompanying salad were found wanting in terms of dressing, leading us to speculate that the serving staff may have been parsimonious in its distribution. The calamari, too, was devoid of flavor, and our request for supplementary lemon was unfortunately ignored. Lastly, the novel iteration of Italian-style buffalo wings was observed to possess an unpleasant aridity. Notwithstanding, our steadfast loyalty to this eatery remains unwavering, as we have frequented this establishment bimonthly and have customarily enjoyed superior cuisine and hospitality. Perhaps this visit can be attributed to an anomalous day."

Eh, the server seemed too busy to actually take care of our needs. The food was kind of dry. I ordered the Steak Gorgonzola and the pasta was dry. We also ordered the Pappardelle Pesctore. Didn't look anything like the picture and was very \"fishy\" smelling. The Norther Tour of Italy was OK too. The salad was also lacking in dressing, like it was coming out of the servers pockets! The calamari was also bland tasting. We asked for more lemon for the calamari but didn't get it toward the end. The \"new\" Italian style buffalo wings was dry. Why a three, because we are loyal Olive Garden people! We come here once every other month and normally we\nget EXCELLENT FOOD AND SERVICE. Maybe it was an off day?

Nice place to eat on the cheap.  You'll get full or drunk off of what they have to offer for sure.  I believe they still provide free donuts and coffee for gamers in the early mornings.  This place is really old but why not try your luck?

Good food but sloooooooooow!
To start- we weren't seated until 20 minutes after our reservation time.  The waiting area/bar is tiny so there really isn't anywhere to wait- but in the pathway of people coming and going. 

When we were seated our waitress was also the hostess- I think it's time for them to get a dedicated hostess (along with about 3 more servers for the restaurant).  She was friendly and explained the menu to us.  We got mussels to start- they were delicious.  They were smaller (which I prefer) and the white wine sauce was great.  I would have preferred bread to the French fries but the server had told us the fries we out of this world- but they aren't; they are actually a little soggy.  The mussels were good enough though that I can overlook the fries.  
I had the special- bouillabaisse for my entrée- it came out piping hot (which I appreciate) and was loaded with delicious seafood and had a thick saffron sauce.  It was pretty awesome.
My husband had the brie stuffed chicken.  He said it was OK but not great.  
Overall I was very impressed with the food- but the dinner for 2 with app and entrée only lasted 2 hours!  If I came back it would have to be during the week and I would never consider going here with a group.  They definitely need more people working so that they can get more people in to eat the delicious food!

We had the pleasure of indulging in a delectable culinary escapade, yet the gastronomical offerings were merely satisfactory. Nonetheless, the establishment presented an array of enticing mixed drinks at a discounted price point during the hours of 3-6 pm, which we found to be quite appealing. It is our sincere desire that we had opted for an earlier dining time, as it would have enabled us to partake in the full scope of epicurean delights available.
We had a great dining experience, however the food was just average. Great cocktail specials from 3-6pm! Wish we would have gone for an earlier dinner.

This was my first time here. We sat in the bar and caught the tail end of happy hour. 
Apparently that have complementary hors d'oeuvres, although I did not have any. 
We had a few cocktails and ordered some Salmon and Yellow tail sashimi and nigri. I love good salmon and I must say their salmon is pretty good. The Yellow tail sashimi was cut too thick for my liking. 
My biggest complaint was the smell of the restaurant. It smelled like a mix of disinfectant and cheap cologne. It was really strong and made me a little sick to my stomach...

Golden Phoenix is the kind of place you visit when you want a decent, inexpensive lunch. The place is rarely full during the week, especially if you arrive closer to 11am, so be prepared to eat your meal while the (slightly creepy) waitstaff sits at a nearby empty table and watches you eat.  The food is nothing spectacular, but it's decent quality, flavorful (although \"very, very spicy\" is really closer to \"my tongue has a slight tingle\"), and dirt cheap.  Today I paid $16 and change before tip for myself and my friend, including soft drinks.  I'll keep coming back for the reasons I listed plus its close proximity to my office.  You can't beat a good deal!

I have made a couple visits over the years (I don't live in Champaign). Located along a major thoroughfare for the city and near campustown. The donuts are pretty good. Quick service. However, not all the donuts are in stock at a given time. I was just there and didn't even see glazed yeast donuts (the classic).- just glazed cake and the glazed minis. I appreciate having someplace to grab a snack with early morning Black Friday shopping.

"If you seek an establishment that offers a tangible representation of southern hospitality amidst the extravagant indulgences synonymous with Las Vegas, then this venue is worth considering. Located within the Treasure Island Hotel, this particular destination boasts an impressive array of amenities designed to cater to patrons who appreciate a more laid-back atmosphere reminiscent of the Deep South. Featuring a spacious dance floor illuminated by vibrant lights, the ambiance is further enhanced by the sounds of country music that permeate the space, creating an environment ideal for enthusiasts of line dancing and two-stepping. Moreover, for those who harbor a sense of adventure, there is a mechanical bull available for riders to test their mettle. However, be cognizant of the proficient skills exhibited by a specific blonde cowgirl, whose prowess on the bull may inspire awe in onlookers. Although the kitchen had closed by the time of our visit, the bartenders remained accommodating and friendly, ensuring that drinks were served promptly despite the modest crowd. Notably, the demographic comprising the majority of patrons appeared to be older, ranging from their late thirties to forties, although this did not detract from the enjoyment experienced by our group, which included ardent country music devotees."

I am compelled to frequent this establishment solely due to my associates' fondness for it, despite my personal reservations regarding the cost-effectiveness of the fare, with the exception of the pizza offerings, which provide a satisfactory value proposition. The alcoholic beverages, particularly the beer, are also reasonably priced, but the same cannot be said for the wine and other potables. While I do not particularly relish their brews owing to their robust and saccharine nature, this venue does boast a certain je ne sais quoi that makes it an agreeable choice for groups seeking a convivial atmosphere in which to partake in copious amounts of food and drink.

I come here just because my friends like it. The food is not bad, somewhat pricey - except the pizzas, which are a good value. Beer is also a good value, but wine and other drinks are not. I'm personally not a fan of their beer - I find it too heavy and sweet, but if you want to get a group and get happy, this place is clean, geared to please, and its dishes are easy to share.

I undertook an excursion to a novel ice cream establishment with my offspring, as they were eager to sample the wares of a previously unvisited venue. Upon arriving at the location, we encountered a duo of young females who were engaged in a state of hilarity, triggered by the presence of a male companion. Despite this initial setback, we opted to persevere and relish the frozen delicacies available. Following our consumption of the delectable treats, we concluded that a revisit may be feasible in the future.

"Fairly satisfactory, but I can conjure up alternative Mexican establishments that I might favor over this one. The hospitality at this venue was ATTENTIVE, yet somewhat unsystematic. I solicited three separate individuals to provide hydration for my companion and myself (we were the final members of our gathering to arrive), and we ultimately received a solitary water vessel. Nonetheless, they were prompt in delivering replenishments of triangular tortilla chips and savory dip, and they regularly checked in on us throughout the duration of the meal. The water vessels may have been an isolated occurrence, considering the large number of patrons and the fact that we didn't encounter any further difficulties with the service. \nThe culinary offerings were adequate, albeit slightly piquant for my taste buds. Indeed, I am aware that it is Mexican cuisine and that I possess a relatively low tolerance for spicy fare. Nevertheless, none of my dining companions appeared to be troubled, so it is worth considering that perspective. It did seem to sit somewhat lighter in my stomach compared to the majority of Mexican dishes, which was a welcome aspect. The margaritas were potent and a pitcher sufficed for the four of us."

Pretty good, but I can think of other Mexican places I prefer. The service here was ATTENTIVE but a bit disorganized. I asked 3 different people to bring water for hubby and I (we were the last in our group to arrive) and we wound up with one water glass. However, they were quick to bring refills of chips and salsa, and checked on us frequently throughout the meal. The water glasses may have been a fluke because it was a pretty crowded table and we didn't have any other issues with the service.\nThe food was decent, if a bit spicy for my taste. Yeah, I know it is Mexican and I'm a wimp. No one else seemed to mind, so take that with a grain of salt. It did seem to sit a bit lighter than most Mexican food, so that was good. The margaritas were STRONG and a pitcher was more than enough for the 4 of us.

"It was indeed surprising that no assembly was necessary, no specialized implements were required, and no essential components were absent from our culinary experience. Nonetheless, the value I would have anticipated from such an establishment was conspicuously lacking. To clarify, this refers to the upscale eatery situated upstairs, rather than the food kiosk located downstairs. The menu showcases a diverse array of options, encompassing wraps, salads, soups, and a hot tray line featuring an assortment of sweetish favorites. My spouse opted for a vegetarian wrap, which, due to the disorganization of the shelves and labels, nearly resembled a chicken wrap. While neither exceptional nor unpalatable, it was deemed satisfactory at a cost of $4. The smoked fish platter, priced at $7, boasted a generous helping of creamy horseradish sauce, varied greens, and a few beans, all complementing the flavorful smoked fish. A pleasant addition was the vegan sweet potato soup, available complimentary upon presentation of one's IKEA Family card. This resulted in a meal priced at $14 for the two of us, which, while not exorbitant, was consumed within a self-service furniture retailer. For individuals seeking mild cuisine in a child-friendly atmosphere with expansive views of furniture, this venue may prove to be their ideal destination."

"While the absence of an apostrophe may be perceived as a minor faux pas, the overall quality of this establishment's service remains uncompromised (albeit the consideration that patrons might crave sustenance subsequent to perusing the menu for an extended period during tea preparation appears to have been mislaid en route). The ambiance, characterized by a harmonious blend of agreeable decor and judicious utilization of natural light courtesy of the expansive windows fronting Frederick Street, contributes significantly to the venue's appeal. With regard to the culinary offerings and beverages, one would not encounter anything particularly innovative or unexpected within the confines of this eatery's menu; however, their execution, though not groundbreaking, is satisfactory. Absent from my assessment are the facilities' restrooms and edibles, precluding me from assigning a definitive rating of four stars, yet based on the available evidence, a subsequent visit would likely yield a favorable appraisal."

I visited this establishment today, feeling somewhat unenthusiastic about the experience that lay ahead. The venue had been selected by my associates, and I couldn't help but deliberate on the plethora of alternative, more contemporary eateries in close proximity. The ambiance of Cafe Grande appeared somewhat antiquated, and the menu offered a limited selection of traditional fare such as burgers and paninis, which failed to excite my gastronomic inclinations.

However, much to my surprise, my culinary expectations were surpassed by the delectable fishcake, albeit diminutive in size, which was complemented by an assortment of crispy chips and a paltry side salad. A subsequent cheese plate showcased an array of delectable Scottish cheeses, which further elevated my dining experience. Observing the diverse dessert offerings, I noticed that the banoffee pie garnered unanimous acclaim from my fellow diners.

Regrettably, not all menu items proved as satisfying as my own. Specifically, the soup and sandwich options struck me as lacking in both creativity and flavor, resembling rather bland, homemade creations. Furthermore, the bean burger arrived lonely and unimpressive, perched upon a plain bun.

In conclusion, while Cafe Grande may not be the most captivating or cutting-edge eatery, it does offer a passable dining experience for those already situated within the vicinity. However, I would not recommend venturing out of one's way specifically to partake in its offerings.

Today, upon my visit, I harbored a rather tepid sentiment. I ventured to this establishment to convene with clients, their selection rather contrasting my contemplations about the myriad of other contemporary venues strewn across this vicinity that could have potentially accommodated our gathering. Cafe Grande, in my perception, emanates a rather antiquated aura, its menu replete with offerings predominantly centered around burgers and paninis. 

 However, despite my initial reservations, I must concede to a rather satisfactory luncheon experience. The fishcake, albeit modest in portion, proved palatable alongside chips and a petite salad, while the cheeseplate that ensued boasted a selection of commendable Scottish cheeses. Amongst the array of desserts, the banoffee pie elicited enthusiastic commendation. 

 Yet, the panorama of lunch options didn't universally shine - the soup and sandwich combination appeared somewhat lackluster, evoking a sense of homemade familiarity, while the presentation of the beanburger on a plain bun seemed somewhat forlorn. 

 Thus, summarily speaking, an acceptable repast for those within the proximity, albeit not compelling enough to warrant a deliberate excursion beyond convenience.

The eyebrow threading used to be $8, but recently raised to $10--the typical price for threading around LV.  She does a good job not taking too much off and maintaining the natural shape of your brow.\n\nFacials are good here too, but they don't stay true to their coupon deals:  The usual facial is 1 hour full price.  My mom got a coupon for 50% off, but instead got 50% off of the time!  30 minutes for half the price = NO 50% DISCOUNT

I am just looking to my right... as I write and I just saw "better that Roscoes"... Not a chance...  But is good no doubt.  The problem is the chicken.  The chicken at Roscoe's is what one would describe as an addictive experience.  It's Crack... Once you have it you can quit.

Back to Lolo's.  Nice place.  An improvement over Roscoe's in terms of the place.  Very colorful and big jars of Kool-Aid.  The chicken and the waffles are good... That is if You have never been in LA and had roscoes.

The breading of the chicken is dry and different.  The waffles and the syrup are great.  Need to improve the chicken thing.  I sure will be back as is definitely better than some fast food chicken but it ain't no roscoe's.

Ok in case you are wondering about Roscoe's.

http://www.mixiaosblock.com/twin_cities_lunch/thats_some_darn_good_chicke.html

Just okay.  Service was good.  Beer was cold.  I'd prefer a good IPA though, which they didn't have.  

Food was just average.  Standard chicken wings.  Sandwich bread was a little stale, fries not very crisp.  Ho hum.  

Nice decor inside, and lots of televisions, so it's a good spot for a beer and a ballgame.  Wood smoke from the pizza oven creates a great aroma, so maybe a pizza is the way to go next time.

I unfortunately fell into the trap pf ordering chips and salsa first. Way too much food. But other than that, it was exactly what you would expect from a Mexican place. Big serves, as often happens in Mexican, and fresh ingredients. Nothing earth-shattering but reasonably priced. I would go back, next time I am in the area and in the mood for Mexican.

"My mother and I visited this establishment due to her unrelenting craving for sweets. Upon inquiring about the presence of caffeine in the coffee-flavored gelato, the young lady behind the counter responded with a dismissive attitude, stating that she was not aware of its contents as she did not participate in its preparation. We were taken aback by her response but decided to continue with our order, requesting a dairy-free option. The same individual demonstrated a lack of knowledge regarding the ingredients of their products, claiming that she did not possess the information we sought. Perplexed by her responses, my mother opted to seek a recommendation for a complementary flavor to pair with chocolate. Unfortunately, the employee's ignorance persisted, as she admitted that she did not consume the product and thus could not offer any insight. Despite the subpar customer service, the quality of the gelato was impressive, and the prices were reasonable. The banana flavor, in particular, was quite satisfying."

The food was average and everything is overpriced. My friend and I were playing video poker the whole time yet only 1 drink was comped. Kinda disappointed because I was hoping to find a good hole-in-the-wall Mexican joint with video poker.

UMM, can you say overrated? Either the people who rated highly of this buffet had not eaten at any other buffets in Vegas or they had a really off night when I came in!

THEY DEDICATE 1/4 OF THE BUFFET TO BREAD FOR GOODNESS SAKE! A $40 per person buffet that does this, really? The best thing I had here was the california roll and that was only because they used real crab meat in it! The service was also very good but that was because we sat at the bar. 

Can someone tell me what's so special about this buffet? If your response is prime rib, cold shrimp or crab, I have news for you  - EVERY BUFFET IN VEGAS OFFERS THESE ITEMS! & THEY WON'T CHARGE YOU $40 TO GET THEM!

Here are some buffets that definitely tops the Bellagio: #1 Rio Carnival World Buffet, #2 Rio Seafood Buffet, #3 Wynn Buffet!

Holy crap, people actually eat here?  The last several times I've been to this RA, I can gauge my level of intoxication between pretty buzzed to blackout-absolutely wasted.  As you can tell, neither I nor any of my compatriots make it a point to actually dine here, mainly drink.  That's right, awesome happy hour and on Sunday night it's Service Industry Night (aka happy hour on Sunday night).  The happy hour menu is pretty extensive with appetizers ranging from the standard california roll to gyoza, seafood dynamite, and coconut shrimp skewer things.  However, where RA truly shines is it's specials on alcohol.  Food may be ordered when the hunger arises concurrently with inebriation, but at that point it doesn't matter if it's just so-so or even sub-par (it's like having beer goggles, but for food, not chicks).  However, I can't give this place a complete crap rating because of all the wonderful drunken memories I've had here (the few times I actually remembered the outings/the first half of the outing).

Hubby and I came here with friends. We had been exploring Luxor with them and wanted food so T&T was suggested.

There is a great amount of options on the menu and we had difficulty in deciding just what to eat. It seems though that whatever you order is great as we all loved the food. The food was a solid 5 stars!

HOWEVER, the service. 2 stars. I had asked about the virgin margaritas, the waiter was snarky as he had supposedly read them out to someone else on the table. Had I heard him I wouldnt have asked. If hubby and I had been here alone then we would have told him to forget it and gone elsewhere seeing as his attitude was terrible. It seemed he just didnt want to be there at all. Not great for the restaurant at all.

If the service had been good then I think I would have been in a better position to give a great review opposed to just an ok.

a good tho not great buffet. peel n eat shrimp and the dessert variety were the standouts. prime rib not very good, but oh they do get an extra star for the tequila-infused watermelon, you could get drunk off that stuff. also rice krispy pops & candy apples. i would have liked to see more salad variety to at least create the illiusion that I was eating healthy but i did like that there was a wide array of breakfast options even at 2 pm. I would probably go back but then Aria and Paris have much better choices on their buffets, I would probably chose those over Wynn. Sorry Steve!

AAAAAA...Excalibur is in a great location.....We checked in on a Saturday and we had a rooom in the newly remodeled tower 2. So we get to our room and we notice something funny the door isnt shut all the way, We just push our door open and the room is all clean and ready to go but apparently something is wrong with the door and it won't shut all the way.So we call and they say we'll be moving next door. They bring the keys up and everythings all good , room was nice remodeled flat screen nice beds etc......But what do you know the next day the same thing happens with the door in our room it wont shut all the way. What a joke we call and the send someone up to fix it.Pool area is nice, windy  as hell why we were there. Walls are paper thin could hear the tramps next door discussing certain things. Check out time is 11 am which sucks when youve been out getting intoxicated the night before. We called down and they extended our checkout till 12...so generous ......so to sum it up stay here if you want some place cheap in a good loacation with ok rooms.

This buffet aligns itself more closely with the likes of Golden Corral and Hometown Buffet, rather than the more upscale offerings found on the Strip. We opted to partake in the brunch selection, which boasted an array of de rigueur items such as a salad bar, carving station, dessert bar, pizza, pasta, corn, mashed potatoes, roasted potatoes, green beans, fish dishes, sushi, and a smattering of Asian-inspired dishes, as well as an assortment of breads. While the menu may not have been particularly inventive or inspired, it did provide a satisfying and filling experience for a reasonable price, especially when compared to other establishments in the area. Furthermore, the wait time was minimal, making it an accessible option for those seeking a hearty meal without the burden of an extended delay. However, aficionados of fine cuisine may wish to explore alternative dining options.

Food was decent- nothing that blew us away. Rice on the sushi seemed soggy.  Service was so-so. We felt rushed, timing of food was bad, and staff wasn't as knowledgable on the menu as I would expect for a place that has a lot of hype in this area.

"The waitress exhibited a remarkable level of cordiality and proficiency in her customer service, which greatly enhanced our dining experience.  The steak boxty, a traditional Irish dish consisting of a thinly sliced steak wrapped in a boxty pancake, was not only delectable but also generously portioned, thereby rendering it a superlative value for the price.  Moreover, the pairing of this culinary delight with a frothy pint of Harp, an iconic Irish lager, proved to be an inspired choice that complemented the flavors of both the food and the beverage in a most harmonious manner."

I think Abuelos is very good for a chain Mexican food restaurant. They are pretty consistent with nice servers and decent food. I remember a time when there were huge lines out the door and hour long waits, but maybe that was in spring training season because the last time I visited, we got right in with a party of 6. I will go there again with out of town guests because they seem to love it but i prefer to frequent local establishments if I can.

I haven't had a chance to eat the food yet but I came on a night where there was a frat-party...I was a little skeptical about the age of the kids allowed in, during the frat party they did allow people who were underage in, and those who were of age wore wristbands...however that really didn't seem to stop kids from drinking; remove that and it was a fun atmosphere. They have beer pong, and the drinks are good. The design is really fun and alternative and my husband and I enjoyed watching the music videos, dancing around and having a few drinks.

Good for a hangover.  It's a little loud however.  I've thrown up in the bathroom many times, not due to the food.\n\nThe fries are thin and kind of disappointing.  The food is good.  Not spectacular. It's decent.  The specialty drinks are strong, and that's a plus.

I opted to visit this establishment for a haircut due to its proximity to my location and my urgent need for a trim.  I customarily request a conventional men's scissor cut, which is readily available at numerous salons, thus, I did not anticipate any significant divergence in the quality of service.  Upon entering the premises, I was greeted by a welcoming atmosphere and an accommodating staff, which facilitated a seamless and expedited process.  I was attended to promptly, and the stylist demonstrated a proficient and meticulous approach to her craft, ensuring a satisfactory outcome.  While the price point of $20 for a standard men's haircut may be slightly elevated in comparison to neighboring establishments, the value lies in the attentive and skilled service provided, rendering it a reasonable and worthwhile investment for an above-average hairdo.

I should start with the positives.. The food here is excellent. I have been here many times and the bruschetta is out of this world..the best I have ever had. The service is here is awful!! We went on a Friday night and even with 3 bartenders behind the bar  and a near empty bar, it was impossible to get service. They were very interested in talking to eachother though. They take empty glasses away without offering refills and when the food arrived I had to retrieve some silverware and plates since the bartender(s) didn't even acknowledge that we needed anything. No joke, it took almost 10 minutes to get the attention of that bartender to get another glass of wine or a beer.\nThe food is what keeps us going back and they do have a great happy hour with $5 glasses of wine. We will try the other location next time to see if the service is any better there.

My assessment is largely consistent with the general consensus expressed by others.

Good aspects include:

* The culinary offerings (once procured) were undoubtedly impressive, particularly the lobster and corn, which elicited a profoundly enthusiastic response. Additionally, the beverage named in honor of nobility, although forgotten, was indeed commendable.

* The menu boasted an array of diverse options, providing ample opportunities for exploration and discovery.

* The beverages, both alcoholic and non-alcoholic, were meticulously crafted and presented in abundance, complemented by an assortment of innovative weekly specials.

Conversely, the following drawbacks were observed:

* The quality of service was subpar, characterized by an excessive number of personnel clad in black attire, alongside two hostesses, which seemed disproportionate to the needs of the establishment. Moreover, the bartender demonstrated remarkable dedication to their duties, reminiscent of the cinematic portrayal of someone possessing exceptional skill or aptitude. However, management would benefit from addressing this discrepancy within the staff.

In conclusion, the eatery offered delectable cuisine, superlative drinks, yet was marred by deficient service.

Below are the daily drink specials:

Margarita Monday: Enjoy $3 off specialty margaritas from 7 p.m. until closing time.

Guys Night Out Tuesday: Relish 1/2 off whiskey, bourbon, and scotch from 7 p.m. until closing time.

Paper Bag Beer Special Wednesday: Savor a randomly selected beer encased in a paper bag for a mere $1 from 7 p.m. until closing time.

Ladies Night Thursday: Indulge in $3 off glasses of wine and $3 360 vodka drinks from 7 p.m. until closing time.

Fireball Friday: Partake in $2 shots of Fireball from 7 p.m. until closing time.

$10 Mimosa Carafes Saturday: Obtain a mimosa carafe for $10 between the hours of 11 a.m. and 3 p.m.

$10 Bloody Mary Carafes Sunday: Acquire a bloody mary carafe for $10 between the hours of 11 a.m. and 3 p.m.
"A culinary establishment offering authentic Italian cuisine in a pleasant ambiance with generous servings at an affordable cost, strategically positioned near the central plaza."

"Beneficial hospitality, somewhat antiquated accommodations, yet the cost-effective nature of the establishment renders it a profitable venture for families, particularly those accompanied by juveniles, who can capitalize on the convenience of connecting rooms."
Not the best burger by any means, but passale   Horrendous setup by the drink machine almost impossible to get by because it is so crowded and tiny aisle to go past

"Personnel exhibiting cordial demeanors and a predominantly youthful clientele characterize the establishment, with a palpable sense of urgency permeating the atmosphere, as though patrons are eager to engage in romantic or sexual liaisons. However, the subterranean section of the venue appears somewhat uninspired, lacking the vivacity and pizzazz that would encourage conviviality among the patronage. A designated dance area, devoid of any actual dancing, exists within this space, its absence of a mirrored sphere, illumination, or laser beams contributing to an overall dearth of ambiance. If the proprietors desire to foster an environment conducive to merriment and movement, they might consider investing in elements that would enhance the experience, such as suitable lighting and perhaps even a DJ spinning melodies that might entice revelers to sway in unison."

"Champaign constitutes a remarkable culinary destination, boasting an array of gastronomical establishments that cater to diverse tastes and preferences. However, within the realm of Middle Eastern cuisine, dining options are somewhat restricted, thereby rendering the presence of Holy Land Grill a veritable blessing. While the fare served at this eatery may not necessarily qualify as the most exceptional Middle Eastern cuisine I have had the pleasure of savoring, it undoubtedly possesses a certain je ne sais quoi that renders it quite palatable. During my recent visit, I relished the falafel and Greek salad, both of which proved to be delectable offerings. The hospitality displayed by the staff was similarly impressive, manifesting as attentive and cordial demeanor that greatly enhanced our dining experience. Notably, our meal commenced with the presentation of complimentary bottles of water, a gesture that, while seemingly incongruous and potentially wasteful, was nevertheless appreciated. Furthermore, the restaurant offers Mexican Coca-Cola, a beverage that, while unconventional, provided an intriguing diversion from the customary cola varieties. The baklava, adorned with a simple syrup, served as a satisfying conclusion to our repast. However, I cannot help but feel that presenting the baklava either plain or accompanied by a drizzle of honey would have yielded a more optimal outcome. One final observation: the absence of any melodic accompaniment during our dining experience struck me as somewhat curious, given that I have previously lamented the prevalence of excessively loud music in restaurants. In retrospect, the incorporation of some discreet Middle Eastern music would have contributed a pleasant ambiance to the setting. Notwithstanding these minor shortcomings, my dining experience at Holy Land Grill proved to be an enjoyable endeavor, and I look forward to returning in the near future."

The Golden Nugget buffet is under construction so we were able to use the buy-one-get-one-free coupons at Carson Street Cafe.  Sweet.

As a Golden Nugget guest, I loved that the Carson Street Cafe was located so close to the elevators.  After a long day walking up and down the Strip, it was nice to be able to grab a bite to eat and then head back to the room.

The food is decent.  I would recommend sticking to the basics.  My BLT was fine and the chicken in the Caesar salad was really tender and tasty.

The customer service varied from person to person but it did seem to be on the slow side overall.
A kind of cool place to get a drink and a snack. Pay with cash to avoid awkwardness. Don't go there for customer service.

Update: Too much of a good thing is a bad thing. For the last two months we were probably at BIg View twice a week. The service and food seemed to trail off during the holidays, and just after Christmas we were even sold extremely stale and old cookies from their bakery. Because of this we haven't been back in the New Year.\n\nPrevious Review: The hubby and I eat here about once a week. Have had a ton of things on the menu and everything has always tasted great. Breakfast plates, french toast, pancakes. Shrimp & grits, chicken souvlaki, spinach pastry, greek salad, crab cake. All tasty! And we love their bakery. The service is generally very friendly and on point. Don't recommend eating at the bar in view of the kitchen because it gets chaotic, but otherwise enjoy dining here. Definitely recommend.

This location was right across from the campus theater, and we were in the area for a show, so this was definitely a convenient spot.  We walked in and were seated right away and our drink orders were taken really quickly too.

It was a little rough in the middle of after drink orders, since it took about 15 minutes after that to have our orders taken and to get our drinks. The hostess ended up stopping by our table to take the order - which we guess was due to the fact that our waitress probably was a little overwhelmed. 

The food came out about 15 minutes after ordering and we had to eat quickly to ensure we didn't miss our show time. I had the Turkey Dinner and he had one of the pancake combos (the white chocolate raspberry I believe was the name). My turkey dinner was just okay.  The turkey was cut into small pieces, and definitely wasn't the long cut strips like it was in the picture on the menu (but it never is right?).  His pancakes were a good pick - the Egg Nog pancakes looked like they would have been a good pick, too!

I paid our ticket as soon as I was done eating so that we could take off as soon as my fiancee was done.  

Overall: B-
Service was good.  Food was okay - definitely an "A-OK" visit.

Was at the W last night for a Bachelorette Party.  Clearly, I don't get out much... well, at least not to hoity-toity Scottsdale spots... so I was floored by the ridiculous $16 drinks.  No, thanks! Water, please!  

The people-watching was topnotch.  The girl prancing around the lounge in her tiny turquoise bikini is still making me laugh... seriously - cover it up.  You are inside and the sun isn't shining!

The pretty waitresses that are all stuffed into teeny, tiny black dresses were very friendly and happily separated the check into smaller tabs for our large group.  

Certainly, the W is a good place to go and drop tons of money... and do some hilarious people-watching of the Scottsdale crowd... but it really isn't my thing.

I am subtracting two stars here based on an experience I had this week.  Was here for drinks on a Tuesday night, the place wasnt packed so my friend and I sat at the bar.  There were two bartenders but obviously their friends were at the bar and they had zero interest in serving anyone else.  It took 15 minutes to get the menu, the bartenders could not have been ruder!!!  When i asked for a beer they didnt have she threw the beer list at me and didnt come back for another 15 minutes.  It was probably some of the worst service I have seen in Charlotte!  Take some midol beotch!!!

We descended to the smorgasbord, as it was the most proximate venue to obtain a morning repast on a Sunday. The quality of the cuisine was satisfactory, given the convenience of merely stepping onto an elevator and having an array of delectable options presented before us. While we did not anticipate indulging in delicacies such as lobster or crab at 11:00 am, the selection included several savory cuts of meat, including prime rib.

The tariff, however, was somewhat prohibitive, amounting to $25 or more per person, which seemed exorbitant considering our origins in Chicago. Nevertheless, given the unique ambiance of Las Vegas, we might be inclined to return, provided we possessed either an insatiable appetite or an abundance of complimentary credits. Those who are financially unrestricted and desire a convenient dining experience may also find satisfaction here.

The Yard House, from my perspective, serves as an optimal venue for indulging in libations during the fleeting hours of happy hour, boasting an impressive array of artisanal brews that would daunt even the most discerning aficionado; however, their culinary offerings, while satisfactory, fail to surpass the plethora of superior gastronomic alternatives available within the immediate vicinity.

The Big Dogs on Sierra was closed, we always went there when we were in town at least twice for the beer and Nachos so we trekked over to the Draft house on Rancho.  Nachos were a disappointment compared to what we used to get.  The beer is good but we were sadly disappointed in our favorite nachos.

"While the culinary offerings at Bellagio's buffet are undeniably delectable, the exorbitant prices during peak hours make it challenging to justify the cost, especially considering the availability of comparable quality food at more affordable establishments. A reduction in price by half would likely elevate the buffet's rating to four stars, but as it stands, the premium charged does not align with the gastronomic experience provided. Ultimately, it is advisable to explore alternative dining options that offer similar quality at a lower price point, allowing you to allocate your financial resources more judiciously and potentially even indulge in a game of chance at the slot machines, where a fortunate outcome could result in a substantial windfall."

Close to my domicile, I have a predilection for visiting this establishment, as it affords me the opportunity to partake in their delectable vegetarian or supreme pizza, accompanied by a pitcher of refreshing cold beer and an assortment of mouthwatering chicken wings, all while reveling in the sporting atmosphere and observing the action on their multitude of televisions. Although the prices have increased somewhat and the culinary quality has diminished slightly, I still find the ambiance, hospitality, and takeout options to be quite appealing. A diverse array of pizzas is available, which serves as the primary draw for patrons, whereas the alternative fare caters to individuals seeking a modicum of variety in their dining experience.

"Love Grand Lux; their corned beef hash is of superior quality, indeed. However, an unfortunate incident occurred during our visit, as my companion discovered a hair in her fries. Nonetheless, the wait staff and manager addressed the situation with utmost professionalism, deducting the cost of the contaminated dish from our bill and offering profuse apologies. Notwithstanding this setback, their assortment of desserts remains truly exceptional."

"The reality is such that the hospitality extended by Tea Lite's staff is truly commendable, as they exhibit remarkable kindness and efficiency in serving patrons, and the culinary offerings are both wholesome and promptly prepared. Furthermore, the cost-to-quality ratio is quite favorable, making it an appealing choice for a nourishing repast. However, my reservation concerning their rating stems from the fact that their menu selections appear to be overly predictable and lacking in boldness, which may be attributed to the eatery's concentration on providing expedited lunches and a simplified menu. Specifically, the pho broth is conspicuously absent of tripe or tendon, and no alternative exists to incorporate these elements should a patron desire a more adventurous dining experience. While various seasoning options are available, they fail to provide the depth of flavor customarily associated with Vietnamese cuisine. It is conceivable that this dearth of variety stems from Tea Lite's emphasis on catering to the local demographic, yet I cannot help but feel a sense of disappointment when comparing it to its competitor in the vicinity. Despite this, I wholeheartedly endorse paying a visit to Tea Lite and expressing gratitude for their exceptional service, all the while politely requesting that certain ingredients be included in their phá»?so that, in the future, they might reassess their menu and warrant a higher rating."

"My dining experience at this establishment was predicated upon perusing a few rave reviews, and my expectations were elevated to encounter a culinary masterpiece. The fare served was indeed delectable, warranting four stars; however, the quality of service was subpar, meriting only two stars. An in-depth analysis of the factors contributing to this discrepancy revealed that the prolonged preparation time for a mere couple of pita sandwiches, in addition to the inaccurate fulfillment of our order, resulted in an unfortunate twenty-five minute delay. Furthermore, my companion was compelled to take their meal to go while I consumed mine, which further underscored the inefficiencies plaguing the service. While the cuisine undoubtedly boasts exceptional quality, it is imperative that the restaurant's staff address the deficiencies in their delivery and expedite their service to ensure a more seamless dining experience for patrons. Perhaps a strategically placed Yelp card or constructive feedback would effectively convey the message that, although the food is superb, enhancements in the realm of customer service are crucial to augment the overall satisfaction of their clientele."

Ive been here a handful of times and it is always packed and a good time for me.  We had a VIP table which always helps getting in and enjoying the time spent there. The DJ music was good to dance to, but the dance area is tight. They offer a platform pole where several women get up and dance on so that is fun to watch. This time the large private back room area was closed....renovations?! The private area last time is separated from the main area and offers private tables and dance areas for larger groups and a separate DJ.  Not a bad place to come with a group, but not so great for just a couple guys. There are better options in Vegas.

I bought the onion and mushroom poutine and a Montreal smoke meat sandwich.  The sandwich was very good.  The meat was warm and so moist.  Very good.  
The poutine was ok, I wish I bought something with bacon or something also meaty to enhance the flavour.  I did like the onion and mushroom though, but just thinking about the possibilities.

The weird thing is, maybe because I was in a hurry, I under tipped.  The waiter asked me if there was something wrong with the service but honestly there was nothing wrong with it but nothing exceptional either.  I happened to go early on a Saturday morning, right when the store opened.  So after I told him nothing was wrong, he informed me that in Montreal the tipping is 15%.  So he asked me for $1.50 more.  I felt embarassed because I wasn't paying attention and I just wanted to give him a flat $30 after eating $26 something. Maybe I am cheap.  Before entering, my brother and I wanted to see how much their poutine was, and already they were shouting at us that it was not opened yet.  So the food was good, but I'm not sure about the service.  I still gave it a chance after being shooed away.
one of the nicest view rooms ive stayed at nothing to go crazy over but liked how it was located right at the miricle mile shops
Good drink selection with some interesting cocktails and was pretty empty when I was there in the afternoon. I didn't try any food but it looked pretty good.

"The culinary delight that was the calamari, was utterly superb. The tacos, while certainly palatable, did not quite live up to the lofty expectations we had established in our minds. However, our server's amicable demeanor and penchant for humor, significantly augmented our dining experience. It is undoubtedly worthwhile to partake in this establishment's offerings."

It was a fun time and very much like the amazing race.  However, I was expecting more brain teasers that wouldn't be answered just by using a smart phone.  Must be in shape and ready to run if you actually want to win! They did forget to give the winners their 100 dollar gift certificate, but when brought up, the workers said they would mail it to them.

"A coterie of four individuals partook in a morning repast, whereupon two members of our group opted for the $5.99 steak and egg special, which encompassed a delectable array of house-fried potatoes and toast, while the remaining duo selected the veggie omelet, an edible masterpiece replete with an abundance of fresh vegetables, smothered in a layer of melted cheese, accompanied by potatoes and toast. Our culinary excursion concluded with a pecuniary outlay of less than $35, inclusive of gratuity and coffee. The quality of service we received was superlative, as our servers exhibited unwavering friendliness and provided copious refills of water and coffee. Encouraged by our previous day's experience, we revisited the establishment for an evening meal, during which two of us indulged in the penne al forno, a dish whose rich creaminess was nothing short of tantalizing. The remaining pair opted for burgers, the quality of which elicited no complaints whatsoever. The crowning glory of our gastronomical adventure lay in the $2.25 20 oz. beers, expertly brewed on the premises. Both the Hefe and Light varieties possessed an unparalleled smoothness, contributing to an overall sense of satisfaction. Our financial investment for five beers and four main courses tallied $45, an eminently reasonable sum given the proximity of the venue to the renowned Las Vegas Strip."

It's a small hole in the wall place that my boyfriends co worker told him about. We went for his birthday dinner . The place is small with a few booths and tables but clean. The service was good and we didn't have to wait long to get our food. They have happy hour all day everyday so the price is pretty good. The food was good but not great. I really like the baked salmon and baked  scallops and the fried tofu appetizer. Do not get the fried calamari! No flavor and it just tasted like tempura batter

I bought a Groupon for cut, all over color and style. The services I received were great, my stylist listened to what I wanted and delivered on my vision. The reason I am giving this experience 3 starts was due to the following two issues:\nThe stylist had my color mixed in her bowl and just as she started to do my hair she informed me that if she ran out of color and needed to mix a second bowl I would have to pay an additional $15. I was shocked and felt cornered as at that point I could not say no nor change what I wanted for my hair. I would not have had an issue if this was clearly explained to my either on my Groupon or when we first started talking about my hair. \nThe shirt I was wearing was ruined because my hair color bled through the robe. When I showed this to the stylist she spoke to her manager who just stated it should come out in the wash. I have not tried this yet but I double it will.

Going to  keep it simple. 
Pro's 
Atmosphere- very good job. TV's everywhere.  
Service-friendly-pretty ladies
Beer is definitely cold!
Menu is limited. We ordered a variety of stuff that came out ok(bar food).Portions, price ok . We had sandwiches which were fine and a Cobb Salad.  

Con's
For lasting power in an area with lots of bars and competition they need to cater to the locals-
- No Happy Hour
- limited menu
- No advertised food or drink specials
-Not open 24hrs
- Pricey for drinks
-UFC $10 per person- but they carry it.
