-limited wine menu-really not much at all and horrible selection.
-No pitchers of beer or bottles of wine for purchase.
-Football season will be interesting because all other places offer specials during the games. 
The splash is now since its new however, I'm confident someone will consider a few of the above. With that said it's worthy of a visit.

This review is long overdue! I honestly find myself at Miller's very often.... there is always someone at working promoting a happy hour and since Miller's is close to the office and convenient for most, we always end up here.  They always have drink specials and the beer selection is good. The food is ok, bar food and nothing that stands out as a must try item. There are lots of tv's to watch filled with the sports events of the day.  The staff can be hit or miss.... I have had excellent service here and then I have had some horrible service.\n\nBut when you have a great group of friends with you- you can always have a good time here!

Looking for old fashioned soul food? You have defiantly found the right place. The fried chicken and cornbread was really good. Lots of sides to choose from.\n\nThe service was good. Defiantly a good place for lunch if you are downtown!

I hope they fired the idiotic valet driver that almost ran me over just to beat a red light, and ended up smashing into another hotel guest's Hyundai. 

Disregarding the fact that they hired a psycho maniac driver, I can't complain too much about The Mirage. Rooms are offered at a decent price, but have been noticeably steeper than what they were in the past. The exotic gardens located at the main entrance make a great photo op. Every dining venue in this building is a tasteful experience and not one to be missed. I especially recommend Japonais, Kokomo, & Samba. And last, but not least, there's a considerable amount of tables scattered amongst the casino grounds. I've seen the basic black jack limits start from $5-15, so it's not a bad place to start off if you're a small gambler. It's a shame they don't pay out for quad aces in the poker room. I've hit some of my biggest winning  pots here, yet no extra cash for the rare obtainable hands. 

Based on a great location on the strip and being close to all the nearby hot spots, I'd recommend staying here. Just remember to look carefully before crossing the street...

What can I say about Panchos... its a buffet with lots of mediocre Mexican food. Upon first entering the strange multiple sectioned building with lots of loud colors on the walls, you must enter a cafeteria style line and pick what you would like. Here, you have all kinds of stuff to choose from: greasy chili rellenos (aka cheese sponges), several types of enchiladas, tamales, small chimichangas, flautas and taquitos, rice, beans, tacos, and tostadas. The cost is pretty reasonable for all the food you can get and if you like non authentic greasy Mexican food made with lots of trans fat, this might be an ok deal for you. Once seated, you can obtain more items from the buffet simply by raising a little flag at your table. I will admit, this might just be the best idea ever! You raise this flag and the waiters are standing at your table literally seconds later. If only all restaurants would get on board with this! All in all, Panchos is an alright spot for a large unhealthy meal. The service is always good thanks to the flag system and it actually seems like a fairly clean restaurant. Also, who can resist fresh hot sopapillas after your meal? I know I can't, which is why I reluctantly agree to go to Panchos when the hubby asks (he loves those cheese sponges).

This particular establishment, situated on the renowned Las Vegas Strip, purports to be an outlet of the ubiquitous coffee franchise, Starbucks; however, it must be noted that its authenticity is somewhat dubious, as it does not adhere to the standardized menu and pricing of a bona fide Starbucks location. Despite accepting the Starbucks gift card, this ostensible Starbucks also accepts Total Rewards cards, thereby betraying its true nature as an unaffiliated entity capitalizing on the brand's widespread recognition. Furthermore, a cursory examination of their offerings reveals a tendency to inflate prices egregiously, rendering the experience financially prohibitive for the average consumer. 
  My order, a passionfruit iced tea infused with a hint of strawberry, typically retails for a modest sum of approximately $2.85; yet, upon placing my order, I was taken aback by the exorbitant price quoted by the youthful server, a staggering amount approaching six dollars. Abiding by the adage "ignorance is bliss," I opted not to interrogate the staff regarding this anomaly and instead tendered my Starbucks card as payment, thus facilitating the procurement of my beverage. 
  The dimensions of this establishment are quite generous, affording ample space for patrons to indulge in their preferred beverages while availing themselves of the numerous electrical outlets provided. Additionally, a diverse array of items, including the customary "you are here" Vegas mugs, juices, and an assortment of sandwiches, are available for purchase. 
  In light of the aforementioned factors, specifically the flagrant price gouging, I have elected to confer a rating of three stars upon this establishment, cognizant of the fact that, as a business, it must strive to generate profits, but simultaneously recognizing that such an astronomical increase in price for a product normally available at a fraction of the cost is utterly untenable.

There is a long hallway to get in so it is definitely pretty secret. There is not much seating inside, about 6 seats. You have to wait for your pizza, atleast 20 minutes so I would call ahead. \n\nThe pizza was alright, I honestly like Slices in Dublin, CA so much more. If I were in Las Vegas again I would not come by here but it was a nice expierence.

Food was really good,  I've been to other Popeyes and was nOt impressed but this one just may change my mind...it will take more than one visit to determine that. I do wish there was a menu prior to the order menu in the drive thru, just because I'm not familiar with their menu and felt rushed once I was at the order menu. Also I given my box of food....no bag just my box of food which I thought was weird, would've liked a bag to carry my food from my car back to work (along with my purse, drink and other stuff).... and no straw for my drink (that's always annoying) but food wAs good so next time I'll walk in and check it out

This constitutes a satisfactory triangular configuration, albeit my sentiments regarding the unusually substantial pepperoni remain ambivalent, as my predilection tends towards the delicate, thinly sliced variety. In terms of overall quality, the pizza fails to meet my expectations of a quintessential New York-style thin crust, which I envision as bearing a closer resemblance to the offerings of esteemed establishments such as Villa or Verrazano. Furthermore, I find the dark, burnt edges of the crust to be somewhat off-putting; a light golden brown hue would align more closely with my personal preferences. It is apparent that considerable resources were invested in refurbishing the establishment, previously known as the Atlanta Bread Company. Despite my lack of familiarity with the local pizza scene, I have had the opportunity to sample a few diverse slices during my visits to New York City. While I may return to this particular eatery, its prospects for becoming a regular haunt remain uncertain.

They no longer put the chicken back on the grill when you order. The chicken is not big chunks of white meat anymore, it is stewed chicken sitting in a broth all day and I'm not even sure it is all white meat anymore. Another issue is the woman who was making the burrito used her gloved hands to fill the burrito with all the toppings. That is fine for rolling, but when your sticking your hand (gloved or not) into each bin of lettuce, corn, tomatoes, cilantro, etc, it just doesn't seem normal. They need to use spoons on thongs for the fillings.

Nothing special, but a bank. \nThey have a convinient, safe on-location drive thru and walk up service. Of course, personal safety is always an issue so just be 'aware' of your surroundings. \nThere is a Smith, Nail place and other business in this corner. Definitely a convinient location.

I don't normally go into American Apparel. Mostly because I like vintage and things that are skintight don't look good on me. But, I was dressing up as a mermaid and found myself in need of a top to wear under my shells so I didn't expose too much skin. Of course, American Apparel had all the selection of shiny, skintight (and skin colored) tops I needed. While I feel like I way over-paid for what I got, at least I got what I needed.

The Saloon feels very corporate and a bit overpriced.  However, the service is also good, and the beers are always cold.

I do not like the set up of the Saloon and the Comedy Zone.  I don't like how you have to go through the Saloon to get to the Comedy Zone.  Poor design lay-out.  I have been here on more than one Saturday night and had my night somewhat interrupted by huge crowds waiting in line to get into the Comedy Zone.  It sucks for everyone that is in the Saloon chillin, having a good time.  The bathrooms are packed and there is literally a human traffic jam towards the rear of the Saloon.

I usually go to the Saloon when looking to pregame before a show at the Fillmore, or before heading to another location within the Music Factory on Friday and Saturday nights.   

It is what  it is.  The live music and DJ there on Saturday nights are a huge plus.  Its still your standard, corporate, expensive bar in Charlotte.  With that being said, I would definitely go back again.

I genuinely aspired to bestow a perfect rating upon this festival, but unfortunately, certain aspects precluded me from doing so. Last year, my fiancÃ© and I participated in the celebration and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves, indulging in delectable cuisine and reveling in the diversity of melodies. However, our experience was marred by an unfortunate encounter with the host of the jousting match, who exhibited reprehensible behavior. 
  Initially, he publicly embarrassed a spectator by demanding she bounce for him, proceeding to offer her financial compensation for the task, only to subsequently admonish her daughter not to emulate her mother's conduct when she declined. This incident left a sour taste in our mouths, as Renaissance festivals are traditionally intended to be lighthearted, family-oriented gatherings where attendees can immerse themselves in merriment and escape reality temporarily. Moreover, it is reasonable to expect that all cast members maintain their characters consistently throughout the day, which sadly, was not upheld in this case. 
  Although I would relish the opportunity to revisit this festival in October, the presence of that individual would compel me to reconsider my attendance.

I was really looking forward to this:  A burger.  A nice, BIG, juicy, fresh, yummy burger at a sit down restaurant that specializes in burgers.  This was going to be my first visit to Fuddruckers and I had high expectations.

Well, eh.

Yeah, it was a burger.  Good but not great.  Not bad, just not exciting.  Nothing special to see here--just a burger.  I thought In n Out tasted a good deal better.  They're a lot cheaper too.

If someone suggests Fuddruckers to me sometime again as a place to eat, I'll go, but if you ask me for a destination if you're looking for a patty between two buns, there are a number of other places that I would suggest instead of it if you gave me the chance.

"First and foremost, it is imperative to establish clarity by acknowledging that the Mickey Mouse mural was, in fact, pre-existing and present on the wall prior to Pho Nhat's occupation of the space. Now, having dispelled any ambiguity regarding that particular aspect, we may proceed to express our ardent admiration for item #42 on the menu, which boasts an impressive ensemble of barbecued beef, shrimp, and egg roll, all artfully arranged atop a generous bed of vermicelli noodles, further complemented by a layer of leafy greens below. It is simply impossible to resist the allure of the delectable fish sauce accompanying this dish, and thus, we find ourselves irresistibly drawn to its savory flavors time and time again. Our devotion to #42 remains unwavering and unshakeable, as we steadfastly refuse to entertain the notion of seeking sustenance elsewhere. However, it is worth noting that during our most recent visit, the staff appeared somewhat displeased to accommodate our (as well as our companion's) patronage, and perhaps, it might be wise to explore alternative options for pho. Moreover, it is mildly disconcerting to observe that the eatery's ambiance has remained largely unchanged over time, with nary a hint of fresh coat of paint or other aesthetic enhancements."

Rehab was okay.  I went today around 1pm expecting extreme lines and expensive cover, but it was only $60 to get in and the wait was less than half an hour for a single guy with no females.  The security is also not as bad as others have mentioned.  It lasted only 3 seconds since I only had a car key, credit card, and ID.

When I walked in, there was a lot of people and most of them were attractive.  However, it wasn't as packed as it looks on video and in photos.  Even at 4pm it wasn't that packed, which I guess is a good thing.  Not a lot of people were dancing and only two people were making out.  In other words, Rehab is NOT as crazy as you're thinking it is!!

Finally, the drinks are extremely expensive, and I'm talking $28 for a single drink, but buckets of Heineken Light were only $25 (5 beers).  Honestly I wouldn't come back here though, because it really wasn't that crazy.

"I have had the experience of visiting this venue on multiple occasions, specifically for the purpose of commemorating the anniversary of my birth, and while it may hold appeal for certain individuals who relish the notion of celebrating their existence within such an environment, I must confess that I do not number among them. My sensory faculties have been affronted by an unpleasant olfactory sensation, and my interactions with the staff have been less than satisfactory, leading me to confer a rating of three stars, primarily due to the fact that the establishment does offer a modicum of diversion for children."

"Although my sole consumable indulgence consisted merely of a singular glass of beer, I must confess that I derived immense satisfaction from this particular brewery's unique interpretation of a traditional wheat beer. The spacious bar area, strategically configured in a square layout, boasted an aesthetically pleasing design, complete with televisions and bartenders positioned at the center, as well as a modest-sized aquarium housing a variety of marine life. Furthermore, the atmosphere was enhanced by the presence of a sizable yet intimate gathering of patrons, which, although not excessively crowded on this particular Super Bowl evening, still managed to maintain a convivial ambiance. Additionally, for those seeking a more secluded drinking experience, an adjacent bar featuring tabletops and stools was also available. All things considered, I would highly recommend this establishment to any individual residing in Middleton and seeking a convenient, quality drinking establishment without the need to venture excessively far into Madison."

My recent breakfast at Perk was OK.  The food was good, but the lackluster service will make me think twice about coming back.

My mom and I both enjoyed our breakfast burritos (mine with bacon and hers with ham).  They were smaller than I anticipated, but tasted good, especially when topped with the side of cilantro jalapeno sauce.  However, our waitress was pretty brusque - no interaction at all after taking our orders.  It would have been nice if she could have managed to come by to check on us, refill our water/my mom's coffee or even make eye contact at all.  The restaurant was NOT busy - less than half of the tables were occupied.  

I had to ask the hostess for both a water refill and our bill.  When our waitress finally showed up with the check, she slapped it on the table without even breaking her stride, all while looking out the window.  Hello!?  No 'thank you', or 'have a nice day'.

Eh...  I can make my own breakfast burrito, thanks.

Me and the boyfriend decided to stop by this spot one night for some cheap drinks. This was my boyfriend's go to spot for a cheap drink when he lived in AZ. I already knew it was a dive bar when I pulled up so I'm not going to complain about the ambiance and restrooms... it's a dive bar! It was pretty low key the night we went so I ordered my Tokyo tea and asked the bartender for the gadget thing so we could play the trivia game that shows on the screen. I also ordered the honey hot wings which were surprisingly delicious!! On our way out we peeked in the karaoke room and it looked like people were having a ball! A good no frills spot for cheap drinks and wings!

"My culinary predilections incline me towards establishments specializing in Greek cuisine, as I find myself enamored with any dish harboring an abundance of phyllo and/or spinach. Thus, I deem it imperative to sample the offerings of any restaurant boasting these ingredients, at least once, in order to satiate my gastronomical desires. Upon partaking in the Spanikopita, I found it to be quite satisfying, and opted to augment its flavor profile by incorporating the feta cheese from my accompanying salad, a practice I commonly engage in, both when consuming this dish at home and while dining out. Furthermore, I appreciated the ample serving size, reasonable price point, and welcoming ambiance of the eatery, which fostered a sense of comfort and tranquility, prompting me to return for a second time during my stay in Madison, and ensuring that I will unquestionably revisit this charming establishment in the future."

Beerarita?  Um yes please!!!  The quesadilla was totally stuffed with chicken, however could have used a little more flavor.  The chips/salsa was yummy and the salsa was exactly what the quesadilla was lacking.

"Although my culinary expectations were not entirely fulfilled during my visit to this establishment, I must admit that the gastronomical offerings were not entirely without merit. My assessment of the venue's quality is predicated upon a thorough examination of the cost-to-culinary-quality ratio, and I must say that my overall satisfaction was somewhat diminished by the fact that each item was served separately, thereby necessitating an additional expenditure for what I deemed to be an already adequate meal. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, I did enjoy the Caesar salad, which was quite generous in portion and did not fail to satiate my hunger. My spouse, however, was not quite as taken with his dining experience, as he found the basic hamburger to be somewhat lacking in both flavor and value, particularly in light of the absence of any complementary side dishes. In conclusion, while I might consider returning to this restaurant at some point in the future, it would largely depend on the availability of alternative dining options and their relative levels of crowding."
Good coffee & tea. A little loud on the radio and blenders constantly whirring... But good wifi and now that I know how to get there will use often...

"The quality of the service we received was satisfactory, albeit somewhat challenging to locate due to its position within a strip mall situated in a rural area north of Guadalupe. Upon perusing the menu, we discovered that the food portions were generous, yet the gastronomical experience was merely adequate. I opted for the 'everything' omelet, while my spouse selected the Scottish eggs Benedict. Although the hollandaise sauce accompanying the latter dish was flavorful, the bread proved to be somewhat dense and chewy. The aforementioned omelet, accompanied by home fries and an English muffin, was merely average in taste."

"Upon arriving at this establishment with two acquaintances of the feminine persuasion subsequent to perusing various commercial establishments within the shopping center, we discovered that the ambiance of the venue was adequate, possessing qualities reminiscent of a conventional barbecue eatery. Upon initiating our dining experience, we were presented with jalapeÃ±o bread, which demonstrated satisfactory culinary attributes. My personal selection from the menu consisted of a turkey sandwich enhanced with stuffing and cranberry sauce, effectively constituting a Thanksgiving-inspired creation. Although the flavors were palatable, the texture of the meat was somewhat lacking in moisture. It is worth mentioning that my companion was displeased by the absence of Pabst Blue Ribbon beer, a preference shared by numerous patrons according to the server, yet unfortunately unavailable at this particular business. The hospitality of the wait staff was quite commendable, as they exhibited kindness and attention to detail, exemplified by the prompt replacement of an undercooked burger. In conclusion, while the cuisine and atmosphere may be deemed unremarkable, the pleasant decor and respectable service contribute to a satisfying dining encounter, particularly following a prolonged and fatiguing day."

I had the pleasure of indulging in the culinary delight known as the "Juan Turkey Wrap," and unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely met. Despite my predilection for gastronomical indulgences, I opted to sample this establishment's fare, hoping to broaden my epicurean horizons. However, upon consuming the wrap, my taste buds were not adequately stimulated, as the texture and flavors failed to distinguish themselves from one another, resulting in an unfortunate blandness that even the copious application of hot sauce could not salvage. Notwithstanding this disappointment, I am resolved to persevere in my pursuit of a satisfying dining experience at this venue and shall endeavor to explore the "happy" side of the menu on my next visit, with the hope that it shall yield a more gratifying culinary adventure.

"Upon entering the establishment for a morning repast, I opted to sample their Mediterranean Omelette, which unfortunately did not quite live up to my expectations in terms of its culinary excellence, as it fell short of the 'gourmet' label that the restaurant purports to offer. Notwithstanding, the cost for the quantity of sustenance provided was reasonable, amounting to a total expenditure of $22 for three individuals. However, the menu selections were somewhat limited, with little variation in options available to patrons. Furthermore, I must express my gratitude for the utilization of disposable utensils, which obviated the need for dubious dishware sanitation practices. Nonetheless, I was dismayed by the scarcity of napkins provided, with a solitary example being offered, rendering it insufficient for my needs, even considering my relatively neat demeanor during meals. The quality of service received was unremarkable, at best, and failed to augment the ambiance created by the charming setting within historic downtown Chandler, conveniently positioned opposite a picturesque park and boasting ample parking facilities. Unfortunately, a single restroom was available, resulting in an unnecessary queue in the cramped passageway. In conclusion, while my experience was not entirely unpleasant, I cannot envision a compelling reason to revisit the establishment in the near future."
Considering the location, it's not too bad. Not the best Chinese food I've ever had but not horrible. It's somewhere in between Panda Express and real authentic Chinese food.

Juicy Pho off the strip

This place is pretty good for Vegas Pho. Vegas Pho is not the same as SGV Pho. 

Ordered the pork chop rice. It wasn't that good and the amount of pork chop there was very small.

Ate some of  my friend's korean bbq ribs, it was pretty good. 

Ate some of my friend's Pho, it was decent. 

What was really good was the Egg Roll wrapped with lettuce. It was delicious!!!!

Kinda far from the strip, was driving at least 10-15 mins to get here.
Cheap burgers for a fancy price. Reminded me of those rubber burgers you got in grade school. Not worth the $10 I spent. I won't be going back soon.
This place was \"OK,\" but I probably wouldn't go back. Food was kind of low end Chinese although service and atmosphere were fine. Not really bad, just not good either.

I visit this establishment with the intention of engaging in the recreational activity of poker and, on occasion, observing a cinematic production. However, it is advisable that prospective patrons be cognizant of the fact that they will likely be enveloped by an odor reminiscent of smoke, the intensity of which rivals that of the aroma emanating from kalbi following a meal at a Korean BBQ restaurant. It is recommended that individuals who wish to avoid the unpleasantness associated with such an olfactory experience take measures to launder their attire promptly upon departure, as the pungent scent of an ashtray tends to linger. 

The poker room within the premises boasts an abundance of tables, thereby providing ample opportunities for enthusiasts of the game to participate in lively competition. It is worth noting, however, that the demographic composition of the clientele tends to skew towards senior citizens, with the writer, in their thirties, being among the younger patrons. 

In terms of culinary options, the selection is satisfactory, with Fuddruckers and Subway offering viable choices for those seeking sustenance. While the oyster bar may not compare to the offerings at Palace Station, it remains a respectable alternative for those seeking a comparable dining experience.

Colectivo is a pretty neat and new-ish coffee shop right on the north east corner of the Capitol square.

It's got a pretty rustic and hipster kind of feel. Cool music, great decor, plenty of seating inside and outside (as well as the "porch"? area).

Good variety of coffees and teas, and even some beer and food. Free wi-fi, but not on the weekends.

Now, upon reflection, it has become apparent to me why I was advised to remain at the Westin; however, I was not particularly keen on traversing a considerable distance to reach my place of employment.  Initially, upon obtaining the room, I began to perceive an anomalous auditory phenomenon, which, at the time, I failed to attribute any significance to. Following the deposit of my belongings, I proceeded to the office, only to return and discover that the noise was still persisting; further investigation revealed that the source of the disturbance was, in fact, a toilet that refused to cease functioning properly. In order to rectify the situation, I descended to the ground floor to seek assistance from a staff member, subsequently departing to acquire sustenance. Upon my return, approximately one hour and thirty minutes later, I was dismayed to discover that the issue remained unresolved. Prompted by my growing frustration, I elected to descend once more to remind the hotel personnel of the problem. Fortunately, the matter was ultimately resolved within a span of forty-five minutes. However, my relief was short-lived, as I soon became aware of a pool of water accumulating behind the toilet, indicative of a leak. I promptly contacted the hotel staff and awaited the arrival of a maintenance worker, who, much to my relief, arrived in a timely manner and efficiently addressed the problem. Notwithstanding the aforementioned inconveniences, there exists a silver lining; specifically, the majority of check-ins occur around three o'clock in the afternoon. Moreover, I must express my gratitude towards the accommodating nature of the hotel staff, who graciously allowed me to check in at eight o'clock in the morning, facilitating my transition from the Hilton Garden to the aforementioned Hilton property.

"Upon my initial visit, I must admit that my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as the culinary offerings, although fresh, were somewhat limited in scope, particularly with regard to the lunch menu. However, I did appreciate the extensive breakfast selection and salad bar, which provided a satisfactory array of options. Unfortunately, the absence of salmon from the menu proved to be a significant disappointment, and the dearth of delectable desserts further contributed to my dissatisfaction. Given the steep price point of $65.00, I cannot say that I will be inclined to return in the near future. Nonetheless, I must commend the staff for their attentive and courteous customer service."

"My sentiments regarding this establishment are rather tepid, as the accommodations, although pleasant, fail to exceed my expectations. However, I must acknowledge that the personnel have been courteous and helpful during my stay, despite the minor inconvenience of being assigned a room on an incorrect floor. It is worth mentioning that the hotel is currently undergoing renovations, which has resulted in a significant amount of construction activity and the presence of numerous work vehicles. Notwithstanding, I would not recommend this particular lodging to prospective travelers, primarily due to the subpar service I received upon check-in. Nonetheless, the physical structure of the hotel itself is quite impressive, and the staff members have been exceptionally hospitable."

"Although I have yet to visit the authentic cronut bakery, the extensive queues have proven to be a formidable deterrent. However, my culinary endeavors have been graced by the presence of La Cornetteria, thereby affording me the opportunity to sample the renowned croissant-donut hybrid, much to my delight. :)"

So after that tragedy of a burger I had earlier from Carl's Jr., I felt a redemption could be made if I just ordered two cheeseburgers at BK.  How hard can it be to make two plain cheeseburgers?  So I waited, and waited, and waited, while other people were getting their chicken nuggets, Whopper Jr's, and Extra Long BBQ Cheeseburgers.  While all that was happening I was staring at their order board and saw my order was in red letters and was passing 5 minutes while all the others were in green letters and most were finished in under a minute.  For two plain cheeseburgers?  C'mon, now!!  Well I finally got my cheeseburgers and they definitely made up for that hot mess I had earlier from Carl's Jr.

Upon initiating contact with the establishment, I requested a reservation, only to be informed that such formalities were deemed unnecessary by the management, and thus, I was taken aback upon arriving at the venue to discover a considerable delay in securing a table, which they attributed to an unforeseen influx of patrons on a Saturday evening in Las Vegas; however, I remained steadfast in my conviction that accepting advance bookings would be a judicious decision, particularly given the preeminence of the city's culinary scene.

The menu, though limited in scope, boasted an array of delectable items, yet the quality of the fare, with the exception of the truffle fries, which were truly sublime, fell somewhat short of my elevated expectations, but the convivial atmosphere engendered by the presence of my companion enabled us to enjoy ourselves thoroughly, thereby rendering our visit a success, albeit one tempered by certain reservations; hence, while I might consider returning under specific circumstances, I would not hasten to do so independently.

Good brunch and the atmosphere on the patio was very nice, but a pretty significant (I won't call fatal) flaw that merits no more than an A-OK.  If you cannot remove an ingredient from a dish on request you either do or do not, there is no try.  We asked for no onions, answer was yes, but when the dish came it had onions in it.  When we pointed it out we were told the cook tried to remove them but couldn't from the pre-made mix.  Appreciate the flexibility in trying to accommodate, but what if instead of a food we preferred to avoid it was in fact an allergy and you knowingly passed it onto us? Why not just tell us it's a mix and you can't really separate it from the meal ... instead of just serving it up anyway? The general lack of interest shown by the waiter on this left us with a bad feeling.  Despite their efforts and a few bright spots, there were some breakdowns in customer service (not just the one mentioned) and staff training, which add up to a lack of compelling reason to return.  So we probably won't.

"Having experienced an extended hiatus from the delectable delights of an authentic Asian buffet for a duration of two days, I decided to indulge in a culinary excursion to this establishment, which, according to the esteemed review platform, Yelp, is designated as 'E-Z Buffet,' although the proprietors have opted to interchangeably refer to it as either 'EZ Buffet,' 'EZ Chinese Buffet,' or 'Easy Buffet,' depending on the specific signage or promotional materials in question. Thus, allowing me to partake in a gastronomical journey that encompassed a diverse array of 75 primary dishes, showcasing an eclectic mix of traditional Chinese cuisine, such as Clam Chowder, beef roast, Stuffed Bell Peppers, Calzone, pizza, and even pink marshmallows, which piqued my curiosity and left me feeling both intrigued and amused. Furthermore, this spacious eatery, characterized by its refined ambiance and hospitable staff, offered an extensive selection of customary Chinese fare, including Sushi (albeit being of Japanese origin), Kim Chee (being Korean in nature), Egg Foo Young (prepared authentically), and an assortment of fried chicken, boneless spare ribs, stuffed mushrooms, various chicken preparations, fish, shrimp, and numerous other options, ultimately culminating in a satisfying medley of desserts, highlighted by genuine ice cream of superior quality. Consequently, I would confer upon this commendable dining establishment a rating of three stars, denoting its well-rounded appeal and reasonable pricing, with lunch buffet prices set at $6.75 or $6.08 for seniors from Monday through Saturday, $8.75 or $7.88 on Sundays, and the availability of a standard menu for patrons seeking alternative dining options."

Chase Field is the home to the Arizona Diamondbacks (or Dbacks, I should say).  It's a rather nice field, with a good amount of seats and multiple levels.  

Located in the heart of Phoenix, this stadium became famous when it was first built.  Having a moving roof to let the sun in (or keep the rain out) was something unheard of at the time.  It is still a thing of wonders.

I've only been to a few games here, but each time that I have come, I find that the experience is good.  It usually does not completely fill up (it's pretty easy to find seats together if you are going in a group), and it makes for a great family getaway.

I would not exactly suggest that you plan on eating a full meal here... Prices are expensive, and the quality of food is not that good.  I would recommend that you eat outside of the stadium, and save room for a few drinks when you get inside.

If you have lived here for 10 years, or if you are just passing through, make sure to stop on by and see the magnificent edifice for itself.

"The sushi served at this establishment consistently boasts an innovative and delectable quality, and the ambiance created by the interior design provides a suitable setting for bringing along any individual, including a romantic partner. However, my recent experiences have led me to deduce that the service here has been subpar, as the servers appear to lack a systematic approach to attending to their patrons. Specifically, during my most recent visit, which included a group of six individuals, we had multiple servers attend to us, resulting in a lack of coordination and communication among them. As a result, we experienced prolonged periods of neglect, ultimately leading to a 45-minute delay in receiving our order. Furthermore, despite the friendly demeanor displayed by the staff, the inefficiency in their service resulted in unnecessary inconvenience for us. To add insult to injury, a 20% gratuity was automatically added to our bill, and we were informed that the maximum number of ways we could split the check was three, thereby necessitating additional calculations and transactions among ourselves. These issues have diminished my inclination to revisit this establishment in the future."

"Had I not had the privilege of dining at Wicked Spoon prior to this experience, my perception of the establishment might have been somewhat skewed, leading me to erroneously assume that the quality of the food and service was of a superior caliber. However, due to the high volume of patrons and the relatively exorbitant prices for the quantity of sustenance provided, I was compelled to reassess my initial impression and liken the ambiance to that of a bustling Disneyland buffet, albeit with a slightly more refined atmosphere."

We have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and our experiences have been rather dichotomous, with the service being either exceptionally impressive (5 stars) or subpar (1 star), while the culinary offerings have consistently met our expectations. Thus, we have arrived at an overall rating of 3 stars, which we deem to be a fair assessment given the variable quality of service we have encountered. However, if there is a decline in the gastronomic experience, we would be compelled to reevaluate our patronage of this venue.

I nearly feel culpable conferring a trio of stellar designations upon this establishment, considering the fact that we visited during the early hours of the day with my seven-year-old offspring and three additional grown-ups. My juvenile progeny availed themselves of the play structure and promptly became acquainted with a fellow juvenile, thus engendering an enjoyable experience. Subsequently, we perambulated towards the Fremont Street Experience, opting to partake of a repast within the park. Upon our return, we placed our order (amounting to approximately twenty dollars per plate for tacos and beer) at approximately 8:48 PM. My daughter petitioned permission to observe the ignited mantis, to which I acquiesced. Her father subsequently accompanied her to the location, only to be informed that reentry was not permissible. She disregarded this injunction and returned unimpeded. At 9:00 PM, a public address announcement declared that minors would no longer be admitted to the park. Considering that we were still awaiting our meal, this development proved somewhat vexing. As we were compelled to hasten our consumption of the recently procured victuals in order to accompany our minor companion, the dining experience proved less than optimal. It appears that this venue purports to cater to families, yet the 9:00 PM closure on weekends does not align with this purported focus. Either this establishment must genuinely commit to accommodating families, or else they should reassess their marketing strategy to better reflect their actual target demographic. I did not appreciate the pressure to expedite my meal.

I've been here for dinner once and twice for brunch. Out of the three times, I would still give it a three star. I honestly don't think the food is that great here even when I come HUNGRY. But I have to admit, they have the presentation on lock-down.

My family visited this restaurant during restaurant week, and it offered the most extensive and diverse menu options among the four establishments we contacted. The ambiance was vibrant, sensual, and welcoming, which made us feel comfortable and relaxed. We enjoyed their creative cocktail selection while waiting for our table at the bar. Our server was friendly, charming, and attentive, which added to our delightful dining experience. The restaurant week menu offered an impressive variety of dishes, and the crab cakes were undoubtedly the most flavorful and well-prepared I have had in Charlotte. The steaks were cooked to perfection, and although the dessert could have been more satisfying, it was still a delectable treat. I would highly recommend returning to this establishment, particularly for happy hour with friends.

Yelp 100 Challenge 2013- 13/100

Red Ridge Park is literally a 10 min stroll from my condo. I will be moving soon and I will miss my frequent visits to this park. When in my hardcore fitness kick, I would run around the park and gauge my distance since 1 lap around the exterior of the park is close to a mile. As other mentioned, two sides are slightly up hill and the other two sides are flat= nice easy run. I also enjoy that it is well lit at night and I always felt safe running by myself. 

The park features a small water park for kids, large play area for older kids,  smaller play area for younger kids (see pics), basketball courts, and a baseball diamond (see pic). The park is always busy, but I never really felt crowded. You will always see people walking, playing with their dogs,or enjoying a sunny day with a picnic. 

They just started to build houses directly across from this park. The Dunhill homes start at around 200K for the base price and the neighborhood is growing. They're worth taking a look at if you like the Southwest area. Views of the park would be nice compared to views of other homes. The new Wet n Wild Water Park is close by, too. 
The one thing I wish they had..... an enclosed dog park like some other parks I travel to visit.

The Food was okay.  It's a bar.  It's better if you are a beer drinker.  I am not a beer drinker.   I had a black bean burger,  it was most likely a morningstar farms one.   Does that constitute a 1.99 additional charge?  I'm not sure.  \n\nThe service was spotty, but at least we got a refill on the drinks when our check got dropped off.

Based on the perusal of patron reviews, I experienced a sense of disillusionment with my entree selection, specifically the chicken pasta dish comprised of linguini, basil, and a rich cream sauce. The culinary execution yielded a dish that was overly substantial and heavily laden with an excessive amount of creamy sauce, which detracted from the overall enjoyment of the meal. Notwithstanding this disappointment, the quality of service provided by the restaurant staff was exceptional and worthy of high praise, leading me to consider giving the establishment another opportunity to demonstrate its culinary prowess. It is conceivable that the subpar experience may have been an isolated incident attributable to an off night in the kitchen. Additionally, I was pleased to note the availability of one of my preferred beverages, Dos Equis amber, which contributed to a more satisfying dining experience.

I've been to Osteria twice now. Once to grab a sandwich for lunch, and then to get a takeout pizza for dinner. I've really hoped this place would be good as I live across the street. My experience has been mixed. Sandwich was a very good Italian deli sandwich. Pizza was mediocre though. While the pizza had the unintended positive effect of reminding me of free pizza consumed when I was in grad school in NYC that's not the best sign of quality. Not bad but could be better. \n\nThere's a lot of potential for Osteria and I hope they succeed. Maybe a weekend brunch would be a good addition? And make pizza less like basic takeout pizza and more \"fancy\" (tasty too).

I don't know that I have ever felt dirtier.

Still, I had a blast the couple of times we floated the river. 

We did the tie-everyone-together-plus-a- beer-cooler thing and enjoyed being wet and dirty. 

Wear a big hat.

"The current state of affairs is satisfactory. Indeed, it is more than satisfactory; it is positively acceptable. Allow me to reiterate that my previous response was not tinged with even a hint of sarcasm or irony. In point of fact, I am entirely serious in my assertion that the present situation is thoroughly adequate. Incidentally, this assessment pertains specifically to the morning repast, which I have had the pleasure of partaking in on multiple occasionsâapproximately 10 to 15 times, to be preciseâas I have a propensity to patronize this establishment whenever I find myself in the vicinity of Pittsburgh."

"Prior to embarking upon a culinary excursion to this establishment, it is prudent to temper one's gastronomical expectations, for the fare served is unlikely to be of exceptional quality; however, a modicum of cordiality and hospitable demeanor on the part of the waiting staff would be a reasonable expectation. Alas, this particular OG has demonstrated a propensity for inconsistency in terms of the service provided, with past experiences ranging from satisfactory to abysmal, contingent upon the competence and attentiveness of the server."

The food is good.  It's a nice breakfast spot and I'll probably end up eating here a lot.  The savory crepes are better than the sweet (in my opinion) and the coffee drinks are tasty.  

There are a few things I'd like to see change though:  

- A hostess would be welcome.  Being my first time here I walked in and was unsure of what to do.  There's a register and a long counter so there was no clear indicator as to whether it was counter service or table service.  I had to track down an employee to find out.  
- The service is spotty.  There were two waitresses working when I was there.  Every table was full so it was 15 minutes before we got to order.  
- The wait times for food.  After ordering it was 20-25 minutes for two crepes.  That's way too much.  I didn't mind as I wasn't in a hurry but it made me sure to never come here if you have anywhere to be in the next 90 minutes.  

I like crepes and  I like coffee and I like good service.  Two out of three ain't bad.

Great value in vegas, $109 per night on a weekend compared to $400 for a cramped little room on the strip.  Throw in the free breakfast and free drinks in the evening and you have yourself a great value.

The hotel has been upgraded.  The rooms are nice enough.  The lobby atrium is a bit dated and the faux plants are a bit dusty.

There were some service issues.  We ordered food to go at the restaurant.  The place was empty and we were quoted 20 minutes to get our food.  In the end, it took 40.

Check in took forever, as did many interactions with the front desk.  The guys working the desk had to always stop and answer phones which was annoying.  But the one guy working the desk called me "cute."  Not sure if I should be flattered or horrified.

There was never a consistent answer on the shuttle to the strip.  We were told they would take us anywhere (and they did) and pick us up.  But when I called for pickup, they said they only pick up and drop off at Planet Hollywood.  In the end, we had to use taxis a lot which ran $10 a trip to the strip.

All things considered, I like the other Embassy Suites on Paradise just a touch better and I have stayed there many times.  But they were $50 a night more when I booked so we stayed here.

working in the gyle industrial estate this shopping centre is the closest thing for a lunchtime escape from the office.  so maybe i see it through rose-tinted shades while others may find this place a bit run down and lacking.  but for me, it's a beacon of clothing shops, food options, and starbucks that i can visit during my lunch break and enjoy a bit of freedom from the office.

i'm pretty sure when the gyle was first opened it was shiny and state of the art, but i do feel that might have been awhile ago.  however what's on offer is still quite good, one of the largest marks & spencers food halls, a good sized morrisons, a huge boots, a decent new look and dorothy perkins, and my beloved starbucks.  they also have a millie's cookie stand which Kelly F can confirm i have a serious love affair with.  omg cookie cake anyone????

yes it is a bit dark and the food court has a lack of options if you're looking for healthier food, but it's still a decent place to spend a lunch hour or make an emergency run to boots for when you're run out of mascara or concealor.  or when i've decided i just desperately need that new dorothy perkins dress i saw in my gossip magazine.  i like this place, it's a-ok and despite being slighty aged still has a fair bit to offer.

Since its construction several years ago, I have been eager to visit this venue, yet my frequent excursions to Las Vegas have confined me to the strip, precluding me from venturing out to this location until my most recent trip.  My previous experiences have been limited to the strip, where I have always found myself indulging in the various attractions and activities available there.  However, on my latest visit, I decided to deviate from my usual routine and explore what this establishment has to offer. 

One aspect that piqued my interest was the outdoor nature of the event, which was complemented by imposing screens that left me in awe.  The ambiance was reminiscent of "Old" Las Vegas, where everything was relatively affordable.  The prices of food and beverages were aligned with my expectations for a city like Las Vegas, making it an economical option for those seeking a unique experience without breaking the bank. 

However, I must admit that the atmosphere was somewhat tarnished by the presence of unsavory elements.  During the night I visited, there were numerous individuals who appeared to be homeless, and some were even openly consuming drugs.  While some may view this as an integral part of the overall experience, I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease and concern for my personal belongings.  It's possible that the earlier shows may be less crowded and rowdy, but my decision to attend the final show of the evening may have contributed to the unfortunate circumstances I encountered.

My wife and I stopped here after seeing Zumanity the night before Halloween. Fortunately there were a ton of people out and about in their costumes. We wanted to find a place where we could have a drink and watch people. This place fit the bill perfectly. 

Fortunately for us we had a couple free drink coupons, so we didn't have to pay. However, the prices aren't too bad for a great selection of craft and microbrews ($6-7). I had a Sin City Amber and the wife had a Sam Adams Cherry Wheat. They had a lot of good beer here from places like Sierra Nevada, Alaska, Abita, Rogue, Stone, etc. This place has a better selection than a lot of other bars in Vegas. 

Being a Friday night NYNY was pretty hopping, but this place wasn't overwhelmingly full, though you would have thought so watching the bartenders running around, that was really my only issue with this place. Even with the free drink coupons, I tip well, so I was hoping for a bit better service. I will chalk it up to a bad night, and will go again, especially as a place to meet friends staying on the Strip.

Fun place, and we will be back.

One of the better Italian restaurants in the city, and one of the nicest restaurants in Oakland, Lucca would be a fantastic choice at a lower price point.  The food is well prepared; the staff is usually friendly and helpful; and the ambiance is nice without being stuffy.  But the pricing for this experience is more appropriate for a city like New York or San Francisco.

"While my expectations were admittedly elevated, I must confess that I was somewhat underwhelmed by the overall experience. Notwithstanding the undeniably breathtaking panorama afforded by the establishment's strategic location, the ambiance and culinary offerings failed to impress me to the extent that I had anticipated. In fact, I would venture to say that the quality of the fare and the aesthetic appeal of the surroundings were merely adequate, and certainly not exceptional. Be that as it may, I must acknowledge that the singular aspect that truly sets this eatery apart from its competitors is, indeed, its unparalleled view. However, as a local resident, I cannot help but feel that there are far more exceptional dining options available in the city."

"Having had the privilege of experiencing Viva Elvis on multiple occasions, ranging from its initial debut to more recent performances, I must say that while the production has undergone some enhancements since its inception, its progression has been somewhat limited. However, it would be inaccurate to imply that the show is of inferior quality; rather, it seems to lack the cohesive integration that characterizes Cirque du Soleil's other productions. What struck me as particularly captivating aspects of the performance were the musical arrangements, scenery, and attire, all of which combined to create an ambiance reminiscent of the iconic Elvis era. Upon entering the venue, I was immediately impressed by the performers' elaborate costumes, which served as a visual representation of the bygone era. The musical numbers, specifically 'Jail House Rock' and 'Return to Sender,' were undoubtedly the highlights of the show for me. Unfortunately, the choreography failed to impress me to the same extent, as it appeared somewhat subdued and lacking in the 'wow' factor that Cirque du Soleil productions are renowned for. Furthermore, I must admit that the inclusion of female vocalists performing Elvis songs was not to my liking, as it seemed incongruous with the essence of the performance. Their vocal abilities were not in question, but rather the fact that the alteration in style detracted from the authenticity of the experience. Additionally, the transitions between scenes were, at times, somewhat clumsy. Notwithstanding these criticisms, I would still recommend attending the show, particularly considering its impending departure."

Unfortunately, it appears that this establishment has recently undergone a change in proprietorship, and my experiences with the quality of the eyebrow waxing services provided have been less than satisfactory. Specifically, the new owner seems to have neglected to maintain the standard of excellence previously upheld by the former proprietor, as evidenced by the fact that one of my brows was left uneven and noticeably thinner than its counterpart. This disparity has necessitated an extension of the time interval between waxings, which unfortunately precludes me from patronizing this business further.

Second time patronizing a culinary dropout, initially encountered at this particular establishment.
 Ambiance persistently captivating, particularly due to the proximity of the yard, an idyllic setting.
 Happy hour specials restricted to bar seating, high tops, and alfresco dining, yet we opted against partaking in said promotion, rendering it inconsequential.
 Previously indulged in casual fare typical of a trendy bar scene during a corporate social gathering. Cuisine proved satisfactory, as expected.
 Undoubtedly, an ideal venue for leisurely socializing with companions, analogous to a grownup playground.

"The seared tuna carpaccio, ninja roll, and elephant roll exhibited an impressive culinary proficiency, boasting a flavor profile that was undoubtedly tantalizing. However, the ambiance, while trendy, suffered from a somewhat claustrophobic atmosphere, which was further exacerbated by the low rise sushi bar counter that, although functional, proved to be aesthetically displeasing to this writer. Nevertheless, the price point for the all-you-can-eat dinner option remained reasonable, rendering it an accessible indulgence for those seeking a gastronomical adventure. Furthermore, the ample parking and melodious background music contributed to an overall pleasant dining experience, despite minor quibbles regarding the physical space. Ultimately, the fare served at this establishment demonstrated a satisfactory quality, thus ensuring a positive outcome for those who partook in the culinary journey."

"I acquired my initial two body art pieces at this establishment, collaborating with Jessy, who demonstrated remarkable proficiency and expertise in her craft, prompting my sibling to seek her services for a personalized design, resulting in an exceptional piece that garnered immense satisfaction. Subsequently, I opted to return to Jessy for a second piece, featuring an inverted color scheme, thereby emphasizing her adaptability and dedication to ensuring a unique and satisfactory experience for each client. Moreover, the shop's pristine condition significantly contributed to my positive encounter."

"Consider patronizing Bang if you derive pleasure from the musical offerings of Billy Joel and Elton John, particularly when performed via piano, and you relish the notion of observing people in a social setting, standing room only, and vocally accompanying Journey's melodies with uninhibited fervor alongside an inebriated female reveler, all while enduring a copious amount of perspiration. Refrain from visiting Bang, however, if the aforementioned attributes do not align with your preferences, especially if you harbor animosity towards bachelorette or birthday celebrations, experience trepidation at the prospect of being coerced onto the stage for a musical performance while spectators scrutinize you, or hold a strong preference for traditional piano-centric establishments that eschew the incorporation of guitar and drum elements commonly associated with dueling piano bars. Additionally, be aware that a cover charge is levied at the entrance, and that Bang may not be the ideal location for individuals experiencing cranial discomfort or possessing an excessively stern demeanor, as these factors may hinder their capacity to fully appreciate the establishment's convivial ambiance."

"A suitable venue for spectating a sporting event, the barkeepers demonstrated adequate attention to our needs, yet the duration of time elapsing between placing our order and receiving our culinary items proved unsatisfactorily prolonged, warranting the cancellation of our request for sustenance and prompting a query regarding the expediency of settling our financial obligations."

I was expecting great things from this sandwich shop but was disappointed to find basically a glorified lunch counter. The ingredients just didn't seem to be very high quality. The steak melt didn't have enough steak in it. The sandos sound good but the execution didn't seem to be there. For the inflated price tag I want a great sandwich. This wasn't.

I was more impressed with Squirrel Hill itself than I was with Bangkok Balcony. My friend and I found this place on a "vegan's guide to Pittsburgh" type Web site, and they were open late, so that worked for us. We found street parking very easily. I was disappointed that most of the clothing stores were closed, because there was such a great mix of vintage and new fashions. 

I digress. I really liked the layout of BB... how it's on the top floor and everything is modern without being sterile. We both really liked the flatware they use here, and that's something we almost never comment on. They had a good selection of tofu items and I loved how they asked me to tell them how spicy I wanted my food "on a scale from one to ten." The food here is also more inexpensive than I would have thought, seeing how packed the place was and how nicely decorated. 

Overall, it was good, but I'm biased -- I love Thai food so much that I could eat it all the time. The reason I'm only giving this place three stars is because we both felt a little sick later on in the evening.

They gave us a great table right next to the floor to ceiling windows. overlooking the strip. the HUGE Jumbo screen and parking lot that were in view aren't very romantic but the Eiffel tower in the distance was. 

Drinks - great cocktails

My only comment is the live music is on the other side of the bar from the windows. so you have to choose -  view or live music.. not both. :P kind of sleepy. everyone here was paired up. good for the "mature" or "date" crowd. I wanted to meet people and laugh so we had one drink and left. still worth checking out.

"I opted for the frozen hot chocolate, electing to consume it extramurally, as the temporal duration preceding its procurement proved to be rather protracted. Notwithstanding the lengthy delay, the beverage's quality was sufficient to justify its consumption, rendering it an acceptable culinary experience. While I am not inclined to endorse the exorbitant price point of $9 for a limited quantity, I acknowledge the existence of certain circumstances that may warrant such a tariff. Upon fulfilling my long-standing desire to sample this item, courtesy of its prominent placement on Oprah's list of preferred products, I shall endeavor to partake in their gastronomical offerings at a future date."

"An early morning repast, comprising of eggs, potatoes, bacon, coffee, and fruit juice, commonly referred to as 'breakfast', was procured at a cost of $22.00. This sum consisted of a $10 entree, a $3 beverage, specifically coffee, and a $6, 10 oz serving of orange juice. A supplementary, plate-sized side dish of hash browns was also obtained, for an additional $3. Although the quality of the culinary offerings was satisfactory, the overall experience did not warrant the expenditure. In contrast, Waffle House, a nearby establishment, provides a more copious amount of nourishment for approximately half the price, and their coffee is of superior quality. Ultimately, this particular dining excursion was deemed acceptable, yet overpriced by a margin of 25%."

"While my culinary excursion to Price's Chicken Coop in Charlotte, North Carolina, in May 2012, was merely average, it was also somewhat underwhelming, given the excessive buzz surrounding this establishment. As a native of Maryland, I had included this eatery on my list of'must-visit' destinations during my trip, primarily due to its reputation for serving delectable chicken wings. However, upon sampling their offerings, I found the portions to be minuscule, which was utterly astonishing, and the flavor was merely passable. In fact, the most memorable aspect of the dining experience was the substitution of tater tots for French fries, which brought back nostalgic memories of my high school days. Nonetheless, I can obtain comparable pressure-fried chicken wings from various Amish markets in Maryland, which are not only more substantial but also more satisfying overall. Therefore, Price's Chicken Coop has been removed from my list of recommended dining establishments."
The food is alright, Only place I could find around for a quick bit to eat. I stayed at the Mandala Bay which is next to this place.

When I saw that a Korean BBQ place had moved in to the empty Mcdonalds store front, I was pretty excited! I would finally be able to try Korean food at a good price..Which was partially correct. They are pricey for 'fast-food', with most of their options, including a la carte, being around $7-9. I have tried their Bulgogi, with steamed vegetables and kimchi, which was all really good! The sweetness of this dish was great with the garlic and spice of the kimchi! 

I really want to try their Mandu and tempura, but they keep it under heat lamps in the front, which makes me wonder how long it has been there..but will probably try it one day ( I was watching ABC 15 and saw they got a D for their health inspection in July. It was for things like improper holding temperatures, kimchi made at home(was removed from service), thermometers, ect. BUT Most of these problems were solved on the same day)

I see now that they have added Boba tea, which I'm also really excited for, seeing as how it's hard to find without driving to the far west or Scottsdale to find!

Hopefully the busier they get, the lower prices will become, but being one of the only Korean places on the East side of Phoenix, they might not.

Not entirely unimpressive, I must admit. Although, I no longer identify as the type of individual who would frequent the nightlife scene in Old Town Scottsdale, particularly during peak hours. Nonetheless, I accompanied twelve of my female companions to The Mint for a Happy Hour excursion on a Friday evening and enjoyed myself moderately. The culinary offerings were indeed impressive, and the potables were satisfactory, with their half-price promotion rendering them rather affordable. The interior design boasted an aesthetic that could be described as captivating or intriguing. However, upon closer inspection, certain aspects of the establishment's layout proved somewhat perplexing. Specifically, the co-ed restroom arrangement struck me as peculiar and not particularly appealing. Furthermore, the staff, despite their physical attractiveness and congenial demeanor, appeared somewhat novice. Our server, though well-intentioned, encountered difficulties managing our large group. Initially, she advocated for a single, collective payment method, only to later suggest separate checks would have been more practical. This led to a delay in settling our bill, as I waited approximately thirty minutes for its preparation, during which time only a few additional patrons were present within the establishment. Despite these inconveniences, I would consider returning for future Happy Hour escapades and exploring the outdoor bar area, yet insisting on separate checks to avoid any further confusion.

"This venue possesses an ambiance characterized by an abundance of artwork and large televisions in the primary bar area, which creates a captivating atmosphere that attracts a diverse clientele. Additionally, the upstairs section boasts pool tables, arcade games, and skee-ball machines, providing entertainment options for patrons of all ages. An outdoor patio area is also available, much to the delight of those who partake in smoking activities. It has become a popular destination for locals to congregate on Sundays to observe sporting events, further enhancing its appeal. Although their menu does not include food, they occasionally host special events such as a complimentary chicken wing buffet, which is readily availed by patrons. Furthermore, they showcase an impressive selection of locally brewed beverages, which aligns with the preferences of many visitors. Lastly, ample parking facilities are provided, both on the street and behind the building, ensuring convenient access for all patrons."

I have to say I was not as impressed as other people on Yelp giving it 4 and 5 star reviews. I will say that it was good but by far not the best burger I've ever had. Also, to pay $60 for a burger, fish sandwich, fries and 2 sodas I felt I should have left amazed. Definitely didn't meet my expectations and my beautiful girlfriend agrees with me. I will say 3 stars....It was ok / good but not amazing.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
That's how I would describe my visit to Canyon Ranch Spa at the Venetian. My expectations were high, based on what I had read in literature and reviews about the original Canyon Ranch. Unfortunately, the reality was far from it. Firstly, the price was exorbitant for the services offered. Additionally, the size of the spa was minuscule compared to the one at The Venetian. But what really left me perplexed was the signature energy massage, which lacked any tangible contact. It was akin to a mystical experience, but not in a good way. To say I was unimpressed would be an understatement. Needless to say, this spa won't be my top pick for future visits.

Husband and I went for HH and also ordered some regular menu items. The drinks were a decent price (hh prices). We ordered the Gladiator burger & daily dose burger which were both just okay. They were both lacking flavor and the msuhroom brie was mediocre. Despite the fact it was dead, we felt very rushed. Hope was training another waitress - I hope the trainee doesn't listen to her. Besides rushing her patrons, she talked down to her own trainee. When she introduced her trainee, she literally said, \"Don't ask her questions because she's new and won't know.\" WOW. I've been a waitress before and I would have been furious if I was talked to like that during my training, and as a patron - it looks horrible that you are degrading your own coworker.

All apple stores for the most part are spacious....well lit....products well displayed....and friendly professional service.. this one is no different. Now with all that being said the prices are horrible for what they are....so please for all you apple lover's realize you can do better with your money. A matter of fact I am taking donations...if you just have money to waste or give away....Thanks. Eat, Drink, and be Merry my Friends!!!

The gastronomical experience was satisfactory, with a diverse array of options that catered to our taste buds' delight, yet did not quite attain an exceptional level of quality that would have rendered it truly remarkable. The ambiance, while not particularly captivating or vibrant, did provide a suitable setting for an enjoyable dining experience, albeit one that was not characterized by an excessive degree of liveliness or energy, which might have been expected in a city such as Las Vegas, known for its exuberant nightlife and entertainment options. Our visit was facilitated by the utilization of a Groupon, which afforded us a reasonable price point that would have otherwise been considered somewhat steep in light of the restaurant's unremarkable reputation and relatively subdued atmosphere.

This Panda Express has a drive-thru, which is great when it's 103 outside and I want lunch without stepping out into the broiler.   It was a fast queue and they got my order right.   \n\nThe orange chicken/Beijing beef was pretty unpalatable though, it was really dried out and sauceless.  It's a Panda Express, that happens.  Basically your average Panda without getting out of the car.

Although I go here a  lot when I'm in Vegas be advised if you're white some dishes will be heavily 'sanitized' to suit  your perceived taste without asking.  For example,  on a recent visit I ordered the super combination pho (the one usually at the top of the list at any pho place) and it came without any tendon or tripe...and they didn't throw in more of the 'regular' meats to compensate.

While I am absolutely in love with the Galaxy Luxury theater, sometimes, I can't drive across town for a movie, or they don't have enough seating for the one I want.\n\nBrenden is a comfy theater, and I've always had good experiences here.  The employees are polite, and prices are standard.

Oh no's!

Mamma Mia has revised their delivery boundary. I live 0.7 mile away. 
No longer close enough to be considered for delivery.
(according to their online system)

If you're:
East of 20th St
West of 64th St
North of Washington
or
South of Lincoln

Just drive!

Pretty good pizza. 
Offered by the slice!
This review is for the Mexican Restaurant.  It's pretty good.  The salsa bar is great.  Big portions.  I would give it 4 stars but the decor is old

"3.5 stars

As an ardent devotee of Flamebroiler (do they have such establishments in AZ?), I am endeavoring to locate a passable teriyaki bowl restaurant in close proximity to my location. It is my conviction that rice bowls serve as the equivalent of sandwiches for Asian/Indian individuals, that is, they are rapid, economical, delectable, and generally salubrious meals. I believe that this particular establishment fulfills the aforementioned criteria! 

I opted for the Cayman combination, which encompasses two of their offerings. I sampled both the Fiji and Singapore curries. The Fiji dish was reminiscent of slow-cooked chuck roast, infused with teriyaki sauce, albeit slightly tough. In contrast, the Singapore curry boasted chicken and carrots immersed in a Japanese curry, akin to the cubes purchasable at Asian markets, yet with a subtle tang. Unfortunately, the meat (chicken) exhibited a stringy texture due to slow cooking, which did not particularly appeal to my palate. 

Despite these minor drawbacks, I thoroughly enjoyed my meal, and the portion size was generous, rendering it impossible for me to complete the entire bowl. The price was remarkably reasonable, a mere five dollars! Furthermore, their distinctive menu showcased an admirable departure from the ubiquitous chicken or beef dishes blanketed in teriyaki sauce, although it failed to elicit a profoundly remarkable impression. Nonetheless, I appreciate the uniqueness of their offerings, and given the proximity of this establishment to Midwestern, coupled with the affordable pricing, I shall certainly revisit it. In fact, I eagerly anticipate sampling their appetizer selections, specifically their crab puffs and egg rolls. Lastly, it is worth mentioning that Midwestern students are entitled to a ten percent discount."

"A pre-opening celebration in honor of Trader Vic's establishment at Planet Hollywood was held last week, to which Tikipug offered a succinct recapitulation of the proceedings. The culinary indulgences were nothing short of regal, featuring an array of delectable delights such as lobster, shrimp, and duck, all of which were devoured with immense relish. Following a hospitable gesture, we were escorted to an opulent banquet hall within the hotel's premises, where we were treated to a captivating spectacle of hula dancers, accompanied by refreshing mai tais and complimentary mugs as tokens of appreciation. Furthermore, we had the privilege of meeting Eve, Trader Vic's granddaughter, who graciously provided us with a guided excursion around the unfinished eatery. The gastronomical mastery of executive chef Rick Giffen, formerly associated with Mon Ami Gabi at Paris next door, was on full display throughout the evening, serving up a veritable feast for the senses that transcended the customary Pu Pu platter. An assessment of three stars has been attributed to the restaurant's fare and potations, while the ambiance has been assigned a solitary star. Perhaps the management would consider implementing VR (visual reality) helmets to enhance the overall experience. As an ardent admirer of Trader Vic's establishments worldwide, including the esteemed Polynesio in Havanna (a tale for another time), I must confess that this particular Trader Vic's Lounge, reminiscent of its counterpart in Beverly Hills, left me somewhat underwhelmed."

"An exceptional lodging experience can be had at this hotel, but be prepared for steep tariffs, especially during peak seasons. My companions and I had the pleasure of staying here during Memorial Day weekend, and while we thoroughly enjoyed the accommodations, we were taken aback by the additional fees for seemingly trivial amenities. A rollaway bed, for instance, cost an extra $20 per night, and utilizing the minibar was only possible after paying a fee. 

Despite these drawbacks, the hotel's prime location cannot be ignored. It is conveniently situated mere minutes from the Las Vegas Strip, making it an ideal choice for those seeking proximity to the city's vibrant nightlife. During our stay, we had the opportunity to attend Rehab, a popular concert series hosted by the hotel, featuring renowned artists such as Drake and Lil Wayne. However, be aware that complimentary tickets for guests are limited to two per room and are subject to availability, resulting in lengthy queues and inflated prices. 

In addition to the aforementioned concert series, the hotel boasts a casino, various dining establishments, and a nightclub, ensuring that guests need not venture beyond the premises to experience an enjoyable stay. Despite the aforementioned grievances, I would consider giving this hotel another chance in the future, perhaps during a less busy period."

We commenced our culinary excursion with an order of Waffle Fry Nachos, which featured an abundance of waffle fries enrobed in a rich, velvety blanket of white cheddar and sloppy joe, further accentuated by a tangy salsa and spicy jalapenos. Although delectable, I might suggest to the kitchen staff that they refrain from incorporating the sloppy joe in future iterations, as its presence proved somewhat superfluous and detracted from the overall enjoyment of the dish. 

In contrast, my companion opted for the Crispy Four Cheese Burger, a gastronomic masterpiece characterized by a symphony of four distinct cheeses, each carefully fused onto the patty to create a delightfully crunchy and creamy amalgamation. While the brioche bun proved somewhat overwhelming and desiccated, the burger itself was skillfully prepared, boasting a perfect balance of flavors and textures. Notably, my spouse preferred the onion roll, selecting a beef patty adorned with pepper jack cheese, jalapenos, and caramelized onions, all situated upon the aforementioned onion roll. The resulting dish was exquisitely crafted, bursting with flavor and juiciness.

Unfortunately, our experience was marred by sluggish service, a common pitfall for establishments in their nascent stages. However, we remained optimistic that with time, the kinks would be ironed out, leading to a more seamless and satisfying dining experience for future patrons.

A-OK describes Steve's Greenhouse Grill perfectly in my opinion. It's somewhat like a Cracker Barrel minus the company backing and plus sports... a rather kitsch design scheme with loud colors, loud TVs, and loud alcohol advertisements hung all around, a large and  eclectic menu with something that will surely please all types of eaters, your very typical bar menu of slightly overpriced drinks, and somewhat over the top servers singing praise over every single menu item (\"You can't go wrong!\" \"They're all my favorite!\"). I had some chicken fried steak with fries and Kristen G. had \"The Special\", which was fish and chips with a bowl of New England clam chowder. Everything was A-OK. Some things were a little salty, some things were just right, some too bland... I'm telling you, if you took a Cracker Barrel, cut the budget by three quarters, and told the manager to attempt to please every kind of patron that would be walking around this area of Phoenix, you would get Steve's Greenhouse Grill.

Like others in the surrounding vicinity, we patiently awaited and attentively observed as this particular space underwent transformation into Central Bistro, boasting a captivating ambiance that, while quite vibrant, was not without its auditory intensity; with the windows open, allowing the gentle breeze to permeate the establishment, it was truly sublime. However, one cannot help but ponder the potential impact on the sonic landscape once the windows are sealed, effectively enclosing the space.  
The culinary offerings were undoubtedly delectable, and the service was generally satisfactory, yet one glaring concern marred our overall experience: during two separate visits, we noticed bartenders engaged in the preparation of garnishes with uncovered hands, exemplified by the peeling of an orange, resulting in the release of juice that flowed down their arms and hands, followed by the slicing of said fruit for use in various beverages. Moreover, during our most recent visit, a bartender was observed inserting his hand directly into an olive jar, retrieving a handful, and depositing them into the garnish tray, prompting us to swiftly remove the olives from our martini.  
To the esteemed personnel of Central Bistro, we implore you to address these issues forthwith, lest a visit from the Maricopa County health authorities prove problematic.
