I determined that I would prefer to conduct all my culinary indulgences at the counter of vintage refurbished residences in the central business district of Phoenix. Fortuitously, I stumbled upon Coronado Cafe. We halted our activities for the midday repast, and thus, I did not feel compelled to order an extensive quantity of comestibles as I customarily enjoy doing when sampling a novel eatery (it was a workday). Alas, my assessment shall be restricted to a solitary menu item. I assure you, dear reader, that I shall compensate for this deficiency in my subsequent visit. We visited the establishment during the noontide hour, and there existed a brief delay in securing a table designed to accommodate two patrons. Consequently, we opted to situate ourselves at the bar. The interior space was somewhat diminutive in size. The bar itself possessed sufficient capacity to accommodate four individuals comfortably, with a maximum occupancy of five patrons. An array of potent potables and vinous beverages were visible to my sight, although unfortunately, I was unable to partake in their consumption. My dinner selection consisted of a delectable roasted fowl sandwich, accompanied by a preference for the potato salad instead of the traditional baked beans. The poultry was delightfully succulent, and the peppers contained within the dish manifested an appropriate degree of fiery zest. The potato salad served as a scrumptious complementary side dish. The entire dining experience was straightforward, yet gratifying. I yearn to revisit this eatery at a later time when the atmosphere is less hectic. The temperature during the month of August rendered the outdoor seating area unsuitable for comfort, and obtaining the attention of the server or bartender proved to be a challenging endeavor.

"Concurring with both Pierre and Donald, I must emphasize that there are indeed two menu items worthy of consideration. Whenever I opt for takeout, I invariably select the lettuce wedge and the willy burger, as they prove to be consistently satisfying options. It is unfortunate, however, that the steak dishes fail to meet expectations, as the chef's heavy-handed application of a certain seasoning renders the meat inedible. Furthermore, there appears to be a fundamental misunderstanding regarding the distinction between medium rare and well done, leading to an unfortunate disparity between my order and the actual preparation of the rib-eye. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, I must admit that the bread, when served fresh from the oven, boasts an impressive quality. Additionally, the wrap up burgers merit praise, while the lettuce wedge remains an undisputed highlight of the menu."

Liked this place. Went on a Sunday so the guy didn't make much because he said their slow on Sundays. We tried a little bit of everything and liked it. I would have given more stars but the service was bad, maybe the guy was in a bad mood, not sure. Make sure you have somewhere to eat after you buy the poke unless you want to eat outside in the Vegas heat! No indoor seating. Would recommend you come here to pick up poke because overall the food was good.

Decent food is served here at affordable prices.  We came during the middle of the week for breakfast after reading so many positive reviews.  Was looking forward to trying one of their pots of bread that we read so much about.

We came at a good time because we had no wait at all.  The restaurant was about half full.  Our server was terrific, friendly, attentive, and fast.  

There are many choices on the menu.  We were getting confused because everything sounded so good.  I finally decided on Jamm's French Toast.  My wife ordered an omelet.

So, what did I think of the food?  Overall, it was okay.  Maybe, we did not order the best food off the menu.  Would I come here again?  Probably not.  There are so many breakfast places yet for us to try in Las Vegas.

"It is abundantly evident that a vast improvement has transpired, owing to the revamped entrance that has replaced the erstwhile arduous ascent of five flights of industrial parking garage-style stairs, followed by an additional two floors to reach the primary dance area. Instead, an unpredictable guest elevator now ferries patrons to a random floor, where they must navigate through a poolside concert before ascending yet another flight of stairs to arrive at the coveted destination. Kudos are extended for this enhancement. However, certain drawbacks persist, such as the minuscule dance floor that remains inaccessible, rendering it challenging to partake in rhythmic movements when the venue reaches capacity. Moreover, the absence of visual proximity to the dance floor when the space becomes congested renders it impossible to relish the experience fully. A brief respite can be obtained outdoors, but this option proves less than desirable during the winter months. It is reasonable to surmise that the same designers responsible for TAO also played a role in creating this establishment, given the lack of fluidity, atmosphere, and enjoyable revelry that permeates the space."

Went out here with some friends on Sunday night, right when you walk in it is a little small, but they do have an outdoor section where it is heated. The menu is fairly large with lots of selections. We all ordered different things but the portions are large! So be careful many items on a small table can make it difficult to eat! BUT- I enjoyed the food, tea gets served in a metal dish container. The food is heavy on the saucy side. The service could have been better.

"The culinary delight that ensued upon consuming the pizza was unfortunately juxtaposed by an utter lack of hospitality and acrimonious demeanor exhibited by a certain staff member. Specifically, the African American female who operated the cash register failed to acknowledge my presence upon my arrival, and subsequent interactions were tainted with brusqueness and disdain. Moreover, following payment, I inquired regarding seating arrangements, to which she responded with an eye-roll, bereft of any semblance of cordiality or articulation. Notably, a male employee with red hair displayed a modicum of civility upon my entrance, yet his efforts were undermined by the discordant exchange he engaged in with the aforementioned colleague prior to his departure for a delivery. It is worth mentioning that the ambiance was also marred by an evident lack of cleanliness, as evidenced by the grimy tables and the haphazard manner in which the pizza was prepared. Despite the gustatory appeal of the pizza, a concerted effort towards improving customer service would greatly enhance the overall experience."

stopped here for a quick dessert b/c my wife love red velvet cupakes.  we came after lunch on a sunday and the selection was extremely limited.  each cupcake runs $3.00 which isnt bad for a "gourmet" cupcake shop.

the cupcakes are definitely loaded with frosting, however i wasnt overly impressed with the taste of caramel on my cupcake and the red velvet ones were not made with cream cheese frosting.

all in all great for a nice dessert.

"An ideal location for culinary indulgence within the confines of the Phoenix airport, this eatery boasts a hospitable ambiance, an accommodating staff, and a delectable menu offering an array of savory delights. My personal preference was the grilled chicken-stuffed pita, complemented by a fresh lettuce and tomato salad, creamy hummus, and a tangy vinaigrette dressing. Additionally, they provide charging stations for convenience. A veritable gastronomic haven amidst the hustle and bustle of air travel."

Beautiful club, no doubt.

I did go on a night where our industry trade show was in town, and my industry happens to be mainly composed of men.  So the guy girl ratio was probably OFF the charts for this club's normal operation, about 50 guys to 1 girl....... no joke!

Besides the sausage-ness of my visit, it was still fun to hang out and grab a few drinks with friends, colleagues, and the occasional female model.  Even if the drinks are a bit watered and expensive....

Would i return?

Yes..... if it's not under the "you have to know someone to get in" stigma it operates under most of the time.

I was looking for best Peking duck in town and found Blossom. According to our server, it takes 2 days to prepare. I had a very high expectation for this place since it is $79 per duck. Fyi: I had pecking duck from one of the best Peking duck restuarant in Beijing. The duck was served with skin and meat and sauce on a wrap. Ummm. It should be served with skin only? The skin is not crispy enough. The sauce is ok. After that the duck was brought back to chop. The meat was juicy but have a bit of distinct smell of the duck. Overall, the Peking duck is better than other places in So cal like duck house. But it is far from comparable to the Peking duck I had in Beijing.  And for the price, I would expect better quality.

Always good. Pass on the pasta dish. Disappointing. 

Also they make a Pizzookie that is supposed to be half cooked and it was not even 20% cooked. 

I mentioned it to our waiter (worst one we ever had there. Thomas I think) and he said "it's supposed to be like that" then walked away! Awesome customer service.

Rating is down from a 4 or 5 due to service. Maybe it will be better if we go back again.

Came here on a Thurs night and there was no wait for dinner. They had a fancy dinner menu with fish, poultry and meats, but we opted for their lighter fare summer dinner menu which had sandwiches, pastas and pizzas. We tried the chicken buffalo wing \"lollipops\" as our appetizer, it was your run of the mill buffalo wings but prepared so that one end was the bone and the other end was the chicken which made it super easy to eat. I'm big on italian food so I was trying to decide between either the pizza or pasta and ended up choosing the \"pasta a la bolognaise\" which was a huge mistake. It was penne-like pasta with tomato and meat sauce which looked like something I could have made and I'm not a cook. It wasn't horrible but I just wasn't expecting something so mediocre in taste and presentation. Portions were big though, I'll give them that. Service was good and the pizzas at the surrounding tables looked good so I would probably try that next time if I ever came back.

"As an individual who adheres to a vegetarian dietary preference and has a penchant for light beverages, my patronage of Alchemy is predicated upon the establishment's willingness to accommodate my culinary inclinations, which, in recent times, they have endeavored to do by augmenting their menu with an increased variety of vegetarian options. However, I must confess that my expectations were not entirely met during my most recent visit, as the menu's emphasis on Southeast Asian cuisine struck me as somewhat incongruous and, regrettably, the Vietnamese Rice Noodle Salad that I opted to sample fell short of my gastronomical standards, thereby necessitating my advice to potential patrons to exercise caution in their selection."

"While not an optimal destination for an extensive culinary experience, this establishment can provide an adequate setting for socializing over a meal, albeit at a premium cost. Beverages, in particular, tend to be overpriced, while the fare itself is merely passable, with sandwiches often exhibiting an excessive sodium content and meat that lacks freshness. Nonetheless, if one's primary objective is to partake in beer or UFC-related activities, this venue can offer a suitable environment for relaxation and casual gatherings with acquaintances. Additionally, karaoke nights can prove to be an enjoyable diversion."

This establishment is evolving into a hub for local hipster students, where the consumption of tea has become a trendy phenomenon. Indeed, the contemporary parlance among youth dictates that tea is now considered "cool," or whatever colloquialism is en vogue at present. The crux of this success lies in the fact that everything about the establishment exudes vitality and youthfulness, a stark contrast to the conventional, dimly lit tea houses that have historically been associated with an older demographic. Upon my initial visit, I harbored some reservations, which were promptly addressed by a remarkably young staff member who suggested that I seek answers online. Although somewhat taken aback by the response, I opted to reserve judgment until a subsequent visit.  
Upon my return, I was greeted by employees who were eager to provide me with what they termed the "DavidsTea experience" - an encounter characterized by an atmosphere of freshness, liveliness, and an unmistakable sense of excitement. It became apparent that patrons could either purchase tea for home consumption or opt for a more portable variety. The prices for the latter were conspicuously displayed, with each selection labeled at $2.50. While some might consider this price point to be steep, I rationalized that the cost was justified given the reputed benefits of tea consumption. Thus, I elected to sample a chocolate-orange blend, augmented by whisked soy milk and agave, at a total cost of $4.50. However, my enthusiasm was tempered by the realization that nearly every aspect of the tea-making process was seemingly optional, leading me to wonder if the price was truly worthwhile. Furthermore, I couldn't help but feel a twinge of dismay as I watched the tea-making specialist discard any excess brew into a sink, rather than allowing it to be savored by those who might appreciate its flavor. Notwithstanding these misgivings, I must admit that the tea was quite palatable. Nonetheless, I cannot help but regard this establishment as more of a convenient stopover for a hasty caffeine fix, rather than a setting conducive to lingering over a leisurely cup of tea. Additionally, the space tends to become congested rather quickly, making it challenging to fully enjoy the ambiance. While the shop does offer a diverse array of tea-related accoutrements, I would advise against purchasing a glass kettle from them, as the prices appear to be inflated.

"I had the occasion to partake in a professional sojourn at this establishment earlier this year, and my experience was somewhat lackluster. The check-in process was tediously slow and appeared to be plagued by an antiquated system, which contributed to the prolonged delay. Furthermore, there was an issue with the delivery of a package I had requested, which was not only late but also seemingly misplaced within the premises. Despite the aforementioned setbacks, I did sample the culinary offerings of one of the on-site cafes, specifically the one renowned for its delectable pastries. However, the persistent French theme became somewhat tiresome after a couple of days. In terms of the accommodations themselves, they were adequate, perhaps slightly superior to the standard fare typically encountered. Nonetheless, my overall impression of the hotel was rather unremarkable, and I would not consider it as a prime choice for a personal vacation."

"I transiently entered this establishment with the intention of ascertaining whether they possessed any antenna balls; however, upon inquiring, it became apparent that they were momentarily depleted and awaiting restocking, though the precise timing of their replenishment remained uncertain. Despite being presented with a visual representation of the item in question, my comprehension of its appearance remained limited. During my brief sojourn within the premises, I opted to consume a Jumbo Jack, which, much to my satisfaction, proved to be flavorsome and provided me with a fleeting experience of JITB that, regrettably, cannot be obtained in Canada."

I was not thoroughly impressed by this establishment. It possesses an unremarkable ambiance reminiscent of a Fox restaurant within the Scottsdale Quarter. 
  The menu exhibits limited options and lacks comprehensive descriptions. The culinary offerings are unexceptional and fail to tantalize my taste buds. I opted for the roasted chicken, influenced by my server's description of it as "half a chicken," which led me to anticipate the presence of breast meat. However, I was disappointed to receive a meager thigh and drumstick, accompanied by an excessive amount of sodium-saturated baby spinach and runny polenta. 
  While the dishes appeared inventive, their flavors fell short of impressive. This dining experience proved to be underwhelming. 
  Observing the waitstaff, I noticed a sense of disarray, as they presented us with various appetizers that we had not ordered. This raises concerns about the potential impact on TK's profit margin. Nevertheless, they seem to compensate for it through modest portion sizes. 
  In conclusion, this restaurant does not warrant a repeat visit in my opinion.

Decent Chinese take-out.  The Lo Mein is good, as are their shrimp and beef dishes.  Did not care for their shrimp and lobster sauce.  Their ribs can be hit or miss, depending on how fatty they are.  Also did not care for their Won ton or egg drop soup.  Their fried rice is good, but then, I've rarely had bad fried rice...

"I recently had the privilege of visiting the authentic location in Fort Lauderdale, and let me tell you, it was an unforgettable experience. The cuisine was exquisite, and the ambiance was truly captivating. However, my recent visit to this particular location fell short of my expectations. Despite being a busy Wednesday evening in Florida, the atmosphere was lackluster, and the quality of the food did not live up to the standards set by its predecessor. 

The meatball was disappointingly dry, and the pasta was undercooked. Although the chicken parmesan was palatable, it failed to impress me. The sauce, however, remained a highlight. 

It's intriguing to observe that the vast majority of favorable reviews for this establishment mention Steve's presence. Perhaps his involvement does have a bearing on the quality. I recall him meticulously examining nearly every dish that emerged from the kitchen at the original location. Unfortunately, such attention to detail was absent during my visit. 

Consequently, I shall confer three stars upon this eatery. While our server was attentive, the culinary offerings did not measure up to the lofty standards established by its sister restaurant. I must confess that I am unlikely to return to this specific location, given the abundance of exceptional dining options in Las Vegas. Nonetheless, my anticipation for my subsequent visit to the Florida location remains unwavering!"

"The embellishments alone solidify the transaction for me. Mid-Century contemporary, and the eatery is executed impeccably. Preferred destination for socializing with a companion and engaging in conversation. The booths provide an unparalleled sense of seclusion. The chopped salad is my consistent selection due to my profound admiration for it. The green goddess dressing is sublime. They offer rolls and butter, and these particular specimens are authentic; a true blast from the past... extraordinarily soft and warm! I may be developing a dependency on iced tea (the jury is still deliberating) and I find myself enchanted by its presentation here...a sizable, towering glass, mint, a side of simple syrup for customized sweetening, and an iced tea spoon! It's the uncomplicated aspects at times that significantly enhance my encounter :) Uncertain if they continue to offer this, but their cake & a shake for dessert is utterly captivating. Minuscule chocolate shake presented alongside a minuscule chocolate cake. A flawless petite indulgence!"

The food is good here, but not up to the quality of the other top notch steakhouses in Scottsdale. The prices are the same as the other high quality restaurants, so I expect the same quality in return. It's just not quite the same. If the price wasn't the same then I would come back because it's still good. However, if I'm going to pay top dollar then I'd rather go to some of the other places that I know are going to be the best like City Hall.\n\nThey do a few things different, which is a nice change like their popover bread to start, and some of their main dishes. The steaks are good, but not excellent, and everything seems to get about the same grade. I will probably come here again for a change of pace and hope that it's just a little better, but definitely not in my top 3 for steakhouses in Scottsdale.

"This location possesses an ambiance that exudes both coolness and affordability, yet it is essential to recognize that the quality of the merchandise is commensurate with the price point. I acquired a keychain for my mother at a cost of twelve dollars, only to witness its sudden demise approximately one week subsequent to my purchase, during which time I was in close proximity. Following this unfortunate occurrence, I opted to exchange it for a replacement, but unfortunately, the new item suffered a similar fate, breaking once again after a brief period of time. Considering my previous experiences, I decided to procure a gift card, given that I had paid in cash and lacked both the receipt and any tangible evidence of my purchase. It is important to acknowledge that this establishment can be somewhat unpredictable, as certain items are reasonably priced, while others may not be worth the investment. Furthermore, due to its location within Tivoli, there are numerous parking options available."

This Thai Rama is a small little place located near the light rail but in a spot that can be easy to miss. Being a huge fan of Thai food and a little picky, I was slightly worried when we approached it. However, one of my friends was craving Thai and I was thinking I could always get a little something :)  

The menu was very large and seemed to have a lot of good offerings. Not being very hungry, I was enthusiastic they had a dessert they called F.B.I. which was friend bananas and coconut ice cream. Myself and another guest ordered that and the other member of our party ordered shrimp pineapple curry (yum). The food came out fairly fast with the ice cream dishes coming out only a minute before the main course dish. 

The ice cream was a little on the ice side (as if it had been overfrozen) but overall was a delicious meal. I tasted some of the shrimp pineapple curry and it was just the right temperature and full of flavor. However, the pineapple was obviously canned which make it lack that something.

I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to come back here again, but with the pleasant staff, if I was in the area, I might swing on in.

It is the crew that makes this store work!
And it is the crew that keeps me coming back!
They always seem to go above and beyond what is being asked.
That kind of service is rare!

Once upon a time, you could walk into Uncle Sal's on a Friday night with no reservations and be seated immediately. (Holy crap - has it really been 20 years since I lived in the area?!?!)
Those days are long gone. Dinner was on me for coordinating - and I dropped the ball.

Luckily, the Blind Pig was right next door, and we 4 hungry patrons could be seated and served right away.

We shared a couple plated for the table, and nibbled each other's entrees. The steak salad was a winner. The short rib was well cooked and flavorful. And everything else was perfectly OK. I had a trio of tacos  - none of which really stood out. Nothing wrong with them. Fresh, flavorful, well executed. I am just spoiled by other places in my current 'hood.

If I am in the area, and someone suggests the Blind Pig, I won't object. 
I also don't think I'd plan another meal there. Nothing in the world wrong with the place - just no "wow" factor for me.

"Upon our initial arrival, it was approaching the late hours of the evening, specifically midnight, and we were delighted to discover that this establishment remained open and operational, extending its hospitality to accommodate our group of twelve individuals. Although the pace of service was somewhat lethargic, it was comprehensible, given the unconventional hour and the substantial number of patrons in our party. My recollection of the culinary offerings is somewhat hazy, although I seem to recall enjoying a satisfactory steak; however, the true highlight of the dining experience was the refreshing and delectable cup of fresh watermelon juice that was presented to us. Despite the slight delay in service, the staff maintained a friendly and courteous demeanor throughout our visit. It is worth mentioning that the prices listed on the menu were slightly elevated, yet this was to be anticipated in a high-end venue such as Aria. Subsequently, we opted to explore alternative dining options, including the hotel's room service, its extensive buffet, and eventually, we made the wise decision to sample the local cuisine, thereby saving ourselves a considerable amount of expenses. In conclusion, while the dining experience at Aria was not particularly memorable, it was not entirely disappointing either."

"When you consider a platter of morning potatoes, specifically those prepared via the process of au gratin, in conjunction with a dish of stir-fried vegetables and noodles, commonly referred to as chow mein, and subsequently cover this entire assortment with an abundance of melted butter, the resultant culinary creation serves as the embodiment of the underlying reason behind the animosity harbored by extremist groups towards the United States of America... 

The establishment's maintenance of cleanliness was satisfactory, the quality of service was adequate, and the array of comestibles presented at the buffet was consistent with my expectations for a Las Vegas casino located in the downtown area: unremarkable yet copious. 

However, the voluminous vessel of liquefied butter remains an enigma, its presence prompting inquiry into the rationale behind such an extravagant display of richness."

This is the place you want to go after a night of drinking. The food is typical Mexican food. The drive thru was quick and efficient. The major issue i had with this location is that the portion size on my Carne Asada fries was ridiculously small. Every other location i've been to usually gives you a good chunk of everything, but this location really got  stingy. That was a major disappointment. Ill revisit again in a couple of weeks and ill see if i have the same experience.
Nothing too impressive. Burgers were pretty decent, but not out if this world. Onion rings were good. Price was expensive for what it was, in Vegas.

This particular site falls within the proximate vicinity of both my domicile and that of my parental unit, thereby rendering me a habitual patron. The diverse beverage preferences of my two offspring and myself often pose a formidable challenge for the establishment's staff, which has experienced periodic fluctuations in personnel. Despite this variable consistency, the venue's accessibility continues to attract me. During peak morning hours, queues tend to accumulate, yet the staff efficiently expedites customers through the line. On the rare occasions when I've needed to return an order, the staff members have demonstrated profuse apologies and cooperation.

Came here on a friday night for drinks. Fun place to check out. People said its like being at a beach, definitely didnt get that feeling. However, drinks were good. Bartender didnt make a three wise men correctly. DJ played really good music. Probly wont come here for tacos though.

Was able to go in without a wait. Part of the Westin Hotel, there is a nice decor to the OFM, but the clientele seem to be going elsewhere.

Our server was very helpful and gave us some suggestions on what to order. We asked about what sushi rolls we could start off with as appetizers for the group, and he suggested two that worked very well. They were both tuna-based, one mild and one spicier. It definitely lives up to the claim that OFM has some good sushi.

We then ordered our mains, and I got the cioppino. Now, I'm used to cioppino coming out as a stew with chunks of fish in a broth, but OFM's chef has decided to serve an entire slab of mahi on a thin layer of the broth with the accompanying shellfish. The dish was cooked well, but the presentation (lack of actual stew) left me wanting for more.

The caesar salad was pretty good, with actual anchovies on top.

The Hawaiian waluu dish got a thumbs up.

The crab cakes were also said to be very tasty.

Overall, the experience was nice and relaxed, and the service is friendly. However, the food itself (besides the sushi) needs to be reinvigorated somehow to get it back into competition with all the new kids on the block.

"Upon my return on multiple occasions subsequent to the transition of ownership, I have observed a marked improvement in the quality of service, precipitating an upward adjustment in my rating. The reinstatement of certain culinary artisans previously associated with the establishment has contributed significantly to the enhancement of the dining experience. While the proprietor's persistent presence near the sushi bar may engender a sense of scrutiny regarding the portioning of seafood delicacies, it is my belief that a visit to this restaurant is indeed warranted."

"I placed an order for two eggs and potatoes, which amounted to a mere $3.85, a veritable bargain!  Upon requesting that my eggs be scrambled, they arrived accompanied by home fries and toast.  While my meal may have lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, it is indeed challenging to botch such fundamental fare as eggs, toast, and potatoes. 

The eggs and toast, while unremarkable, were adequate â?a far cry from the uninspired effort exhibited in the preparation of the home fries.  It appeared that someone had merely boiled some potatoes, carelessly plunked them into a pan, and then served them without so much as a cursory seasoning.  My futile attempts to enhance their flavor with salt and pepper notwithstanding, the potatoes seemed resolute in their blandness.  After a few half-hearted forkfuls, I relinquished my efforts.  

My visit took place during a morning meeting, and the establishment was relatively unfrequented.  Although there were a smattering of regular patrons present, the ambiance was generally subdued.  It is conceivable that this venue might appeal to individuals seeking sustenance following a night of revelry, when the craving for nourishment often surpasses concerns regarding culinary refinement.  However, I would not deliberately seek out Ritters except in the event of an unexpected late-night hunger pang or the need for a 24-hour eatery.  It is worth noting that payment is restricted to cash transactions."

You know - I wanted to write "I love Sunset Grille", but then I thought about it and it really occurred to me that I don't love Sunset Grille.  I like Sunset Grille, and I will return to Sunset Grille, but it's not my favorite place in Charlotte.  

It's OK.  The service is great, the layout is cool and it appears to have a happening bar if you hit it at the right time.  Food-wise, it's just OK.  I love breakfast sandwiches (and you should try this place for brunch...), but they do not have a typical breakfast sandwich, which was disappointing.  I had an Eggs Benedict's, sans Hollandaise (because you should not really eat that in a restaurant unless you know they made it right then - Thanks Anthony Bourdain for that tip).  The canadian bacon was really, really, really salty though.  

Other things I have had: An open face turkey sandwich, which now that I think about it - was salty too.  I also tried a blackbean burger with fries that was OK.  

So, as I wrote above - the more I think about it, Sunset is OK.  They try hard and are extremely attentive there, but there are better places for food in my opinion.

Is it better than Chipukele?  Sure.  Is that saying much?  Not really. The best part about this place is their tortillas which are hand-made right in front of you.  The corn tortillas are delicious.\n\nI found the sweet pork to be WAY too sweet.  The shredded beef was OK.  The rice and pinto beans, IMO, were the best part.  I guess if I had to go to Chipotle, I'd pick this place, but if there was no gun to my head, it would be easy to forget about this establishment.  There wasn't really anything wrong with it, it's just there.

"My culinary predilection gravitates towards Thai cuisine; however, the gastronomical offerings at this establishment are merely satisfactory, and the prices for the meager portions served during the luncheon hour are exorbitant. Moreover, upon conveying my desire for a less piquant sauce, the chef failed to accommodate my request by omitting any discernible seasonings. Although I might consider revisiting this restaurant, I would not be inclined to do so at my own expense."

"Following my previous critique of North Carolina barbecue, I must confess that the poultry-based offering at this particular eatery did not entirely fail to meet my expectations. Indeed, the juxtaposition of crispy, golden batter and succulent, flavorful chicken in the fried pickle dish was rather pleasing to my palate, and I would unhesitatingly return to sample it again. Furthermore, the cost of the meal, while not insignificant, was reasonable considering the venue's location within the airport terminal. Additionally, the complimentary wireless internet access and electrical outlets available in the seating area allowed me to productively utilize my time during my visit, making the overall experience more satisfying. In conclusion, while Charlotte Douglas International Airport may have its drawbacks, this specific dining establishment is certainly worthy of a brief detour."
Good food. Way too chaotic!  Very loud. Nowhere to sit because tables aren't bused. Half the price of PF Chang's but miss the ambiance.

Maybe the novelty of In-n-Out has worn off on me. I didn't find this location to be any different than the ones I used to eat at in California, but I guess my tastes have matured. For all the hype and history, in the end it's just a fast food burger (although a decent one).

I made the mistake of arriving for my 11PM reservation with a hangover, so I didn't quite get to enjoy the full excellence. Seating was very cramped, but in full view of the kitchen, which made the experience much more enjoyable. Food was good, but expect to spend $$$. \n\nOh, and make reservations EARLY. The night before my reservation someone offered me $500 for it, so that's a good indication of the popularity of the place.

"The most advantageous aspect of this lodging establishment is the complimentary, made-to-order breakfast, which is accessible via a ticket that can be redeemed in the dining area. The breakfast menu offers a variety of options, including eggs, French toast, or pancakes, all of which are served with potatoes and a choice of either sausage or bacon. Additionally, a selection of cereals, oatmeal, bread or toast, muffins, and fruit is available, along with a variety of beverages such as juice, milk, and coffee. 

The location of this hotel is highly convenient, as it is situated just across from the shopping mall and numerous restaurants, and is easily accessible from the nearby interstate highway. 

The room we stayed in, which featured a king-sized bed and a sleeper sofa, was quite spacious and reminiscent of a small studio or efficiency apartment. Furthermore, it was equipped with a full refrigerator, stove, and microwave, and was maintained in a clean and tidy manner. 

However, there were a few drawbacks to our stay. Firstly, the room tended to feel oppressively warm whenever we entered it, and adjusting the air conditioning did not seem to alleviate this issue. Secondly, the pillows provided were unacceptably flat and lacked sufficient support, even when using two pillows. Lastly, the stairs leading to the second floor were rather steep, and the absence of an elevator may present a challenge for individuals with mobility issues or those carrying excessive luggage. 

Despite these minor shortcomings, this hotel still offers a perfectly adequate and hospitable environment for a brief stay."

Apparently this is the largest restaurant in the state of Arizona. From the outside and the dining area I ate in, could have fooled me. A good friend of mine was working his last shift as a server so that is why I went. Not a huge fan of steakhouses. 

The atmosphere was pretty throw-back, 70s vibe, someplace your grandpa and dad would take you for your first real steak experience. It was dark inside and they sitting area had a retro feel like an Arizona mobster may be biting down into his steak right next to you. I was told there's a lot of history in the building so I respected the decor. 

I order a wonderful shrimp salad that came topped with the biggest, juiciest shrimps I've seen in a long time. I saved them for last because they were so crunchy to eat. My roommate ordered a sirloin and sadly had to send it back twice to get it recooked. Our wiater said that wsn't the first time that evening that had happened with someone's food and that particular chef. But the bread basket made up for it. With wonderful rosemary topped, the bread was light and buttery. 

Best part of the night? Check in on Foursquare and you can get a beer for .5 cents at the bar. We knew the waiter so he hooked us up at the table, but I have NEVER seen a deal that insane on Fourswaure before.

"The aspects I appreciated about this dining establishment were: 
-The reasonable pricing of their casual lunch fare, which is quite uncommon in Las Vegas. 
-The brief waiting period of less than ten minutes to accommodate our group of ten individuals. 
-The availability of seating shortly after the conclusion of the Rock and Roll half-marathon, which is quite remarkable given the race's proximity to the venue. We presumed that the restaurant might be congested. 
-The culinary quality of their burgers, although it's worth mentioning that our palates were heightened due to completing a 13-mile run. 

The elements that did not meet my expectations were: 
-The depletion of their sweet potato fries inventory. We were eagerly anticipating savoring them. Disappointment ensued. 
-The sluggishness of their service, despite the absence of a large clientele. We had to seek assistance from multiple staff members to procure water and place our orders. 
-The inconsistent preparation of our meals. Onions were included in dishes where they shouldn't have been. Salads arrived after the main course. Some entrees were served five to eight minutes prior to the rest of the party. Missteps of this nature. 

In summary, it was an average dining experience. I am not particularly enthusiastic about revisiting this establishment in the near future."

"Our most recent dining excursion to this esteemed establishment proved to be somewhat disparate from our previous visits, as various aspects of the experience appeared to be somewhat disorganized and lacking in coherence. Specifically, there was a considerable delay in being seated, despite having made a reservation well in advance, and certain technical issues pertaining to the processing of our club benefits arisen, which hindered our ability to fully enjoy the dining experience. Furthermore, the Caesar salad we ordered was of an inferior quality and quantity compared to our expectations, and the lobster entree we shared failed to meet our expectations in terms of both its size and visual appeal. Throughout the meal, we encountered numerous minor yet cumulatively significant mishaps and inconsistencies, leading us to surmise that perhaps there have been some recent changes within the restaurant's management or staff that may have contributed to the overall feeling of 'glitchiness' that permeated our visit. Despite these issues, the taste and preparation of the food remained satisfactory, and we shall indeed return to this establishment in the future, albeit with a heightened sense of vigilance and caution, in light of the aforementioned anomalies."

"Indulge in a delectable steak and eggs culinary experience at this esteemed eatery, conveniently situated near an array of luxurious hotels. Following an exhilarating night of revelry and merriment, this venue offers the perfect setting for a satisfying meal and brief respite before retiring to one's lodgings. Although the fare may not be of the highest caliber, the affordability and generous portions more than compensate for any perceived deficiencies in quality. Be prepared to endure a prolonged wait, as the popularity of this establishment tends to attract a sizable crowd, particularly among those seeking sustenance prior to returning to their accommodations. However, by placing your name on the waiting list and patiently awaiting your turn, you may observe that those ahead of you in line gradually disappear, either due to fatigue from waiting or the allure of a nearby slot machine. Laughter and amusement are sure to ensue."
I ordered an almond taro milk tea, which was pretty good. However, the popcorn chicken is not the typical popcorn I was expecting. And I got a bunch of breaded pieces left :/

This was was my first visit to smash em up, bash em up burger.  The staff was very friendly upon taking my order and was really good about saying about how long it would take for the food.   I had the classic smash 1/3 pounder and it was good, except it was not done quite enough.  I found it surprising that they didn't ask me how I liked my burger cooked.  For $10, I thought they should have asked.  The food was hot and tasty, I just didn't find it visually appealing for the price.  For a couple bucks less I'd rather go to Culvers.  The decor is minimalist and feels very corporatized.  My friend who suggested the place asked if they actually grilled their burgers and we found out they use 80/20 ground beef.  That was also a bit surprising but then they seemed a little on the greasy side.  I'd come back again, but seems like these places are a dime a dozen.  This one does not come out on my top five burger places.

The chicken here is one of my favorites from any other fast food place in town. Crispy and super-southern! They also have an extensive menu on side choices, from mashed potatoes to a few types of beans, coleslaw, and even mac n cheese (DING DING DING winner) 

While the food here is delicious, the service sucks. I've never come in to contact with so many people that hate their lives than I have at this particular location. You just walk into the place and the cashier gives you this snooty look of HOW DARE YOU COME HERE. Like, bitch please I just want some chicken not your first born child.

Never go through the drive-thru if you can, at this location either. I've only done it about 3 times, and EVERY GODDAMN time, they fucked up my order, or didn't give me a fork or some shit. Plus the girl running the drive-thru window has a shit ton of acne, super gross face. She'll make you lose your appetite.

"A plethora of pizza varieties possess distinct gustatory attributes, with certain iterations exhibiting superior flavor profiles compared to their counterparts; however, an overall mediocrity permeates the culinary experience. A once-pristine establishment, the current state of cleanliness suggests a shift in management priorities, concurrent with a decline in service quality. Notwithstanding, the cinnamon rolls maintain an unparalleled allure, fostering an irresistible craving that prompts repeated visits for gratification."
"This diminutive, cramped eatery, offering economical yet palatable fare, has garnered an excessive amount of acclaim on Yelp, unwarrantedly so, in my opinion."

Nothing to do on a summer night? Head out to a Hounds game. Prices are cheap - certainly more so than about any other sports team in the area, and most nights you'll get to hang out with a bunch of other folks and see and be seen.

The only problem? While lacrosse may be an up-and-coming sport, it's in the same boat as soccer when it comes to being a spectator: It just isn't that great to watch. That isn't to say that these guys don't play hard, because they do. But since there just isn't much to do other than hang out and watch them run around, and occasionally score, the best thing to do at a Hounds game is to socialize and enjoy a nice summer evening.

Also, huge kudos to the Hounds for making use of Memorial Stadium. Have to love that this oldie isn't going to waste, or even worse, being demolished to make use for some new development that may never even happen.

"While my overall assessment of this establishment would be a moderate 3.5 stars, I comprehend the reasoning behind certain patrons' inclination to confer a perfect 4-star rating. Although the culinary offerings and hospitality are undoubtedly deserving of a 4-star distinction, the steep tariffs attached to the tapas selections are somewhat problematic. As a seasoned traveler who has had the privilege of sampling an array of authentic Spanish cuisine, including tapas, in various upscale and casual eateries throughout Spain, I must assert that the prices associated with Jaleo's tapas are exorbitant, particularly in relation to the cheese tapas. Nonetheless, I would highly recommend the delectable paellas served here."

"It was utterly impossible to consider purchasing a divided pizza due to the exorbitant cost, which was tantamount to an astronomical figure, rendering it unfeasible and unjustifiable to indulge in such an extravagance. The sum of twenty-six dollars for a single large pizza was nothing short of preposterous and egregious, especially when juxtaposed with the superior quality and comparatively reasonable pricing offered by Athens Pizza, located just down the road. In point of fact, the latter establishment's culinary offerings were not only more affordable but also boasted a markedly superior taste and overall experience for the consumer."

its always good to have some Chinese food after a few buffets...

came here for lunch... food is pricy for chinese food and dim sum... but i came here on comps... so it didnt matter...

the salmon cold noodle was superb... apart from that... everything is just slightly about average...

"It is imperative that every individual has access to a traditional British public house, as it provides an atmosphere of conviviality and serves as a venue for social gatherings and relaxation. The bartenders, who are the purveyors of beverages and hospitality, possess a refreshing lack of pretentiousness, creating a welcoming ambiance devoid of superfluous embellishments. Patrons can indulge in a variety of potations and enjoy uncomplicated fare, making it an ideal setting for viewing sporting events or partaking in post-work Happy Hour revelry."

"The evaluations for this culinary establishment were predominantly favorable, with numerous patrons praising the exceptional quality of the service and the complementary vegetables that accompanied the primary dishes. However, some minor drawbacks were noted, specifically pertaining to the inadequate quantity and questionable flavor profile of the fillings in both the fried dumplings and bibimbap. Additionally, the latter dish was presented in a sizzling stone pot, which, while aesthetically pleasing, did not adequately showcase the meager amount of beef present, which was often overpowered by the abundance of rice. To enhance the overall dining experience, it is suggested that the restaurant consider augmenting the portion size and variety of vegetables and meat, while proportionally reducing the amount of starches."

Decent bean and cheese, but the cheese is cold and not melted. They use oil, supposedly, instead of lard so thats a plus. Green salsa is good, would be nice if served a small side of chips though,. Hard tacos good but way too much iceburg lettuce, it filled half the taco shell.

3 Stars.

This place is big and I dig the decor.  It was cold so we did not go outside but there is an upstairs balcony area which apparently is pretty neat when the weather is appropriate.  There were two rooms with two different DJs.  One was just hip hop and the other was a top 40 type.  I actually thought the DJ in the top 40 (main room) was terrible...the guy had trouble beat matching playing top 40 stuff...lame.  Given that its Vegas and that it was New Years Day (not eve, but still) I would expect that some of the areas best DJs would be at most of these Vegas clubs.  Maybe he was just having a bad night.

I must say, in most clubs the staff/bouncers are rude as hell but they were quite nice here.  The cover charge if your a normal dude is $40 on the weekends and $20 for ladies.  STEEP!  Especially when that allows you to buy $10 beers at the bar.  I was not going to pay $60 to get me and my girl in.  The bouncer let my girl in for free and I just paid the $40 so for two people $20 a pop if you don't "know anyone" is normal Vegas club pricing I suppose   

I dont think I would go back unless I was staying at Ceaser's, not because it was a negative experience but I just think I would want to try a new club.

"I recently partook in a culinary excursion to this establishment, opting for the convenience of takeout, and my gastronomical exploits led me to sample both the pad tai and PH\u00d2. Upon entering the eatery, I was immediately struck by its bright and pristine ambiance, which suggested a recent renovation or inauguration. The service was indeed cordial and expedient, as the staff displayed an admirable level of proficiency in their duties. The pad tai lived up to my expectations, boasting a delectable combination of flavors and textures that left me thoroughly satiated. My companion's beef dish also garnered praise, further reinforcing the kitchen's reputation for culinary prowess. However, my primary motive for visiting this venue was to indulge in a bowl of steaming hot ph\u00f2, owing to my unfortunate absence of such delicacies in my local vicinity. Unfortunately, my enthusiasm was quickly extinguished upon opening the container, as the broth lacked the characteristic pungency and instead presented a sickly sweet and viscous consistency. Moreover, the coloration of the broth appeared unnaturally dark brown, even though I had specifically requested chicken ph\u00f2. In spite of these shortcomings, I elected to afford the dish the benefit of the doubt and incorporated the noodles and spices, as well as cooked chicken, in accordance with my personal preferences. Alas, my efforts were futile, as the offensive odor and flavor persisted, leaving me no choice but to discard the broth and consume only the noodles. It is conceivable that my experience was an isolated incident, perhaps attributable to an aberrant day in the kitchen; nonetheless, the underwhelming encounter with the ph\u00f2 unfortunately nullified my initial inclination to bestow a perfect five-star rating upon this establishment."

Cheap drinks for happy hour for sure. Tiny bar with real \"creekers\".. very smokey and loud with serious drinkers. This is where you find the locals. Hit or miss with the entertainment but the crowd itself is entertaining enough. I have had a few dishes there that were tasty. Free popcorn inside if you go into the indoor bar. P.S. The dartboard sucks, bring your own plastic darts if you want them to stick. The staff is friendly, never had a problem here.

I have had the pleasure of partaking in the culinary delights offered by Daisho sushi on two separate occasions, with the initial visit taking place shortly after its grand opening, and the second instance occurring earlier this evening. While the experience was not without its merits, it did not quite live up to my expectations, as the quality of the nigiri was inconsistent, with some pieces boasting an impressive freshness and others falling short of my expectations in terms of taste and texture. Furthermore, the green tea ice cream, which I had eagerly anticipated, proved to be somewhat of a disappointment, as its flavor profile failed to deliver the depth and complexity that I had hoped for. In regards to the service, it was adequate, albeit lacking the polished finesse that one might expect from a dining establishment of this caliber. Lastly, it is worth noting that the rolls we opted for did not possess the robust flavors that we had envisioned, leading me to surmise that perhaps our choices were not the most judicious. Considering my proximity to the restaurant, I had intended to provide it with a fair assessment, but ultimately, I find myself inclined to continue frequenting my preferred sushi spot, where the quality of the food and the overall experience are more aligned with my discerning tastes.

I always drive by this place and decided to see what it's all about.  I wasn't hungry, so decided to buy a loaf of sourdough bread.  Granted it was a few days before Christmas, so I guess it was busier than usual.  There were less than 10 people when I came in, but I waited about 10 minutes to pay for my bread.  Maybe I was a little impatient, but if I waited any longer I would've walked out of that place.  In my opinion, the workers were really slow.  I've worked in retail and you never want your customers waiting too long to pay, especially if it's bread!  I'm mean, don't they want my money?  \n\nOn a positive note, the sourdough bread was really good and would probably continue buying my bread there.  Hopefully their cashiers become more efficient.

My family and I have an ardent affinity for the culinary offerings at this establishment, and we typically procure our sustenance through the convenience of the drive-thru window. Our orders have consistently been prepared to our satisfaction, with the food being fresh, hot, and delectable. However, of late, the elderly female employee with the heavily pencil-thin eyebrows, who has been tasked with the responsibility of attending to customers at the drive-thru window, has displayed a marked propensity for irritability and a perceptible lack of enthusiasm towards her occupation. Her behavior has been characterized by an air of superiority and a palpable reluctance to accommodate even the most trivial of requests, thereby creating an unfortunate ambiance that has significantly diminished our overall dining experience. It is with great relief that we have discovered the recent opening of an alternative Mexican food restaurant located further down Greenway, which we eagerly anticipate will provide a more pleasant and hospitable dining environment. Notwithstanding, we cannot help but express our profound disappointment and discontent with the unfortunate prevalence of surliness and discourtesy exhibited by said employee, which has regrettably tarnished our erstwhile favorable impression of this eatery. Consequently, we feel compelled to confer a rating of three stars, accompanied by our fervent hope that a concerted effort will be made towards rectifying this unacceptable state of affairs.

"An exceptional setting with a panoramic view of the pool and an culinary experience that was satisfactory, albeit with a price point that could be considered somewhat elevated in relation to the fundamental nature of the fare offered, yet still within the customary range for establishments of this caliber in the Miami Beach area."

"Upon entering the establishment, I was struck by the capacious nature of the interior, particularly in light of the fact that it appeared to be bustling with activity. Furthermore, I was impressed by the expediency with which I was seated and presented with a menu, as it transpired that my beverage order was already being prepared by the time I had settled into my seat. 

My attention was drawn to the 'All-You-Can-Eat' option, which offered an array of dishes at a fixed price of $20. Given that the majority of the individual rolls were priced at $10 or more apiece, this represented a remarkable value proposition. Accordingly, I opted to sample five rolls in total, thereby ensuring that the quantity of cuisine I received was commensurate with the tariff. Alas, the gastronomic experience itself was merely adequate, as the presentation of the dishes lacked a certain je ne sais quoi and the quality was, at best, slightly superior to middling. 

Furthermore, I encountered a degree of discomfort in procuring additional beverages, as it required multiple attempts to attract the attention of my server, despite the fact that the dining area had become relatively deserted by that point. Moreover, there was a considerable delay in receiving my bill, which necessitated my requesting it multiple times over the course of approximately 20 minutes. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the culinary offerings did possess a certain appeal, particularly in light of the $20 price point and the fact that I departed the premises feeling satiated. Thus, I shall consider paying the restaurant another visit in the future, as it is possible that the issues I encountered may have been anomalous and not necessarily indicative of the establishment's customary level of service."

Just because you are in Vegas don't expect to wine and dine here.  This is meant to be a quick service restaurant with food to satisfy hunger, not give you the \"wow\" factor.\n\nHad the prosciutto sandwich and it tasted just as I anticipated.  Crusty baguette, prosciutto di parma, mozzarella, arugula, and balsamic.  Simple, fast, and on the go.  The cheese pizza would have used some extra time in the oven because the under crust had gone soggy.

I stopped in earlier this month with a friend. We went on a Tuesday night, and almost completely had the place to ourselves. That was OK  as we were able to chat without yelling @ each other, and were able to chat a little bit with Heidi. Great gal...very friendly service. I ordered the Oggie (The Traditional Pasty), mushy peas (mainly after gauging my friend's expression of comfort to see them on the menu...childhood memories no doubt), and chips (potato wedges). I wasn't overwhelmed by the food. However, is English food ever overwhelming?. The pasty was a little dry and the wine gravy takes some getting used to. Although the beef was lean, it wasn't too tender. I can't say I'd recommend on the food, but the Strongbow Cider and the Hoegaarden were both pretty good. Also stuck around to play some Cricket @ the dartboard, which probably wouldn't have normally been available. I think it seems like a good place to have some drinks with friends, and soak up a good crowd atmosphere on a busier night.

"Meeeehhh...it was merely adequate. My acquaintance and I had heard favorable reviews, thus we opted to procure tickets for our second evening in Las Vegas...it was excessively cheesy and the majority of the males lacked the ability to execute even rudimentary choreography with any semblance of proficiency!! Some individuals appeared to be either prematurely or tardily synchronized with the remainder of the ensemble, resulting in an overall lackluster and haphazard appearance...although mildly engaging, I wouldn't attend such a production again. Some of the male performers possessed a certain degree of physical attractiveness, yet others exhibited an unsettling and somewhat menacing demeanor (specifically, the individual with long hair who became overly enthusiastic)...the most enjoyable aspect? The emcee/announcer displayed remarkable comedic talent and significantly enhanced the overall viewing experience. If you are partaking in a bachelorette celebration, this venue may serve as an ideal location to embarrass the future bride...trust me!!"

"While the sandwich may be considered satisfactory in Las Vegas, any individual hailing from Chicago would unquestionably assert that the bread is inadequate and requires improvement; once this crucial element is properly addressed, a truly exceptional sandwich can be attained."

Stopped by here because we needed a quick bite to eat before the Michael Jackson One show.  Thought it would be faster if we went to the bar. Took a while for the bartender to show up, but once she did service was fine. We had the chili cheese kobe beef fries, which hit the spot. Decent place to watch sports as well.

Going to Avalon always appears to be a fantastic notion until I physically attend. Let me clarify, this store does possess an aura of hipness, and one can indeed discover some intriguing items on occasion; however, my personal experience has been that it's either a resounding success or a catastrophic failure. I find their pricing system to be perplexing at times. For instance, I once selected a t-shirt with visible holes, and the price tag read $14. Concerning the term "thrift store," I wouldn't categorize it as exceptionally frugal. Nonetheless, I have acquired several items at a lower price than their original retail value (AE jeans, Urban Outfitters top).  

Another enigma is their purchasing procedure. I've brought clothing to sell on multiple occasions, and the outcome has been inconsistent. I've presented nearly new, stylish attire, only to be met with rejection, while the racks are stocked with garments that appear to belong to someone's grandmother.  

In summary, shopping at Avalon is invariably a mixed bag. Nevertheless, whenever I find myself in Squirrel Hill, I ensure that I visit the store to explore their inventory. Additionally, they maintain an impressive assortment of Halloween costumes throughout October.

"This establishment manifests itself as a veritable behemoth in comparison to its contemporaries, boasting an expansive square footage that is approximately twice the magnitude of its competitors, thereby providing an impressive array of merchandise for perusal and purchase. Upon entering the premises, I was acknowledged by a staff member whose demeanor, while not exuding unbridled enthusiasm, remained courteous and welcoming. As I conducted my brief shopping excursion, I elected not to seek guidance or advice from the sales personnel, opting instead to independently select and procure a specific cosmetic item utilizing a discount coupon that I had obtained through my membership in the Sally Beauty Club loyalty program. During the checkout process, the cashier exhibited a cordial demeanor, thus culminating a satisfactory retail experience that will likely ensure my future patronage."

3.5 stars for cheap Jameson, somewhat decent food, and a fun patio.

Never thought I'd be a Yelp app regular at Gilley's, but lo and behold, there was my golden checkmark (of shame). I visited a while back with Dana S (the S is for Some Hot Bitch) where we got cheap Jame-O and loled at karaoke. 

Visited again recently for food and more drinks, and I was not disappointed (but then again, I was not paying). The nachos were alright--tasted like my beloved Taco John's  which is a pretty good compliment coming from me. The chicken strips were just that--frozen animal flesh fried in un-food batter and grease--but the vinegary mustardy sauce sold me. Also had a bite of the jalapeno grits which were the highlight of the meal.

Overall, not a terrible place, but not the best either. The Strip has so much more to offer but in a pinch, this place wasn't horrible.

So, I would have rate this place less if it were not for the celebrities that were seen here...
I'm not sure if there was even a dance floor but if there was one, that was the smallest dance floor ever at a club. The music was ok and the club was more of place to chill. When we went girls got in for free and champagne was complimentary.
We went Valentine's weekend and we were about to leave at midnight (because the music was not to our liking) until we saw LMFAO! We stayed for the whole night just for them...it was AWESOME!
My friends also have been there last year and said that they saw Far East Movement...so pick your weekends wisely...

"If you possess a predilection for partially clothed, stunning wait staff and an affinity for alcoholic beverages, you may find this establishment conducive to an enjoyable nocturnal experience. However, if you prioritize superior culinary offerings and exceptional customer service, it would be advisable to seek alternative dining options. Notwithstanding the possibility of receiving an incorrect bill at your table on multiple occasions and experiencing inconsistencies in both beverage and food quality, one must acknowledge that such shortcomings are of little consequence in the grand scheme. After all, the beer is adequately chilled, and the female staff members are undeniably attractive, rendering any additional aspects of the dining experience somewhat irrelevant."

"When it comes to selecting an optimal venue for a midday meal, Jimmy John's undoubtedly ranks as a premier choice, offering the convenience of both delivery and takeout options. Furthermore, their menu boasts an array of delectable subs, which can be further customized by opting for a nutritious nine-grain bread alternative to the traditional white roll. Specifically, the Beach Club sub, featuring turkey breast, provolone cheese, tomato, lettuce, and guacamole, constitutes a personal favorite, with the latter ingredient being a particularly noteworthy aspect. In addition, vegetarians will find solace in the Veggie sub, which showcases a medley of fresh sprouts, cheese, tomato, cucumber, and, once again, guacamole. Lastly, those with a sweet tooth would be remiss not to sample one of their gargantuan cookies, especially the chocolate chip variety."

Always a good choice. Service is VERY slow but the corn chowder makes up for it. Good menu choices and staff seems to always be friendly. They also have good breads and muffins. Good place for any of the 3 meals.

I went to enso for lunch the other day with one other person. The ginger salad was just like you would expect. The sushi really pretty but tasted just like typical sushi. The spider roll was awesome. As for atmosphere, it's way too dark inside and it's super swanky. The place is run by Americans and there is nothing authentic about it. We ended up spending $100 without any alcohol. It's pretty good but not worth the price. Head to New Zealand cafe for better sushi for half the price.

We entered the establishment with the expectation of capitalizing on one of the most optimal rooftop settings within the city limits, only to be informed that while we could indeed consume food and beverages upstairs, we would be responsible for tidying up after ourselves and procuring any necessary items independently.  Such an underutilization of exceptional terrain! 
The hospitality we received was adequate.  Our server was quite personable, though perhaps a tad distracted.  She delivered two beverages of the alcoholic variety to my spouse and me, despite the fact that we had only placed an order for a single drink. 
The culinary offerings were unremarkable.  While not utterly deplorable, they failed to impress us to the extent that we would actively seek them out.  We sampled the pork queso dip, which, while lacking the fiery zest we customarily associate with queso, was undeniably palatable.  I would certainly consider ordering it again in the future.  My spouse opted for the Cuban sandwich.  Following the waitress's recommendation, he attempted to consume it with both lettuce and tomato, but unfortunately, these additional elements overpowered the inherent flavors of the BBQ, rendering it somewhat unpalatable.  Upon removing the produce from the sandwich, the BBQ itself proved to be fairly satisfying.  My better half relished the flavor of the meat, but, much like the rest of the dish, it did not particularly stand out. 
While this eatery will not be incorporated into our regular dining rotation, I would not object if others wished to frequent it.

I live down the street from this WH so my circle of friends often finds ourselves here after a night of debauchery. It's really nothing special, trucker food at it's best, but the staff is really nice and there's something about it that makes my hangovers feel better.

"The aspect that piqued my interest in this location was the striking similarity between its terrain and that of the red planet, evoking the sensation of having arrived on Mars. A cursory examination of the exterior rock formations reinforces this impression, showcasing a topography that is both alien and captivating. However, my enthusiasm for this site is somewhat tempered by its unfortunate proximity to Arizona, a factor that, regrettably, cannot be ignored or dismissed lightly."

"I find myself in a state of ambivalence regarding this critique, as our dining experience at the establishment was marked by both exceptional service and delectable cuisine, yet unfortunately marred by an unfortunate incident involving two members of our party who suffered from food poisoning, which we suspect was caused by the mussels. Despite this setback, we opted to sample a variety of dishes, including their signature jumbo lump crab cake, braised short ribs pierogies, arancinis, potato gnocchi & lobster, and the aforementioned mussels. During the meal, I thoroughly enjoyed all of the dishes, with my particular favorites being the lobster gnocchi and the arancinis, although the latter were slightly tainted by the bitterness of the port wine. In addition, we also indulged in a selection of their beverages, ranging from the Braddock's smash to the Moscow mule and Prohibition pear martini, as well as the option to create one's own Manhattan cocktail. Considering its status as a hotel restaurant, this venue within The Renaissance proved to be a truly exceptional choice, were it not for the unfortunate occurrence of food poisoning, which sadly reduces this review's rating to three stars."

This is quite an inconspicuous wee bar at the bottom of Howe Street, but it's pretty popular with New Town and Stockbridge locals, and actually surprisingly larger than it looks when you get inside. 

The interior of The Standard is smart and plushly furnished, so it's a pretty comfortable place to sit and have a beer, or a nice Sauvignon, or whatever your poison may be. The bar has a good feel about it, so you can sit for quite a while and banter away without actually feeling you're really in a bar environment (apart from the fact you're glugging down alcohol). 

The menu is decent too and inexpensive, so if you're in the mood for proper pub food, like a big helping of burger and chips, or a full breakfast to soak up the hangover, The Standard is a good call. I am automatically biased against anywhere that blares out sport at high volume levels, but I know half the world love watching a good sports match/game on decent screens, so I would recommend The Standard for such activities, and it gets very, very busy around rugby match season.

I visit Chili's with my kin and acquaintances approximately two times per month. We typically frequent the establishment located at the intersection of Bell and 7th Streets or 27th Avenue and 101st Street. The culinary offerings, for the most part, are at least average to slightly above average in quality. The complimentary chips and salsa are a remarkable value, and the green chile and enchilada soups are particularly delectable. The consistency of the fare across all Chili's locations we visit is quite gratifying. However, there appears to be a persistent issue with the service at the North Valley Parkway branch. During their initial opening phase, we attempted to dine there twice due to its proximity to our domicile. Unfortunately, both experiences were marred by botched orders and friendly yet menu-ignorant servers. The prolonged delay in receiving our cuisine was further exacerbated by the absence of any contrite sentiments. Following a brief hiatus, we opted to give them another chance, presuming that the novelty had worn off and any glitches would have been ironed out. Alas, our expectations were not met, as the wait time for our edibles was extraordinary, and securing a replenishment of our beverages proved to be a futile endeavor. Fast forward over a year, and our most recent visit transpired last Saturday. Our server was quite pleasant, and the hostesses were cordial, yet the duration between ordering and consuming our soup and salad, accompanied by water as our beverage, spanned an unacceptable ninety minutes. It is reasonable to surmise that four instances of subpar service are unlikely to be mere happenstance. In stark contrast, the Chili's situated on 7th Street consistently delivers exceptional hospitality and customary waiting periods. It is my ardent hope that this anomaly shall be rectified, as Chili's poses a respectable dining option.

A good local buffet. I thought the sashimi was very fresh, especially the salmon. Chinese traditional dishes we're very good and everything is refilled extremely fast. Crab legs were very good as well and plentiful. Spring rolls were terrible and the dumplings could be better.  \n***Make sure you read the sign on the table before going up to to the buffet.\" If you take to much food and leave enough waste your plate then there is an $8 additional charge\"**\nRecommended though as far as Chinese buffets go.

"In the event that a reservation at Pied Au Corchon proves unattainable, this establishment serves as a suitable substitute. Freshly prepared dishes, judiciously portioned, and an refined rustic atmosphere characterize this eatery, rendering it a suitable selection for out-of-town visitors or intimate gatherings. Drawbacks include a leisurely pace of service and a boisterous dining environment. My evening meal was delectable and, for the most part, justified the cost. I sampled the veal heart tartare, which displayed remarkable freshness and a robust flavor profile, albeit with a subtle yet indescribable lacking quality that eluded my attempts at identification. Accompanying this dish were paper-thin frites, expertly cooked and seasoned with precision, as well as a raw vegetable salad, finely sliced and dressed with a vinaigrette. For dessert, I shared the apple tarte intended for two individuals. The presentation of the tarte was aesthetically pleasing, featuring a unique combination of slightly vinegared apple slices and a minuscule scoop of apple sorbet as a garnish. While not extraordinary, the tarte was pleasant, served at a comfortable temperature, and boasted a flaky crust. In conclusion, this restaurant merits consideration as a worthy alternative to other renowned upscale establishments in Le Plateau."

"The French press coffee resembled an aquatic beverage, with residual sedimentary particles dispersed throughout, which was subpar, to say the least, considering that a morning establishment should serve a superior quality of coffee, if not an exceptional one. The coffee I received, at the very least, was unimpressive, prompting me to surmise that perhaps the proprietors should consider implementing certain adjustments to elevate their offerings by a few notches, preferably two, to create a more satisfactory experience for their clientele. Notwithstanding, the ambiance of the venue possessed a certain je ne sais quoi that was quite agreeable."

"This establishment possesses considerable potential; the television sets are strategically positioned in optimal locations, including within the bathrooms. I would unquestionably confer a five-star rating upon this venue if they were to upgrade their culinary offerings and expand their selection of draft beers and premium spirits. Specifically, I have attempted to procure Crown Royal Cask No. 16, Jack Daniel's Honey, Kraken, Captain Morgan Private Stock, and Jack Daniel's Single Barrel, but unfortunately, they do not carry any of these top-shelf liquors. Half Moon, take note! It is imperative that you address these two issues promptly, as I am eager to provide an updated review that accurately reflects the full scope of your amenities and services."
Just came here and ordered a caesars salad. It was a snack between meals. It was dressed nicely but slightly overseasoned. Nice casual place.

Restaurant review
My first venture into Korean food in Champaign was good. We decided to stop for a quick lunch and ended up at the first restaurant that opened at 11 AM on a weekday. It was easy to order because we were the first customers of the day. They have a nice laminated menu at the desk to chose your entree. It would be nicer if they had pictures instead of a word description of each item. I selected the combo platter of bulgogi which was 9.99. Afterwards it was a long wait of approximately 25 minutes before we got our food. The dish itself came with a large amount of rice and 2 ban chae along with a bean soup. Based on the pictures I could have chose the beef bulgogi paid less and likely gotten the same amount of food except less variety. The bulgogi was well seasoned, but the meat was cut into smaller slices which detracted from it. Prices have gone up according to my wife since she was in college. Overall slightly above average, I will have to find another korean restaurant to compare too.

Pro: average price korean food, large portion

Cons: long cook time, higher price than average lunch places

Hidden gem:
Your meal comes with rice, soup, and 2 korean ban chae

Food is hit and miss, I noticed that the food is horrible in the afternoon (salty fries, bland meat etc..) but fantastic at night. Sandwiches are good. their BBQ ribs when they have them are a joke. I am not much of a drinker so I cannot comment on the Bar but just the grill :-)

I was on a solo trip to Arizona and I wanted to make sure i stopped to try local food ...or actually real Native American Food... The Fry Bread House was my first spot I went to, to try the culture out!...  The food has some SPICE to it for sure!! What i Had was SPICY but it was good...The bread is made to order and tasty.. Im not sure what I would recommend there because I have not tried many of the items...but the flatbread is pretty good :)

I don't know why, but this Bruegger's stands head and shoulders above the location three blocks away on Grant.  Employees are almost always in good spirits and much more efficient at taking orders.\n\nLike most Bruegger's, they have the standard Bagel, Sandwich, Soup, Coffee and Tea selection.  They also have nice booth seating along an outside window.

"The ambiance is thoroughly enjoyable, the tariffs are reasonable, the wine-a-ritas offer a distinctive and flavorful experience, albeit slightly subpar, while the locally procured vintages possess a certain je ne sais quoi, yet lack the robust qualities that I typically associate with California wines, although they are still palatable, if somewhat overpriced; I would have been inclined to purchase the pinot grigio had it been more affordably priced, but I shall certainly return and take advantage of the exceptional value offered by the flight selection, which allows one to sample six diverse varieties for a mere $6, an absolute bargain."

"This eatery specializing in sushi manifests an overall quality that can be classified as ranging from mediocre to slightly above average, with a physical bar area that exudes a sense of elegance while simultaneously possessing limited seating capacity, a characteristic commonly observed in establishments of this culinary genre.
