The sushi served within this establishment is of a quality that, while palatable, lacks any truly distinctive or remarkable attributes, positioning it on a parallel plane with respect to Ra, but ultimately falling short of the exceptional standards set by Sakana, thereby prompting me to engage in a deliberate and thorough assessment before finally determining a rating of three stars, as the experience, though satisfying, proved to be merely average."

"Enormous aerofoils, unfortunately, their operational status has transitioned to closed, and upon perusal of previous patrons' feedback, it appears that sluggish servicing was a contributing factor to such an unfortunate fate."

"Adequate pizza, albeit with some reservations regarding the texture of the wings, which seemed slightly desiccated, yet attributable to an isolated production mishap, rather than a systemic flaw. The sauce, however, demonstrated a satisfactory level of flavor and richness, although it failed to fully satiate my yearning for an authentic New York-style pizza experience in Pittsburgh."

Food was great as usual.  Love the new building.  However, the chairs are probably the most uncomfortable chairs I've ever sat in and the music was way too loud.  I don't like shouting at my dinner companions to be heard.  Get better chairs and turn it down during dinner time, please.  If it's going to remain that loud, I'll just get my food to go.

It's nice to finally find an uptown lunch spot that focuses on honest health instead of hiding behind vague menu descriptions and health information from the 1980s, like so many others.  This place really impresses me with their commitment to healthy, natural ingredients.
Overall, I think the food is very good, and the menu options are as extensive as they need to be to make this a weekly lunch stop.  However, I have one issue with the price point, particularly with breakfast.  The cost of a breakfast sandwich is pretty outrageous for what you actually get.  For $5, i don't expect someone to reach into a steamer and pull out a 2 hour old poached egg, place it on a stale wrap, and throw a pinch of turkey bacon on it and call it a decent breakfast.
In contrast though, the lunch is spectacular.  You definitely get a decent bang for the buck, especially if you eat in (tea refills and complimentary froyo).  In my experiences, it always tastes fresh, healthy, and delicious... and I'm actually somewhat full afterward. 
For breakfast this place gets 2 stars, but for lunch it gets 4.  So an overall 3 it is.

First off, I am not a 20-something who regularly hangs out in Old Town.  But, I have lived in Phx for 30+ years and have been to most upper-level eating establishments around town.  We went with friends for Restaurant Week.  We will not be heading back any time soon.  Service was very attentive.  The ambiance has been overstated by many other reviewers - it's got a little bit of kitsch, but in the end, the tables are extremely close to each other and the noise level is on the high end.  It is definitely not an intimate dining experience.  The food was very good, but not home run material.  The entree of venison that I ordered was served raw on the inside.  I'm not talking a little bit on the rare side, it was sashimi raw.  Having not been asked how I would like my meat prepared, I assumed it would be cooked.  I'm a medium-well kinda guy, but my dining partner likes her meat medium rare and she sent hers back to be cooked.  We ordered a dessert of foie gras and donuts, and it was just weird.  All 4 of us tried it, but none of us liked it.  You must really have to like foie gras to enjoy this dessert.  We are not really cocktail kinda people, but they did look tempting.  The regular menu looks like it is probably over-priced for the serving sizes that we got during Restaurant Week, but it was worth trying once.

We recently had the privilege of dining at Vogue, a culinary establishment that has been highly recommended by various sources, and thus, our expectations were suitably elevated. Upon perusing the menu, we elected to sample the meatloaf and lasagna, respectively, as our primary courses, and decided to share the calamari fritta appetizer, primarily due to its intriguing combination of flavors and textures. Our initial impression of the entrees was overwhelmingly positive, as both dishes demonstrated an unwavering commitment to quality and presentation, making them undoubtedly worth the expense. However, our enthusiasm was momentarily curtailed when we sampled the calamari fritta, which, unfortunately, did not live up to our expectations. Despite the novel incorporation of ginger amidst the julienned carrots, the overall execution of the dish seemed somewhat lacking, with the tempura-fried calamari pieces being sparse and somewhat lost amidst the abundance of vegetation. Notwithstanding this minor setback, we generally enjoyed our dining experience, albeit with a few reservations regarding the service, which, although polite and relatively prompt, seemed somewhat detached and unengaging, leaving us with a lingering sense of indifference.

After a solitary visit, I must say that the ambiance was rather impressive, earning a commendable grade of B+. The ornamentation was tasteful and visually pleasing, yet the illumination left much to be desired, as it was rather dim and made it challenging to discern objects clearly. Concerning the service, I would have awarded Pin Kaow an A, but unfortunately, they were excessively attentive, bordering on being overbearing. We had no less than five staff members attend to us within a mere five minutes, which proved to be somewhat overwhelming. In terms of culinary offerings, I must confess that while the dishes were undoubtedly delectable, they failed to elicit a robust response from my taste buds, falling short of my expectations. Specifically, the grilled chicken in the chicken satay was cooked to perfection, but the accompanying peanut sauce, presumably authentic, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, leaving me unimpressed. Similarly, the tom ka koong, a lemongrass soup replete with coconut milk, galanga root, mushrooms, and shrimp, though enjoyable in limited quantities, proved too rich and slightly sour for my liking, causing the flavors to become overpowering by the time I finished a single small bowl. However, I must admit that the novel concept of roasted rice beef, featuring beef, cabbage, roasted rice, Thai basil, and various spices, did pique my interest, even if it did not necessarily win me over. Lastly, the chicken yellow curry was indeed appetizing, rounding off the meal on a satisfying note. All things considered, I would give this establishment an overall rating of B+, and I do harbor hopes of revisiting it in the future to sample additional unfamiliar dishes.

"It is utterly vexing when a local establishment fails to meet expectations, particularly when it falls short of the quintessential general store experience offered by the likes of Mast Drug or Renfrow in Matthews. While Monroe Hardware may possess some charm, it falls short of embodying the essence of a traditional general store, and yet it does not boast the extensive resources of a behemoth like Home Depot or Lowe's. Rather, it occupies a nebulous middle ground that proves problematic in terms of creating an optimal customer experience. My exposure to Monroe Hardware has been limited to the Mint Hill location, and it is conceivable that the vast expanse of the store (formerly a Winn Dixie, I believe) contributes to the sense of emptiness and lack of personalized attention. If the space were halved, the atmosphere would likely become more inviting and intimate, thereby enhancing the overall shopping experience. Presently, the sprawling layout necessitates a greater dispersal of staff, leading to periods where customers may feel neglected. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the proximity of Monroe Hardware to my domicile renders it a convenient option for casual excursions. However, when undertaking more elaborate projects, I tend to favor the comprehensive resources and expertise available at Home Depot or Lowe's, which I encounter during my various errands."

This Dillard's has metamorphosed into a mere outlet center, with the entire lower level lying dormant and uninhabited. The upper level has transmogrified into a terminus for last season's, damaged, and irregularly sized designer attire, eliciting a sense of familiarity with Ross, albeit sans the plethora of inferior brands and foul-smelling changing areas.

The minimum reduction observed was a substantial 40% discount, while the majority of racks flaunted a 50% price decrease, and a select few were adorned with a remarkable 75% markdown. Furthermore, the assortment was methodically categorized by size, facilitating a seamless shopping experience.

Prominent designers were responsible for the majority of the merchandise, including a stylish Michael Kors top that originally retailed for approximately $50 but was acquired for a mere $18, exemplifying a substantial savings.

Garments constituted the primary focus, complemented by a medley of bedding, accessories, and footwear. However, the selection of shoes proved to be underwhelming, catering only to diminutive feet, colossal sasquatch feet, or those enamored with flamboyant styles, leaving the rest in a state of dismay.

Sure, here's a modified version of the paragraph using longer and more complex sentences and professional vocabulary while maintaining the same meaning:

"It became apparent rather swiftly that I did not possess the characteristics befitting a patron of Las Vegas nightlife. In the company of an acquaintance possessing connections, I bypassed the queue and entrance fee. However, my attire, which included footwear devoid of heels due to a pinched nerve in my back, nearly resulted in my exclusion from the venue, until the bouncer relented. The panoramic view of the strip, touted as exceptional, fell short of expectations, both in terms of elevation and scope. The dance floor was overcrowded, rendering movement a challenge, and beverages were priced exorbitantly ($8 per bottle of low-end beer). To avoid unwanted physical contact with strangers, it would be advisable to procure a table, but this would come at a cost. For those opting to visit, a word of advice: purchase a quantity of spirits at a nearby pharmacy (approximately $13 for a bottle of Smirnoff) and ensure a considerable level of intoxication prior to arrival to maximize enjoyment."

As far as chains go, Bravo is dependable. I can always count on getting a decent salad. This location offers reservations, which is helpful in avoiding long lines and 45 minute waits.

I enjoy the Romano crusted chicken salad as well as the balsamic chicken salad. The Parmesan dressing is delicious, and I have even tried to recreate it at home.

I am not a big fan of the entrées here as they are loaded with salt, but I do enjoy stopping in to grab a salad while shopping at the Waterfront or catching a movie.

There is always plenty of parking, which is key.

I am with Jamie C. on this one.  I think maybe I will have to come back to make my final decision.  Our server was great!  I wish i would have got his name so I could mention him by name... very attentive!  I enjoyed the 2 glasses of sangria I had, but Michael was not that enthused about his mojito.  He switched to Stella for his second:).  For our entrees we shared the calamari and their special which was a blue corn chicken enchilada.  The calamari was very tasty!  I really liked the sauces that came with them and we ate it all!  The enchiladas were very tasty too.  There were many shared plates that I wanted to try so I will definitely come back!

We've heard and seen on the Food Network great things about Bouchon and certainly was not disappointed with the service. The dining hall is elegant and proper. Brunch was good, but not blow- your- mind great. We tried the Salmon Baguette, a take on salmon and smear on a bagel only for $15, but this is to be expected. Nevertheless, it was good. We also had the Bouchon French Toast which is done in a bread pudding- like style. It shouldn't be be called French toast because it does not resemble anything like it. It really should be called bread pudding. It was more like dessert-- too sweet to be had as a brunch meal.

Aw, poor Kamakura, why all the hate?

I have a soft spot for this place, because it's been a family favorite for YEARS - my dad took us there when they first opened because he had recently discovered sushi (remember when not everyone was aware of this heaven?  However passé it may be now, sushi had it's place 10ish years ago...), and we continued going back periodically.  Mostly for special occasions (my Prom group went here senior year), because for our standards at the time it was pricey.

We still stop in most every time I visit, usually for the Teppan.  I can't tell if the chefs/waiters aren't as jazzed about their restaurant as they used to be, or if it's just my perspective that's changed.  Either way, the experience is never "special" like it was back in the day.

Still, they do well.  I'm surprised at the negative reviews because, to be honest, Kamakura would likely earn a solid 3.5-star average where I currently hail from (LA), and I would have thought we had higher standards for cuisine -- especially of the Asian variety -- out here.   !

A very cute gift shop, with adorable and quirky gift ideas. 
However, as Emily T pointed out the price tags are quite high when you start considering the actual item on sale. 

Still Miam Miam can be a saver when you are stuck on a present for someone that's a bit more unique but not too crazy. When I came in here it was empty (coincidence or economic crisis effect?) but the staff are super friendly and I got a great card for my friends graduation.

I got the Gold Standard, he got the Longhorn. They were pricey dogs with minimal toppings. These are no Buldogis dogs...look it up and go there now and get one! You won't regret it. \nThey were edible and satisfied our hunger but I wouldn't go any further. Las Vegas Pinks is below them, so they have something going for them. Staff was helpful and pleasant. We expected high prices...it's the strip.  I say skip it unless your a hot dog fiend.

RESULT: The parent company, Frias, effectively addressed my concern by dedicating sufficient time to investigate and locate the specific taxi and driver in question, utilizing our credit card information. Their thorough approach and diligence in the follow-up process were impressive, although the severity of the driver's consequences remains unknown. Despite the uncertainty, I would still consider using Ace Cab in the future, but I will certainly exercise greater vigilance to ensure that all personal belongings are retrieved before exiting the vehicle. 
  EDITED: Below is my initial post. One day after posting, I received communication from the parent company, and they are actively examining the situation. I appreciate their efforts and will update everyone on any progress made. 
  ORIGINAL POST: The driver displayed both rudeness and dishonesty! We discovered that our iPad was missing and, subsequently, left a message on the taxi company's lost and found number without receiving any response. However, we received a call from an individual who acquired the iPad from the taxi driver, raising suspicions of a potential scam. Regardless of the circumstances, the driver failed to return the iPad, and the company showed indifference towards my concerns by neglecting to follow up. Considering that Ace is merely one of numerous cab companies operated by a single parent company, I will deliberately avoid them all if this is how they conduct their business practices. At the very least, I expect them to demonstrate a pretense of concern and follow through on their responsibilities. While it may be challenging to monitor every driver, a mere show of effort in customer care would suffice.

"It is advisable to capitalize on the complimentary wireless internet access available at this location (albeit intermittently), particularly when utilizing Southwest Airlines, as their gates are dispersed across two separate areas within the terminal. This layout can pose a challenge for passengers seeking to access alternative gates or reunite with companions, necessitating an arduous trek across the entire airport. Additionally, the rental car facility requires a shuttle service, consuming valuable time. Furthermore, select rental car companies, such as Fox, are situated remotely, thereby rendering them inconvenient and time-consuming options. It is recommended to avoid these vendors and opt for more proximate and affordable alternatives, as rental prices in Las Vegas are generally reasonable."

We had dinner here this past week based on all the good reviews. Our food was good but not outstanding. We had duck, steak and salmon entrees. The duck was probably the best and the steak was fair at best. The cheese plate appetizer was excellent. Service was very good. We will give this place another try before making a final judgement.

Pretty good food, but a bit overpriced. Roasted duck appetizer was disappointing; dry meat and zero crisp to the skin. Sweet and Sour Pork was very good, and the coconut rice was awesome. I want to eat that every day.  But $30, incl. tip, is a bit much IMHO.\n\nWill return for the coconut rice and pair it with the satay next time, and will add an update at that time.

I ordered brisket with nacho fries with outlaw burger. Ordered before my cousin and he got only the outlaw burger with Mac, and he got his order first. And I look across of me and I see a guy that ordered his food after me, and he got the same exact burger before they got my order. 
So I ask the waiter why he got the burger before me when I ordered before him, and he just simply said that yours is coming up, playing it off knowing that he messed up. 
So after 10 mins later they bring my food, but I only  got my fries no burger. Waiter said its coming right out. 
After another 10 mins I finally get it. Was kind of hard to enjoy my food. But nevertheless fries were good and the burger was just as good. And the price for all the food was just. I would of given 4 stars if they didn't mess up my order and not try to play it off that it wasn't the waiters fault.
Don't get me wrong I would definitely come back again and hopefully get better service.

I pretty much come here with large parties (the tables allow for huge groups) or when I just can't make my mind up on what I feel like eating because this place has a little bit of everything. 

I've tried quite a few different things on the menu and it has all been pretty good. Nothing spectacular, but not disappointing either. The Chicken Madeira and the Farfalle w/ Chicken and Roasted Garlic (tell them to hold some of the garlic) are among my favorites.

And the cheesecake is always good. Lots of different varieties. Snickers, turtle, tuxedo, strawberry, etc. They are all good. But I've never met a piece of cheesecake I didn't devour.

Not impressed with dinner at Davio.  Service can make or break a dining experience and I have to admit, I felt as though I was eating at Eat 'N Park.  The food was ok, but not on par with other similar restaurants.  The server was unprofessional and had no idea what was on the menu, or how to answer questions regarding it.  Do not waste your time, spend a few more dollars and go to Arlecchino or Alla Familia.

Visited on May 8th, 2012...

While meandering through an unfamiliar vicinity in pursuit of a unique dining experience, I chanced upon this eatery. It appears to be a recently established establishment. 

Situated within the same edifice as a gas station, specifically at the northeastern junction of Southern and Higley, this restaurant boasts an unpretentious ambiance. 

With a hankering for a straightforward meal, I opted for the Gyro and Fries. Executing my order as a takeout, I noted that only a single individual was present, indulging in their midday repast at 12:15 pm. This sparse attendance could be attributed to either an absence of publicity or a dearth of patronage, neither of which bodes well for the venue's longevity. 

Although the cuisine was palatable, I have relished more delectable fare at diverse locales. Disappointment ensued when I beheld the meager portion size, comprising three strips of meat and a mere two tomato slices. Nonetheless, for a hasty midday meal, it proved sufficient. 

Upon perusing the menu, my attention was captivated by several intriguing options. These entries piqued my curiosity, prompting me to consider a future visit to sample them. 

Assessed in relation to neighboring fast-food establishments, this eatery presents a pleasant alternative. However, its unobtrusive location and limited visibility from the main road may pose challenges in attracting a consistent clientele. Thus, I shall revisit the premises after a brief interval of approximately a month to assess whether they continue to operate successfully.

I stayed three nights in Paris. I requested a room with King bed. They gave me room with two queen beds. Next day, there was availability and they moved me to a room with King bed. Queen size bed was very uncomfortable. King size was not bad. Rooms were very clean. Bathrooms were clean, wide, functional. Check in was fast, although there was a big line. What I really liked about bathrooms were they had closed cabin shower and a separate bath tub. TV was basic, some good channels. It was very quite, had no noise problem. Hotel location is awesome, at the center of everywhere. Elevators worked really fast. My view was back, looked towards airport. I also used their spa company, wrote separate review for it. Paris has good restaurants inside. I also recommend going top of Eiffel Tower, view was spectacular. Monorail metro is also very close, you do not need to leave hotel to get to metro, very convenient. My only problem was that they did not let me use spa the day I checked out, which was disappointing. Overall good place to stay.

"Upon returning for an evening meal several days subsequent to my initial visit, I began to perceive that the visually appealing ambiance of the establishment was, regrettably, misleading. The pours of alcoholic beverages were remarkably parsimonious, with both the beer and wine glasses being modern and aesthetically pleasing, yet the quantity of liquid they contained left me feeling somewhat shortchanged by the bartender. For our repast, we opted for the Louisiana Chicken pasta dish and the Bibimbap. The Louisiana Chicken pasta possessed an exceptional gustatory quality and, quite frankly, likely clocked in at a substantial 2,000-3,000 caloric content. In contrast, a double cheeseburger and fries at Five Guys would have provided a lighter meal. It arrived in the form of a sizable bowl overflowing with heavy whipping cream and melted cheese, accompanied by pasta for texture. As I consumed it, I couldn't help but feel that the waitress should have been attired in a vest adorned with flair pins, exclaiming, 'Welcome to Applebees!' Instead of the anticipated culinary experience associated with Miga. Unfortunately, the Bibimbap, while aesthetically captivating, failed to meet expectations regarding its flavor profile. The absence of the signature dolsot, or hot stone bowl, rendered the dish lacking in essence. Its taste was merely passable, and it more closely resembled a cold salad than any authentic Bibimbap I have had the pleasure of experiencing. Despite these shortcomings, I shall indeed revisit this establishment, allowing sufficient time for the menu to undergo refinement."

Distrito exhibits a palpable shortfall in its capacity to evoke a memorable dining experience, despite the extensive promotion it has garnered.  This deficiency is particularly discernible in the eatery's ambiance, which is characterized by an excessive dimness and an uninspired lounge-like quality that ultimately renders the setting rather monotonous.  
The meal initiated with an order of guacamole and chips accompanied by salsa, yet the latter was regrettably overseasoned with salt, rendering it nearly inedible.  Notwithstanding this flaw, I persevered and consumed the chips while endeavoring to remove the excess salt by utilizing my fingers to brush it off.  The guacamole and salsa, however, demonstrated appreciable quality.  Subsequently, we progressed to sample the vegetarian tacos, which were adequately prepared and presented a satisfying taste, in addition to a type of Mexican flatbread embellished with mushrooms and complemented by a huiltacoche sauce.  
The rice, prepared with corn, cream, and habaneros, had the potential to emerge as a delectable Mexican risotto; unfortunately, it was once again marred by an excess of salt, thereby diminishing its overall effectiveness. 
Distrito boasts an assortment of marginally diverse margaritas, and we opted to sample both the watermelon-cucumber and cilantro varieties, which yielded satisfactory results. 
It has been rumored that the restaurant's service can be somewhat problematic; nevertheless, our server, though unremarkable in their performance, delivered competent and attentive assistance.  Ultimately, Distrito proved to be a passable dining option for us, yet we do not find ourselves yearning to revisit the establishment.

I have had the pleasure of visiting Aunt Chilada's on multiple occasions during my time in Arizona, and while each experience has been relatively uneventful, there was one particular visit that stands out as particularly memorable. It was an evening when one of my companions and I decided to engage in a playful activity, inspired by the iconic Disney character, Ariel, from The Little Mermaid, where we used plastic forks to groom our hair before entering the establishment. Furthermore, I recall that shortly after making a humorous observation regarding individuals from rural areas, we felt compelled to utilize the aforementioned utensils to tidy up our coiffures. The motivation behind this behavior remains unclear, but it seemed amusing at the time. Moving on, the culinary offerings at Aunt Chilada's have never been exceptional or remarkably poor; they are perhaps adequate enough to warrant a visit if one is in close proximity and desires to partake in a leisurely meal accompanied by refreshing margaritas on the outdoor seating area. In conclusion, while not outstanding, the eatery does not necessarily warrant avoidance, and thus, I shall confer an additional star in recognition of its mediocrity.

I don't know how to review this place.....I have been coming here for years and honestly it was great but I have not been crazy about it lately...everyone try's to be Italian host,waiters bussboy...but they are all Eastern European which is fine but speak English instead of butchering the Italian language.  I have tried most of the menu in the past, my favorite is the veal ouso bucco everything else is borderline chain restaurant quality....however if you get a table in the outdoor veranda you will likely not even know the food is just ok because the obeisance is terrific. I still would recommend this place but if you have good Italian food in your area you will not be Impressed.  Not the best in Vegas but worth trying at least once.

"On certain occasions, I have an inclination towards consuming a well-prepared gourmet meal, while on other days, my preference veers towards indulging in a lavish spread at a buffet. Our companions opted for Bouchon for brunch due to our collective yearning for the former experience. 

I sampled a small portion of the sourdough waffles accompanied by fresh strawberries and vanilla bean butter, which yielded a flavor profile reminiscent of a crispy waffle. The inclusion of vanilla bean butter added a welcome subtlety to the dish. 

The vanilla bean yogurt complemented by an ample serving of granola was indeed palatable, although the generous helping of granola rendered the combination somewhat overwhelming for my taste buds. Nonetheless, the granola served to counterbalance the richness of the yogurt. 

The Cobb salad, albeit unphotographed, proved underwhelming. The dish consisted of limp iceberg lettuce, sparse pieces of chicken, and an undersized portion, all for a price point of $17. 

Bouchon serves as a suitable venue for individuals seeking to consume a substantial meal prior to engaging in intense physical activity, such as dancing, later in the evening. The service was attentive, and our water glasses were consistently replenished. 

In terms of pricing, Bouchon's offerings, while satisfactory, do not justify the cost, particularly when considering the quality of the meal. For those seeking a more diverse array of options, Grand Luxe presents a preferable alternative. Individuals with a preference for health-conscious fare may find Bouchon's menu unsuitable, as each item tasted excessively rich and heavy."

I have been to tgi only twice so far. The first time I ordered the filled potato skin appetizer. The portion was big and It could have been great if it had a sauce or something but it was just way too dry. 

And the second time I ordered their Caribbean chicken sandwich with "Caribbean" sauce. The sauce was so disgusting I had to send the entire sandwich back. I couldn't even believe they seriously considered that sauce. So the sandwich was grilled chicken breast (very good) with tomatoes, avocados (still sounds good, right?) and then this sauce, which tasted like Christmas and pumpkin pie!??? It definitely had cinnamon and cloves in it... on a chicken avocado sandwich??? Like seriously? That is not Caribbean! Please if you are a staff from TGI Fridays and you are reading this, please take that sauce off of your menu, it is NOT good and my husband and mother in law who tried it, 100% agreed with me. Well, I sent back my food and ordered the turkey burger. It tasted not bad but I couldn't really enjoy it because everybody else was done eating and I felt stressed out. 

Positive was definitely the service though. Always friendly and professional. And they didn't charge me for the first order.

Fun, casual place to eat with your friends. If you're looking for authentic Southern barbeque, move along, but if you want to chow down on some good cheap ribs and chicken, Bar-B-Barn fits the bill. 

We came here hoping to watch the hockey game (well, the guys wanted to watch the hockey game, and we girls were wanting a place that wasn't filled with drunk hockey lunatics) while eating dinner. No TV, so no dice, but the homey barn-y environment still made for a fun night. 

Good cheap ribs. The meat was pretty tender. Sweet sticky sauce. Mmmm. I got the small portion with three ribs and fries and that filled me up.

"I indulged in an intimate dining experience with my beloved spouse at this esteemed establishment prior to a late-night screening at the adjacent Manor Theater. We partook in potent mixed beverages, specifically a delectable ginger-infused cooler containing copious amounts of genuine ginger. Additionally, we shared a diverse array of diminutive plates, including miniature spring rolls and taro puffs. Although the vegetarian options were somewhat limited, I believe this scarcity was actually a blessing in disguise, as it eliminated the burden of making arduous decisions from an excessive number of delectable alternatives. The ambiance was refined, the illumination was romantically dim, and the hospitality was attentive yet unobtrusive. Throughout the meal, my partner and I maintained physical contact above the table while subtly engaging in playful foot interactions beneath it, ultimately concluding our visit in a state of contentment and satisfaction with both the culinary offerings and beverages. While the prices may seem lofty, similar to the presentation, it's challenging to dispute the justification for such expenses given the exceptional ambiance and meticulous attention to detail, making it an occasional splurge worth the investment, in my opinion."
It was \"ok\" there wasn't much of a selection and it was a little high priced! i might try this again. The server was very nice but wasn't very attentive.

My better half and I had been cognizant of the acclaim surrounding Freddy's for quite some time, thus opting to partake in a culinary excursion to the establishment. Upon our arrival, the dining area was brimming with patrons, further piquing my expectations. I elected to sample their flagship offering, specifically the #1, comprising a double burger augmented with cheese. Alas, upon its presentation, I was dismayed by the meager proportions of the entree. It appeared that the beef patties were of a comparable dimension to those of cold cuts, thereby rendering the bread slices excessively dominant. Notwithstanding the palatable nature of the burger, my overall satisfaction was compromised by the conspicuous absence of meat. While Freddy's remains a viable option, my underwhelming experience precludes me from venturing out of my way to frequent the establishment in the future.

"Panoramic vistas at North Shore Terrace proffer an aesthetically pleasing visual experience that somewhat justifies the cost of a $16 margarita, albeit with certain reservations. Additionally, the implementation of misting systems, while well-intentioned in theory, can become problematic during periods of high temperatures, as the water has a tendency to seep from the umbrella and onto one's person, thereby creating an uncomfortable situation for those seeking refuge from the heat."

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are somewhat restricted, with a primary emphasis on noodles and dumplings, yet the prices remain reasonable and affordable for the budget-conscious patron. The ambiance is characteristic of fast food establishments, with an efficient service model that enables patrons to quickly procure their sustenance. This venue experiences high volumes of foot traffic during peak hours, attributed to both the palatable flavors and economic pricing. On a particularly frigid winter evening, I opted for a bowl of pork feet noodle soup, which proved to be an immensely satisfying and comforting choice, with the warm broth and springy noodles providing a welcome respite from the chill in the air. The portion size was adequate, neither excessive nor insufficient, and the service staff, despite their hectic workload, demonstrated a commendable commitment to ensuring a smooth and expedient dining experience for all patrons."

I'm a bit shocked that the reviews on this place are so high.  I do believe I am picky when it comes to comedy but I just was okay with this place and the show that was put on.  The seats are quite uncomfortable, old fashion, gold theater style seats.  The show is interactive which made it fun in some ways and bad in others.  (I wasn't familiar with things like World of Warcraft that were thrown out as suggestions from the audience.)\n\nI would say I was bored more often then laughing.  The skits were drawn out to much at times.  I don't think I will bother to go back.  It is nice that it is so kid friendly though.

Place is alright. The blizzards are really good, especially the Oreo one. I also love the French fries here. The service in the drive thru can be annoyingly slow sometimes but it's worth the wait when craving ice cream late at night.

"Culinary excellence, ambient surroundings, and satisfactory service converge to create a positive dining experience, albeit at a moderately elevated cost for the fare served during the luncheon period; however, the quality of the cuisine and the absence of overcrowding render the establishment worthy of future visits."

I was meandering along the Las Vegas Strip, pondering which nightclub to visit, when I encountered a representative from a financial institution distributing complimentary admission wristbands outside of the Bellagio. Intrigued by the prospect of gaining entry to a popular nightspot without incurring the customary cover charge, I opted to take advantage of the offer. However, upon entering the establishment, I discovered that the "free" entrance came with a caveat; specifically, a $20 fee (allegedly discounted) still needed to be paid. Despite this, I elected to continue with my plans and waited in line for approximately five minutes before gaining admittance. Upon entering, I availed myself of the coat-check service, albeit at a cost of $5 (a fee I deemed worthwhile to avoid misplacing my outerwear). Proceeding directly to the bar, I presented my voucher for a gratis beverage, and the bartender offered me a selection of options. I chose one of the drinks, which, while unremarkable, was palatable. As I savored my cocktail, I observed the gogo dancers and other female patrons dancing and reveling; the dancers, while aesthetically pleasing, displayed only a modicum of impressive choreography, although their congeniality was evident as they accommodated requests for photographs with enthusiasm. The ladies present in the nightclub were indeed stunning. Unfortunately, I did not have the opportunity to partake in dancing, but I thoroughly enjoyed the melodies emanating from the DJ booth, which consisted of an assortment of dance tracks and speaker volumes that were sufficiently loud without becoming overpowering. The dance floor appeared to be a respectable size, and the venue also featured a VIP section designated for exclusive gatherings. Based on my experience, I would consider returning to this nightclub in the future.

I've been to both Terminals in one day, and it's a nightmare sometimes.

Terminal 1: For all domestic flights. 

Parking:

Covered parking is nice in the parking garage.. but they removed the coin-meter parking, & I MISS IT!!
Well, at least we can pay with card now.

Cleanliness:

It's clean, sometimes. Not spotless, but hey, it's airport.

Service(s):

The information desk employees are friendly, and atleast they know what they're doing.

The signs for departure/arrival are pretty easy to read on nice LCD screens.

I wish there signs for where which escalator flights would be coming down from instead of asking attendants on the floor. 

If you can avoid it, don't schedule flights arrival/departure on Fridays & Weekends. The airport is packed.



Terminal 2: International flights & Hawaii.

The signs for Terminal 2 are easy to miss. 
I hope they can make it easier to access and find. Maybe even just a big TERMINAL 2 sign.

Parking:

No covered parking here, but the parking rates are the same as Terminal 1.

Cleanliness:

It's a mess in there. It looks dirty, and it feels dirty. If you have to stay long for any reason, remember to carry antibacterial.

Service(s):

There are only 4 carousels for luggage. This isn't bad in my opinion. It makes it easier to find your stuff if anything.

Keep an eye on your belongings, it feels pretty "ghetto" in Terminal 2.

While the meal I had was authentic and fresh (more onions than I'd like), I had to settle for the menu item because there are NO SUBSTITUTIONS. I am a diner who believes I should get exactly what I want when ordering at a restaurant because I'm using my hard earned money to pay for it. Romeos believes his dishes are created to absolute perfection and any deviation from this would ruin the taste of the dish. That is fine, but I didn't find perfection with the menu so I will probably not return for a meal. However, the desserts are delectable. Amazing selection. If I return it will be for dessert only.

Sigh. I really wanted to like this show. There were aspects of it that I did like but I didnt leave thinking "wow that was so good!" or "that was worth the $$" and I didnt even pay! 

The first part of the show, all you see is holly's back. -__-'' But no worries her boobies will come out later. 

Overall, I really liked the Green pole dancer. The chosen guy was really awkward cute n__n  Most of the girls surprisingly had real boobs. I've never seen so many boobies in my life. 

I suggest just waiting for discount tickets the night of or before the show. We watched it Christmas weekend and the row in front of us was completely empty.

I'm not really sure how to rate Kung Fu Tea, because it looks like a wonderful and hip boba addition to Vegas. However, our teas left a little to be desired. I think I would rate 3 stars for the actual drinks, 5 stars for the tea quality, and 5 stars for the service = 3.5 stars overall. 

We had the milk black tea and milk oolong tea. We chose 70% sugar, so it was not very sweet. I felt like that took away from being able to taste the flavor or the tea, because the drink tasted more diluted. I would definitely recommend just doing normal sugar, since their drinks are not too sweet. 

The tea leaves taste of high quality. Perhaps too high for us... the oolong is very woodsy and smoky, so you definitely have to really like oolong. The black tea has bergamot oil in it, so it tastes more floral. I thought it was nice, but my friend and bf thought it tasted soapy. My bf went back to the store and told them that he didn't like the taste, and they generously offered to make him something else. It was extremely nice that they were accommodating to personal preference. That alone will get me back to try some other teas next time I'm back in Vegas!

The best place to go for a mid-day pick me up. I love their banana Nutella one. It's not too sweet, just right. You can also try their smoothies, which are the same price as the Beaver Tails (probably a better deal 'cause you get actual fruits instead of sugar).

Played here on 11/26/05\nCourse was in great shape. Greens were slow. Some amazing views and some not so amazing views on the course. Great course for ladies as their tees only play to 4400. Good value for 100 bucks not quite as challenging as Wildfire.

Visiting town from Colorado, my friend and I love Hawaiian restaurants. Moki's was good. Nice menu selection. Got the chicken katsu and short ribs. Pretty good. Ribs were a little tough, and the katsu sauce was t great. A little pricey also.

It's a hassle to get served if you don't have a reservation.  The bar area is packed and you really have to move fast to score a place to sit.\n\nThat being said, the swedish meatballs were excellent!

"An economical dining venue that offers palatable fare, albeit with some reservations regarding the seasoning of certain menu items. Specifically, the fiery poultry dish at Changs Spicy Chicken is quite satisfactory, while the savory broth of the Hot and Sour soup could benefit from a more judicious application of salt. The ambiance of the restaurant's interior, characterized by subdued illumination, aligns appropriately with the culinary offerings and overall aesthetic. The waiting staff exhibits a commendable level of cordiality, and the quality of service generally meets or exceeds expectations. A diverse array of beverages is available for patrons to select from."

First visit and I had a drip coffee and the tuna sandwich. Both were excellent. Sandwich though was borderline pricey @ $8.  Service was efficient and prompt. Ambiance was nothing special and had a very much starbucks feel. \n\nOverall impressions: not bad, not great

So let's start with 5 stars....well they lose a star just on service.   When I was there this afternoon there was only one other customer.   From the time I ordered to the time I received my food. ..15 minutes...a car pulled up behind me and eventually pulled over and the couple walked inside.  Another star lost due the food  being very heavy on the salt.   However on the plus side the man who took my order was very polite and made sure my order was correct and that I had all my extras condiments.   This place was first known via Food Network's Diners DriveIns and Dives....well this location is a dive. So that is factored in as well. Evidently they filmed at the Decatur St location.   My Pastrami Burger was as delicious as advertised.   The highlight however were the garlic fries.  Absolutely awesome!!  They are thin but moist and flavorful. .....Overall I will go back to try again but maybe try the other location.   It is also rather expensive but you do get a lot of food. ......

My principal grievance pertains to the fact that the culinary establishment in question maintained an ambient temperature that was unacceptably frigid, bordering on glacial, despite the seasonal timing, ostensibly due to the presence of an overactive air conditioning system within its interior spaces; however, I must admit that the pico de gallo and guacamole appetizers exhibited exceptional flavor profiles, while the fish tacos, although not necessarily conforming to our preconceived expectations, still demonstrated a certain degree of gastronomic merit. Nonetheless, I would not consider traveling a considerable distance specifically to partake of sustenance at this venue, although I might potentially return for future dining experiences if circumstances permit.

As a fervent devotee of wagering and games of chance, I have always derived immense pleasure from visiting Las Vegas, a city renowned for its vibrant casinos and captivating atmosphere. Throughout my numerous excursions to this fabled city, I have had the privilege of frequenting various gaming establishments in Northern California, including Red Hawk, Cache Creek, Thunder Valley, and even Win-River Casino, located in the quaint town of Redding. However, it was not until my most recent visit to a Pai Gow table that I was presented with an unprecedented offer, one that piqued my curiosity and left me feeling both intrigued and pampered.  

Upon accepting the proposition, I was surprised when the attendant transformed the player's seat into a comfortable, rotated position, complete with a substantial cushion designed to facilitate utmost relaxation. During the game's progression, the masseuse diligently applied their expertise, administering a thorough, ten-minute massage to the player adjacent to me. Following this indulgent interlude, the masseuse disclosed the nominal fee of $20 for the service, should the player opt to prolong their therapeutic experience. In my estimation, this represented an eminently reasonable tariff for such an indulgence.  

Regrettably, our beverage service during this sojourn proved less than satisfactory, as the cocktail waitstaff only intermittently visited our table, typically once every two hours. Despite this minor drawback, I would still eagerly return to this establishment, as it offered an overall satisfying experience, albeit one lacking any truly exceptional features, aside from the aforementioned massage therapist. Consequently, I would assign three stars to this venue, denoting it as an average casino that generally met my expectations, yet failed to distinguish itself in any remarkable manner, save for the aforementioned amenity.

"Audibly boisterous ambient sonance permeates the atmosphere, precipitating an exclusive reliance on paper currency for financial transactions, while simultaneously accentuating the prominence of mammary glands in the visual realm. Patrons are advised to prepare themselves for prolonged periods of standing, as the prospect of seating appears improbable, given the densely packed nature of the venue. The musical offerings, characterized by their cacophonous quality, are likely to induce euphoria among aficionados of the genre. Furthermore, the presence of female patrons engaging in rhythmic movements atop the bar serves as a testament to the establishment's convivial ambiance. However, it is worth noting that certain staff members, specifically those tasked with the dispensation of potent beverages, exhibit a propensity towards facetious behavior. Notwithstanding the aforementioned attributes, a significant segment of the patronage, including this pale-complected, flaxen-haired individual, experienced feelings of apprehension and discomfort amidst the throngs of rugged, leather-clad bikers, whose demeanor seemed to convey a sense of disapproval."

Cute spot. Good food.

The only thing I wanted from Eat was not available--the beignets!! Ugh. My heart was crushed to learn they didn't have any :( Alas, I opted for a chicken sandwich and it was good; nothing too special. The service was okay and given how small the menu is, I expect the staff to know the ingredients of the menu items which wasn't the case.

Would I return? Only If I happened to be in the area but wouldn't be my first choice.

if you're into heavy, rich food, Cowboy Ciao is your place.  i wasn't thoroughly impressed with the food, but the service is good.  very welcoming hostess, if i do say so myself.\n\nhonestly, i'd rather walk around the corner to fnb - it's way better.

This is one of the many MGM-Mirage properties on the strip.  The casino and hotel staff are all welcoming and friendly.   The casino floor and selection of shops and eateries is  decent and complete.\n\nThe casino floor and shops are all looking very nice with the New York theme design and  layout (Obviously very well maintained). The hotel rooms, however, are starting to look a little dated and might be due for updating (My room had a tube TV, which seems like a ancient relic now in 2009 - especially for a large, reputable, mid-strip property).

"A visually stunning lodging facility, yet the culinary establishments affiliated with said premises possess pricing structures that are marginally prohibitive for local patrons. Notwithstanding, the live entertainment options, specifically the 'Yellow Brick Road' and 'Steel Panther' performances, are of considerable quality. The aquatic recreational area is quite impressive, but unfortunately, we were compelled to vacate the premises on a recent Saturday afternoon to accommodate a nuptial ceremony, which resulted in an abrupt and hasty departure, thereby necessitating the settlement of an outstanding financial obligation."

I believe I fell prey to an exaggerated culinary experience, whereby my anticipation was elevated to an unreasonable extent, only to be met with a gustatory encounter that, while satisfactory, failed to surpass the ordinary or elicit an emotional response of profound amazement. The quality of the patty was undeniably superior, and the cooking process was executed adequately; however, I find myself partial to a burger that boasts an abundance of flavor, achieved through the judicious application of seasonings, rather than mere reliance on the inherent taste of the meat. In point of fact, I found it necessary to supplement my dish with a minuscule amount of salt to enhance its flavor profile. The accompanying side salad, though modest in proportions, presented itself quite agreeably, thanks in large part to the commendable dressing that graced its leaves. My dining companion opted for a grilled chicken sandwich, which, while palatable, suffered from an absence of seasoning, thereby mirroring my own experience with its burger counterpart. In light of these observations, I suggest that one consider paying a visit to Tessaro's, albeit with a tempered sense of expectation.

Dinner here was really, really OK.  No, I mean it.  Absolutely adequate.  It won't hurt you at all.  You might not remember it, though.  The atmosphere is absolutely present.  Also, the service happens.

La Place Dupuis peut Ãªtre considÃ©rÃ©e comme un fantÃ´me qui subsiste dans l'esprit de la population locale, malgrÃ© sa transformation en un centre commercial dotÃ© d'un hÃ´tel et d'une tour de bureaux. En effet, cette place importante de l'histoire du QuÃ©bec occupe une position secondaire par rapport Ã  sa vocation premiÃ¨re, qui datait des annÃ©es 1970, Ã©poque pendant laquelle elle abritait la grande surface Dupuis et frÃ¨res, une entreprise de commerce de dÃ©tail fondÃ©e et exploitÃ©e par une famille de Canadiens franÃ§ais. Si l'on effectue des recherches dans les archives des journaux locaux et disparus de MontrÃ©al, on dÃ©couvrira que le plus important annonceur Ã©tait souvent Dupuis et frÃ¨res, dont les publicitÃ©s s'Ã©talaient sur plusieurs pages. Cette institution fondÃ©e au 19Ã¨me siÃ¨cle n'Ã©tait pas simplement un grand magasin trÃ¨s populaire, mais reprÃ©sentait Ã©galement un symbole de rÃ©ussite pour les Canadiens franÃ§ais. De nos jours, on y retrouve principalement des comptoirs de restauration rapide, trÃ¨s populaires auprÃ¨s des employÃ©s de la tour de bureaux et des Ã©tudiants de l'UQAM, qui y mangent leur dÃ©jeuner. On y trouve Ã©galement plusieurs dÃ©taillants, notamment un Bureau en gros, mais il semble que cela ne constitue pas une destination de magasinage pour qui que ce soit. On traverse la Place Dupuis, qui est reliÃ©e Ã  la station de mÃ©tro Berri-UQAM, et on y fait des achats occasionnels, mais sans plus.

We revisited the establishment to partake in a chocolate concrete, which was accompanied by a solitary supplement, specifically toasted coconut that failed to enhance the beverage's flavor profile in any appreciable manner. Notwithstanding, the shake itself was of exceptional quality; however, we were grateful for our decision to share it, as it proved to be remarkably satiating.

I love my chinese food - so I always jump at the chance to go and review a chinese restaurant. We chose this place because of its excellent happy hour deal; something which seems to be amiss throughout the area's chinese restaurants. However, even without the happy hour deals, I would venture this place is a pretty low budget night out as it is. This is reflected in the quality and taste of the food - its not the best I have ever had, and one of my dining companions questioned what type of meat was in his dish more than once. However, as I mentioned, this place is cheap, and you get what you pay for - something not to great, but filling and cheap.

We came here for dinner with my boyfriend's family. They come here often and it was my first time. The prices are good for big portions. I came in with an empty stomach and left fully satisfied.

It's not the nicest place, but for what we ordered it was good. I got walnut shrimp and wonton noodle soup. The shrimp was good and tasty. Crunchy where needed. The broth to the soup however had no taste and the noodles were kinda hard. My boyfriend ordered duck and basically ate the whole thing. He really liked it. It was good but I've tasted tastier duck at Sam Woo. The sweet and sour soup was just as named. And the crispy noodles were thin and crispy. 

The customer service was good. They were nice and accommodating and continuously cleaning our table off because we did order a lot and it got pretty messy. They were also filling up waters constantly so no problem there. 

Their bathrooms were okay. And there was a cart full of dirty dishes by our table, I wasn't so sure about that. But they did clean it out every so often. Didn't really bother us but I was just wondering if that was supposed to go there in the first place. 

Affordable for the whole family.

"As I have reiterated on numerous occasions, my affinity for Italian cuisine is unwavering. Upon arriving at the proximate Best Western, I conducted a thorough examination of the most highly regarded dining establishments in the vicinity, utilizing the popular review platform, Yelp. My culinary exploration led me to the quaint Ristorante Foccaccio, which, while authentically Italian in essence, unfortunately failed to meet the elevated standards of quality I have had the pleasure of experiencing at other esteemed eateries. My primary grievance pertained to the Parmigiano Reggiano; instead of the customary fresh, artisanal variety, I was dismayed to discover that the restaurant opted for a processed, bottled alternative. Although the flavors were undoubtedly palatable, the portion sizes were somewhat diminutive, bordering on meager. Notwithstanding, I would still consider partaking in a future dining experience at this establishment, albeit with tempered expectations, provided that one is seeking a humble, family-operated Italian restaurant that falls short of exceptional."

I would definitely stay here again. I wasn't expecting luxury by any means but I also wasn't expecting it to be as decent as it was. We needed a last minute place to stay and booked a room for that night for $50. You get what you pay for, and those that complain about how grungy it was should have known that when they booked it. It is pretty far off the strip, but not nearly as far as Hard Rock. They sell $1.50 Bud Lights at the bar inside which is always a plus. I joined the Owl Club to get the $200 free slot play. I didn't win anything but I didn't lose anything either. The people that worked the counter were friendly and accommodating. The room was clean and had a television, what more can you ask for? Like I said, I definitely would stay here again when I was looking for a cheap hotel option in Vegas.

Oh and just a warning, the walls are REALLY thin and you can hear pretty much everything going on in the room next to you. If you are going to Vegas for a quiet experience you are in the wrong place anyways.

Also, DO NOT go to the Hooters inside the hotel. Its absolutely awful. (see my other review)

This place has potential to be a fun place to hang out.  Good staff, a stage and games for entertainment, a roach coach on the side that makes decent food-the potential for a fun neighborhood hangout is there.  The Living Social deal was well worth it to check the place out and sample their beers.

I came here last night with a friend for dinner and received average service.. Our waitress was very nice and prompt. +1  The margaritas were way way too sour and basically tasted like slurpees.  I ordered the Bleu Cheese Chopped Salad (in which the cheese is made from vegetable enzymes and is imported from Denmark, containing no dairy which was nice +2) and it was very filling. The side of potatoes were very good as well.  I will most likely be returning.
It was ok. I went for weekday brunch and Wynn paid half of the meal. There was nothing terrible and nothing exceptional. If you have a sweet tooth, I think wicked spoon has better selections.

Wine list is ok, not what I would have expected for a Wine Spectator award winner, and the markup is ENORMOUS. Generally the fish menu is sustainable but when I commented to the waitress about the CRITICALLY ENDANGERED Chilean sea bass she didn't even know the difference between farmed and wild caught fish let alone what sustainable meant - wait staff needs to be trained on that. Quality and flavor of the dinners was great overall, but the risotto side dish had zero flavor - where's the salt?? Beautiful view but in my opinion NOT totally worth $100 per person for dinner...and that didn't even include an appetizer or dessert!

"Four years have elapsed since their inauguration, and upon entering the establishment, I observed a dearth of patrons, with merely two individuals occupying the chairs, engaging in conversation. The absence of a queue afforded me the luxury of immediate attention, as I was promptly escorted to the station previously utilized by my threader. Following a succinct inquiry regarding my exposure to this treatment, she embarked on the process, initiating with a thorough sanitization of both her hands and my brows. 

The specialist executed her tasks with utmost efficiency, employing a systematic approach characterized by rolling, grasping broad sections, and exerting forceful pulls. My apprehensions concerning the potential for discomfort were quickly dispelled, as my initial encounter proved to be remarkably painless. However, during the subsequent session, I experienced an unanticipated jolt of surprise, as the cleaning procedure produced an intensified sensation that caught me off guard. Upon completion, my countenance allegedly reflected a state of perpetual astonishment, according to my companion's observation. Notwithstanding, I appreciated the benefits of having well-defined brows with a conspicuous contour, complemented by a gentle brush and clip at the conclusion. The entire process transpired within a span of 10 to 15 minutes. 

Although my previous exposure to this technique was somewhat more satisfying, as it yielded a more natural outcome with the bottoms being merely cleaned up and not artificially shaped, thus providing me with a fuller appearance, I must acknowledge that the precision displayed in the work merits praise. To ensure optimal results, I shall strive to communicate my preferences more effectively during future appointments. With a price point of $10, this service falls within the standard range offered by most threading salons."

"I endeavored to sample the conventional coffee offered at this establishment, and my assessment is that it was merely average in quality. However, I have not had the opportunity to indulge in the diverse array of flavors available, which seem to be a highlight among the clientele who have partaken in them. Thus, I eagerly anticipate receiving recommendations for some indispensable options to enhance my coffee experience. Notwithstanding the unremarkable taste of the coffee, I must commend the staff for their exceptional service and ability to adeptly prepare me for social interactions during my morning visits. Their proficiency in fostering an inviting ambiance is truly laudable, and I attribute this to both their warm demeanor and the stimulating effects of the caffeine they serve. Consequently, I shall persist in frequenting this establishment and remain optimistic about the prospect of discovering novel flavors that will garner my unequivocal approval. I enthusiastically encourage my fellow patrons to share their suggestions, as I am ardently devoted to sampling an assortment of flavors and relishing the unique qualities each one has to offer."

I'd been here a while back for a Yelp event so we headed here when we were looking for a place to chill rather than get onto a crowded Light Rail train. Extremely loud music and really, not all that good. But we had a couple of beers and managed to shout over the racket for a bit.\n\nIf you're planning a visit, I'd recommend avoiding the band. Why does it have to be so damn loud?

"Prioritizing primacy, I would never consider patronizing Digger, as my decision is predicated on an unwavering commitment to personal preference, rather than any personal animosity towards the establishment; albeit, I can appreciate the aesthetic appeal of its sunshine-colored facade, complemented by an array of charming hanging decorations, artisanal greeting cards, and visually striking ornaments, et cetera. Nonetheless, it regrettably fails to resonate with my individualized sensibilities, thereby rendering it incongruous with my distinctive tastes and preferences. Notwithstanding, I can conjecture that the shop's quaint charm may hold appeal for certain demographics, such as mothers and daughters, who might relish the opportunity to peruse its 'twee' assortment, as characterized by my mother."

The gastronomical experience we had the pleasure of indulging in was unfortunately subpar, particularly considering the tariff we were charged. My spouse and I both opted for the medium rare preference, yet our orders were not fulfilled in accordance with our expectations, as my partner received a rare steak and I was presented with a medium cooked cut. The restaurant staff maintained that the steaks were prepared appropriately, yet their justifications failed to assuage our dissatisfaction. In contrast, I have had the pleasure of partaking in superior quality steaks at establishments such as Outback and Longhorn, which offered a more satisfying culinary experience.

My third favorite steakhouse. They have the best blooming onion and green vegetable selections with brocolli, string beans, and asparagus. Texas Roadhouse edges them in the steak department. Outback also had the better mushrooms. Delfrisco's has the best steak with a steak called the Wygul but it is pricey. The front entrance position is a little weird to me. That's just my 2 cent.

Visited here for the first time on 1/21/2012 with a Groupon!

Atmosphere was nice, dark with lots of recessed lighting, you could definitely go casual or dress fancy and be in place with either. The service was really good, fairly quick to take your order and bring out plates. Plus, they had a waitress constantly refilling your glass of water (which can be a blessing at an Indian restaurant if you accidentally order something to spicy for your taste!)

Half of the menu was vegetarian, thumbs up for that!!

I was impressed that they immediately bring out a complimentary plate of very thin flat bread and chutneys as soon as you're seated. We ordered the veg sampler appetizer, which was pretty good. I definitely preferred the paneer pakoras and cauliflower pakoras over the samosas. I ordered the malai kafta as my main course, good. Garlic naan and paneer bread were very impressive.

I enjoyed Bombay Grille, but it doesn't top the quality of food at Woodlands... I'm forever spoiled.

These sandwiches are delicious, but there is one problem....Why is it that only the fire department and police officers get a discount in Las Vegas? I am in private EMS, and even when in uniform I am told that there are no discounts for us. Police, Fire and EMS are a TEAM... we work together as public safety guardians! Please fix this error!

"En route to Noodles of Asia for a 6:00 pm luncheon prior to our 11:30 pm dinner reservations at Raku (conventional dining hours do not apply, as it is Vegas!), we chanced upon Pinot Brasserie and, after a cursory examination of the menu, deemed it innocuous enough to warrant further exploration. The prices were reasonable, with $9.00 for a bowl of French onion soup and $15.00 for mussels and frites. Upon partaking of the culinary offerings, I found myself already yearning for the mussels a mere hour later, which is a testament to their gastronomical appeal. The white wine, butter, and garlic sauce combination was truly divine, particularly when one submerges the frites in said sauce for a brief interlude, allowing the flavors to meld together in a most harmonious manner. The French onion soup was also noteworthy, as it was one of the more superior examples of this particular dish that I have had the pleasure of consuming. It is all too common for establishments to rely on salt as a means of masking the absence of genuine onion flavor in their soups, but at Pinot Brasserie, the onion broth is allowed to shine in its unadulterated form, much to my gustatory delight. In conclusion, the edible aspects of our experience were indeed satisfactory. However, the quality of service left much to be desired. Our server was abysmal, displaying a complete lack of warmth or welcoming demeanor. She seemed taken aback by our expressions of gratitude, failing to demonstrate even a semblance of cordiality. Her attempts to promote dessert were also overly zealous, bordering on annoying. I must stress that a smile and a modicum of friendliness would greatly enhance her tip earning potential."

If you're looking for fabulous, go elsewhere. I've stayed a lot of places in Vegas and the MGM was rather disappointing. When I checked in, they had overbooked the large suite that I booked online, and offered to DOWNGRADE me to a room half the size. Are you kidding me?\n\nEverything from the rooms, to the casino, to the pool, to the service, is extremely mediocre and unmemorable. If you're spending the money to have a nice vacation I'd say take your business elsewhere.

Still a respectable three stars, mindful of my preferences for a watering hole and nocturnal diversion. A genuine public house with a playful Australian motif, replete with risquÃ© postcards and a cheeky placard directed at an unwitting patron, lending an air of conviviality reminiscent of a well-maintained student union. Patrons are affable, while barkeeps exhibit a no-nonsense brand of hospitality, albeit with a singular area demarcated by a conspicuous sign admonishing imbibers to avoid it, lest they incur the disfavor of the establishment's denizens. The recreational amenities, including a pair of pool tables, constitute a significant asset, although aspirants seeking participation must inscribe their names on a chalkboard roster, potentially facilitating interactions with intriguing individuals. A pedestrian selection of potations (i.e., excluding elaborate mixed drinks) characteristic of a typical bar, served within a cozy, unpretentious venue that finds itself overrun with Australians on their national holiday. Ultimately, an unremarkable but satisfactory experience.

"My most recent sojourn to Las Vegas afforded me the opportunity to partake in a culinary excursion to Chinatown, which piqued my interest due to the presence of a ramen establishment. Our group of five arrived promptly, thereby avoiding the throngs of patrons that typically congregate at this popular eatery. Upon being seated within a quarter of an hour, I opted for the'screaming for vengeance' variety of ramen, which boasted an additional component of corn, given my predilection for fiery broths. Unfortunately, my expectations regarding the spiciness level were not entirely fulfilled, as the broth did not quite live up to my standards. Furthermore, I cannot help but surmise that my taste buds may have been slightly impaired due to previous alcohol consumption, as I found the broth to be somewhat salty. Notwithstanding, I was rather taken by the pork belly, which offered an unparalleled experience of rich, unctuous deliciousness. The noodles, too, were cooked to perfection, possessing a satisfying texture that was neither too soft nor too firm. In conclusion, I would assign this restaurant a rating of three and a half stars, denoting a commendable effort, yet falling short of exceptional."

A ton of tea on offer and my raspberry hibiscus iced tea was brewed perfectly. I'd frequent this place if it were closer and not in the middle of Tempe Marketplace.\n\nLess stars because they were out of my first choice and the guy running the till went into an anti-Starbucks rant not knowing I was with a Starbucks manager. Have your opinions but it's not really something to start going off about in front of first-time (or really any) customers. You never know who's listening!

"Acknowledged. The proprietor connected with me and manifested palpable consternation regarding my singular assessment and critique. He displayed authentic concern for enhancing the issue and conveyed appreciation for my evaluation, which furnished him with insight to facilitate improvement. He appears to be an owner who genuinely values patron feedback and refrains from dismissing unfavorable reviews as mere musings of a disgruntled individual, as numerous proprietors are wont to do. In response to his proactive demeanor, I augmented my appraisal from a single star to three. He extended an invitation for me to visit the establishment during his tenure, affording us the opportunity to engage in discourse and potentially warranting a score revision. It is likely that I shall revisit the venue and revise my assessment accordingly."

I work late somtimes and they are open rather late and do not mind if you show up 5 min before closing time. The food is better then the normal cheap chinese/asain type places. Ask for a suggestion and they will give it. \n\nChicken fried rice is my usual.

A major drawback is the stale smell of the dining room.  My meal would probably have been a lot more enjoyable if I got to eat in the outdoor patio.\n\nIt's a good place, however, to take a mixed group - there's something for everyone - gyros and shwarmas for carnivores, Med platter (hummus, baba, tsaziki, tabouleh, falafel) for vegetarians.  Portions are generous - especially the lentil and rice side which was as big if not bigger than the mains.  Food hits the table fast and the prices are reasonable - no wonder this place is always packed.

"As an employee on the North Side, I decided to take a stroll in search of a novel lunch option, having grown weary of the monotony of dining at Eco Bistro, located directly beneath my office at Allegheny Center. During my peregrination, I chanced upon this eatery situated at the confluence of Ohio Avenue and the onramp leading to 279; the luncheon special was offered at a reasonable price, and I opted to accompany my meal with a carbonated beverage, bringing the total cost to approximately $6. The culinary delight I selected was the Kung Pao Chicken, which was cooked to my exacting specifications. The gastronomical experience was satisfying, economical, and expedient, and I chose to consume my repast within the establishment, which boasted a modest number of tables and maintained a level of cleanliness that was, at the very least, decent."

This place has awesome ratings on both yelp and zagat, but i was so disappointed. My expectations must've been too high. I WILL give them props for having the *best* and most smooth Thai Iced Tea I've ever had in my life though. Onto their food? The waiter suggested their duck in red curry. The duck meat tasted a bit... expired.. and rotten. It was also rough, and the curry lacked in flavor. We also ordered a green curry with chicken, which wasn't bad, but it didn't amaze me. I've had much better green curry at any reg Thai joint back home in New York. Now... the appetizer that the waiter said we HAD to order was GROSS. It's some crispy rice sort of thing.. and it's sour, and sour, and sour, and also expired tasting. Why is it their most popular item? People in Vegas must be weird then, sorry guys. \n\nOh, the lady behind the bar area was also rude. She had a huge diamond on her finger and wasn't in a uniform, so she might be some kind of owner/manager. To me though, that means you should step it up a level and be even more nice, not be a snotface. Skinny face, medium long black hair, pale, slender asian woman with a big rock -- BEWARE OF HER, she will make your whole meal unpleasant.

Casanova is a cute little Italian restaurant in the Venetian. Unfortunately, I didn't know how small it was. I had a table reservation for 13 people and was seated outside the actual restaurant which was really the middle of the walkway of the Grand Canal Shoppes. It was extremely loud, especially since there is a bar not 10 feet away. It's also right before the food court so there was a ton of food traffic throughout dinner. I would definitely reccommend this place if you were in a small group, up to 4 at the most. They would most likely seat you inside where it is very adorably decorated.

For an Italian restaurant at The Venetian, the food was extremely affordable. I got the Timballo which is basically penne in a creamy pesto sauce baked with parmesan on top. It was so flavorful and very filling; I wasn't able to finish my plate. The bread they serve you is so good too and delightfully roasted and warm. 

If you want good Italian at a reasonable cost, I definitely suggest Casanova.

"A profusion of commercial activity permeates this establishment, rendering it a veritable hub of transactional velocity. Frequently, an abundance of patrons seeking to avail themselves of the wares offered within results in the formation of protracted queues; however, such lines tend to dissipate with reasonable celerity. Certain items available for purchase at this location possess a quality that renders them particularly advantageous, often at a cost of $0.99 or, on occasion, two items for $0.99. While this store may not boast the most extensive inventory of such establishments in the vicinity, its proximity to my domicile renders it a convenient option. Despite the occasional untidiness of the premises, I customarily enter with the intention of acquiring a specific item, only to find myself succumbing to impulsive purchases totaling no less than $5-$10."

Due to the convenience factor associated with the location, I opted to explore Beijing as an alternative to my customary preference, Ho Ho Cherry House. Upon placing an order for the Sesame chicken (extra crispy), I was pleasantly surprised by the generous portion size, which included a substantial amount of chicken, fried rice, egg roll, a choice of soup (won-ton being my selection), and a small serving of steamed broccoli. In contrast to Ho Ho Cherry House, Beijing offered both soup and broccoli, thereby rendering me thoroughly satisfied. My order was prepared within a mere 10 minutes, giving the impression of being cooked-to-order. Furthermore, their egg rolls surpassed those of Ho Ho's, primarily due to the incorporation of ingredients beyond merely cabbage. Notably, the taste of the fried rice and the soup was quite impressive. So much so, that I shared some of the won-ton soup broth with the children I was babysitting, and their enthusiasm for it was evident. However, Beijing fell short in terms of the crispiness factor, which is a crucial aspect of my evaluation for Chinese cuisine. Unfortunately, the chicken failed to meet my expectations regarding crispiness, and I cannot help but wonder how it would have fared without the extra crispy specification. Additionally, I found the sauce to be less appealing compared to Ho-Ho's. Despite this, the sides were expertly cooked, and considering the reasonable price point and prime location, I would consider giving Beijing another chance, while emphasizing the importance of the extra crispy element.

Overall good experience.  I had the slider trio with a side of jalapeno coleslaw. Was expecting the slaw to knock my socks off but was anything to write home about. Pulled pork wasn't my favorite texture seemed more like pork roast. But the hot link was fantastic! Very spicy!  I was very disappointed with the country berry cobbler, lacked sweetness entirely. The place packed & decor and atmosphere were real homey. Liked the personal touches with their murals. We'll definitely go back. Looking forward to trying the smoked meatloaf.

A good friend of mine is a secret fan of gift shops- he can spend hours in them- so long as they are the official ones. Well this one is an official one and despite the twee gift ideas and corny souvenirs there are some more classier and elegant gift ideas in here. 

The quality is also much better than the cheaper alternatives on the Royal mile, minus the bad and loud music and bright colours the later ones have. 
So it really depends on your budget and how much you want to hunt around for gifts or souvenirs. I like the service in the gift shop- the lady is always so nice and didn't mind my friend browsing for an age either. (and didn't follow us around like a certain other cheaper gift shop did). If you payed to get into the Castle might as well have a walk around even if you do choose the cheaper options down the street.

Last week, I had the pleasure of dining at this establishment with a friend. The parking situation in the vicinity is quite convenient, with ample parking spaces available along the street or in nearby parking lots. Upon entering the restaurant, I was immediately struck by the enticing aroma of spices that permeated the air. The ambiance was cozy and intimate, with a well-designed layout that maximized the use of space. However, as a larger individual, I found the seating arrangements to be somewhat cramped. Fortunately, we were able to secure a table that afforded me sufficient legroom without feeling too claustrophobic.
