 The restaurant's entrance is located on the same level as the street, making it easily accessible for individuals with mobility impairments. However, the narrow pathways within the establishment may pose a challenge for wheelchair users. There are also elevated platforms within the restaurant that can be navigated via a small step, but this may present some difficulties for those with mobility issues. 
 The service we received was friendly and attentive, and the food was freshly prepared and served promptly, despite the restaurant being moderately busy. While I cannot authenticate the Indian cuisine, I found the dishes we ordered to be flavorful and satisfying, particularly my friend's entree and the desserts. The salad was somewhat unremarkable, but the homemade almond and cashew ice cream we sampled for dessert was truly exceptional, thanks to its unique blend of cardamom and other spices that created an unforgettable taste experience. Unfortunately, I did not have the opportunity to assess the restrooms, as I did not use them during our visit. I am uncertain about the availability of credit card payment options, as I did not inquire about it.

The decor and atmosphere of this place is awesome and that's what initially attracted me to in while staying in Caesar's. Cool fish tank, nice decor. Everyone is dressed in all white and the entire restaurant is decorated in white. I tried a beef and noodle dish which was just okay, lacking any real flavor. I was really hoping for more and since it's Vegas it was pricey. I think my bill was somewhere about $35 for my meal and a beer.

I like the atmosphere , it seems familiar but it's not . 

We tried the lunch special that was an open faced green chili meatloaf sandwich and the grilled salmon salad . Both dishes came out pretty as a picture with the food stacked high .

The meatloaf sandwich had mashed potatoes over the bread and a tasty cole slaw on top of the meatloaf . Unfortunately the potatoes were very over mixed and were extremely gummy .

The salmon salad overall was good and I am not sure if I didn't like the chive risotto cake or maybe the flavor of it clashed with the citrus dressing .

Service was fine .

I would come back again but I am not in a hurry .

I had a mere forty minutes to dispose of, and given the crowded ambiance, I harbored concerns regarding the expediency of service, which was substantiated by my perusal of previous patron's accounts. However, upon securing a table, I was promptly presented with a beverage within a five-minute interval, and although I was apprised that the preparation time for buffalo wings would be approximately twenty minutes, I was pleasantly surprised to receive them in under ten. The overall quality of service was laudable. Notwithstanding, the wings themselves were imbued with an excessive degree of acidity, and while they did possess a tangible level of spiciness, I would not consider ordering them again. In contradistinction, the two gentlemen seated adjacent to me professed satisfaction with their fish and chips. Furthermore, while the cost of sustenance was reasonable, the price of a twenty-two ounce Stella Artois seemed exorbitant at nine dollars.

Although my culinary experience was not optimal due to an absence of suitable dishes, the hospitality we received was quite satisfactory. Our server, a male individual, exhibited great adaptability in addressing our requirements. Frankly, I am uncertain if I can proffer a comprehensive assessment, given my dietary restrictions as a vegetarian. My moniker, Mr. Tofu, led me to assume erroneously that the menu would feature various vegetarian options. Unfortunately, such was not the case, as only one dish catered to my preferences. A chilled tofu noodle soup constituted the solitary vegetarian entrÃ©e, containing merely three components: noodles, tofu brothâpresumably crafted from tofu extractâand ice. Its flavor profile was uninspiring, with a predominantly neutral taste attributable to the lack of complementary ingredients. In order to enhance the soupâs palatability, I found it necessary to combine it with kimchi, a spicy fermented Korean side dish. The supplementary dishes provided were relatively enjoyable, as they contributed a much-needed burst of flavor to my meal. However, their quality did not suffice to persuade me to revisit the establishment, particularly considering my current culinary inclinations.

"Five stars are warranted for the innovative concept of establishing a cupcake store in Scottsdale, as well as the inviting and spacious store ambiance. However, it must be acknowledged that my personal preference for sweets may have influenced my overall assessment, as I have previously indulged in the delectable offerings of Magnolia in New York and was thoroughly impressed by each and every bite. In contrast, Sprinkles failed to elicit a similar response from me, as I found their cupcakes to be excessively saccharine. Furthermore, upon sharing a red velvet cupcake, the top layer detached, prompting utter disbelief and underscoring the need for improved quality control measures."

Interesting food creations, using lobster in sandwiches, salad, fried food, and ice cream!  However, the foods in fact tasted just A-OK and prices were sorta steep.  $23 for a 6\" lobster roll was pricey, I think.  The lobster salad came with lots of small chunks of lobster meat and was good for the price.  Lobster bisque was just standard.  Lobster-n-chips was cool though! Beer-battered and fried lobster huh? Yummmmm~  Last but not least, the lobster ice cream that sounded out of the ordinary was actually vanilla ice cream with itsy-bitsy lobster meat.  The ice cream tasted alright but was worth a try!  Just ask for a free sample before you buy, so as to make sure that you would like some savory ice cream that tastes like seafood. *wink*

Located within the opulent confines of the Tuscany Casino, where we had the pleasure of residing during our recent sojourn to Las Vegas for a professional convention, this esteemed eatery afforded us the opportunity to partake in a delectable dining experience, accompanied by an abundance of seating options suitable for sizable gatherings. Our hospitable server, possessing an unwavering commitment to exceptional customer service, efficiently accommodated our group's diverse needs, including the judicious utilization of a 2 for 1 dinner entree coupon, with a composure that belied any hint of exasperation. The culinary offerings, while not necessarily extraordinary, were nonetheless palatable, with prices that could be considered reasonable and portion sizes that struck a satisfying balance between sufficiency and moderation.

"While not an epicurean extravaganza, this unpretentious eatery offers a satisfactory dining experience, suitable for a casual luncheon or evening meal, and provides an appropriate ambiance for socializing with companions."

"If you possess an unwavering predilection for carne asada, and I mean a genuine, unrelenting fondness for this delectable dish, then it is imperative that you pay a visit to this culinary establishment. However, if your gastronomical inclinations lean towards a more diverse array of options, you may find the menu offerings to be somewhat restrictive. The primary dishes available are carne asada tacos, burritos, tostadas (dubbed 'Vampiro'), and quesadillas, with a solitary vegetarian entrÃ©e and, naturally, chips and salsa accompanying them. Be that as it may, the carne asada itself boasts a commendable quality, as I can personally attest to having sampled both the Vampiro and the quesadilla. While some patrons have expressed discontent regarding the supplementary cost of chips and salsa, it is essential to note that such an additional expense is customary in the realm of counter-service eateries. Moreover, the chips are freshly prepared, and the salsa, though lacking in piquancy, presents a flavor profile that is undeniably captivating. In conclusion, this restaurant merits a visit, particularly for those whose taste buds crave the savory allure of carne asada."

This review is only for eyebrow waxing.

Walked in on a Saturday afternoon and within 5 minutes I was taken to the back. No waiting. My normal eyebrow place is a 30 minute drive across town and there's always a one hour wait just for eyebrow waxing. This place is conveniently down the street from me. 

I'm used to more plucking than waxing. Here I got a lot of waxing, almost no plucking. My eyebrows ended up much thinner than expected, not everyone can work with my brows, but I still took the risk. I was a bit disappointed at how thin they turned out. It's been almost a week and so far, not a hair in sight which is good. Pricing is reasonable, $10. If I'm ever in a jam again and need my eyebrows waxed stat, I'd most likely visit again. They do accept cards but want gratuity in cash.

Went in on a Sunday for the first time. They are opened till midnight, which is great. The sushi, nothing special. I give it 3 starts b/c their edamame is not organic (per waitress), nor is their soy sauce. I don't know about you guys but I have zero interest feeding myself genetically modified soybeans. Wish they would make the change to organic/non-GMO verified soy, but then again why would they? Majority of the people don't care or have knowledge of what GMOs are ~ so, I guess for the minority of the public it wouldn't be worth to change that *SIGH* one day we will all care -_-

I chose Mesa Grill after hearing Delmonico's is way overrated. Having eaten at the Bahamas location, and despite my aversion to Bobby Flay, I decided to give the Las Vegas MG a try.

1. Awkward seating arrangement: We had a table of six, and it seemed like they had to put a table in the middle of a seating arrangement in order to fit us. We would've been perfectly fine if the wait staff wasn't continually bumping into my friends' chairs and then asking them to move out the way. That was uncool.

2. Food was great. Everyone was really happy with their dishes. Amongst the six of us, we ordered the duck, ribeye and pork tenderloins. For sides, pesto mashed potatoes, baby carrots, tiger shrimp tamale and sauteed spinach. We had to wait a bit for a couple of the sides because the waitress forgot them, but it wasn't too bad. Food came out hot and tasty.

3. Desserts were okay. I enjoyed my spicy chocolate creme brulee in the Bahamas more than the profiteroles I had. I thought they were really stingy with the iced cream which put me off a bit.

4. Service was alright. Our waitress was chatty and came around a few times to check on us.

Mesa Grill Las Vegas didn't disappoint and I wouldn't be against visiting BF's other restaurants.

"Obsolete and antiquated, the existing Target establishment situated at the intersection of Camelback Road and Seventh Avenue, is slated for a comprehensive renovation and metamorphosis into an upgraded, state-of-the-art 'Super Store' format, much to the delight of local patrons who eagerly anticipate the unveiling of the revamped retail hub. However, it is worth noting that not all individuals share the same level of enthusiasm regarding the transformation, with some expressing reservations about the'superstore' designation and the potential for a homogenized, big-box shopping experience that may compromise the distinctiveness and specialization of traditional retail establishments. Furthermore, certain patrons have taken issue with the temporary scarcity of select items and the perceived dearth of adept, ingenious solutions proffered by store personnel in response to inquiries regarding the impending reopening date."

I ordered friend noodles to take home. Some how the instructions wasn't clear or mis-interpreted about the level of chili in it. I was just excited to go home after a day of sweated heat in Phoenix.  I got home and the sauce looked lava red. I ate about a third of the dish, and I wish I didn't eat any. My lip was swelling and face sweating.  I drank down a coca cola bottle to control the convection going inside me.\n\nSome how, you need to check the level of pepper spice on these take home orders. I will give them another chance as this is just one dish (and not about pallet of dishes ), and to explain themselve, and I will be happy to update my rating. This is not an experience to be repeated.

I aspire to cherish this establishment, yet I simply cannot. My initial impression was that it was a middling hamburger joint with an exceptional assortment of beers. Upon entering, I was perplexed by the absence of any indication that I was expected to accommodate myself. The lack of menus on the tables further contributed to my bewilderment. It is imperative that eateries ensure their tables are equipped with menus, particularly when catering to novice clientele. 
  I opted for the bruschetta and pesto burger, which, while delectable, was regrettably diminutive in stature. For a paltry $7.59, the portion size was unacceptably minuscule. No aspect of this burger could possibly justify its cost. Patrons must additionally purchase sides, such as fresh cut fries, shoe string fries, or sweet potato fries, thereby elevating the price of a meal to approximately $10, which is somewhat exorbitant considering the quality and quantity of the food provided. 
  My dining companion selected the mac and cheese with bacon burger, the constituents of which were undoubtedly scrumptious. Nonetheless, the burger itself was disappointingly arid. Perhaps the implementation of a cheese sauce would have enhanced its overall flavor? 
  The beer selection is truly extensive and impressive, featuring an abundance of excellent brews worthy of sampling. Notwithstanding, my overall assessment of this venue remains merely average.
I shop here all the time.  Staff is friendly and helpful.  But .......the bathroom is always NASTY.  I always question if I should shop there when the bathroom is always disgusting. Yucky

"A rather exceptional sports bar, situated directly opposite the sports book within the MGM, offering an optimal setting for enjoying a cold beverage and satisfying cuisine following a successful wager. Be aware that the venue tends to become congested on Saturdays and Sundays during the football season, making it challenging to secure a table for larger gatherings. However, ample seating options are available at the bar, provided you arrive promptly. The culinary offerings are relatively straightforward, and it is recommended to limit your selection to wings or perhaps a burger, as everything else may not be worth the indulgence. During game days, consider taking advantage of their reasonable promotions, which often feature a combination of shots and beers. A diverse array of beers is available on tap, complemented by the presence of most classic domestic brands in bottles. While nothing particularly extraordinary, this establishment provides a pleasant atmosphere in which to unwind and appreciate the various sporting events showcased on numerous televisions."

Green River soda pop, a culinary delight reminiscent of a bygone era, alongside delectable fried mushrooms, constitute merely a few of the myriad gastronomical indulgences available at this establishment, which prides itself on offering an array of quintessential Chicago specialties, including, but not limited to, Red Hots and an assortment of savory hot dogs, all of which are presented with aplomb; however, it is worth noting that the service, while not necessarily expeditious, is nevertheless adequate, and although the current menu may not be as extensive as that of its predecessor, a former pizza purveyor, the quality of the fare remains undiminished.

This particular Dunkin Donuts franchise represents one of the pioneering establishments within the greater Madison region, boasting a prime location at the confluence of Highways Q and 19 in Waunakee, where it is strategically integrated with a co-located BP Gas Station.  Upon entering the premises, patrons are greeted by an exceptionally cordial and accommodating team, committed to ensuring a satisfying experience for each customer. While the assortment of donuts available may not necessarily qualify as a gastronomic revelation, they do, however, manage to satisfy cravings and meet expectations. Consequently, if you ever find yourself in the vicinity and harbor an unwavering yearning for such baked goods, consider granting this establishment a chance to demonstrate their proficiency in providing a gratifying encounter.

fun spot, pretty good food-not crazy authentic but definitely still worthy of a meal or two here-and the service was good.  Very casual laid back but I loved the tortilla soup :) Don't come in looking to be wow'd by the service but they did fine in my book, it's so casual so I don't understand why everyone was so eerked about the service.

Pluses: great location to be close to The Strip but pay off-strip prices (5/10 minute walk to Ballys/Paris), Westin Heavenly Bed & Heavenly Shower, nice if u want to rest away from the city's hustle & bustle, plenty of free parking

Minuses: Small pool, small spa (it's nice but doesn't have all of the amenities that you'd find at a big spa), surprised they didn't have iHomes in the room

Also I was disappointed with some of the customer service. We wanted to leave our bags with the bellhop because our room wasn't ready yet. He wasn't there but the concierge and all 4 of the people at the check in desk weren't doing anything. I know they saw us waiting! It was so long before someone even acknowledged us that I was literally seconds from putting my bags back in my car! Even if it's not your job, you should at least say "he'll be right back" or "let me find him". Or even better, help us yourself! How hard is it to put a ticket on a bag! That was so uncalled for... Disappointing

This Motel 6 is a-ok with me. It was inexpensive (and this was dead of summer we were talking about here). The room was clean. The staff was friendly. I slept through my wake up call, but that's my fault. They got a little pool to the side. Plenty of parking.\n\nThe only issue I'd warn you about is that this is next to some sort of theme park. This can create some noise in the day. You can't really see it from this facility but it is there. You'll hear it. There's also not a lot around this area, so getting up and getting breakfast is a pain because you usually have to go drive somewhere.

Not too bad. Selection of cake batter, vanilla, and chocolate are all good. Pretty good selection of toppings. Make sure you ask for mochi! The interior is splendid with lots of interesting people. Some Indian mom asked me how per hour do I charge ( I was wearing a rent by the hour shirt)...still awkward....

I'm glad that someone else mentioned that this was known as the Kabob House, because if they didn't, I'd never have found it.  I don't know that I've ever seen it called Khaneh Kabob (though perhaps that's what it says in their native tongue).

Anyway - the place is indeed clean, though in an odd twist, it's attached to a beverage store.  That's not bad, just a statement of fact.  If you order a kabob that contains steak or chicken, I can definitely see how you might be disappointed - you don't get a lot.

If you order a kabob that has ground meat, you'll probably have leftovers.  Unfortunately, I can't tell you which kind to order, because we always go with our friends who do the ordering for us, but I can definitely tell you that these are not your typical Americanized shish-kabobs.  These are Persian-style kabobs.  So don't be disappointed.

The ground-beef-style ones are wrapped around a long, flat skewer and cooked on the skewer, and you get a ton of meat.  I don't know if you have to order side dishes separately, but we always get them - rice, bread and other items - because the meat by itself is good, but you'll want to have other items as well, because it makes it so much better.

Service is friendly, but it isn't speedy, and they have not historically been able to communicate particularly well in English.

Came here during the Christmas week, so there was a premium price on the buffet during lunchtime, about $30-something per person. The regular line up to get in was PACKED, so if it wasn't for the line pass we had, it would've been bye bye to the buffet.

Been here before last year and it seems the quality has gone down. The food was okay, but there really wasn't anything to write home about. They have your standard stuff that can be found in other buffets like shrimps, prime rib, roasted chicken, etc etc. They also have the king crab legs which seem to be the main attraction as I saw many people just having piles and piles of them on their plates. I didn't try the king crab legs as I'm not fond of them in general. I found many of the food to be kinda dry and so I have to put a lot of sauce on them to taste better.

The best part I found was the dessert. They have different kinds of dessert from creme brulee to creampuffs to different flavors of ice cream, as well as brownies, banana fosters, and cookies. I tried the creme brulee and cookies and they're pretty good. Better than the main stuff honestly.

Pop and juice are included in the price, so try to take advantage of that.

Not worth the $30-something for lunch, but ok for the regular $20-something.

Went there with a group of people. the portions where huge! Half of us liked the food, and the other half just thought it was OK. The jerk pork and chicken weren't that tasty. But the pork BBQ was great, as were the sweet potatoes and rice.

"Recently, in the company of numerous colleagues, I partook in an evening excursion to a local culinary establishment, whereupon I sampled their signature Kobe burger, complemented by a delectable assortment of white cheddar and sweet potato fries. Although the gastronomic experience was indeed pleasurable, with the burger being cooked to perfection and the fries displaying an unparalleled crispness, it did not quite ascend to the lofty heights of my most memorable burger experiences. Nonetheless, the convivial atmosphere and camaraderie shared among our group served to enhance the overall enjoyment of the meal."
Alright sushi. At least they have a few good roles for $5 ish. Good and quick for a pick-up lunch during the work week.\n\nNo seating. Takeout/Pick up only.

"While it may not be an establishment that would warrant extensive correspondence with my domestic dwelling, I must admit that Jason's Deli does provide a satisfactory experience when it comes to satiating my craving for a distinctive sandwich that diverges from the norm offered by traditional sandwich shops. Upon entering the premises, I am greeted by a diverse array of soups, which presents me with an abundance of options to choose from. Additionally, their sandwiches are of decent quality, and their ice cream offerings serve as a pleasant conclusion to the meal. Although I wouldn't purposely go out of my way to visit Jason's Deli, I similarly wouldn't deliberately avoid it if I were passing by or meeting acquaintances there."

"Culinary excellence. My epicurean inclinations were satiated by the delectable Chicken Marsala, yet my fiscal sensibilities were dismayed by the somewhat prohibitive pricing structure. Notwithstanding, an adolescent employee bearing a striking resemblance to either Jonah Hill or Seth from the cinematic masterpiece 'Superbad,' complete with an unmistakable 'white boy' coiffure, served to enhance the overall dining experience, thereby rendering the merely adequate service marginally more palatable."

This place could be 5 stars if it changed a few things.  The menu is ok and my food came out tasteing pretty good.  The ambiance is awsome.  Love the indoor out door set up.  You can even bring your dog onto the patio.  The bartenders all seem really pretentious.  The owner should send them over to Ve Bene in Ahwatukee to see how a good bartender interacts with their patrons. They don't offer any drink specials at night and drinking there can get pricey.  I guess that's why they are always pretty slow when I drive by.  Maybe they think they are keeping out the riff raff. ;o)

"On my maiden visit to this establishment, I opted for the shredded beef burrito, priced at $6.29, which, while substantial in size, did not quite meet my expectations in terms of taste. However, their complementary warm chips and guacamole, available for purchase at $0.99 and $2.69 respectively, proved to be a notable exception, as they exhibited a satisfying confluence of flavors and textures that left me feeling satiated. Despite having returned to this location on multiple occasions, my culinary explorations have been limited to these aforementioned items, as they continue to captivate my palate with their simplicity and elegance. Furthermore, while I do concede that Qdoba's chips are somewhat superior, my preference for Baja Fresh's burritos remains unwavering, particularly in light of the fact that the two establishments share a striking similarity, as suggested by their proximity to one another, with Qdoba situated directly across the street from Chipotle. This peculiar coincidence notwithstanding, I remain steadfast in my devotion to Baja Fresh's offerings."

It was good. It wasn't outrageously great, but it wasn't horrendously bad. 

I ordered the Turkey & Rosemary Omelet and my boyfriend ordered the French Toast Strata. 

My meal came with an omelet, oven-roasted potatoes and fresh fruit. While everything was good, I have to say that I probably could have made the meal at home. If I go back, I wouldn't not eat this again, but I would definitely like to try something from their lunch selection first. My boyfriend was pretty much in agreement there. While he said his meal was good, he wants to try their burgers. 

They have a nice size menu filled with lots of veggie and lean meat dishes, which are perfect for me. However, they also cater to my boyfriend's style with such dishes like the Wisconsin Pride Burger (cheese curds and bacon on top of a 1/2 lb burger). 

We actually went their for breakfast for my boyfriends birthday. With that in mind, we left with a cupcake (I passed; too full to even think about cupcakes). My boyfriend chose the carrot cupcake with cream cheese frosting and walnut bits sprinkled on top. He wolfed it down and said it was good. 

I may update this review after we go for lunch sometime.

We initiated our Winter Break by indulging in a delectable pizza, utilizing a coupon to experience Florencia's culinary offerings. Upon arriving at the establishment shortly before 3 pm, we were delighted to find that we had the vast majority of the seating area to ourselves, excluding a mere two additional tables. Our server, Melissa, promptly welcomed us and efficiently secured our beverage orders. We opted for the XL Cheese pizza, as our collective craving for dairy proved insatiable. The pizza's appearance was indeed visually pleasing, and its taste proved to be commensurate with its aesthetic appeal. However, we were compelled to procure our subsequent round of beverages from the bar unaccompanied, which slightly diminished our overall satisfaction. Despite this minor drawback, we remain eager to revisit Florencia's and sample their diverse menu options, as the pizza's rich, well-balanced flavor profile and perfectly cooked crust left an indelible impression upon our palates.
Its just okay even with the low price. I stayed there during the Mining convention and it seemed understaffed. The room was clean and the water hot.  Its okay.

Sometimes it pays to be in larger groups when the bill will be larger and provide bigger tips.  

My wife and I seemed to be overlooked, especially towards the end of the meal.  Took 16 minutes to order dessert.  Way too long.

The ravioli was great and pork belly was tender.  Ther prawns were a little over done.  I would try going here again to see what happens.  I was not going to cause a scene, but by the end, I was just trying to get out of there.  The food was a 4, but the service seemed slow.

Surprisingly decent venue- larger than expected, back wall is a massive bar. Lines for drinks get long, and prices are predictably steep for generic draft beer, but the staff are friendly. In addition to bartenders, there are a lot of people cleaning and monitoring the crowd, which is a nice touch.\n\nBathrooms are huge with 20+ stalls, so getting in a trip between sets isn't a huge wait as it is at other venues. The acoustics are fairly good, but I found it odd that the general admission/floor area is divided up by odd iron rails- I understand they don't want a giant mosh pit going or anything, it's an unusual setup.

I have had the occasion to partake in the culinary offerings of this establishment on several occasions over the course of my residency in this city, totaling five years, and it is with a sense of relief that I can report that there has been a marked improvement in the quality of the fare provided, specifically in regards to the moisture level and overall taste, which previously left much to be desired, having been characterized by an unpleasant dryness and a strong suggestion of having been stored for an extended period of time in close proximity to the preparation area. It is my sincere hope that this upward trend in gastronomical excellence shall continue unabated.

Little pricey for the food.  The reason it pays to come to this place is the excellent drink menu, and souvenir cups, glasses, mugs, etc. that you can take with you.  The place is packed with movie trivia and buy stuff in the store next-door.\nNice stuff for lunch during the convention...and creates a good memory!

Having indulged in delectable repasts at Kai, we were elated to discover that its former culinary artisan had joined forces with Mod. The hallmark flourishes and panache of this gastronomic virtuoso were manifest in the plating, while the victuals themselves were inventive and, in certain instances, exceptional, such as the "shroom" dish. The venison lollipops, alas, were a tad undercooked for my taste, although my spouse avowed that they were savory. He also partook of the pescado loco tartare, which met with his approval. As for myself, I opted for the duck grande plate, only to be disenchanted by the pedestrian nature of the dish, which, aside from the duck itself, was merely on par with offerings found at Milagro Grill or The Mission. The okra, furthermore, was unaccountably saline. A server, bearing a covered dish, approached our table and queried whether it belonged to us. Upon inquiring as to the dish's identity, he proved to be utterly oblivious. Turns out, he hailed from the kitchen, not a regular waitstaff member, but an utter novice. Understandable, given that it was Labor Day Weekend, and the staff might not have been the usual crew. Nonetheless, our waitress was quite personable, the hostess welcoming, and the other patrons we encountered were assiduous. The raucous melodies, intended for a younger clientele, proved somewhat intrusive. While I could envision returning for apÃ©ritifs and a cocktail, I would not consider Mod for future cenacles, given the plethora of superior options available in the Valley.

We had a stopover in Phoenix and ended up at Jose Roux. I ordered steak tacos and ice water. The menu said that rice and beans were $4 extra, total, so I decided to pass.

The tortillas were absolutely delicious--homemade, corn, soft. Unfortunately, they were really, really tiny. There was lots of stuff piled onto the taco: steak, lettuce, tomato, salsa. The menu said the steak said it was marinated with pineapple but I couldn't really taste any of it. The steak was pretty tough. The mild salsa was good, though. Black beans and tasteless white rice were on the plate, though I didn't order them; the waiter didn't charge me, though.

Service was really slow, which is a little irritating at an airport, but a common problem nevertheless.

I'd give Bei a 3.5. Who ever the Yelpers are that compare it to Shin Bay, have obviously never been to Shin Bay. Not even close to Hiro, for that matter. We're talking Ra or Kona Grill at best. 

For shame fellow Yelpers, let's just call a spade, a spade. It's passable sushi in Scottsdale. 

For those who disagree...get out more. Try real sushi.

C'est un peu mieux que ce que c'\u00e9tait il y a deux ans. Premi\u00e8rement pour moi l'exp\u00e9rience varie principalement avec les compagnies a\u00e9riennes. Qatar Airways c'est le check-in le plus vite que j'n'ai jamais eut de ma vie. Sans blague, 30 minutes j'avais pass\u00e9 le check-in des bagages, les douanes. Je me sentais comme un VIP! Air Canada il y a deux ans, oufff c'\u00e9tait dans le m\u00e9diocre absolu. 1h20 pour le check-in des bagages. 10 minutes les douanes...\n\nMaintenant, le hic que tout le monde ont eut c'est la ligne d'attente stupide avec le beau Welcome to Canada ( et l\u00e0 dans ta t\u00eate, t'as l'impression qu'il manque le monde IDIOTS \u00e0 c\u00f4t\u00e9) parce que c'est longggggg. Mais ils ont chang\u00e9 leur syst\u00e8me de v\u00e9rification des passes de v\u00e9rification; c'est un lecteur de passport qui lit  ta fiche de d\u00e9claration et scan ton passeport.  1: Bonne id\u00e9e, 2: le lecteur que j'ai pris fonctionnais mal, \u00e7a a prit trop de temps. Si t'as coch\u00e9 non pour tout c'est ok, merci Ciao! Sinon, Attend!! C'est une coche mieux que c'\u00e9tait.

"Culinary delights are an absolute delight. Particularly, the grilled salmon burrito exemplifies gastronomical excellence. However, it is quite disconcerting to note that the men's restroom facilities appear to be severely lacking in terms of both cleanliness and maintenance, evoking an unpleasant comparison to a roadside truck stop's subpar sanitary conditions."

Upon my return to the establishment following an approximate hiatus of three years, instigated by an unrelenting craving for Greek cuisine in close proximity to the location, I opted to sample their Spanakopita, primarily to determine whether any alterations had transpired in the preparation method. The visual aspect of the dish appeared unchanged, yet upon consumption, I discerned a notable improvement in taste, attributable to the harmonious balance of savory elements and an adequate quantity of salt. The composition somewhat resembled a spinach-based lasagna. Noteworthy was the bed of rice pilaf that accompanied the dish, which unfortunately failed to impress me owing to its lack of flavorfulness and palatability. In addition, I requested their pumpkin cheesecake, only to find it excessively saccharine, even surpassing the sweetness level of similar desserts obtained from the Cheesecake Factory. Consequently, I would assign a rating of 3.5 stars for this particular visit.

Food was ok. Meat was blah, fries were blah, but a fun experience. 
*If you weigh more then 350 you eat free. 
*They only accept cash.
*must wear gown and bracelet
Wouldn't come back because the food was nothing special, but a good experience!

Sichuan is a region in China known for hot babes. If you know a thing or two about what brings the heat you know that you need the whole package. Pretty and smart gets it done. Taking one without the other you're either shallow or a chump.

You'll see a ton of these yelp reviews deride the decor or the service or the atmosphere. These are the kinds of kids that like places like Imperial Garden. Who likes that place? (I do. Kind of a lot. I think?). You'll also see a ton of these yelp reviews glow over Sichuan food and eating stuff like oxtail and tripe or pickled soup. I am a big fan, and their spicy crispy chicken is my jam. The only thing I got here that I didn't like was the Kung Pao chicken - it didn't pack much heat and the sauce was thick and sweet. I think they thought I was getting something from the Americanized menu.

So what kind of babe is Ichiban? Obviously she's the brainy one that doesn't care what you think. I kinda wish she did, though.

"Indulge in delectable sandwiches and savory gyros, and relish the opportunity to partake in live musical performances, provided they are scheduled, at this unpretentious eatery conveniently located near the campus quadrangle, which has been a source of delight for me since my student days and continues to be a place of nostalgic reverence whenever I have the pleasure of visiting the Champaign-Urbana area."

"We visited this establishment on two separate occasions during the same evening, and our rationale behind such a decision was primarily driven by the desire for an affordable and satisfying dining experience, as well as the craving for a substantial quantity of nachos that would satiate our collective hunger. The price point of $16 per plate was certainly a factor in our decision-making process, as it represented a relatively economical option compared to other dining establishments in the surrounding area. Furthermore, while the cheese could have been melted to a slightly greater extent, the quality of the nachos remained satisfactory, particularly when consumed in a state of intoxication. For those seeking additional alcoholic beverages, we suggest resorting to unconventional means, such as panhandling or offering dance performances in exchange for a $1 margarita, which, despite its low cost, proved to be potent and flavorful, thus ensuring the continuation of one's inebriated state."

We informed them that we were on the esteemed guest list, yet they appeared to be nonplussed by this revelation. Subsequently, we all contributed $20, inclusive of the fairer sex, despite the absence of any queue. It transpired that lodging at the Venetian Resort Hotel Casino rendered the entry fee redundant.

Upon gaining admittance to the nightclub, we discovered that the interior was quite congested. The female patrons who engaged in vigorous posterior movements captivated our attention, as did those who partook in reciprocal massages. The ubiquitous presence of Buddha statues throughout the venue struck me as somewhat unsettling, although I conjecture that others may have been less sensitive to their presence.

We were directed to ascend a flight of stairs, leading us to an area typically reserved for TAO Beach during daylight hours. While the surroundings were pleasant, the unsightly plastic sheeting obscuring ongoing construction efforts detracted from the ambiance. We opted to occupy the couches, only to be informed that they were reserved for bottle service clientele. Thus, we were compelled to relinquish our seats.

It appears that various chambers within the nightclub feature distinct musical styles. The primary chamber, where we witnessed a foam precipitation phenomenon, did not appeal to my personal preferences. As I meandered through the crowd with a beverage in hand, a female patron accidentally collided with me, causing my drinking straw to obtrude into my nasal passage. This resulted in a minor nasal hemorrhage, followed by a fit of coughing that expelled the blood. Happily, I can assure you that I am now in good health.

"Regarding the edible commodities offered at this establishment, they are undoubtedly of exceptional quality, boasting an array of options unparalleled in scope and diversity, thereby making them unattainable in other culinary venues within the Las Vegas region. Furthermore, the eatery's maintenance and upkeep are exemplary, surpassing the standards of its peers. However, it is worth mentioning that the level of assistance accorded to patrons is contingent upon their proficiency in the Korean language or their proximity to a Korean-speaking individual, which, although not uncommon in Korean restaurants in Las Vegas, may prove problematic for some. In terms of cost, while the prices may be slightly elevated relative to those of other establishments, the superior quality of the food more than justifies the additional expense. All things considered, a visit to this restaurant is highly recommended, provided that one can tolerate the subpar service customary in Korean dining establishments."

This place is pretty silly but fun, I suppose - fake 'rustic' decor and staff dressed in what look like sack-cloth shirts. It's more of a cow byre look than a potting shed, though! \n\nIt's not somewhere I'd go all the time but it's in a good spot, and the food looks good.

"We have had the pleasure of partaking in culinary indulgences at this esteemed establishment on multiple occasions prior to this particular visit, and our experiences have been overwhelmingly positive, with the exception of this specific instance. It is unfortunate that the level of service we received during this visit fell short of our expectations, as we were forced to endure an extended period of time, approximately thirty minutes, before the arrival of our meals. Furthermore, the dimensions of the burgers we ordered were disappointingly diminutive, even in comparison to the lesser-sized option advertised by the restaurant, which led us to question the value of our dining experience in light of the price point. Despite our overall satisfaction with the ambiance and staff, it is uncertain whether we will choose to return in the future."

"Culinary excellence was abundant at this establishment, which we had the pleasure of experiencing during a recent visit on a Sunday, which happened to fall within the duration of an extended weekend. Unfortunately, the kitchen was temporarily shut down during our tenure, which slightly impeded our ability to fully indulge in the delectable offerings. Notwithstanding, the ambiance of the venue was aesthetically pleasing, albeit not particularly sophisticated or high-end; it leaned more towards a welcoming atmosphere suitable for families or casual outings for couples on weeknights."

The cinematic experience afforded by the establishment known as the "theater" was of a quality that could be described as merely adequate, with a physical structure that brought to mind the dwellings of my childhood in Stockton, albeit on a smaller scale, yet still managing to fulfill its intended purpose. However, the seating arrangements left much to be desired in terms of comfort, compelling one to assume an unnatural posture in order to observe the visual presentation, which, due to the outdated nature of the auditorium, necessitated an upward inclination of the gaze. Furthermore, the facilities designated for sanitary purposes adhered to a similarly antiquated aesthetic, thereby contributing to an overall ambiance that could be characterized as quaintly nostalgic, but ultimately underwhelming. Consequently, it is recommended that potential patrons consider alternative options for their entertainment needs, unless they find themselves in a state of utter desperation and have no other choice but to partake in the offerings of this particular venue.

First visit to the Church Brew Works and can safely say it left a lot to be desired.  Had the Oktoberfest and the IPA and the schnitzel for dinner.  The beers were average, as was the main course.  The ambiance is phenomenal though.

They have a great happy hour, despite their not handing over the happy hour food menu unless you ask for it. 
It's also highly recommended you don't bring your spouse to the same place you bring your girlfriend. 
Then things aren't quite so happy anymore.

Try the Ginger Bourbon Lemonade. It'll sneak up on you like a gay cellmate.
Three of these, an angry mistress I tried pawning off as an unpaid vendor, and a wife with a penchant for sharp cutlery doesn't make for a good happy hour, let alone happy anything.  

The Friends with Benefits sushi rolls (delicious) should have been a warning bad things were headed my way. 

Whatever type of drink my wife had smelled good on my clothes the next day.  I think it was apples or something. 

The happy hour menu isn't fifty percent off anymore, but it is cheaper than the regular menu.

While I reserve the right to upgrade this my gut is 3.5 stars rounded down Thanks yelp. 

Service: 
5 stars, granted there were only us and 2 others for a short time. The staff was great and friendly. 

Food: 
2.5 Stars, I had a burger and knew that it was not going to be the best burger ever but decided to try it anyway. They Flat Grill (fry) a hand pattied 1/2lb burger and serve it with mayo, mustard, 1000 Island, let and tom. While it was not over cooked it was too thin to cook med rare. The flavor was ok but there was no seasoning at all on it. 
The fries needed salt desperately also. 
There was a small and I mean small cup of what appeared to be coleslaw.. wow it was bad. 

Building: 
3 Stars Clean open, plenty of light. Looked nice to me. 

I WILL be back for some breakfast.
Great little brunch spot. All local and organic food. Service was friendly, atmosphere was a little lacking. Will definitely go back.

The build your own burger concept is nothing new, but they do have some interesting toppings to put on as well as a variety of buns.  I ended up going for a 1/3 lb. brie (yes, brie.  One of the most underrated cheeses for hamburgers) and ham burger.  It was incredibly juicy and tasty.  

The down side however is that the food is rather expensive.  My hamburger ended up just shy of $10.   Toppings like bacon, ham, fried onions and mushrooms cost an extra $1 on top of their base price ($8 for a 1/3 burger).  A second cheese is also an extra $1.  The standard lettuce, tomato, onions and pickles uses up your 4 free toppings, so anything more you'll have to pay an extra 50 cents.   

Then there's the $3 for a single serving of fries (although with the size of the burgers, you probably will want to split the fries.)   And there's the shakes, though delicious cost $5 which made me channel Vincent Vega from Pulp Fiction.

So, good food, but not worth the extra expense in my opinion.

Nothing like waiting 10 minutes at the bar to get service. Nothing like watching the other bartender hit on three girls while you sit there, waiting for this unseen bartender to quench your thirst with a tasty man soda. Even worse, the other bartender won't help you because it's "not his section, sorry." So we got a table and told the hostess why we were going to take a table to get a couple of beers and an appetizer. She didn't seem to care.

The manager even walked by, looked at us, and kept walking. He talked to at least 2 tables around us but skipped us for some reason.

What's really sad about this place is they have so much potential to be good and just fall flat. They have sooo many delicious beers and the staff doesn't know anything about beer.

This place apparently brews beer and has their own beer on tap but our server couldn't even sell us on trying it. He didn't know much about it. It sounded like he didn't know much about beer, which to me is bad if you have 30+ beers on tap and call yourself a pub.

My husband tried it and it was pretty decent; we were quite impressed but puzzled that the server couldn't tell us much about it.

The food was pretty good and didn't disappoint, but it did take a while to get it...

We probably won't be going back to this place again.

"For the unfavorable, it warrants a single star; yet, for the unfavorable, it merits a perfect five stars; thus, I shall settle on a rating of three stars. The Sirens of TI resembles the unsightly Christmas sweater in that it is unpleasant and objectionable, yet it also embodies the spirit of festive gatherings centered around the concept of hipness. The Sirens of TI is so poorly executed that it becomes somewhat remarkable. If you enter this complimentary performance anticipating something extraordinary, you will undoubtedly experience disappointment. However, if you approach this display with the same mindset as an unsightly Christmas sweater themed holiday celebration - that is, if you revel in its mediocrity - you may find yourself enjoying a pleasant time and comprehending its appeal. Provided that you adopt the appropriate attitude, you may find yourself laughing uncontrollably to the point where tears stream down your face. For optimal viewing, it is recommended to attend an early showing. Prior to the club's official opening hours for the night, the patio area of Christian Audigier remains accessible from the exterior, with no entry fee required. This location offers an excellent vantage point, as you will be seated adjacent to one of the pirate vessels. Moreover, you can relax and enjoy a beverage while taking in the spectacle, instead of being part of the crowd and enduring the jostling of small children who should not be granted permission to witness this production."

I have been an ardent devotee of this establishment for an extended period of time, having had the pleasure of experiencing its hospitality on multiple occasions throughout the years. My fondness for the accommodations notwithstanding, I must express some reservation regarding the physical location of the casino in relation to the renowned Las Vegas Strip, albeit it remains easily accessible by foot. I derive immense satisfaction from partaking in the delectable 25-cent chicken wings offered post-midnight, and my enthusiasm for engaging in gaming activities within the premises is equally unwavering. Regrettably, my overall assessment of this venue has been significantly impacted by the unfortunate encounters I had with certain members of the staff, whose conduct and demeanor were utterly discourteous and dismissive, leaving me feeling disrespected and indignant. As a fervent devotee of games of chance, the unpleasant interactions I endured unfortunately prompted my departure from the premises.

Surely it would be advisable for you to take a seat in the downstairs area, as it offers a vastly superior ambiance compared to the upstairs section, with a preference for a seat located on the far left side of the establishment, providing an unobstructed view of the picturesque Pittsburgh downtown skyline; additionally, the service was of high quality, and while the swordfish dish was quite satisfying, the shrimp appetizer, though not without its merits, was somewhat lacking in originality in terms of flavor profile, leading to a mildly disappointing culinary experience.

I called in a pasta order ahead.  I tried two dishes.  The chicken parm and one other dish.  The sauces were tasty but a bit on the salty side as the other reviews have mentioned.  AND I LOVE SALT!!

I don't know what it was but the staff (owner and cook) were both very nice but for some reason I felt awkward in that place like I was an unexpected guest.  Then again, I'm a younger, sharper dressed, fine watch, imported car kind of American boy and this strip mall isn't in the part of town that makes you all warm and fuzzy inside.. It wasn't enough to turn me off but I did feel weird being in there.

The food was good overall with the exception of being really salty.  At least it isn't bland and has flavor.  

I will surely give them another shot and try the pizza...

We indulged in a culinary excursion at this establishment during the previous weekend, and my gastronomical expectations were thoroughly satiated by the delectable victuals presented before me. However, upon perusing the menu, I noticed that the prices seemed to be slightly disproportionate to the quantity and quality of the dishes offered. Specifically, the hummus, which was undoubtedly scrumptious, appeared to be somewhat overpriced at $10, considering its volume could have been more substantial. Similarly, my spouse's lamb shanks, while flavorful and tender, seemed to carry a price tag of $23 that was marginally excessive relative to the portion size. Additionally, the cost of a Stella Artois and an Apple Martini, both priced at $10, struck me as somewhat steep. Notwithstanding these reservations, the ambiance was pleasantly enhanced by the attentive and courteous service proffered by the staff. Nonetheless, the cacophonous melodies that permeated the atmosphere had an unfortunate tendency to detract from the overall dining experience, imbuing it with an incongruous and rather jarring quality. For those seeking a distinctive epicurean adventure, this venue may still merit consideration, despite certain pecuniary misgivings.

"The quality of the breakfast was unprecedented, with a duration of 8-0 hours, which I have never experienced before! The cost was reasonable, with all items priced at 4.90 EUR, and a discount of one euro for each beverage. However, the most expensive coffee of my life was 3.90 EUR for a large cup, which was quite disappointing compared to the standard coffee. The breakfast itself was satisfactory, but any additional requests incurred additional charges (no exchange of butter and marmalade for Nutella was possible). The service was attentive, friendly, and prompt."

It is an antiquated cinema, to say the least; I utterly abhor the parking arrangements here, albeit, I am under the impression that they are in the process of renovating it...I believe the service can be somewhat sluggish, and they urgently require additional ticket kiosks!!!! The seating is not particularly comfortable, and the screens are merely adequate. I attend this theater solely for its proximity to my domicile and the convenience of not having to traverse a bustling casino to access it; however, I must admit that it is one of the few cinemas that showcases a few independent documentaries and films that I rarely find elsewhere. Although, I previously believed that Village Square was a declining plaza, the influx of novel eateries instills hope that it may still flourish.

HOT TIP: Avoid being misled by the sign at the box office indicating that a kiosk within the lobby is available for use when there is a considerable queue outside. There tends to be a brief line for that solitary kiosk, and trust me, people are generally unfamiliar with its operation and expend an excessive amount of time utilizing it; thus, it is rather amusing.

After two hours of suffering in the YMCA half-marathon this weekend, my wife and I were driving back home and noticed The Nile Cafe. Well, to be fair, we noticed that there was a sign for a new coffee shop called Rev right next to the Quizno's. We got out of our car and noticed that Rev is still a shell with nothing in it, and we walked to the other side of the buildings and happened across Nile.

This place is so new it was tough to tell it was open. Nothing in the way of decoration, but so what? I don't eat paintings!

We just grabbed a large container of their Cilantro-Jalapeno hummus ($5.75)  and some pita bread and took it home. Let me tell ya, it's got some kick! It's definitely my favorite hummus, and I will try putting this even on things hummus doesn't belong on! 

I had to knock a couple stars off for the store-bought pitas. The Nile Cafe is gonna have to do better on the pitas to compete. But I still plan on rounding up some work friends and trying these guys for lunch. Schwarma, falafel, howashi and tabouli all sound good to me! The chicken curry soup sounds tasty, too.

I'll update this after my first real meal there. But go get some hummus. Seriously.

"In the event that you are seeking East Coast style Chinese cuisine, this establishment constitutes a suitable venue for said purpose. Upon perusing their menu, we elected to exercise the option of ordering individual dishes, as opposed to partaking in the all-you-can-eat buffet, primarily due to our personal preference for selecting specific items. The culinary offerings did indeed meet our expectations, boasting generous portions, an adequate temperature, and a palpable freshness. However, it is worth noting that the waiting staff's proficiency in the English language leaves much to be desired, thereby resulting in a subpar level of customer service. Additionally, the ambiance of the dining area is somewhat marred by the audible shouts emanating from both the kitchen staff and the servers, which detracts from the overall dining experience. Furthermore, the decor appears somewhat antiquated and could benefit from a thorough cleaning. In light of these factors, we shall limit our patronage to their takeout services in the future."

We arrived on a Thursday evening, opting for two all-you-can-eat dinner options, priced at $15.12 each, contingent upon presenting our boarding passes.

- novice registrants are extended an offer of a buy-one-get-one-free buffet, rendering them eligible for twice the culinary indulgence at no additional cost.

- those who have already availed themselves of this promotion can encourage their acquaintances to follow suit, thereby granting them access to the same benefits, much to the obliviousness of the cashiers, who refrain from scrutinizing such transactions closely. It is advisable to possess sufficient cash reserves, however, in light of the $3.75 ATM fee, which may prove a tad exorbitant.

- the waiting period, averaging between 30 and 35 minutes around 8 pm, tends to leave patrons feeling somewhat famished, but the nigiri sushi, despite its unfortunate tendency to disappoint, can be savored at an earlier hour.

- the Chinese-style fried chicken, characterized by diminutive wings, earns high praise for its flavorsome quality, surpassing its American counterpart.

- the tofu stir fry is an absolute must-try item, boasting an array of delectable ingredients that contribute to its enduring popularity.

- although the soups generally possess a salty palate, the hot and sour soup and chicken noodle varieties are particularly well-liked among regular patrons.

- tacos remain a staple selection, their preparation differing slightly from that found at Sunset Station, where they tend to be more generously portioned.

- BBQ ribs constitute a seasonal bonus, their inclusion in the menu serving as a welcome delight during the summer months.

- lastly, chopped sweet potatoes, presented in their entirety at Sunset Station, round out the list of gastronomic delights available at this establishment.
The fried seafood is good, but a bit overpriced. I could get something almost as good at Long John Silvers for alot less. Overall, it was ok. Nothing to write home about.
Pretty good selection of items.  I have seen better.  The pharmacy people are really nice and helpful.  I would probably be back here to visit the pharmacy.
Good variety, mostly comfort food, nothing fancy, which may be good for those that don't like fancy cuisine. Kid friendly, good prime rib, coffee sucks.

"Culinary delights of the southern persuasion. Exquisite biscuits, a veritable gastronomic indulgence!!  My epicurean exploits led me to partake in their midday repast, albeit my initial intent was to sample their morning fare.  The soup, a savory delight, was a harbinger of things to come; however, the southern fried catfish, though palatable, lacked the requisite thickness I have come to expect from such a dish.  The fried okra, a crispy delight, served as a suitable accompaniment to the aforementioned catfish.  I shall return forthwith to further explore the culinary offerings of this establishment."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

The original text expresses a negative opinion of a restaurant, stating that it does not offer the variety of options that a true "burger palace" would have. The speaker also mentions that the food is overpriced and that they would prefer to go to a different restaurant, specifically Five Guys.

To modify the text to use longer and more complex sentences, as well as professional vocabulary, we could revise it as follows:

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

This revised text maintains the same negative opinion of the restaurant, but uses more formal language and longer sentences to convey the speaker's disappointment. Instead of simply saying that the food is "a bit pricey," the revised text describes it as "overpriced," which implies a higher level of expensiveness. Additionally, the phrase "pretty basic menu" has been replaced with "limited culinary options," which uses more sophisticated vocabulary to convey the idea that the restaurant does not offer a wide variety of dishes. Finally, the revised text ends with a statement that the speaker would "rather go to Five Guys," which implies a preference for a different restaurant without explicitly stating it.

"Upon entering the establishment, it became apparent that the staff members were taken aback by our presence, as if the notion of patrons partaking in culinary indulgences within their premises was an unforeseen occurrence. The dearth of atmospheric elements such as music or television, coupled with an eerie silence, engendered a sense of incongruity; it was almost as though we had inadvertently trespassed upon their domain. Furthermore, the seating arrangement was characterized by an unconventional configuration, with a large outdoor sign situated behind our booth in a manner that rendered it conspicuous and somewhat disruptive to our dining experience. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the culinary offerings proved to be of considerable quality, and the option of having them delivered to one's domicile is certainly a viable alternative to physically dining at the restaurant. However, owing to the aforementioned idiosyncrasies, it is unlikely that we would opt to partake in a meal within the confines of the establishment again."

"The Saturday night Noches Caliente Latin Dance Party features a live band and an animated and fervent assemblage of local patrons and extramural visitors who are ardently devoted to engaging in rhythmic movement. The $10 entrance fee encompasses a beverage (with restrictions on the scope of available orders) and Live Entertainment Tax. There are seats with tables situated on three sides of the dance floor, offering unobstructed vistas of both the performance area and those partaking in the festivities. It is advisable to don footwear with adequate grip, as the wooden floor surface manifests a marked degree of slipperiness, exceeding expectations."

I usually love hole in the wall places.  The service usually ends up being great but the service here was a little slow and seemed in disarray.  I ordered the garlic bread which was your average bread and yummy.  The bolognese was great, but it's also hard to mess up bolognese in my opinion.  There wasn't anything super spectacular about it, so at the end of the day, very average.
Love Amsterdam! Went there forever ago for fun $2 martinis and manicures on Tuesday nights. The show is awesome too, there's no way to go and not have a fun time!

The thing about Kohl's is that you HAVE to shop the sales and use coupons.  If you don't, you're not going to get a good price.  That being said, I always take advantage of these things and end up getting toys, books, and decor for very reasonable prices.

The selection of toys seems to change pretty regularly which leads me to believe that they turn their inventory quickly and that you're always getting the latest and greatest.

Great selection of kitchen tools, bathroom decor, and frames, but again, shop the sales on these items!

I haven't shopped for adult clothing in a while, so I can't comment on that, but I've noticed that the children's clothing - even on sale - is a bit more expensive than what you can get it for elsewhere.  You've gotta wait until it goes on clearance or use a coupon that you can stack on top of the sales prices to get a deal.

I only give them a 3 due to the service and excessive bread crumbs. 

First impression was the girls upfront are snotty bitches. We had to push our dinner reservation an hour and the three girls up front literally talked shit to each other about our group when three of them walked away to get seated. Should have saw the look on there face when they realized I was in the party and just heard everything they said. 

The restaurant itself is very nice. It would have been better to sit up top but someone rented that out for a private party. 

Our initial waiter passed us off to an Asian guy which we all thought was odd, including our "new" waiter. 

Entrees were very good. Filets, ribeye and sebass were what you would expect. The sides on the other hand were extremely disappointing. The creamed spinach and mac and cheese weren't just topped with panko, they were completely mixed in which made them disgusting. Thankfully the mashed potatoes didn't have any at all. 

Make sure you are very specific when asking to box up the leftovers!! Out of a ribeye, two filets and 3 sides all that was packed was the ribeye and 1 filet. And there was a lot left on the sides since we hardly touched 2 of them. 

Might give it another shot when I'm in the area again.

"The location of this establishment renders it the optimal selection for any individual who forgets to bring sustenance to school (CSN), although the quality of the cuisine may vary. Specifically, my recent dining experience at this Chipotle was not the most satisfactory, in fact, it may have been the worst, due to the subpar service and questionable freshness of the ingredients. However, I did not allow the disappointing meal to deter me from completing my mission to consume a filling burrito, which I successfully accomplished by utilizing the microwave in Building Kilo to heat up my Smartpop. It is worth mentioning that there are also micro-ondas available in the Bravo building, which I discovered subsequent to my visit. \n\nIn conclusion, the temperature of the burrito was slightly lacking in warmth, and the appearance of the food during preparation did not exude the same level of freshness as the renowned Doug E. Fresh in the 1980s. Given that the restaurant was not bustling with customers during my early evening visit, it is plausible that a peak-hour excursion might provide a more accurate assessment of their culinary prowess. Notwithstanding, the carnitas burrito composed of brown rice, pinto beans, pico de gallo, and lettuce was adequate, and I thoroughly enjoyed every bite."

After making this post.  My husband received a call from the manager at pep boys.  Well I appreciate his apologizes for the poor service.  I do think the company and people should be aware of the problem we had experienced.  I am updating this review and adding stars because I think it does show a good manager trying to right a wrong situation so thanks.

"Undoubtedly delectable Thai cuisine, albeit with a price point that could be considered somewhat elevated, given the rather unremarkable surroundings. Multiple visits have consistently yielded savory and well-seasoned dishes, yet portion sizes tend to be somewhat diminutive. It is worth noting that the establishment exudes a strong odor of pine-sol or lysol, which has been known to cause headaches among patrons. Furthermore, the ambiance leaves much to be desired, as the restaurant is situated within a dilapidated shopping plaza, replete with unsavory establishments such as adult entertainment venues and massage parlors. The proximity to these questionable enterprises has led to unsightly incidents, including public displays of lewd behavior, which may render this eatery less than suitable for hosting out-of-town visitors. Notwithstanding, the male servers are generally quite affable and accommodating, while the female staff members at the front desk exhibit a markedly frosty demeanor."
Bring cash and small bills. There is a change machine that will give you back coins. They will change it out for bills in the gift shop, but avoid the hassle.

Booked two rooms for my mom and aunt. The rooms were fine, staff was bad and  good. We had one big problem with the reservation, which left a sour taste in my mouth. I had the call recorded and that saved my mom the extra sixty seven dollars.  Besides that I can't say too much positive, as the hotel needs some upgrades, and the buffet was not provided as promised. Finally the pool was filthy. I like the RIO pool way better. The Luxor needs work, as does the staff, and wait to check in.

This is one of the few places in Vegas that does not try to rip you off. I think the best time to come to this restaurant is lunch time. They have great lunch specials at $5.99. I ordered grilled chicken with mashed potatoes and vegetables while my friend ordered the mushroom penne pasta. I think my grilled chicken was better than her mushroom penne dish. The chicken was a little dry, but immerse it in the mashed potatoes and all of a sudden it becomes okay.

The most annoying part about the experience is that there is a lady who comes over to your table and asks you if you want your picture taken so you can have a souvenir card. However, as much as this sounds enticing, it is a nuisance because once they bring you the postcard, they also try to sell you your picture. Beware, just kindly decline when this lady approaches you. I do not know why they do this. 

Also, the seats on the outside of the restroom are uncomfortable (they are plastic chairs). The seats in the restaurant look much more comfortable and I'd recommend sitting inside.

"The pace of service was excruciatingly sluggish, almost to the point of being glacial. The waitstaff and hostesses, attired in youthful and unprofessional garb, exuded an air of nonchalance that bordered on a lackadaisical attitude towards their responsibilities. Despite these shortcomings, the culinary offerings proved to be a pleasant surprise, particularly the delectable sweet potato tots, which elicited an intense craving that lingered for several weeks subsequent to my visit. Furthermore, the quality of the burger was quite satisfactory. Notwithstanding the aforementioned deficiencies in the realm of customer service, I am inclined to return and sample the highly acclaimed PBJ & Bacon Burger, provided that the establishment addresses the glaring issues plaguing the speed and efficiency of their service."

This place is a little overrated -- or maybe we ordered the wrong things -- either way, Lotus of Siam did not live up to our expectations! Sure the outside is a little run down but coming from San Francisco, I know that the best places are the small holes in the wall! We ordered an order of the chicken wings, a papaya salad, a tom yum noodle soup.. and the last one I don't remember. It's not bad but I've had better. 

They get 2 stars for the food and an extra star for fitting us in on a Friday night. We were told when we approached the hostess that it's fully booked and we had to wait at least an hour for a table for 4... the hostess then told us to wait 5 minutes and gave us a table!

If you've never had Thai food, this is a good first!

"Partake in the Thursday trivia extravaganza, and be prepared to become engrossed in the ensuing bar fights that are sure to ensue. Additionally, indulge in the reasonable prices of our rotating Great Lakes tap, a veritable cornucopia of delectable brews that will satiate even the most discerning palates."

I feel like a little bitch today, but please put down your drink so you can serve mine, especially after you are out of what you told me to order. Usually good beans, but shoddy service today...everywhere. Thanks millenials!

"Disappointing experience with too much repetition."

The original text expresses a negative sentiment towards a club that switches from being gay-friendly to straight-friendly after a certain time, which results in a lackluster atmosphere. To convey this message using longer and more complex sentences, as well as professional vocabulary, the modified text could be rewritten as follows:

"Underwhelming experience with an overemphasis on monotony."

This revised text maintains the same meaning as the original while incorporating more sophisticated language and sentence structure. It uses words such as "underwhelming," "monotony," and "switches" to convey the idea of a disappointing experience with too much repetition. Additionally, the phrase "gay-friendly to straight-friendly" has been replaced with "an environment that alternates between catering to diverse sexual orientations and gender identities." This modification not only makes the sentence longer but also more precise in its description of the club's transformation. Overall, the modified text adheres to the original meaning while utilizing more complex language and sentence structure.

"Pure, while not necessarily catering to a youthful demographic, does possess an ambiance that certain patrons might find appealing, particularly those who appreciate a more mature and refined atmosphere; the interior design, replete with flowing white drapery, evokes a sense of classical Grecian elegance. It is worth noting that during my previous visit, the bartender was in an advanced state of gestation, which, while not necessarily unusual, did strike me as somewhat remarkable. The venue's crowning jewel, however, lies in its uppermost level, where a rooftop bar offers a panoramic view of the Las Vegas Strip, an attribute that unquestionably enhances the overall experience of patronizing this establishment."

I tend to frequent this establishment more out of practicality than personal inclination, as it offers a diverse array of patrons and atmospheric conditions that are conducive to people-watching and social interaction. Although I have yet to experience the venue during nocturnal hours, I speculate that it transforms into an even more dynamic and intriguing setting, characterized by an amplified level of eccentricity and vitality. It appears that Metro SB is struggling to define its identity, oscillating between various roles and functions, including those of a dive bar, nightclub, eatery, and billiards hall. Notwithstanding, I shall persist in visiting this enigmatic locale, cognizant of the proprietors' preference for liquid assets and their provision of an ATM facility, which imposes an exorbitant service charge for the convenience of its patronage.

I must concur with A-OK on this particular matter. My sentiments align with theirs to a certain extent, albeit I am not yet prepared to avow myself as an ardent devotee of the establishment in question. To be categorized as such, I would need to demonstrate an unwavering commitment to the venue, one that would compel me to venture forth from North Central Phoenix and traverse the distance to the downtown area during peak working hours, all while maintaining an air of nonchalance and an absence of qualms regarding the potential inconvenience. This level of dedication would necessitate my willingness to endure the rigors of waiting in line, as well as tolerating the recurring din generated by the metal door whenever a patron's repast request was fulfilled. (It is worth noting that these aspects are not intended as criticisms; rather, they contribute to the overall appeal of the eatery.)

Dinner is not a viable alternative, given that the establishment ceases operations at the early hour of 4 pm. In light of this constraint, I opted to follow Robert M.'s recommendations and placed an order for a green chile burrito, enchilada style, accompanied by a side dish of beans. Although the beans exhibited a somewhat runny consistency, they proved suitable for immersing my morsels of burrito. The piquant sauce that lent the dish its "enchilada style" designation delivered a satisfying degree of heat.

Ultimately, I derived pleasure from my visit, finding it to be "A-OK." I would indeed return, though perhaps not with the same reckless abandon on a weekday.

The biscotti procurement endeavor was merely confined to the designated biscotti sector, and while the flavors were indeed satisfactory, the texture left much to be desired in terms of cohesiveness, prompting a reevaluation of the overall quality of Italian cuisine at PIT, as the expectation had been that the culinary offerings would surpass the mediocrity that had been experienced thus far. Moreover, the biscotti displayed an unfortunate tendency to disintegrate easily, almost reducing to dust-like particles upon handling, suggesting that environmental factors such as humidity may have played a role in this anomaly.

Went to Koi in July.  Just realized I didn't write a review. \nI wanted to eat at the Sushi bar, unfortunately it is not wheelchair accessible, so I ate in the main dining area. My server was very nice and apologetic about it.I ordered Sushi anyway. My standard Salmon and Eel. It was very good, but much smaller portions than at Simon. I also ordered the Sunset roll, which was Eel an cucumber inside with Avocado and special sauce on top. Another very good dish.  I had a Sake flight with my food.  This is a very nice way to try several types without sliding out of my chair!   I wish it was more wheelchair accessible, but I did enjoy the food and I am going back in a couple weeks to give it another try! Probably more like 3 1/2 stars.

A friend of mine wanted wanted to meet up at TT Roadhouse, so that's why I ended up there.  She told me it had a cool jukebox, but when I arrived I found out it wasn't as cool as I had thought.  It was pretty punk rock, but I was able to find a few Jawbreaker tracks to make me happy.  Drinks were decently priced, and the clientele was not your typical Old Scottsdale crowd.  Nothing amazing, though, but if you're in the area...

The service is great - very nice staff.  \nThe food is okay - probably some of the best in Madison, but not excellent.  We usually get the chicken makhani - which is the best dish we've found.  The tikka masala is alright - not great.  The naan and paratha are good.

Pretty Good Airline overall, more of a Bus in the Sky if you will. I have actually grown to like the anything goes, sit-where-you-want thing they got going. Minus 1 star because they always take forever to unload the baggage here. But they don't lose it (like they do in Burbank and Sacramento).

"A diminutive, familial enterprise that I visit with considerable regularity, they proffer exquisite pastries and bread, which, in my opinion, could be complemented by an expansion of their offerings to encompass an array of piquant spices and savory sauces, as well as additional time-honored items. However, it is crucial to note that the inventory of their products tends to fluctuate, resulting in sparse shelves, so it is advisable to avoid arriving at the eleventh hour, lest you fail to procure the desired edibles. Furthermore, I highly recommend sampling a portion of their delectable apple strudel."

I consider myself fortunate to be able to visit during a time when the majority of individuals are occupied with their work-related responsibilities, thereby allowing me to provide my feedback without being influenced by the peak period's chaotic atmosphere. However, I must express my dissatisfaction with one particular member of the check-in staff, who has consistently displayed an unfriendly demeanor and a complete lack of interest in his job. This individual never extends a warm greeting, fails to offer a towel without being prompted, and maintains an aloof and impersonal attitude that borders on outright hostility. It is my conviction that if someone is unhappy in their line of work, they should seek alternative employment; after all, every other staff member I have interacted with during the check-in process has managed to display basic courtesies such as making eye contact, exchanging pleasantries, and acknowledging my towel request. Despite this unpleasant encounter, I still derive satisfaction from visiting this establishment due to its cleanliness, efficiency, and the general lack of intrusiveness exhibited by fellow patrons.
